HEADLINE: RESIDENTIAL REAL ESTATE;
For Brooklyn, a New Rental Tower

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
The 32-story building rising on Montague Street is adding an imposing new presence to the Brooklyn Heights skyline and the first new luxury rental building in the neighborhood in nearly four decades.
When leasing begins on April 1, it also will test renters' willingness to pay a premium for the building's 186 apartments. Monthly asking rents will range from $1,900 for the smallest 518-square-foot studio to $6,800 for the largest 1,247-square-foot three-bedroom apartment. 
 The building will have a rooftop health club, and the apartments will have nine-foot-high ceilings. There will be 6,000 square feet of ground-floor retail space and a garage for 75 to 80 cars in the building. It is replacing a two-story commercial structure that stood on the site, between Court and Clinton Streets.
The $50 million-plus project is being developed by the Continuum Company, headed by Ian Bruce Eichner, who lives in the neighborhood. "It presented a unique opportunity to build something not now available in my own backyard," he said, adding that the rental market also was strong.
The rental vacancy rate in Brooklyn Heights is below 2 percent. That is lower than the citywide rate of 5 percent, according to the Brooklyn office of William B. May, the Manhattan-based brokerage concern.
The vacancy rate is more pronounced in Brooklyn Heights because of the lack of development sites and strict zoning regulations that govern most of the neighborhood, which is a city-designated historic district. New buildings developed in the district, the area generally between Atlantic Avenue and Court Street and Cadman Plaza West and the Promenade, are limited to five stories. And their facades must blend with those of the neighboring buildings.
The Montague Street site is just outside the historic district in a primarily commercial area of low- and high-rise buildings. When Mr. Eichner acquired the site in 1998, its zoning permitted the construction of a 20-story building. But to build the "Manhattan style" luxury rental that he envisioned and make it economically viable, Mr. Eichner said, he also bought air rights over two adjacent structures. That enabled him to add 12 stories to the building, providing apartments on the 15th floor and above with views of Manhattan.
Mr. Eichner said that though he could have bought more air rights that would have increased the building's height to up to 50 stories, he decided against it because of, among other things, the expense of building such a tall structure. And a 32-story building, he added, "also made more sense on the block."
In an area where local community groups have fought to protect the brownstone neighborhood's low-rise scale, the height of the Montague Street building provoked some concerns. They were overshadowed, however, by community opposition to a commercial project, including a multiplex movie theater, on Court Street four blocks away, said Judy Stanton, executive director of the Brooklyn Heights Association, a civic group.
The Montague Street building, Ms. Stanton said, "will probably bring night life" to that part of the street and "retailers are looking forward" to an influx of new families." But "people expressed concerns that it is inappropriately tall and out of place," she said, adding that with the parking garage's entrance on busy Montague Street, "I have no idea how the cars are going to get in and out."
Mr. Eichner said he has all necessary approvals for the garage.
The Brooklyn Heights Association has opposed new development in the past, including Mr. Eichner's attempt in the 1980's to build a 15-story cooperative building on the site of an old hotel in the landmark district. The battle ended in the developer's favor, but he gained approval only for an 11-story building, which ultimately was sold to the Jehovah's Witnesses for use as a dormitory.
Ms. Stanton said Mr. Eichner's new building "certainly could have been prettier." She described it as having "a lot of brick," not enough windows and little architectural detail. "More could have been done," especially to break up the building's mass, she said.
Mr. Eichner said he and Thomas O'Hara and Associates of Manhattan, his architects, "made a significant effort" to put up a building that was appropriate and are cladding the building in brick rather than glass and installing "oversized windows," consistent with those in upscale housing in Manhattan. The building also has a nine-story base with a setback tower to reduce its scale, he said.
But it will be the services and amenities offered inside the building, which also include Internet access and a concierge, that will distinguish it from the stock of rental units, mostly within brownstones, in the neighborhood. Such services are now available only in cooperative buildings, said Christopher D. Thomas, a senior vice president at the May brokerage.
Mr. Thomas said the project was opening at a time when monthly rents for existing rentals have risen about 10 percent a year for each of the last two years. He said current rents were $1,700 to $2,400 a month on average for one-bedroom apartments with 500 to 800 square feet, and $2,300 to $3,600 for two-bedrooms with 800 to 1,200 square feet.
"My guts tell me that renters will be willing to pay the premium for services" and apartments that are larger and in a new high-rise in an established community like Brooklyn Heights where they can walk to stores, he said.
Mr. Eichner said he was negotiating with "an upscale grocery store" to lease the retail space in the building. He said he expected the building to draw young professionals as well as families from the area and Manhattan. Occupancy is expected to begin by August.

HEADLINE: Riders Know, Study Confirms: Taxis Are Harder to Find

BYLINE: By RANDY KENNEDY 

 BODY:
It's not your imagination. Hailing a yellow cab really has become a lot harder.
According to an analysis of a decade of taxi meter and odometer readings, obtained recently from New York City by a transportation consultant, the availability of cabs over the last seven years has fallen sharply, by 13 percent -- even with an expansion of taxi medallions, two fare increases and the introduction of subway and bus fare discounts. 
 The analysis confirms what anyone who relies on cabs almost anywhere in Manhattan already knows: the city's surging economy is increasing the demand for a taxi supply that has not increased in several years. And the imbalance is beginning to show.
Taxi experts add that the effect on minorities and people seeking to travel outside Manhattan is probably much worse, because as competition for cabs increases so do refusals -- cabdrivers ignoring some hailing passengers or refusing to take them to certain destinations.
"The bottom line here is that the anecdotal stories about how it's much harder to catch a cab are more than borne out by the objective data," said Bruce Schaller, a former policy analyst for the city's Taxi and Limousine Commission and now a private consultant, who obtained the cab data through Freedom of Information laws.
Mr. Schaller said he thought the cab shortage had become so pronounced that the city "really needs to start looking at how to make cab service more readily available."
The analysis, conducted on data that is collected three times a year by the taxi commission during cab inspections, found that the number of passengers in yellow cabs, the most frequently used means of traveling within Manhattan after the subway, had increased 17 percent over the decade. Ridership rose from 206 million a year in 1990 to 240 million last year, the 1999 figure equivalent to more than three-quarters of the population of the United States.
Passengers last year paid an average metered fare of $6.85, or $8.07 with the night surcharge and a 15 percent tip. The length of the average trip -- three miles -- was also greater than in years past, partly because of more airport trips.
Revenue for the taxi industry rose 46 percent in the 1990's, from $949 million in 1990 to $1.39 billion in 1999 -- roughly the amount that investors paid for Rockefeller Center four years ago.
But the statistic that means the most to taxi riders is the number of "dead miles," an estimate of how much time cabbies spent cruising for passengers and the best indicator of how readily a cab can be hailed. As cruising miles increase, a person standing on a street corner is more likely to encounter an available cab. When the miles decrease, finding a cab becomes harder.
In 1992, when cab availability was at a high during the recession, the number of cruising miles was 310 million. The figure decreased to 271 million last year, out of 772 million miles driven on duty.
The records also show that last year, 65 percent of the average cabby's time was spent with a passenger, up from 57 percent in 1992. Because these numbers are skewed by graveyard-shift drivers, who can cruise for long periods without a fare, the percentage of time cabs are occupied during business hours is probably much higher, Mr. Schaller said.
The analysis found that a 1990 fare increase of 11.5 percent was one of several factors that helped taxi availability rise during the first three years of the decade. As the economy heated up, more people were willing to pay the higher fares, and availability began to drop rapidly, hitting a low in 1996.
An additional fare increase in 1996, of about 20 percent, had little effect on availability -- even with the competition from discounted subway and bus fares for Metrocard users and with the auction of 400 more taxi medallions, the first expansion of the cab fleet since the Depression. (A medallion is the badge that gives a cabdriver the right to pick up riders; there are now 12,187.)
Those factors caused taxi availability to rise for just one year, from 1996 to 1997. Then it began to drop again because, Mr. Schaller theorized, tremendous demand was spurred by the creation of many more jobs in the city and a rise in tourism.
Allan J. Fromberg, a spokesman for the Taxi and Limousine Commission, said the numbers "show what we've believed to be true for some time, which is that the industry has never been more viable."
"This is probably the strongest taxi industry in many years," Mr. Fromberg said.
But the increase in demand, and in industry revenues, has not been as a big a boon to cabdrivers, the report found. The average driver grossed $1.80 per on-duty mile, or $254 for an average shift of 141 miles. The figure includes the additional money from night surcharges and an estimated 15 percent tip, but does not take into account what the drivers must pay for gas and to fleets to lease their cabs.
In 1990, cabbies made about $196 on an average shift. But Mr. Schaller said that in general, increased fare revenue for drivers had been offset by inflation and by higher lease fees.
Mr. Schaller added, however, that the report also showed that the expansion of the taxi fleet in 1996 did not have the dire effect that many drivers feared: driving down their income. And he said he thought this was an argument for increasing the fleet more, a decision that would be up to the State Legislature.
"There's a reservoir of unmet demand for taxis, both through the boom times and the recession, that has absorbed every single mile of additional service," he said.
But others who have studied the taxi industry make an analogy to a rule used by traffic planners -- that cities can never build their way out of traffic congestion by adding roads -- and say that increasing the number of medallions will probably never have any appreciable effect on increasing taxi availability.
"Let's suppose you added 50,000 medallions," said Edward G. Rogoff, a professor of management at Baruch College in Manhattan who has studied the industry for many years. "What's going to happen? The area they serve is just going to push out to a larger part of the city, the places that livery cabs serve now."

HEADLINE: For Those Who Can Afford It, Old-Style Medicine Returns

BYLINE: By GINA KOLATA 

 BODY:
Two years ago, William O. Daniel's doctor adopted a new policy. No longer would the doctor, Herbert Rubin of Beverly Hills, Calif., accept payments from health maintenance organizations. No longer would he be on insurance companies' preferred provider lists. No longer would he even accept Medicare. From then on, if you wanted to see Dr. Rubin, you paid cash.
"That was frightening to me," said Mr. Daniel, a 72-year-old retired insurance salesman who lives in Hollywood. Reluctantly, he changed doctors. But, he said, his new doctor's waiting room was always crowded and the doctor seemed pressed for time. "I had to get out my symptoms in about 20 seconds or he would start interrupting me," Mr. Daniel said. "Then I would have to wait while he saw more patients and then got back to me." 
 Now Mr. Daniel has returned to Dr. Rubin, one of a growing number of doctors who have severed their ties to health maintenance organizations and insurance companies. In return for cash payments, the doctors often offer a lavish level of service -- uncrowded waiting rooms, long, uninterrupted office visits, and an office staff that knows the patients.
"You always get what you pay for," Dr. Rubin said.
Several years after President Clinton's failed effort to remake health care in America, the health care market is remaking itself. For those with insurance or the money to pay for health care, there is evolving a two-tiered system. One tier is made up of doctors who have cut their prices at the insistence of health insurers and who make up for the reduced prices by increasing their volume, seeing more patients per hour. The other tier is made up of those like Dr. Rubin who offer time and attention -- but at a cost.
While there are no national figures on how many doctors are joining the new tier, health care experts agreed that all of a sudden, doctors who never before dared to abandon health insurance plans were taking the plunge.
They are a different breed from the growing ranks of doctors who are focusing their practices on cosmetic procedures, like laser eye surgery or liposuction, that patients pay for out of their own pockets. Instead, these are doctors like family practitioners and internists who provide basic medical care as well as specialists, like general surgeons, gastroenterologists, psychiatrists and psychologists, and cardiologists, who take care of serious medical problems. These renegade doctors tend to be in urban areas, where managed care has made the greatest inroads, the doctors said.
Patients of these doctors can submit the doctors' bills to their insurance companies, but it is the patient, not the doctor, who must accept whatever the insurer provides. Some of these doctors accept Medicare payments or payments from a few other select insurance plans. Others, like Dr. Rubin, do not. Some doctors are asking patients to give them yearly retainers of thousands of dollars.
"The market is reasserting itself," said Dr. Alan Garber, an economist and specialist in internal medicine at Stanford University. "In characteristic fashion in America, markets have emerged where they didn't exist."
Health policy experts say there is no proof that patients who see doctors like Dr. Rubin are buying better health -- although they are buying more of a doctor's time and attention.
"People are buying what to them is very valuable," said Victor R. Fuchs, an emeritus professor of health economics at Stanford. "They are getting instant attention, instant service. You call the doctor's office and one person is on the phone and he knows you. Suppose you have a medical test. In some situations you have to wait a week for the results. Here, it can be two hours. What some experts don't realize is that a huge amount of the dissatisfaction with medical care has to do with the level of service."
Doctors and health policy experts differ on whether the trend is to be lauded, accepted or deplored. But they agree that it was inevitable, a consequence of peoples' growing irritation with impersonal medical care by rushed doctors and a booming economy that allows many people to pay for the service they want. Dr. Thomas Reardon, a general practitioner who is president of the American Medical Association, said that his organization had no policy on the trend, but that he understood why it was occurring.
"What the doctors are saying is, 'We're tired of managed care, we're tired of Medicare, we're tired of the hassle,' " Dr. Reardon said. Patients are equally peeved by much of medical care today, he added.
But some worry about a loss of fundamental equity and justice, that the affluent are insulating themselves. "We are in an incredibly entrepreneurial climate in medicine, and I think this kind of tiering undercuts people's thinking about collective solutions to the health care problems," said Norman Daniels, a professor of philosophy at Tufts University who specializes in ethics and health care..
Others worry about the effects on patients when their doctors suddenly announce that they will not accept the patients' insurance.
"It is a burden," said Dr. Bernard Katz, a family practitioner who sees H.M.O. patients and is co-chief executive of SMBP Health Services, a company in Santa Monica, Calif., that manages doctors like himself.
Dr. Michael Lockshin, a rheumatologist at the Hospital for Special Surgery in New York, said that in his hospital it is becoming almost impossible to find surgeons who will accept H.M.O. insurance.
"They basically thumb their noses at the H.M.O.'s," Dr. Lockshin said, adding that he often cannot refer patients to the best surgeons. "I have to deal with patients on a daily basis and it sometimes makes me want to tear my hair out."
The same thing is happening in west Los Angeles as more and more specialists refuse payments from H.M.O.'s and most insurance companies, said Dr. Richard L. Taw Jr., a cardiologist in Santa Monica. Dr. Taw himself has stopped accepting most insurance payments, but his patients stuck with him. "Nobody left me, not one patient," he said. "The economy is so good now that people want to go to doctors that don't treat them like a number."
Not too long ago it was excruciatingly difficult for an independent doctor to thrive. One who tried, Dr. Thomas W. LaGrelius, a general practitioner in Torrance, Calif., said he spent years watching helplessly as his patients bailed out of his practice, refusing to go to a doctor whose fees were not covered by their insurance. Dr. LaGrelius had decided as long ago as 1980 that he wanted no part of H.M.O's.
When his partners decided to stay with an H.M.O., Dr. LaGrelius quit the group and began practicing by himself, but for years he had trouble finding patients.
Now, Dr. LaGrelius said, the climate has changed and patients seek him out. He is head of an organization of independent doctors in his area, called Indoc, which has 104 members and gets inquiries from all over the country.
Some doctors, who once belonged to every H.M.O. in sight, said they recently decided to drop those contracts. When H.M.O.'s came to the New York area in the 1990's, doctors like Andrew Weiland, an orthopedic hand and plastic surgeon at the Hospital for Special Surgery, were afraid that if they did not join they would have no patients. "Everyone jumped on the bandwagon and joined as many as they could for fear of being left off when the train left the station," Dr. Weiland said. But, he added: "You can only run so fast and see so many patients and not run an assembly line."
And so Dr. Weiland started to drop his H.M.O. contracts over about three years. He said he has had no trouble finding patients. "Patients sort of think that if you're out of the plans, you must be good enough to drop out of the plans," he said.
The independent doctors say they see fewer patients and offer them better services. The doctors are easy to reach, patients are not kept on hold, and no one has to wait weeks for an appointment.
Dr. Bradley Fenton, a Philadelphia internist who does not accept payments from H.M.O.'s, says he offers "time and attention." He reserves an hour for a new patient who comes in for a physical examination and allows 15 to 20 minutes for follow-up visits.
"While it may cost more," Dr. Fenton said, "many can afford it if they want to. Instead of going out to dinner one night one week, they can spend an hour with me."
Dr. Richard Schubert, a fee-for-service internist in Washington, says he spends whatever time it takes with his patients -- 30 minutes for a routine office visit, an hour for a consultation. "It costs patients more money, they have to pay for it out of pocket, they have to decide if they think it's good value for the service," he said. "Maybe you think spending the extra money on a doctor is not important and you'd rather get a B.M.W. You have to decide how you want to spend your money."
Many patients say that they are willing to pay the price for a doctor who showers them with attention. Harry Haber, the president of Ginsey Industries, a company in Bellmawr, N.J., that manufactures and distributes novelty bathroom accessories, said he provided an Aetna/US Healthcare health maintenance organization for his 150 employees and himself. But he and his wife are patients of Dr. Fenton of Philadelphia, paying most of the cost themselves.
"Not everyone can afford it," Mr. Haber said. But, he added, "I am a person who's made a choice." He added that when Dr. Fenton suggests an expensive test he may go to his Aetna doctor and hope that he will recommend the same test, so it can be paid for by Aetna.
"That is not always easy," Mr. Haber said. In fact, he recently was turned down for a medical test by his Aetna doctor, forcing him into a decision on whether to pay for it himself.
"I will probably absorb the cost," Mr. Haber said.
Health care economists predict that the two-tiered system may be here to stay, and that no national health care plan is going to obviate it.
"The notion that you're going to provide the same level of care for everyone," Professor Fuchs of Stanford said, "means either that it's going to be enormously expensive or that it's going to be a level of care that's far below what some people are willing and able to pay for." But, said Uwe Reinhardt, a health economist at Princeton University, doctors with fee-for-service practices may find themselves under a new sort of competitive pressure. People who can afford such doctors also tend to be people who are comfortable using computers and the Internet, he said.
"They will create Web sites that will rank these doctors on quality," Professor Reinhardt said. "That will be the obvious next step. They will put these doctors into statistical fishbowls where everything about these doctors will be on the Web.
"I think the physicians will find it is not quite the world of the late 1950's and the 1960's," Dr. Reinhardt said. "It will be utterly brutal."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
A RECORDVOLUME AS STOCKS SURGE ON THE BIG BOARD

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Investors bought stocks furiously yesterday, sending the Dow Jones industrial average up nearly 500 points in its biggest one-day point gain ever. Broader indexes also rose sharply as investors -- at least for the day -- put aside fears that the Federal Reserve would aggressively raise interest rates and slow the economy to a crawl.
When trading began, buyers flocked to the old-economy companies that make up the bulk of the stock market but that have languished much of this year. Stocks of financial companies like J. P. Morgan performed especially well, as did shares of airlines and other companies whose profits will probably be strong if the United States economy stays healthy. 
 But by midafternoon, the buying had spread to technology and Internet companies, the new-economy stocks that had already posted strong gains this year. By the end of the day, all segments of the market were sharply higher, with the Dow Jones industrials rising 499.19 points, or nearly 5 percent, to 10,630.60.
The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index ended three days of sharp losses with a gain of nearly 3 percent. Apparently afraid that they would miss out on gains, investors scurried to join the rally, setting a record for trading on the New York Stock Exchange, with 1.48 billion shares changing hands.
By any standard, the gains were outsized. Old-economy companies like American Express and General Motors had their stocks dancing like new-technology butterflies, with American Express gaining $10.875, to $143.75, and G.M. $4.9375, to $83.75.
The performance of the broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was equally giddy. The S.& P. 500, which represents about 70 percent of the value of all stocks, rose 66.32, or 4.8 percent, to 1,458.47. The point gain was the biggest for the Dow ever, easily surpassing a 380.53 point rise in September 1998. But in percentage terms, the two gains were about the same, 5 percent.
Combined with Wednesday's 3.3 percent increase, yesterday's gain amounted to the best two-day performance for the index since its rally after the crash of October 1987.
"A calm is settling in over the market on interest rates," said James Weiss, deputy chief investment officer of State Street Research, which manages $55 billion. "The market at the moment seems to be comfortable that the Fed is going to raise interest rates a couple of times but not more than that."
The Federal Reserve has raised short-term interest rates four times since June in an effort to slow the booming economy, and the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, has said he is worried about the potential for inflation to accelerate. Along with higher oil prices, the higher interest rates appear to have slowed the economy slightly, said Jeffrey Applegate of Lehman Brothers.
Mr. Applegate, a longtime bull, said a moderate economic slowdown was good news for stocks, because it meant that over the next few months, the Federal Reserve would not have to raise rates as much as investors previously expected. So investors can begin to look well past the expected quarter-point increase by the Fed policy makers next week to another period of steady interest rates and strong corporate profits. That combination almost always makes for higher stock prices.
"If, in fact, the Fed can go on hold, because there's not a reason to do a lot of tightening, that's good for the markets," Mr. Applegate said.
Still, Mr. Greenspan has expressed concern that the meteoric rise in technology stocks is encouraging spending by consumers who feel increasingly wealthy on paper, which could in turn fuel inflation. To reduce that risk, Mr. Greenspan has said he would like stock prices to grow more slowly, a warning heeded by technology investors in the previous three days but disregarded yesterday.
Wall Street traders, who were even more swamped than usual yesterday, said buy orders seemed to come from all directions. While investors' appetite for stock mutual funds has abated from its record highs in February, when it averaged $10 billion a week, it remains strong, according to AMG Data Services of Arcata, Calif. AMG, which tracks investment in mutual funds, said $5 billion went into stock funds in the week ended Wednesday.
The day began rather quietly. Right after the opening bell on the New York Stock Exchange, the Dow was up fewer than 100 points. The Nasdaq, which has been extremely volatile lately and was down more than 9 percent the previous three days, opened up, but fell sharply toward midday. Shortly after 11 a.m., it was down more than 100 points.
As the day progressed, the Dow rocketed higher, and by mid-afternoon, it had pulled the Nasdaq into positive territory.
The rally in old-economy stalwarts, from drugmakers like Johnson & Johnson to airlines like Delta, actually began on Monday. Many of those companies are posting record profits, but they have been largely ignored by investors seeking the supercharged revenue growth of technology and Internet companies like Cisco Systems and Yahoo.
As a result, many well-known old- economy companies are trading at relatively cheap levels, while some Internet stocks are valued much higher. The average S.& P. 500 company is valued at about 28 times its 1999 profits, while the average Nasdaq stock trades for well over 100 times last year's profits. Yet many S.& P. 500 stocks are showing strong profit growth, with the average S.& P. 500 stock expected to post a profit gain of 17.7 percent this year on top of last year's 18 percent gain.
In the last week, that gap became too wide to ignore, said Seth Tobias of Circle T Partners, a hedge fund that manages $450 million. As an example, Mr. Tobias said he bought shares of United Parcel Service just above $52 on Wednesday after seeing they were trading near their lowest level since the delivery company offered shares to the public last fall -- and seeing that other transportation companies were rallying.
"I swept out all the sellers in the stock, the stock went to $55, and today it's at $57.50," Mr. Tobias said. U.P.S. closed at $56.25, up $1.3125.

Treasury Prices Rise
By Bloomberg News
Bond prices rose after a producer price report showed inflation stayed tame outside of energy and food costs and the government bought back $1 billion of 30-year bonds for the second time this month.
The Treasury Department bought back bonds that mature between 2018 and 2021, at an average yield of 6.358 percent. It received offers of $6.446 billion from dealers.
The benchmark 30-year bond rose 13/32, to 102 28/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, dropped to 6.04 percent from 6.07 percent on Wednesday. The current 10-year note yield fell to 6.24 percent. from 6.28 percent.

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
Get Real on Kosovo

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Karl Kraus, the famous Austrian journalist and playwright, once observed that European wars were caused by diplomats who lied to journalists and then believed what they read in the newspapers.
One is reminded of that aphorism today when listening to U.S. and NATO officials insist that they are still committed to building a multi-ethnic Kosovo -- despite the murderous inter-ethnic violence still going on there, and the obvious desire of the Pentagon and NATO to get out of Kosovo forever. 
 It's time U.S. and NATO officials stopped fibbing to themselves and then believing their own quotes. It's obvious that the Kosovar Serbs and Albanians hate each other and have no intention of living together in the idealistic multi-ethnic state that the Clintonites once envisaged.
Now it might be momentarily satisfying to just walk away, telling both sides: "You people deserve each other. Why don't you just slug it out and call us when you're exhausted." But that would only lead to another bloodbath and refugee turmoil. Like it or not, the U.S. and NATO do have an interest in stability in the Balkans -- if for no other reason than that it would allow them to focus on more important problems.
Since we can't walk away, our real choices are clear: Either we disarm the warriors of Kosovo or we disarm the warring politics of Kosovo. That is to say, when dealing with an unfinished civil war, in which people hate each other but are still living side by side, one option is to use overwhelming force to disarm the whole population and then stand guard on every street corner until they learn to love each other. At a time when NATO wants to reduce its troops in Kosovo, this option is not realistic.
That leaves the other option -- disarming the politics of Kosovo. Right now the politics of Kosovo is always on the verge of explosion, because neither of the big parties -- the Serbs nor the Albanian Kosovo Liberation Army -- is content or exhausted. The K.L.A. is using the U.S. zone in Kosovo as a privileged sanctuary to infiltrate southern Serbia and aid ethnic Albanians living there, while the Serbs are infiltrating men and materiel into northern Kosovo to protect their people there.
The only way NATO can reduce its presence in Kosovo, without it blowing up, is by doing what NATO did in Bosnia: disarm the politics by tacitly partitioning the country. Bosnia is stable today because the key factions were exhausted by four years of war and got what they wanted: their own ethnic zones. Once the dividing lines were stable, all NATO had to do was patrol them. And once the parties in Bosnia were secure in their own space, they were more willing to reach out to one another.
To disarm the politics of Kosovo, NATO needs to convene the parties and redraw the map or impose a new one. One idea would be to move the Serbian border with Kosovo near Mitrovica to the south -- to encompass the biggest pocket of Serbs still living inside Kosovo. In return, the Serbs would be asked to give the Kosovo Albanians the two small counties of Serbia along Kosovo's eastern border, where a large number of Albanians still live. That would create much cleaner dividing lines. Then NATO could make Kosovo a self-ruling republic of Yugoslavia, with a promise to consider independence sometime in the future.
Finally, NATO could tell the Serbs that if they agreed to this land swap the sanctions on them would be lifted. The Serbs would get out of their deep economic hole. The Albanians would have self-rule. And NATO could patrol the fence between them.
True, this would mean the world would effectively have two Albanias -- the original Albania and a new Kosovo Albania. Although the Albanians have not shown any capacity for running one state properly, let alone two, Europe will have to live with it.
A broken Kosovo is no place to be experimenting with multiculturalism or affirmative action. As Stalin would say, talking of a self-sustaining, multicultural Kosovo today is like talking about "hot ice or dry water." Our interest is that Kosovo, like Bosnia, be a place where the different ethnic communities can live apart, stably, until they choose to live together again, and where the U.S. and NATO can ensure that stability at the lowest cost. Since the Kosovo war ended before a stable dividing line could be established there, we need to draw that now. Without a stable dividing line we will always be peacekeepers in a land with no peace to keep. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Dow Up Nearly 500 Points In Biggest Daily Point Gain
Investors bought stocks furiously, sending the Dow Jones industrial average up nearly 500 points in its biggest one-day point gain ever. Broader indexes also rose sharply as investors -- at least for the day -- put aside fears that the Federal Reserve will aggressively raise interest rates and slow the economy to a crawl.
The Dow gained 499.19 points, or nearly 5 percent, to 10,630.60. The technology-heavy Nasdaq composite index ended three days of sharp losses with a gain of 134.77 points, or nearly 3 percent, to 4,717.39. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose 66.32 points, or 4.8 percent, to 1,458.47. Page A1.
 
Disk Drive Breakthrough Reported
A group of I.B.M. scientists said it had achieved a breakthrough that could result in one-inch disk drives capable of holding 100 times the data of the most sophisticated existing hard drives. The breakthrough is significant for the emerging field of nanotechnology, an effort to build microscopic circuitry and machines only a few molecules in size. C2. 

U.S. Candidate Out of I.M.F. Race
The five-month-long scramble to find a new leader for the International Monetary Fund came to a de facto conclusion as the Japanese and American rivals for the job -- Eisuke Sakakibara and Stanley Fischer -- formally withdrew their nominations and cleared a path for a German, Horst Kohler. A12.
 
Nasdaq Spinoff Plan Is Released
The fine print on the National Association of Securities Dealers' plan to issue stock and spin off the Nasdaq stock market later this year became public. While N.A.S.D. executives predict the deal will pass a membership vote easily, some small brokerage firms expressed hostility to the offering in a conference call. Another group may file suit to stop the deal. C8.
 
Wall St. Urged to Disclose All Orders
The chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, Arthur Levitt, called on Wall Street to voluntarily put together a system that would disclose all stock orders that have not yet been filled. All markets are now required to disclose any limit orders -- orders to buy or sell a stock at a particular price -- if that order represents the best available price in the market. Mr. Levitt proposed going further than that, but he also said that he was "deeply troubled" by evidence that even the disclosures required are often not being made. C8.
 
Peapod Exploring a Possible Sale
Peapod, the pioneer of the online grocery business, announced that its chief executive, Bill Malloy, would be leaving for health reasons. Then a group of investors who had promised to put $120 million into the company said they would not be doing so, given the departure of Mr. Malloy. The company said it had asked its investment bank to explore alternatives, including a sale. C2.
 
Credit Suisse Comes Under Scrutiny
Allegations of improprieties in the way the Ukrainian central bank managed International Monetary Fund loans are raising serious questions about the role of Credit Suisse, the European banking giant, in the matter. C4.
 
February Producer Prices Rose 1%
Prices paid to factories, farmers and other producers rose 1 percent last month, but excluding food and energy costs they rose 0.3 percent. Reports showing gains in housing starts and manufacturing suggested that the economy was continuing its robust expansion. C2.
 
Some Mutual Funds Not Available
About 735 mutual funds that are normally listed in the tables were not available because of a technical problem at the Interactive Data Corporation, which provides some pricing data.

HEADLINE: BMW Will Shed Rover, Selling Sport Utility Vehicle Line to Ford

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS with ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: FRANKFURT, March 16

 BODY:
Six years and nearly $6 billion after buying the Rover Group, BMW of Germany abandoned the British automaker today.
BMW essentially gave Rover's money-losing car business to a little-known group of British investors. And it negotiated a deal to sell the Land Rover line of sport utility vehicles to the Ford Motor Company for just under $3 billion. 
 "We really can't think of a better group of brands and products than the Land Rover Group," Jacques Nasser, Ford's chief executive, said at Ford's headquarters in Dearborn, Mich.
Ford already owns another venerable British brand, Jaguar, and Mr. Nasser said that Jaguar and Land Rover dealers worldwide would probably team up to sell more of both brands. "We've always referred to the Range Rover as the Jaguar of off-road vehicles," Mr. Nasser said. "They fit together in a showroom very well."
Today's moves by BMW marked a retreat from a strategy of getting bigger and broader, at a time that rivals around the world are merging and forming alliances.
The ownership upheavals came as a shock to Rover's 30,000 workers in Britain as well as to the British government, which has been hoping to salvage one of Rover's main factories with a taxpayer subsidy around $220 million.
BMW, based in Munich, bought Rover in 1994 in the hope of expanding beyond its market for luxury vehicles and of keeping up with larger competitors.
The steps today represented a reversal for BMW and more uncertainty for Rover's workers, whose new boss will be Alchemy Partners, an investor group that includes a former Rover executive, Kevin Morley.
Because nearly half of BMW's shares are controlled by the Quandt family of Germany, which has so far rejected all overtures, BMW's independence seemed assured for now. But analysts say the pressures are increasing. Volvo of Sweden sold its car business last year to Ford. And earlier this week, the Agnelli family of Italy agreed to sell 20 percent of Fiat to General Motors.
Though BMW did not disclose the terms, Alchemy Partners is expected to pay little, if any, money up front, and BMW will assume many of Rover's debts.
BMW said the expense of shedding the Rover car business would cost about 3.15 billion euros, or $3.06 billion. As a result, BMW will report an annual loss of about $2.4 billion.
BMW was officially silent today on the future of Land Rover, the profitable and growing sport utility business, but was expected to announce the deal on Friday. Mr. Nasser discussed the deal with reporters gathered in Dearborn today after the boards of Ford and the BMW Group approved a memorandum of understanding on the sale.
The jettisoning of Rover came as a relief to the parent company's investors, who have viewed the British car line as a black hole for money.
Rover lost more than $1 billion in 1998 and $1.2 billion in 1999. Its annual car sales plunged 24.9 percent last year, to 251,000 vehicles.
In further fallout from the Rover developments, BMW dismissed three of its top executives, the second big boardroom shake-up in 13 months. The three executives, responsible respectively for marketing, production and research and development, had been named to the board in February 1999 and were supposed to oversee the integration of Rover and BMW. Joachim Millberg, who became chief executive after the ouster last year of Bernd Pischetsrieder, appears to have been the main architect of today's moves and will remain.
Stephen Reitman, an automobile analyst in London with Merrill Lynch, said today that BMW's future would be brighter now that it has freed itself from Rover. "It has a massive effect on BMW, in the sense that it removes a significant problem," Mr. Reitman said. But he added, "What it doesn't answer is the issue they themselves have been talking about -- the need for scale."
Excluding Rover, BMW's profit margins are the highest of any car manufacturer in the world except for Porsche. Mr. Reitman estimated BMW's profit margin at 12 or 13 percent, based on American rather than German accounting standards. By contrast, he said, the Mercedes business of DaimlerChrysler has a profit margin oround 8.5 percent.
But BMW faces assaults in the luxury market from the Audi unit of Volkswagen A.G., Volvo and Jaguar, owned by Ford; and of course, DaimlerChrysler.
Many analysts are skeptical that sheer size is the basis of success. But large size can make it easier to distribute research and development costs over more vehicles and achieve economies of scale.
Under the deal announced today, Alchemy will take over Rover's unprofitable line of midpriced sedans, including the more expensive Rover 75, and will acquire Rover's big factory at Longbridge, near Birmingham, which has been in danger of closing for more than a year.
Instead of trying to build smaller cars through Rover, BMW will revive a strategy it discarded years ago and design a new line of cheaper cars under the BMW brand. That is a reversal: BMW executives have strenuously argued that they did not want to "stretch" their prized brand with cars that sell too cheap.
In an odd twist, BMW indicated that it would also give Alchemy Partners the line of Mini subcompacts produced by Rover. Yet it said it would retain the redesigned "new Mini" that is due out later this year.
It is unclear exactly what will happen to Rover, but there were signs today that it would disappear as a brand name. In a statement today, Alchemy Partners said it would reintroduce Rover as the MG Car Company -- adopting the MG marque acquired years ago by Rover's owner then, British Leyland.
Under BMW's previous chief executive, Mr. Pischetsrieder, the company committed itself to becoming bigger and capable of competing in the largest and fastest-growing segment of the market -- medium-priced mass-market cars. But the plan turned disastrous. The rising value of the British pound, in relation to the falling euro, made British cars expensive in Continental Europe and open to competition from Volkswagen and G.M.'s Opel subsidiary. Rover also failed to reduce its costs and the size of its labor force. On top of all that, its midsize car models suffered declining popularity.
Though many experts said the sale of Rover was overdue, some analysts contend that BMW and the Quandt family were so concerned with protecting their independence that they missed opportunities. "It is the Quandts' biggest mistake," said Markus Plumer, an analyst with WestLB Research in Dusseldorf. "G.M. or Ford would have been willing to pay an enormous premium for Rover," Mr. Plumer said. Had BMW been willing to trade off 20 percent of its shares, he added, it could have preserved its independence, raised billions in extra capital and tapped the expertise of companies already making mass-market cars.
Georg Sturzer, an analyst at Hypovereinsbank in Munich, said BMW could navigate on its own. Noting that shares of DaimlerChrysler had plunged in the last year, Mr. Sturzer argued that BMW may have been well advised to focus on luxury cars. "The experience of Porsche gives us an indication," he said. "If size were indicative of operating margins, then Porsche should have the lowest margins in the industry. But it has the highest."

Chart: "A Bumpy Ride"
BMW has spent the last six years and billions of dollars trying to turn around Rover, the British car and sport utility vehicle maker. Yesterday, it abandoned the troubled company.
 
1994 -- BMW buys Rover from British Aerospace and Honda for $1.2 billion.
1998 -- In July, 1,500 jobs are cut from Rover's work force of nearly 40,000. A further 2,500 job cuts through attrition are announced in November, and hours are reduced. Rover's losses reach nearly $1 billion for the year.
FEBRUARY 1999 -- After a seven-hour board room battle, BMW's chairman, Bernd Pischetsrieder, is ousted over the losses at Rover.
MARCH 2000 -- With Rover's losses for 1999 expected to be even higher than 1998's and negotiations with the British government for subsidies stalled, BMW announces a deal to give Rover's car business to a British venture capital firm. A deal to sell the sport utility business to Ford was expected today.(pg. C5)

HEADLINE: Pataki Appoints an Adviser To Assess Nassau Finances

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

DATELINE: GARDEN CITY, N.Y., March 16

 BODY:
Warning that Nassau County's fiscal troubles could affect both its taxpayers and the Long Island economy as a whole, Gov. George E. Pataki named a special adviser today to evaluate the county's finances.
In tapping Frank G. Zarb, the chairman of the group that runs the Nasdaq stock market, to study Nassau's budget woes, the governor took the unusual step of invoking his executive powers to look into a local government's trials and tribulations. 
 "The last thing I need to do is inject myself into the problems of a local government or a county government," Mr. Pataki said, explaining the move at his office in Manhattan. "We try not to do that. But I have an obligation as governor to make sure this state's local entities and county entities function as well as possible."
Nassau County has not, by most accounts, been functioning as well as possible. While other local governments have been buoyed by the booming economy, Nassau is in the midst of a fiscal crisis.
Its 2000 budget is expected to fall short by $200 million; its bond rating has been downgraded to the level just above junk status; and its elected officials are weighing fee increases, new taxes and service cuts to put the county's finances back in shape.
Today, county officials traded a new round of proposals and counterproposals to make the county solvent, and by evening, it was unclear what, if anything, would be done.
At 11 a.m., the county comptroller, Frederick E. Parola, announced his plan, which is to refinance the county's debt. At noon, the county executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, announced his plan -- a package of increased fees, new taxes and cutbacks in service intended to eliminate this year's projected $200 million deficit. And by 1 p.m., major elements of Mr. Gulotta's fiscal plan were being called into question by legislative leaders of both major parties.
Mr. Zarb, who has plenty of experience with Nassau politics as the former chairman of the Long Island Power Authority, said he would take a businesslike approach to his audit. "This is not a complex nuclear formula," he said of the county's finances. "It's a pretty straightforward business question, and the answers are going to be pretty straightforward as to the options."
His appointment drew mixed responses from state and local officials.
Sheldon Silver, a Democrat who is speaker of the State Assembly, has already lent his support to a stronger measure, the creation of a fiscal oversight board with the power to certify or reject county budgets. A bill calling for such a board was passed by the Assembly last week; it faces strong opposition in the Republican-controlled State Senate.
But Mr. Silver said today that he welcomed the appointment of Mr. Zarb, who is chairman of the National Association of Securities Dealers, to study the state of the county. "I respect his opinion," he said.
State Comptroller H. Carl McCall, another Democrat, said that after all the studies of Nassau's finances that had been done in recent years by his office, by the county comptroller and by others, he questioned the need for further study. "I think the assessment has been done," he said. "What's needed now is some action to bring about fiscal stability in the county."
With that end in mind, Mr. Gulotta, the Republican county executive, announced the long-awaited details of his fiscal recovery plan today. The plan calls for union concessions, new park and health fees, a 5-cent cigarette tax and other measures.
And Mr. Gulotta set a deadline, saying he wanted firm commitments from the County Legislature within 45 days that it would enact certain elements of the plan. "If that does not happen within the next 45 days," he said, "then I am prepared to submit legislation to our County Legislature that will seek increases in our local taxes."
But county lawmakers immediately rejected the biggest component of Mr. Gulotta's plan that requires their approval: his request to borrow the remaining $54 million of the county's share of the nation's tobacco settlement. The money is now held in a trust that is used to pay for health care for the county's uninsured residents.
Judith A. Jacobs, a Democrat who is the Legislature's presiding officer, said she would not agree to "raid" the tobacco funds. Peter J. Schmitt, the Republican leader, said that he did not think the Legislature had the authority to use the money and that he would be against doing so if it did.
But both Democratic and Republican lawmakers said they were willing to go along with part of Mr. Gulotta's plan: raising fees for a variety of services, from skating lessons at county rinks to docking at county marinas, for an expected $3.5 million in revenue the rest of this year.
Officials questioned whether several other components of Mr. Gulotta's plan were likely to win approval. Mr. Silver noted that the county executive's call to defer a $19 million payment to the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which would need state approval, could harm other areas in the state.

HEADLINE: Suddenly, Reclusive North Korea Reaches Out to the World

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 16

 BODY:
In the space of a few short weeks, North Korea has gone from one of the world's most politically reclusive states to the most diplomatically ambitious.
With little fanfare, but with a speed that has surprised many people, the Communist government in Pyongyang has established diplomatic relations with Italy and has resumed diplomatic discussions with Japan and Australia for the first time in years. 
It has also recently sent out discreet feelers to at least two other major Western nations, Canada and Britain. And according to diplomats in the Philippines, it has approached their country about joining the Association of Southeast Asian Nations Regional Forum.
Political experts attribute much of this diplomatic activity to a feeling among North Korean leaders that they have consolidated their authority and that their government will survive any threats by foreign countries. They also believe that the overall direction of the country is promising, given that only recently it was on the brink of economic collapse, with much of its population hit by famine.
These moves are taking place against the backdrop of talks between the United States and North Korea that diplomats say will be crucial to easing the country's isolation and lowering tensions on the Korean peninsula, one of the cold war's final flash points.
In New York this week, North Korea's deputy foreign minister, Kim Gye Gwan, and an American delegation led by Charles Kartman have been discussing final arrangements for high-level talks between the two countries tentatively scheduled for April in Washington. No high-ranking North Korean official has visited Washington since the Korean War ended in 1953.
In September, the Clinton administration lifted some trade, banking and other sanctions that had been imposed on North Korea for decades. Now Pyongyang wants Washington to take it off a list of nations that Washington says support terrorism. Among other things, the United States reportedly wants North Korea to agree that it will not resume tests of ballistic missiles like the one it fired over Japan in 1998.
Washington has also sought to encourage Pyongyang to respond more favorably to the so-called Sunshine Policy of the South Korean leader, Kim Dae Jung. North Korea has recently accepted limited forms of investment and tourism from South Korea, but has spurned offers for direct talks.
"The U.S. has been encouraging them to engage with the outside world," said Park Young Ho, a senior research fellow at the Korean Institute for National Unification, in Seoul. "This is happening at a time when North Korea seems to have realized that it needs to have more relations with other countries in order to improve its own situation."
Other experts have taken a much more skeptical view of Pyongyang's opening. They say it is a short-term ploy meant to keep North Korea's weapons programs and its often belligerent posturing from becoming campaign issues in important legislative elections in South Korea in April, and in the United States presidential election in November.
"This may be a diplomatic flurry for the Democratic People's Republic of Korea," said Nicholas Eberstadt, a North Korea expert at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington. "But, like they say, they've been down so long it looks like up now. All of the new diplomacy is with countries that are willing to give assistance, and it is meant to cover them in case the Washington scenario doesn't work out."
But other recent signs of diplomatic activity by Pyongyang have involved its historic ideological patrons. This month the North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, paid an unusual visit to the Chinese Embassy in Pyongyang, at the invitation of the ambassador, Wan Yongxiang.
In its only explanation of the visit, the official North Korean media said Mr. Kim "expressed thanks for the invitation and conversed with the leading officials of the embassy."
The visit set off speculation among North Korea experts that Mr. Kim was preparing to visit China. It would be his first overseas trip since assuming power after the death of his father, Kim Il Sung, in 1994.
North Korea has also recently signed a new friendship treaty with Russia.
This diplomatic activity comes at a time when Mr. Kim believes that he is in a strong position politically, despite a sharp and prolonged economic decline brought on by the disappearance of its cold war allies from the Soviet bloc, and by unusually harsh weather and crop failures that led to famine.
Last year, the economy is believed to have grown slightly, for the first time in a decade. And in a change from his normal diet of visits to military installations, the 58-year-old North Korean leader began emphasizing visits to factories and food production centers.
Now, many experts say, Mr. Kim appears determined to bring about a rebound from economic collapse. He has apparently decided that one of the keys to doing this is through a controlled opening to the rest of the world. If this is so, there is still considerable divergence among experts over the economic direction to expect from Pyongyang.
Under its Sunshine Policy, South Korea is investing heavily, both in economic and diplomatic terms, in encouraging its neighbor to emulate the gradual evolution toward capitalism undertaken by Communist nations like China and Vietnam.
In a recent interview, President Kim of South Korea said Pyongyang had three options before it: war, which would end disastrously for it; the status quo, which he said has already proven a dead end, and evolutionary change.
"This third option, which I believe is the only viable option, is to follow the example of China and Vietnam," Mr. Kim said. "They have maintained their political systems, while gradually opening up economically. This is what we, and all of our friends and allies, want from North Korea, and we are prepared to help them."

HEADLINE: Sports of The Times;
Thornton Is the Calm In the Storm

BYLINE: By WILLIAM C. RHODEN 

DATELINE: TUCSON

 BODY:
LATE Wednesday evening Darlene Grimes was talking about the hectic week she had already had. While her son, Bootsy Thornton, was in Tucson leading St. John's to a narrow first-round victory in the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament, Grimes was in Baltimore, where she is a medical assistance specialist. Grimes goes from hospital to hospital helping patients fill out insurance paperwork. The hardest part this week has been carrying around the heavy silver trophy her son won last week as the Big East tournament's most valuable player.
The trophy has become a great conversation piece. On Monday she took it to Johns Hopkins University Hospital, where doctors, nurses and patients admired it and offered their congratulations. Then Tuesday it was off to Liberty Medical Center. Yesterday she was taking it to Union Memorial Hospital. 
 "I took it with me when I got my shoes repaired," she said, laughing.
In each place, faces lighted up because Grimes's face was glowing. This was a happy story. Thornton was born in East Baltimore, where he attended Dunbar High School, then played at Tallahassee Community College before coming to St. John's.
"It means a lot to me that he's made it this far," his mother said by telephone. "Since he was 8 years old this has been his dream. He wanted to play college basketball, wanted to play in the N.B.A. I wanted him to get a good education and be an artist. I never thought he'd get this close."
What she is most proud of, she said, is her son's independent mind. Earlier in the season, when teammates wore Band-Aids on their cheeks to commemorate Erick Barkley's N.C.A.A. suspension, Thornton went Band-Aid-less. He refuses to wear earrings.
Last night, Thornton, in his typically cool fashion, bailed St. John's out of a potential nightmare first-round elimination. He hit key shots, grabbed critical rebounds and handed out timely assists, and, finally, hit the last 2 points of the game.
Unfortunately for Thornton, a remarkable senior season -- one that included a dramatic basket to beat Duke -- has been overshadowed by N.C.A.A. investigations and daily disclosures surrounding Barkley, his backcourt mate. For all his on-court accomplishments, Thornton achieved national attention last weekend for a locker-room altercation. He and Barkley exchanged heated words at halftime of a Big East tournament semifinal game.
"I made the paper that day," Thornton said with a hint of humor. "No matter how many good games I had, I never seemed to make the back page; but one little negative thing happened and I get headlines, 'Erick and Bootsy Fight.' That bothered me a little."
He said he and Barkley are friends, not just teammates. "If it's just on court and not off the court, it carries over on the court," he said. "So you have to have a great off-the-court relationship as well as on-court."
Thornton's real first name is Marvis. His mother, who separated from Bootsy's father and was married several years ago, said when she was pregnant she and Bootsy's father had debates over how they would name the baby. "At first he said he wanted the name Marvis, because his name is Marvis and his father's name is Marvis; then he said he didn't care," she said. "I was thinking about naming him Teon Terrell Thornton."
His father changed his mind again. "So we named him Marvis Thornton III," Grimes said. "But I just couldn't call him Marvis. So I tried to come up with different nicknames."
She settled on one inspired by Bootsy Collins, the trend-setting bass player for Parliament-Funkadelic, the band that laid the foundation for generations of rappers. "I really liked him," she said. "I remembered songs he made that I liked, like "Flashlight.' "
Two decades later the nickname is fitting. Thornton has assumed the bass player's role for St. John's. He moves without the ball, deftly uses space, and has an economy of movement that keeps the offense going. When nerves begin to fray, the understated Thornton, standing in the back of the rhythm section, exhorts teammates to keep a cool head, to channel the anger and frustration into the game. Last night, he provided desperately needed offense, scoring 20 points, handing out 3 assists and grabbing 7 rebounds.
"I've always been the quiet, behind-the-scenes guy -- a calm guy who gets the job done," he said. So far it has worked. The tempest continues, the investigation continues. Bootsy Thornton is still keeping steady time.

HEADLINE: Angry Over Confederate Flag, Mayor Plans March

BYLINE: By DAVID FIRESTONE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, March 16

 BODY:
For years, Mayor Joseph P. Riley Jr. of Charleston, S.C., has done everything but beg the South Carolina Legislature to stop embarrassing the state and lower the Confederate battle flag from atop the state Capitol. Today, frustrated by the lack of progress on the issue, the mayor announced his boldest gesture yet: a 120-mile march from Charleston to Columbia, S.C., next month to increase the pressure on flag supporters.
Mr. Riley, who has been in office since 1975, is a popular figure in South Carolina, widely credited with revitalizing the city as a tolerant and gracious tourist attraction. Although the mayor has never been particularly known for dramatic gestures, he said the flag's divisive presence called for an updated use of an old civil rights technique. 
 "I've been increasingly concerned that the lack of action by our legislature is presenting an inaccurate portrayal of our state," Mr. Riley said in an interview. "The broad majority of citizens in our state want the flag removed -- every religious group, civic group, business group. Our legislature is simply out of step with the people of our state, and I wanted a way to convey that to the country, and to put pressure on the legislature to act, and act now."
The mayor has invited dozens of business and civic leaders to join him on the five-day trek, which is to begin on April 2, and has said he hopes hundreds of people will join in. The march will take place only in daylight hours and will follow U.S. 176, which runs northwest from Charleston and parallels Interstate 26. Mr. Riley said marchers would carry the state flag, which features a palmetto tree and a crescent moon.
"People understand that it's the state flag you should fly on your Capitol," he said, "not the one that represents another government that's been gone for 135 years."
The Confederate battle flag has flown over the Statehouse since 1962, when it was raised as a symbol of defiance to the civil rights movement. There have many campaigns to remove the flag over the years, but it became a flash point in this year's presidential campaign after the N.A.A.C.P., calling the flag a symbol of slavery and intolerance, declared an economic boycott of South Carolina until it is removed.
Vice President Al Gore has urged that the flag be removed; his Republican opponent for the presidency, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas, has said the matter should be left to the people of South Carolina.
Despite increasing pressure from the state's business community to remove the flag, the matter has been stalled for months by several hard-line legislators who say they will never agree to move the flag as long as the boycott is in place. Last month Gov. Jim Hodges of South Carolina, a Democrat, proposed a compromise that would move the flag near a statue of Wade Hampton, a Confederate general from South Carolina, at the rear of the Statehouse. But flag supporters oppose the idea, saying the spot is not sufficiently prominent.
Two state senators on opposite sides of the issue -- Glenn F. McConnell, a flag supporter, and Darrell Jackson, an opponent -- said yesterday that they had been negotiating for weeks on a possible compromise, but had not yet succeeded. In general, however, the mood in the Statehouse has been increasingly tense and racially divided.
One leading flag supporter today accused the state's business leaders, many of whom will be joining Mr. Riley on his march, of selling out the state's traditions because of economic concerns. Christopher Sullivan, chairman of the South Carolina Heritage Coalition, which has close ties to many pro-flag legislators, said businesses were so concerned about the boycott that they had made the South Carolina Chamber of Commerce "nothing more than a political shill for the N.A.A.C.P."
Because of its status as a tourist attraction, the Charleston area has been the hardest-hit region of the state by the boycott. Several conventions and sports events have been canceled, along with a performance by the Bill T. Jones dance company, a prominent part of the city's Spoleto arts festival in May and June.
But Mayor Riley said economic pressure was the least of his reasons for organizing the march.
"The boycott concerns me," he said, "but I'm far more worried about the state's reputation. We've had good race relations here. Our governors didn't stand in front of schoolhouse doors and resist integration."
"But this flag issue is creating a different impression," he added, "and I think it's time that the legislature finally feels the heat from the people of South Carolina."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Jobless Rate Lowest For Month Since '89

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
New York State's unemployment rate dipped 0.2 percentage points in February to 4.7 percent, the lowest for a February since 1989, the State Labor Department reported yesterday.
The state's unemployment rate was 4.9 percent in January and 5.3 percent in February 1999. 
 Nationally, unemployment was 4.1 percent in February, compared with 4.0 percent in January and 4.4 percent in February 1999.
Joblessness in New York City fell last month to 5.8 percent from 6.1 percent in January and 7.1 percent in February 1999. Among counties, Putnam's jobless rate of 2.9 percent was the lowest for February.
Counties across New York's North Country were the only ones in the state with double-digit unemployment in February: Hamilton (13.9 percent); Lewis (12.8 percent); Jefferson (12.2 percent); Franklin (11.2 percent); Essex (10.4 percent); and St. Lawrence (10.1 percent). Joblessness typically rises across that region in the winter and drops in the summer, when the tourism industry is revived.

HEADLINE: In Culture's Capital, Respect the Librarian

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Forlorn and Forgotten in the Stacks" (news article, March 14):
New York City's public librarians are reported to be paid less than the city's garbage collectors, despite librarians' vital role in public education and the fact that they are required to have a master's degree. Many have been forced to leave for the suburbs or the private sector in search of better pay. 
 It is a disgrace for a city that often boasts of being the cultural capital of the United States, or even of the world, not to be willing or able to pay its librarians decent salaries.
For the city to remain vibrant, economically and culturally, successful librarians are just as important as successful investment bankers.
 
RYUJI MUKAE
Kew Gardens, Queens

HEADLINE: The Big City;
Coming Closer To a Utopia In the Bronx

BYLINE: By JOHN TIERNEY 

 BODY:
DESPITE Clarence Stein's painstaking plans, his apartment complex in the Bronx is still not quite the utopia he had in mind. But it's a lot closer than it was a few years ago.
It was called Hillside Homes when Mr. Stein designed it in the early 1930's, shortly after he and Lewis Mumford organized the famous utopian housing project in Queens, Sunnyside Gardens. Mr. Stein moved on to the Williamsbridge section of the North Bronx, at the intersection of Eastchester and Boston Roads, and covered five blocks with low-rise brick buildings. 
 Mr. Stein disdained conventional development as the "marketing and protection of property." His goal was "to create communities." The apartments in the Bronx were built around interconnected courtyards, and included playgrounds and common rooms for workshops and clubs and a nursery school.
The community flourished by attracting Eastern European and Italian immigrants from the Lower East Side, but eventually it declined, for various reasons -- suburban flight, rent control, incompetent management, crack cocaine. By the mid-90's, nearly half of the 1,400 apartments were vacant. The playground was used for pit-bull fights, and the maze of courtyards was a haven for drug dealers.
"The police were afraid to come in," said Brian Lewis, who began managing the project in 1996. "They called it Ambush Alley after an officer was killed here. There were 132 apartments occupied by drug dealers." The buildings were covered with graffiti, and Mr. Lewis counted 4,000 broken windows.
"You were afraid to send kids to the playground," said Dave Burrell, a retired police officer who is the leader of the newly organized tenants' group. "Now you go out there, and there's a group of seniors watching the children play. There's a new pride in the neighborhood."
Now all the buildings are full. The residents, many of them Caribbean immigrants, pay rents from $400 to $750 for a one-bedroom apartment. Mr. Lewis has won an award from the Department of Housing and Urban Development for helping to create that rarity in New York: affordable housing.
What makes it especially rare is that taxpayers are not footing the bill. Although the complex has a long history of government subsidy -- it was originally financed with New Deal money and later was supported by the state's Mitchell-Lama housing program -- the rehabilitation has been paid for entirely by the Emmes Group, the company that took over the bankrupt development three years ago.
The new owners have spent $5 million, a pittance for such a large project, and they say the key to success has been that intangible asset prized by the original architect. "We had to restore the feeling of community," said Harley Frank, a vice president of the company, who grew up not far from the apartment complex.
ONE of the first steps was to rename the complex. Hillside Homes became Eastchester Heights. Mr. Stein might have dismissed it as a mere ploy for the "marketing of property," but the new owners figured the new image was crucial. It was the broken-window theory in reverse.
"We wanted to quickly change everyone's perception of this place," Mr. Frank said. "We wanted to make it clear to the drug dealers that there's a new landlord paying attention, and we wanted tenants to feel the community was worth saving."
The new landlord focused on Mr. Stein's communal spaces. Courtyards were cleaned and landscaped. Graffiti was removed. The playground got new equipment for toddlers and top-of-the-line backboards on the basketball court. Community rooms were refurbished for new after-school programs and clubs.
The result may not meet Mr. Stein's utopian expectations -- you can still find the occasional patch of graffiti and remnant of a drug deal -- but it's impressive by comparison with other efforts to house the working classes. Eastchester Heights feels a lot more public-spirited than the nearby city housing project, Edenwald Houses. The first thing you notice upon visiting the two places is how much less trash there is on the grounds at Eastchester.
"I'll bet you that the city project has twice as many maintenance people as we do, but look at the garbage there," said Jerry Williams, who recently left the New York City Housing Authority to manage Eastchester Heights. "Money is not enough. You have to change people's attitude. When people take pride in their community, they don't throw garbage on the ground."
