HEADLINE: Census Takers Moved by Money And Civic Duty;
A Temp Position That Counts, Even if It Doesn't Last Long

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
It's not a job with a future, but the future of many neighborhoods in America may be affected by how well the job is done.
Every 10 years, the Census Bureau hires an army of census takers -- enumerators, in bureau parlance. For the 2000 count, which has just begun, the bureau needs about a half-million of them. 
 The job lasts only six weeks or so. It involves knocking on the doors of strangers -- people who do not return the forms recently sent to every household in the nation -- and asking them personal questions: their ages, their races, the names of their children and, in many cases, whether they are married and how much money they make.
In New York City, it pays $18.50 an hour -- not bad for a temp job. It requires math, reasoning ability and an F.B.I. background check.
Oh, and there's also a quiz.
On a recent morning, two dozen would-be census takers were hunkered down over the test in a conference room at a Downtown Brooklyn building, answering -- or vainly puzzling over -- the 28 questions, which were intended to measure their mathematical, reading, clerical and organizational skills. (Sample question: "Ms. Jones can't remember the year of her birth, but she knows she was born in the month of September. If it is now May 1990, and Ms. Jones tells you she is 78 years old, in what year was she born?" Answer: 1911.)
Despite the thriving economy and low unemployment, many people seem eager for the work, either because they need the money or because they believe it is their civic duty.
On this day, at least two applicants were there because of population pressures in their own families. "I've got two babies to support," said Jose Pena, 25, an unemployed construction worker from the Sunset Park area. Damark Mitchell, 34, of Fort Greene, said he already had a full-time job as a carpenter, but that he was willing to work nights and weekends knocking on doors. "I need extra money," he explained. "I've got three small kids."
Another applicant, Jerry Schultz, 68, of Cobble Hill, said he had worked as an actor, a welfare investigator and a market researcher, among many pursuits, but he was retired now and struggling to meet expenses from his wife's illness. Because of the medical bills, he said, "My bank account is being depleted." He added: "I enjoy meeting people, so it should be interesting."
For Jasmine Lozada, 20, of Sunset Park, the goal was "saving money for college." A graduate of South Brooklyn Community High School, she said she hoped to enroll at the Borough of Manhattan Community College. And while she said, "All that matters is I'll be making the money," to the Census Bureau it matters that she is fluent in Spanish. Bureau officials say those hired will be assigned to the greatest degree possible to the areas they live in, and Sunset Park has a large population of Hispanic immigrants.
"We'll be hiring by the thousands," said Kathy Nicolaou-Hagianis, the recruiting coordinator for the bureau's New York region. She said she could not be more specific until it was clear next month how many of the region's households had failed to return the questionnaire.
Census officials said this week that they had met 90 percent of their goal of testing 3 million applicants nationwide, including about 250,000 in the New York region, for the enumerator jobs. They want a pool of 2.4 million qualified applicants across the country, five times the number they expect to hire, because experience indicates that many who are found eligible will not accept the jobs. Some will have found permanent jobs. Others will have had second thoughts about knocking on strangers' doors.
In the 1990 census, 35 percent of the New York region's 6.1 million households at the time failed to return the form -- the same percentage as in the country generally -- while in New York City that figure was 41 percent.
In its intensive effort to recruit census takers, the bureau has announced the job openings in letters and cards mailed to every residence in the country. Ms. Lozada said she learned about the jobs through television announcements and fliers that the bureau had posted on lampposts and other highly visible places, giving local numbers to call or a national number reachable anywhere in the country: 1-888-325-7733.
Census takers must be at least 17. They need not be citizens, though they must be in the country legally and permitted to work. The pay varies across the country, with the range this year -- from a low of $8.25 an hour in Duncan, Okla., to a high of $18.50 in New York City -- "more competitive with local labor rates than 10 years ago," said Clifton Taylor Jr., chief of recruiting. Those assigned as crew leaders will receive somewhat more.
The census was once handled entirely by door-to-door enumerators. But since 1970, the bureau has relied on the questionnaires, followed by visits to those who did not respond to them. This time, the surveys were mailed in recent days to 98 million homes. In the case of an additional 20 million homes, mostly in rural areas where people pick up their mail at post offices and other central locations, the forms are being delivered to the residences.
The forms are due back by April 1. Near the end of April, the census takers will begin making their rounds. If nobody is home, they are supposed to return as many as three times, and make up to three telephone calls, said Peter Sefton, the Census Bureau's chief of household enumeration. If those efforts fail, he said, "they are to try to get the information from a neighbor" or someone like an apartment house manager.
In the 1990 census, not all the enumerators were so diligent; some made up the information instead. In northern New Jersey, census workers said some supervisors told them to fabricate data for thousands of households in response to pressure from the Philadelphia regional office to finish the count. As a result, the bureau sent new enumerators to 18,000 homes at an additional cost of several hundred thousand dollars.
This year, Mr. Sefton said, the bureau is taking "proactive steps" to combat falsification, including checking a random sample of each census taker's work by sending another enumerator back to the homes in the sample.
Critics of the census say the real accuracy problem is not the few instances of faked forms, but the undercount. In recent years, there have been politically and racially charged debates and lawsuits about the accuracy of the census, which is used for apportioning seats among the states in the House of Representatives and for redistricting state legislatures.
Those disputes have stemmed from the difficulty of achieving a full and accurate count because of people who, out of fear, suspicion or the belief that some of the questions are intrusive, refuse to return the surveys, provide false or incomplete information or try to avoid the census takers. They include illegal immigrants fearful of deportation, welfare recipients worried about losing benefits if they list their spouses as living with them, and people afraid of being evicted if they report relatives or friends who have moved into the home without the landlord's permission. As a result, demographic experts estimate, the 1990 census missed about four million people, or 1.6 percent of the nation's population. New York City officials say that about 300,000 people living in the city were not counted. That census missed a disproportionately large number of minorities in low-income urban areas, experts said.
For these reasons, census takers have a crucial role to play in persuading people to cooperate.
Officials said the enumerators will be instructed to stress that federal law mandates that census information remain confidential, even from law enforcement and immigration agencies. They will be told to point out that a full and accurate count is important to the family and its community because of the data's role in determining how much government money is distributed to cities and neighborhoods for programs like school aid, job training, housing assistance and health services. As a last resort, they can point out that refusing to answer the census can bring a $100 fine -- although in 1990, nobody was prosecuted.
If census takers feel threatened, officials said, they are supposed to leave immediately.
In the test-taking session in Downtown Brooklyn, the applicants who were interviewed said they were not concerned about where they might be assigned. But Helene Leskin, a recruiting official for the area running from Brooklyn Heights to Sunset Park, said some applicants, especially the elderly, did indicate concern about safety. "We'll say, 'You're going to be working in your neighborhood,' and they feel more comfortable," she said.
One applicant, Rafael Torres Jr., 21, a mason tender from Red Hook, said that for him, working in his own neighborhood was precisely the point. Red Hook is one of the areas in the city that Ms. Leskin called "red zones," those with census tracts that had very low rates of questionnaire returns in 1990.
"I come from an impoverished neighborhood," Mr. Torres said, "and I noticed that ghetto communities go undercounted." He said he wanted to do his part to ensure that everyone in his community is counted.
"We're always complaining," he said. "We should be doing."

HEADLINE: Surging Petroleum Prices Push Inflation Rate to 3-Year High

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Surging petroleum prices pushed the inflation rate in February to its highest level in three years, the Labor Department reported yesterday. But beyond fuel and energy, the nation remained remarkably free of the rising inflation that the booming economy was expected to have produced by now.
The Consumer Price Index, the best-known inflation gauge, has risen 3.2 percent over the last 12 months, the first time the yearlong rate had gone above 3 percent since February 1997. But with energy excluded, the annual rate was only 2.1 percent, unchanged for many months, although some economists had expected a much greater impact from labor shortages and rising wages. 
 The inflation rate remained at 2.1 percent when food was excluded as well as energy. Prices in these sectors often jump around from month to month, so economists subtract them to get a "core" inflation rate.
"In a certain bizarre way, life would be easier for Alan Greenspan and the Federal Reserve if there had been a bad C.P.I.," said Robert Barbera, chief economist for the Hoenig Group. "They could then have dealt with their real problem, an excessively high stock market, and blamed their actions on inflation in goods and services."
The Fed's policy makers are expected to raise interest rates when they meet on Tuesday, but not by enough to inhibit stock market investors, many analysts say.
Most of last month's increase of 0.5 percent -- the largest one-month rise since last April -- reflected the run-up in petroleum prices. Gasoline at the pump averaged $1.42 a gallon, up from $1.36 in January. Airline fares rose as airlines tacked on surcharges to cover higher fuel prices. And the cost of running a home rose, reflecting higher prices for heating oil and natural gas, whose price fluctuates with that of petroleum.
Natural gas is widely used to generate electricity, and electricity rates jumped 0.8 percent in February, the biggest increase since July 1997. So far, however, the rise in petroleum and natural gas prices has not spread to other products, like plastics, which are made from oil or natural gas.
Toy prices, for example, did not rise, and vehicle prices, adjusted for quality improvements, fell last month, the Bureau of Labor Statistics reported. Even truckers have not managed to jack up freight rates, although the squeeze on their earnings from higher fuel prices has truckers protesting in Washington for relief.
Those situations will change, says Chris Varvares, a partner at Macroeconomic Advisers L.L.C. in St. Louis, if the petroleum-producing countries somehow manage to make the oil price increases stick.
"If companies expect the increase to be temporary, they will eat the cost and squeeze profit margins temporarily," he said. "But if energy prices stay high, firms will try to restore their profits by raising prices."
Beyond energy, there were scattered price increases, in cigarettes, for example, and hospital rates. Meat and pork prices rose 1.7 percent, which is more than usual, and such increases may repeat themselves because of a supply shortage, said Patrick Jackman, a senior economist in the consumer price division at the Bureau of Labor Statistics.
Fruit and vegetable prices also rose last month, but the 0.7 percent increase mainly reflected an aberration in the way prices are adjusted for seasonal factors, Mr. Jackman said.
And some prices fell in February. Vehicle prices dropped 0.1 percent after a 0.3 percent drop in January. Long-distance telephone rates also fell, along with the cost of purchasing and using a cell phone.

SECTION: Section A; Page 14; Column 1; Editorial Desk

HEADLINE: Caviar-and-Carpet Diplomacy

 BODY:
The White House responded smartly yesterday to the recent election of a moderate Iranian Parliament by lifting some economic sanctions and hinting that more might follow. Tehran must make the next move by dropping its resistance to direct government-to-government talks with Washington.
The American actions, outlined by Secretary of State Madeleine Albright, end a ban on the import of Iranian food and handicrafts, accelerate talks on resolving competing financial claims going back to the 1979 Iranian revolution and ease licensing rules for cultural and academic exchanges. Food and handicraft exports like caviar, pistachio nuts and carpets bring in far less revenue than oil exports, which remain barred. But Dr. Albright implied that other steps could come if Iran responds positively, including reconsideration of a prohibition on American investment in Iran's oil industry. 
 The reform coalition around President Mohammad Khatami has an ambitious domestic agenda that includes working out a reallocation of power with conservative clerical authorities, reviving Iran's economy and restoring rule of law. Until now, the reformers have been skittish about taking on sensitive foreign policy issues like mending ties with Washington. But Dr. Albright's proposals demonstrate the domestic advantages to be gained from less strained relations with the United States. Food and handicraft exports to America can generate millions of jobs, helping the reformers reduce Iran's dangerously high unemployment rate. A successful conclusion to the claims talks could also free assets needed for development.
As Dr. Albright noted, conservative clerical leaders still exercise great power. There can be no normal ties, and probably no lifting of oil sanctions, until the clerically controlled Revolutionary Guards and intelligence agencies sever their ties with terrorism and the military abandons its efforts to develop nuclear weapons. Dr. Albright also drew a proper link between human rights issues and future improvements in relations with Iran.
Washington has now offered a gesture of friendship, including a frank acknowledgment of past American policy mistakes toward Iran. With his strengthened political hand at home, Mr. Khatami should do his part to ease an estrangement that serves neither America's interests nor Iran's.

HEADLINE: Predatory Loan Scams

 BODY:
A Minnesota paralegal realizes too late that her home equity loan was for $13,000 more than she thought. A borrower finds out belatedly that her $45,000 loan required not only $90,000 of repayments over 15 years, but also a final additional payment of $41,000. These are despicable examples of predatory subprime home equity loans -- loans using the borrower's home as collateral that are made to people with blemished credit records and that impose exorbitant fees or conditions that virtually force the borrower into foreclosure.
As reported this week by Diana Henriques of The Times in cooperation with ABC News, one such lender, First Alliance Corporation, has been sued for deceptive practices by a dozen homeowners, the AARP and regulators in several states. First Alliance and some other subprime lenders are accused of preying upon naive and desperate people who could not borrow from conventional lenders. They wound up borrowing amounts they could not afford to repay at rates that were far out of line with what other subprime lenders were charging. First Alliance denies the allegations. 
 The courts can take care of any misrepresentation or fraud, but who should clamp down on the lenders is a trickier question. Subprime lenders, good and bad, get their money from some of Wall Street's finest. First Alliance's money came from securities sold to investors by Lehman Brothers, and Lehman says it disclosed all relevant financial risks to these investors. But underwriters do not attest to the moral virtue of their clients.
States, however, can step in. In New York, regulators are designing rules that would outlaw some of the worst features of predatory lending. The rules set limits on some of the fees that borrowers could be charged and would require lenders to consider whether the borrower could afford to repay the loan as negotiated.
Subprime lenders, most of whom are legitimate, must charge people with blemished credit records higher than normal fees and interest rates in order to compensate for the risk. If state regulators crack down too hard they risk driving legitimate lenders out of the market, leaving needy borrowers in the lurch. But the New York proposals, if anything, are overly lenient. Many of the people in the subprime market are unsophisticated in financial matters and easy victims for sleazy sales practices. They deserve better legal protection.

HEADLINE: E-Commerce the Japanese Way;
Ubiquitous Convenience Stores Branch Into Cyberspace

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 17

 BODY:
Tucked amid the instant noodles, pantyhose and canned drinks at the local Lawson, Japan's second-largest convenience store chain, customers now find a computer terminal that gives them access to a system called Loppi. With a few stabs at the keyboard, they can order concert tickets, make train and plane reservations and pay at the cash register on the way out.
Need a book? Seven-Eleven Japan, the country's largest operator of convenience stores, lets a customer hop online to eShopping Books, a site owned by Softbank, Seven-Eleven, Yahoo! Japan and Tohan, Japan's leading book distributor. A day or so later, on the way home from work perhaps, the customer picks up the selection and pays for it at the local Seven-Eleven. 
 Seven-Eleven -- with the Seven spelled out, unlike its American counterpart -- can also help with elderly parents. Just order a meal online and the company will deliver it.
With no further room to expand physically in this densely packed country and with competition intensifying as new stores cannibalize old, the neighborhood convenience store, or "conbini," is betting on the new economy in Japan, moving to embrace technology. Long accustomed to adding some 50 new products to its merchandise mix every week on average, the conbini are fast grabbing hunks of cyberspace to expand its limited shelf space.
At the same time, the deregulation that has been unfolding since the mid-1990's is allowing Japanese convenience stores to encroach on territory long out of their reach, like beauty and health aids and banking.
"In the last year, the convenience store has become an indispensable part of the mosaic that is electronic commerce," said Kenyu Adachi, director of the distribution industry division of the Ministry of Trade and Industry. "Without the convenience store, e-commerce in Japan would have more trouble taking off."
Nonetheless, Mr. Adachi and his ministry express a more tempered enthusiasm for e-tailing in Japan than do investors, who have, at least initially, bid up to astonishing levels the stocks of any Japanese company remotely associated with the Internet and information technology.
A study last year by the ministry and Andersen Consulting concluded that while e-commerce in Japan would one day have the same market share it has in the United States, Japan's less-developed information technology infrastructure and its still significant regulatory hurdles would mean a much slower rollout.
But the big convenience store chains, which have most of the market, are adding new virtual services and connections at such a clip that analysts complain they cannot keep track of it all. Almost simultaneously, the major chains have begun introducing Internet strategies, raising questions about the profitability of such ventures.
Convenience stores have a special place in society here, where tiny homes with space for only miniature refrigerators and minimal storage make frequent shopping a necessity. Because of its size, averaging about 100 square meters, the convenience store escaped the reach of Japanese regulators and thus can be far nimbler and more responsive to customer whims and fancies than its larger brethren.
At Seven-Eleven, inventory is controlled by advanced inventory management and technology. Plus, unlike other stores, most conbini are open round the clock.
There are more than 33,000 convenience stores across the country and traffic in them is high: some 900 people a day visit the average Seven-Eleven store, while two other large chains, FamilyMart and the Circle K Japan unit of the UNY Corporation, have about 700 customers a day. (Lawson, part of the Japanese retailer Daiei Inc., does not make its numbers available.) Makoto Usui, director and general manager of information systems at Seven-Eleven, said the average customer visits a Seven-Eleven store once every other day.
The bonds are deep. In a recent interview, when Hidetoshi Nakata, the Japanese soccer star who plays for Rome, was asked what he most missed about home, he answered, "Conbini."
Their ubiquity and popularity make them attractive partners to the many virtually unknown e-commerce companies out there, whose biggest expense is likely to be marketing. "They have a huge advantage over the typical Internet start-up," said Mike Allen, a retail analyst at ING Barings here. "The biggest cost that has prevented dot-com companies from making money is promotion, and convenience stores have almost no promotional costs because customers flock to them."
The conbini have helped Japanese e-commerce pioneers like the Softbank Corporation and Rakuten Ichiba, an online bazaar, leap two major hurdles: payment and delivery. Japanese consumers are more reluctant than their American counterparts to send their credit card account numbers out into cyberspace. And the product orders can piggyback onto the stores' existing distribution system.
The conbini also give consumers access to a computer terminal. Though computers have been selling at a blistering pace here of late, penetration is still lower than in the United States and Internet access charges are still high in comparison with those in other parts of the world. And though conbini customers cannot yet surf the entire World Wide Web, they soon will be able to.
"What does a convenience store have that makes it attractive to us and our customers?" said Yasuhiro Suzuki, president and chief executive of the e-Shopping Information Corporation, the Softbank unit that manages e-commerce ventures. "In a word, convenience."
Operations like Mr. Suzuki's would, in turn, appear to solve a major problem for Japanese convenience stores: the lack of space. The only way they have kept sales moving forward is by opening more stores; in general, sales in stores open at least one year are falling. But there are few practical locations left.
"The backdrop of expanding our business to include e-commerce is the need to expand our current offering of goods and services and increase our ability to meet the needs of customers without expanding our space," Mr. Usui of Seven-Eleven said.
Whether e-commerce will help the convenience stores become more profitable is unclear. Take the introduction of so-called energy drinks. Previously sold only in drugstores, convenience stores started selling the vitamin- and herb-laced drinks last spring, when deregulation opened the market to them.
But unlike the addition of beer and sake to the merchandise mix five years ago, the introduction of energy drinks has not significantly increased the stores' overall revenues. While sales of the new products have met projections, they merely replaced those of the other items that previously occupied the selling space.
Though those constraints do not exist in cyberspace, there, too, profitability may be a problem. E-Shopping Books, the joint venture, was billed as a baby Amazon.com, but sales so far are minuscule: as of the end of January, each Seven-Eleven store was selling four books every 10 days on average.
Mr. Suzuki said that figure represented a quadrupling in volume since the service started in November, and added, "The progress we've seen in the business has been better than expected."
He said he was confident the business would turn profitable, in part because its cost structure may be lower than Amazon.com's. E-Shopping Books does not shoulder the costs of warehousing merchandise, since it can use Tohan's and Seven-Eleven's warehouses, and it pays for the books only after they have been sold. The business will also share the e-shopping name, administrative functions and technological infrastructure with Softbank's online toy and car parts businesses, as well as others introduced in the future, cutting marketing and administrative costs.
"A newcomer to the business would have a tough time finding temporary warehousing for delivery to customers, but convenience stores can act as the final pick-up point quite easily because of their infrastructure," said Ken Sakamura, a professor at Tokyo University. "They already have warehouses."
But while such teamwork lowers costs, it also means that profits, should they materialize, have to be divided.
The same sort of division of the spoils has so far, in an experimental stage, proved unprofitable for the conbini. Although polls show that consumers here have long wished for automated teller machines in convenience stores, they have not used the A.T.M.'s enough in the few months they have been available to make it worthwhile.
The machines allow customers to do everything from arrange money transfers to make deposits and withdrawals and even obtain small consumer loans. Mr. Allen at ING Barings said 100 transactions a day were needed to make store-based A.T.M.'s profitable. In test cases by various convenience store chains, which have placed A.T.M.'s in their bigger stores, transactions are running at 10 to 50 a day, a level that generates a loss for the stores after they pay their banking partner and their technology and software providers.
To help overcome this barrier to profitability, the Ito-Yokado Company, which controls Seven-Eleven, plans to apply for a banking license.
The most promising area of new business for the convenience stores is likely to be online services like ticketing and reservations. Such services are popular -- and go quickly -- because people typically know exactly what they are looking for, said Hideki Tanaka, an e-commerce analyst at the Fujitsu Research Institute. "But I question whether the typical convenience store customer is going to take 10 or 20 extra minutes to stand at a computer terminal in the store browsing for goods they want to buy," he said.
Considering that the most popular use of Loppi, Lawson's online system, is looking up one's horoscope, that is a question well worth contemplating.

HEADLINE: Outlining Goals, I.M.F. Heir Apparent Cites Dialogue and Stability

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
The presumptive new leader of the International Monetary Fund gave a general outline of his goals today, promising to listen to criticism from outsiders and to make the fund "a cornerstone for promoting growth and stability."
Horst Kohler, whose way to become the managing director of the monetary fund was cleared when American and Japanese rivals for the post dropped out on Thursday, said he was committed to a dialogue with the United States Congress. Some of its members have been sharply critical of the fund in the past, and with the public in general. 
 "I do think that it's an obligation to explain I.M.F. policy, better maybe than we have in the past," Mr. Kohler said at a get-acquainted news conference at the fund's headquarters here.
The fund was founded in 1946 to promote economic stability around the world, partly through loans to countries in need. From time to time, it has been accused of straying from its original mission and trying ineffectually to bring about profound social changes.
Mr. Kohler's remarks came just 10 days after a study commissioned by Congress recommended that the fund and its sister organization, the World Bank, be trimmed back. The commission further suggested that the fund emphasize short-term, emergency aid to countries as opposed to trying to effect major social changes, like relieving poverty.
Responding to a question, Mr. Kohler said today that he would try to keep the fund focused on "crisis prevention" in individual countries.
On an especially sensitive subject, Russia, Mr. Kohler said he was "open for a constructive dialogue" with Russia's acting president, Vladimir V. Putin, whom he met in December, and was willing to give him the benefit of the doubt.
The fund has met political resistance in Russia and has repeatedly delayed disbursing its funds there. Moreover, the institution that Mr. Kohler is leaving to head the I.M.F., the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, has had a series of bad loans in Russia under Mr. Kohler's watch.
Taking care not to appear over-confident, even though most of the representatives of the fund's 182 member nations have signaled their support for him, Mr. Kohler said he was "honored by this expression of confidence." He said he had had fruitful discussions with Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers and with Stanley Fischer, the deputy managing director who was in the running for the directorship.
Mr. Kohler praised Mr. Fischer's "intellectual brilliance and experience" and said he was pleased that Mr. Fischer had said he would stay at the agency. The other man Mr. Kohler beat out was Eisuke Sakakibara, a former Finance Ministry official in Japan.
Alluding to the weeks of controversy in which he emerged as the top contender after the United States rejected Germany's first choice, Caio Koch-Weser, Mr. Kohler said, "I agree that this process was really not the best I could imagine."

HEADLINE: PUBLIC LIVES;
A Catholic Who Found a Harmony in His Apology to Jews

BYLINE: By GUSTAV NIEBUHR 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE

 BODY:
IN the living room of the 19th-century brick house that serves as the residence of Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland stands a studio grand piano, with sheets of Chopin waltzes spread out above the keys.
For a visitor, it is a reminder that the archbishop, the spiritual head of nearly 700,000 Roman Catholics in southern Wisconsin, was recently notified by Columbia University in New York that he would soon receive his doctorate in music, completing a degree he began working on in the 1950's, then halted, only to resume a few years ago. His first music teacher, a nun at a parochial school in Pennsylvania, would no doubt have been proud. 
 But yesterday morning, the talk turns from music to the spoken word -- to two highly unusual homilies, one given by Pope John Paul II last Sunday, the other four months earlier by Archbishop Weakland. Both were apologies for errors committed by Catholics against others.
While the pope's remarks were broad and timed for the first Sunday in Lent, the archbishop was more specific, directing his statements to Jews, in Milwaukee and elsewhere. Speaking in a local synagogue last Nov. 7, Archbishop Weakland said that conversion, the change of attitude that precedes an effort to change one's life and society, must include acknowledgment of wrongdoing, a request for forgiveness and a resolve to reform.
Both the timing of the speech and its "interactive quality," in which the archbishop asked his Catholic listeners to say "amen" as he made his points, marked the occasion as a major event, said Rabbi A. James Rudin, interreligious affairs director of the American Jewish Committee. "That Nov. 7 speech electrified the Jewish community, not only in Milwaukee but throughout the United States," he said.
Although other prelates have since offered apologies (notably Cardinal Bernard Law, archbishop of Boston, and Cardinal Roger Mahony, archbishop of Los Angeles), Archbishop Weakland's homily "was the first of the millennial season, of the run-up to the year 2000," Rabbi Rudin said.
In his homily last November, Archbishop Weakland said that "we Catholics" had acted "contrary to God's law" in dealings with Jews in the past, that the Jewish community was harmed as a result, and that by preaching "that the Jewish people were unfaithful, hypocritical and God-killers," Catholics had reduced Jews' human dignity. And that, he said, "contributed to attitudes that made the Holocaust possible." He called on members of both faiths to work together to heal the world.
In an interview, Archbishop Weakland said: "The idea of apologies for the past is difficult. We have only the sense of personal sin and personal guilt." But he added that he did not think people could move ahead unless they regarded themselves as part of a group and were responsible for its actions. "Otherwise," he said, "the fear remains that history will repeat."
Archbishop Weakland said he did not want to be accusatory. But neither is he finished with this process. He plans apologies to African-Americans and probably to others as well. These must be made on appropriate occasions, he said, lest the intent of the message be lost and the apology be reduced to mere words.
In a larger sense, he said, he sees the major religions as standing at a unique juncture in history, when modern communications have brought them into much closer proximity than ever. "How much must we hold in common in order to live in common?" he asked, adding that what religions contribute positively to society will depend in part on how their members cooperate with one another.
Back in September 1977, when Pope Paul VI appointed him to the archdiocese here, Archbishop Weakland found an interfaith group already established. His homily last November was timed for its 25th anniversary.
"I was talking to a group that knew each other well, that I knew well," he said, responding to a question about why he had felt he could be more specific in his remarks than the pope would be later. "The pope had to be general, because he's talking to the whole church."
Nonetheless, Archbishop Weakland has become known for a certain outspokenness, perhaps more obvious now that the nation's Catholic hierarchy, in its annual meetings, seems far more cautious than it was a decade ago, when the bishops issued major pastoral statements on peace and the economy.
In the interview, the archbishop said he could recall no single instance that persuaded him he needed to preach the apology. But then he recalled a trip he made with parishioners to Poland in 1990. Visiting Krakow, he said, they saw a wall with anti-Semitic graffiti. When he asked a guide why the statements were not painted over, she replied that whoever did it would just put them up again. "I had a feeling that what caused the Holocaust was not completely over," he said.
The archbishop will turn 73 in April. He became a Benedictine monk at 22 and was ordained a priest two years later. He was, for a time in his 30's, a music teacher at a Catholic college.
His roots lie in Pennsylvania coal country, where he was one of six children in a family that received public assistance. "The only possessions the family had," he said, "were an upright piano and 10 volumes of music." He tinkered at the keys, but it was his fourth-grade teacher -- the nun -- who really taught him how to play.
Is there any relationship between playing music and the awareness that one needs to apologize for errors? Well, yes, Archbishop Weakland replied. Music, especially pieces like those that Mozart composed, can be very difficult to get right. "You realize that no human being is perfect," he said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
As Some Look for More Fireworks, the Dow Takes a Dip

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
If history is any guide, the powerful 499-point gain in the Dow Jones industrial average on Thursday augurs well for investors over the next few months.
Past performance, of course, is no guarantee of future success, as many a mutual fund advertisement notes. But the statistics are unambiguous. 
 Before this week, the Dow, which gained 4.9 percent on Thursday, had rallied at least 4 percent 10 times since the current bull market began in 1982. On eight of those occasions, stocks extended their gains for at least three months after the big one-day move, according to Richard McCabe, chief market strategist at Merrill Lynch. The gains were substantial, too. Even factoring in the two times the Dow did not continue to rally, the gains over the three months after the market's big day averaged a 7.5 percent gain.
Over a longer period, the positive results are even more pronounced, according to a study by Birinyi Associates. Including Thursday, Birinyi looked at the Dow's 25 best days since 1970, a period that covers both bull and bear markets. The firm found that those best days presaged a gain of more than 14 percent over the following six months.
"What the last move is showing is that investors have not abandoned stocks, " said Robin Griffiths, the chief technical analyst at HSBC Securities. "This is greed rather than fear, and as long as we have greed around, we have a bull market."
The Dow pulled back slightly yesterday, falling 35.37 points, to 10,595.23, a 0.33 percent drop. The Nasdaq composite index rose 80.74 points, or 1.71 percent, to 4,798.13, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 6 points, or 0.41 percent, to 1,464.47.
Despite history's pattern of further gains, technical analysts on Wall Street said the rally this week might be an exception to the trend.
These technicians try to divine future moves of stocks from their price histories. To the many investors and economists who believe stocks are impossible to predict that way, technicians are little more than psychics with computers. But most major Wall Street firms keep at least a couple of technical analysts on staff.
Generally, a rally will have staying power, technicians say, if in addition to price movements it has heavy trading volume and breadth, meaning that several stocks rise for each stock that falls. The rally on Thursday seems to fit all three criteria. Almost 1.5 billion shares were traded on the New York Stock Exchange, a record, and seven stocks rose for every two that dropped.
Rallies like that "have tended to mean that the market will go up for a number of weeks and in many cases a number of months," said Ricky Harrington, technical analyst for Wachovia Securities in North Carolina. But he said he remained "very cautious about this market," in part because the Dow remains below its average of the last 200 days, a trend that technicians view as bearish.
Mr. McCabe said he was also uncertain that Thursday's gains would hold, though for a different reason. He is worried that investors are too bullish. It may seem counterintuitive, but technical analysts say the strongest rallies begin when most investors have turned very negative and selling pressure has reached a climax. Recent surveys show that investors are very complacent, as opposed to negative, about the market, Mr. McCabe said. He fears that stocks will turn down again "sometime in the spring," he said.
Bob Dickey, managing director for technical analysis at Dain Rauscher, said he expected stocks to remain in a tight range over the next several months and finish the year not far from current levels. Slipping a bit of fundamental analysis into his explanation, Mr. Dickey said, "We're in a period of rising interest rates similar to 1994, and so I think this year will be similar to 1994," a year when most stocks ended slightly down.
In fact, "Don't fight the Fed" is one of Wall Street's hoariest maxims, and the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, has repeatedly indicated concern about stock price levels.
But though the Fed has raised short-term interest rates four times since June in an effort to slow the economy, corporate profits continue to chug along. Analysts expect profits to rise 17.7 percent this year, following a rise of 18 percent last year, according to First Call/Thomson Financial. Long-term interest rates have also dropped substantially since hitting highs in January. Lower interest rates are considered good for stocks, because they reduce the cost of corporate borrowing while making bonds less attractive as an investment alternative.
In the bond market, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 18/32 yesterday, to 10314/32 . The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 6.00 percent from 6.04 percent on Thursday.

HEADLINE: As Taiwan Votes in Close 3-Way Race Today, a Weak Government Is the Likeliest Outcome

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 17

 BODY:
No matter who wins the hotly contested presidential election on Saturday, the outcome will almost certainly be the weakest, most divided government since Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists fled to the island in 1949.
At fervent rallies tonight that brought hundreds of thousands of flag-waving citizens into the capital's streets, the three main candidates made their final appeals in a race that appeared too close to call. 
 Polling has not been allowed in the final 10 days, adding to the suspense of an election that has been fought with all the exuberance of a young democracy facing profound choices.
The contenders are Vice President Lien Chan from the governing Nationalist Party; James Soong, a former Nationalist official who is running as an independent; and Chen Shui-bian of the Democratic Progressives, the main opposition party.
Hanging over the campaign were heavy-handed warnings from Beijing, which considers Taiwan a region separated from the mainland since the civil war of the 1940's and threatened war if the island indefinitely delayed reunification talks.
But a more immediate problem for the Nationalists, who have firmly governed Taiwan through 51 years of dictatorship and then a democracy that they ushered in, is that this election represents a wrenching turning point, transforming the island's politics.
The Nationalist candidate, Mr. Lien, is in serious danger of losing in a three-way, winner-take-all race that has disastrously divided the party's traditional majority. Even if he wins, the prospect is for debilitating internal clashes.
"Everyone is focusing so much on the cross-straits problem," said Steven M. Goldstein, an expert on Taiwan politics at Smith College, in Massachusetts. "But no matter who gets elected, there's going to be a constitutional crisis."
The once impregnable Nationalists have been seriously weakened by charges of corruption and by an internal rift that produced Mr. Soong's breakaway candidacy and improves the chances of victory for Mr. Chen.
However, in an unusual prospect of a divided government here, either Mr. Chen or Mr. Soong, if elected, would have to contend with a Nationalist majority in the legislature, which is not up for re-election.
Even if Vice President Lien gains a plurality, allowing the Nationalists to hold on the presidency, the party will face new challenges to its vast business holdings and freewheeling political deals.
Both Mr. Chen and Mr. Soong have gained from their campaigning against "black gold" in politics, the term here for the business manipulations, alliances with mobsters and vote buying that have plagued Taiwanese politics. Many supporters of Mr. Chen and Mr. Soong are united in disgust at what they call the continued corruption of the Nationalists under the departing president, Lee Teng-hui.
"We have to get rid of the corruption and organized crime and vote buying," said Lu Chiu-chien, 42, a social worker from Keelung City who furiously waved a Chen flag here tonight.
Mr. Soong's credibility was hurt by evidence, released by the Nationalists, that he diverted party money to personal accounts in the past. But supporters like Mary Lu, 45, a homemaker who was out cheering for Mr. Soong, say he has been persecuted by a vindictive Mr. Lee.
Also, although he is stepping down as president, Mr. Lee has said he wants to serve out his remaining one and a half years as chairman of the Nationalist Party, a position that has arguably been more powerful than the presidency.
"Suddenly, the same person will no longer be both president and chairman of the party," said John Hsieh, the Taiwan-born director of the Center for Asian Studies at the University of South Carolina. "A serious confrontation is likely."
But attitudes toward Taiwan's independence remain the fundamental cleavage in the electorate, said Mr. Hsieh, an expert on public opinion here. The campaign has not only brought out festering animosities within the Nationalist Party, but also between those who basically favor independence and the majority, who want to leave well enough alone.
Cheng Yin-fu, 41, a furniture seller who was wildly waving a Chen Shui-bian flag at the stadium tonight, expressed the attitude that China -- and some worried Taiwanese -- dread to hear. "Spiritually and morally I support independence," he said. "But as for the actual action, we can wait for a while."
President Lee has outraged Chinese officials with his insistence on Taiwan's equal status with the mainland, a position that is widely shared here. But in recent days, Beijing has pointedly attacked Mr. Chen, the opposition party challenger, warning that his victory would be dangerous.
Alone among the candidates, Mr. Chen long championed a Taiwanese declaration of independence. But in this campaign, he moderated his position, saying a formal declaration would be unnecessary because Taiwan was effectively sovereign.
Although he has tried to press the anticorruption theme, he has had to spend much of his campaign trying to assure voters that he will not act recklessly and will seek peace.
Given China's deep suspicions, his election would open a period of serious tension, anxiously watched in Washington, because the United States has pledged to help defend Taiwan and would be drawn into a cross-strait war.
With a wide sense that Mr. Chen was gaining ground, Vice President Lien started trying to scare voters with warnings that electing Mr. Chen would court a military attack. Tonight he told cheering supporters that Mr. Chen and his party represented "chaos, disaster, war!"
Holding high Mr. Lien's hand at tonight's rally, President Lee continued this line of attack, shouting that Mr. Chen "is inexperienced, and everything he says will give jitters to everyone!"
But Mr. Chen's generally ardent supporters, including many younger people who yearn for a fresh and cleaner government, as well as an independent Taiwanese identity, have not been deterred.
"Taiwan, stand up!" was a loud chant at the Chen rally tonight, the largest and most frenzied of the three, which spilled far into the streets from a packed football stadium.
Considered by many to be a weak candidate, Mr. Lien, who has an American doctorate in political science and has held several top government posts, has offered little more in his campaign than appeals to experience and stability.
After having been pushed aside by his former mentor, President Lee, Mr. Soong, a onetime Nationalist stalwart, has driven his independent run by attacking the corruption of the party that he had long served and by billing himself as a more competent leader than Mr. Lien.
At the same time, Mr. Soong, who also has an American doctorate in politics, is more willing to discuss the mainland's core principle of "one China." He says he would be best able to negotiate with the mainland. But the independence-leaning supporters of Mr. Chen fear that he would sell out Taiwan's interests.
All three candidates say they will seek to broaden economic ties with the mainland. But whether any of them can meet Beijing's demands for unity talks is unclear, because the vast majority of voters prefer their current status of undeclared independence. And political experts wonder how the island will cope with pressures from Beijing if its government is seriously divided.
At the Hsingtien Buddhist temple here today, hundreds of people attended daily services. Most were older women. "At the beginning of the prayers, everybody here made a wish for peace and stability," said one, Zhang Pai-tsai. She was worried by China's threats and said she would vote for Mr. Lien.
Outside the temple, Lin Tsai-cheng, 32, an electrician, said he was leaning toward Mr. Soong. "It's time for a change, but since Soong comes out of the KMT, it won't be too drastic a change," said Mr. Lin, using the initials for the Nationalists.
Mr. Chen's supporters tend to shrug off the mainland warnings.
"I don't give a damn about the threats from the mainland," Li Jing-huang, 50, a guide for Japanese tourists, said. "I was in the Taiwanese marines in Vietnam and I saw real war. But I don't think they'll attack. China can't afford a war."

HEADLINE: Newark Residents File Suit For the Right to Speak Out

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

DATELINE: NEWARK, March 17

 BODY:
Democracy has always had its messy side, and here in New Jersey's largest city, where politics is a rough-and-tumble affair, almost everyone agrees that City Council meetings have become more acrid than a drum of battery acid. Protesters have been arrested, Council members have been called Nazis and sessions have often stretched into the wee hours.
In response to the increasing venom -- and to the growing length of the gatherings -- the Council began trying three years ago to limit the open-mike part of the meetings. 
 People who wish to speak at regular meetings are now required to sign up five days in advance, and comments are limited to matters up for a vote. As an alternative to the tumultuous public sessions, the Council has established special "citizens' hearings" in each of the city's five wards, but residents often find themselves addressing only one or two of the Council's nine members.
Saying that their right to free speech is being violated, a group of residents filed suit against the Council today in an effort to bring back the days when the full Council was forced to listen to comments on matters as varied as police misconduct, broken street lamps or a once-beloved Council member gone bad.
"They may not like what we have to say, but the way this country works, they have to hear us out," said Ras Baraka, a teacher and a plaintiff in the lawsuit. "You can't use your power to stop people from speaking their minds."
The lawsuit was filed by the American Civil Liberties Union of New Jersey, the Constitutional Litigation Clinic of Rutgers University School of Law and the Public Interest Law Center of New Jersey.
Although Council members have said that their actions were not meant to stifle free speech, none of them returned calls seeking comment.
Today's suit is just the latest skirmish in a war between the Council and some of the city's most tenacious gadflies. Both sides agree that the strife has grown more intense in recent years as Newark, once mostly concerned with survival, finds itself in the midst of a modest boom.
With a flurry of new development proposals before the Council, including a downtown sports arena that would displace residents and businesses, many people complain that their elected officials are deaf to their concerns, and that there is little airing of dissent. A majority of the nine-member Council, they point out, sides with Mayor Sharpe James.
"Newark is supposedly having a renaissance, but you can't have a rebirth without the participation of the people who live here," said Manuel Lavin, a community organizer whose group stopped the city from building a minor league baseball stadium in the East Ward's biggest park three years ago.
It was during the outpouring of anger over the stadium that the Council moved to restrict the public comment period. To Mr. Lavin, it was clear that many Council members felt threatened by the growing number of residents willing to speak out against their elected officials. Because the hearings were televised on a local cable channel, he said, people from other wards were drawn to the sessions and began freely venting their frustrations.
"Since the riots, we've all been divided up in separate wards, and for the first time we're starting to come together," Mr. Lavin said. "That really scares the Council."
Opponents say that by ending the anything-goes public sessions and replacing them with periodic "citizens' hearings" in the city's five wards, the Council is trying to isolate popular discontent by funneling it into far-flung meetings that are poorly attended and never televised.
Last year, a group of residents collected 3,600 signatures in an effort to force a referendum on whether the public should be allowed to speak on any matter of their choosing during Council meetings. Although the number of signatures qualified the issue for next November's ballot, the Council instead adopted a new meeting ordinance that they said would accomplish the same goal. In addition to requiring at least five Council members at each citizens' hearing, the ordinance established a public session two hours before each regular Council meeting.
The city clerk, Robert Marasco, said the Council had the right to decide if an issue was worthy of a referendum, which can cost up to $500,000. The Council has addressed criticisms, he said, by increasing the opportunities for public participation. But the residents' lawsuit insists that the referendum take place.
Lenora Lapidus, legal director of the A.C.L.U. in New Jersey, called the ordinance "a watered-down version" of the ballot measure and said it was a clear effort to subvert state law on referendums. She pointed out that Council members were not required to attend the newly established sessions. As for the citizens' hearings, she said, if fewer than five Council members show up, the meeting is simply canceled.
Renee Steinhagen, executive director of the Public Interest Law Center of New Jersey, said she knew of no other municipality in the state that had tried to limit public comment during regular meetings. Rejecting a ballot initiative, she said, was especially egregious.
"It's obvious that they want to make decisions without being bothered by criticism," she said. "Not only is it patronizing, but it's outrageous."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

 
Nasdaq Continues to Rise But Dow Industrials Drop
The stock market returned to a calmer mode as the Nasdaq continued to climb, while blue- chip shares retreated one day after Thursday's 499-point gain in the Dow Jones industrial average.
The Nasdaq composite index rose 80.74 points, or 1.7 percent, to 4,798.13, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was up 6 points, at 1,464.47. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 35.37 points, to 10,595.23. C3. 

Gunmaker Sets Safety Measures
The gun manufacturer Smith & Wesson has agreed to put safety locks on its handguns within 60 days and to make them child-resistant within a year in a deal with federal and state agencies. The government agreed to withdraw pending legal action against the gunmaker in return. A1.
 
I.M.F. Candidate Outlines His Goals
Horst Kohler, the likely new managing director of the International Monetary Fund, gave a general outline of his goals at a news conference in Washington. He promised to listen to criticism from outsiders and to make the fund "a cornerstone for promoting growth and stability." A3.
 
Energy Prices Fuel Inflation Gain
Surging oil prices pushed the inflation rate in February to its highest level in three years, the Labor Department said. The Consumer Price Index, the best-known inflation gauge, rose 3.2 percent over the last 12 months. That is the first time the yearlong rate has been above 3 percent since February 1997. C3.
 
Hearst Sells San Francisco Paper
The Hearst Corporation sold The San Francisco Examiner to Ted Fang, the owner of two local newspapers and part of a well-connected family with a strong political base in San Francisco's Chinatown. A7.
 
America Online to Buy Out Partner
America Online plans to buy out Bertelsmann's 50 percent stake in their joint ventures, AOL Europe and AOL Australia, for more than $8 billion. The move had been expected since AOL agreed to acquire Time Warner. C2.
 
Life Magazine to Cease Publication
Time Inc. said it would cease regular publication of Life magazine, the illustrated chronicle of America for more than six decades, with the May issue because the market for magazines has become too competitive for a general interest publication. It was the second time the company stopped regular publication of the magazine since it was introduced in 1936. Time will continue to publish Life for special events. C14.
 
Rover Workers Fear for their Jobs
Many of the 9,000 employees at the Rover manufacturing plant in Longbridge, England, fear that they will lose their jobs now that BMW has sold the plant. The reverberations extended also to the 50,000 people who depend on the auto industry for their livelihood in the region, which was once the heart of the British auto industry. BMW's move also drew criticism from the British government. C2.
 
Bank One to Eliminate 5,100 Jobs
Bank One said that it would eliminate 5,100 jobs, or about 5.6 percent of its work force, to lower costs as the bank struggles to raise earnings and its share price. The bank also said it gave its chairman and chief executive, John B. McCoy, a $10.3 million severance payment and a $3 million annual pension when he resigned in December after profit problems. C3.
 
Sprint Ties In to Mexican Company
Sprint PCS, the mobile telephone unit of Sprint, paid $200 million for an undisclosed stake in Pegaso PCS, the first cellular phone company to offer 100 percent digital services in Mexico, in a deal that will offer cross-border telephone services. C2.

INTERNATIONAL A3-6
 
U.S. Eases Iran Sanctions In Overture to Moderates
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright ended a few of the economic sanctions against Iran and declared a commitment to take far more extensive steps toward ending two decades of hostility "if Iran indicates a desire and commitment to do so." Asylum for a Terrorist
Lebanon granted political asylum to Kozo Okamoto, a 52-year-old Japanese man who had served a prison sentence in Israel for helping carry out the Lod airport massacre in 1972. He later spent time in Lebanese prisons for immigration violations and forgery. But Beirut deported to Jordan four other members of the Japanese Red Army, a terrorist group whose heyday was in the 1970's. A3
 
Theory on Swissair Crash
Canadian investigators looking into the crash of Swissair 111 say a pilot's map light, built into the ceiling of the cockpit, may be a source of fire in that model plane, an MD-11. Boeing responded by urging airlines that fly the plane to check the part frequently until it could be replaced. A4
 
Taiwan to Choose President
Voters in Taiwan go to the polls today to settle the hotly contested presidential election whose outcome will almost certainly produce the weakest, most divided government since Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalists fled to the island in 1949. The three main candidates made their final appeals at rallies that brought hundreds of thousands into the streets. A4
 
U.N. Considers Senate Offer
Members of the Security Council are pondering an invitation to visit Washington from a frequent critic, Senator Jesse Helms, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, and from Joseph R. Biden Jr., its ranking Democrat. Some diplomats are concerned about the image of the powerful 15-member council trundling off to Capitol Hill. A6
 
I.M.F. Nominee's Plans
The fund's presumptive new leader, Horst Kohler, outlined his goals, promising to listen to criticism from outsiders and to make the fund "a cornerstone for promoting growth and stability." He also said he was committed to a dialogue with Congress, some of whose members have been sharply critical of the fund. A3
 
World Briefing A5
 
NATIONAL A7-10
 
Gun Maker's Concessions Avert 15 Cities' Lawsuits
Smith & Wesson, the nation's oldest and largest manufacturer of handguns, agreed to accept a wide array of restrictions on the way it makes, sells and distributes handguns each year in exchange for ending lawsuits by 15 cities that had threatened to bankrupt it. But 15 other cities and counties that had filed similar suits had not signed on by the end of the day. The agreement, which also heads off potential suits by the federal government, New York and Connecticut, was immediately attacked by other manufacturers. A1
 
The move prompted debate among gun-control advocates and criticism from within the gun industry. A8
 
Re-examining Waco Siege
The government, acting on a court order, will attempt tomorrow to recreate various actions on the deadly last day of the siege of the Branch Davidian compound. The purpose is to try to determine if flashes seen on infrared videotape could have come from federal agents' weapons. A1
 
Candidates Spar on Education
A television commercial for Gov. George W. Bush attacked the education policies of President Clinton and Vice President Al Gore, saying they had failed to raise standards and close the "achievement gap" between rich and poor. HEADLINE: In Clinton, India Sees a Bridegroom

BYLINE: By CELIA W. DUGGER 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, March 17

 BODY:
Like a family preparing for a sumptuous wedding that will unite two great ancestral lines, India has been dressing itself up for its first visit from an American president in more than two decades -- a visit in which the world's largest democracy and its most powerful one will again try to build an alliance that has eluded them for a half-century.
With President Clinton touching down here on Sunday evening, workers were out in force today. There were battalions of malis -- or gardeners -- planting frowsy-headed yellow dahlias along the route he will drive. Sweepers with spiky brooms were ridding lawns of leaves and teams of men were pushing wheelbarrows of steaming tar to spread in potholes. 
 Indians believe that it is auspicious to paint their homes and repair what is broken before the occasion of a marriage. And if the relationship between India and the United States is to progress, a great deal of good fortune will be required.
President Clinton -- cast as an Indian bridegroom on the cover of a newsmagazine here in a full-length golden jacket and curly-toed slippers -- recently decided to make the trip despite the failure of intensive American efforts to persuade India to sign the nuclear test ban treaty or to cap its nuclear arsenal.
But with his tenure as president running out, President Clinton's timing, again, has not proved lucky; relations between India and its longtime rival and neighbor, Pakistan, have continued to deteriorate.
His decision to pay a brief visit to America's old ally, Pakistan -- despite the explicit opposition of the Indian prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, and Mr. Vajpayee's request that the Americans instead put Pakistan on a list of terrorist states -- has tempered any euphoria here about Mr. Clinton's far longer five-day visit to India.
American diplomats, businessmen and policy analysts have been trying to convince India, the subcontinent's economic power, that the president's visit is fundamentally about building a broader, deeper relationship -- one that will encompass cooperative efforts in trade, science and technology, the environment and health, among others.
And the Indians, who do not like being treated as though their country is no more important than far smaller Pakistan, seem encouraged by a speech Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright gave last week and its not-so-veiled criticisms of Pakistan.
While declaring India's decision to conduct nuclear tests "a historic mistake," she also said that Pakistan should take steps to "address the effects of terror on Pakistan's neighbors, notably India." The United States has asked Pakistan to ban a Pakistan-based Islamic fundamentalist group the Americans have categorized as terrorist -- and whose members are waging a holy war against India in the disputed territory of Kashmir.
Politicians in India applauded the remarks meant for Pakistan in which Dr. Albright also said the so-called Line of Control that divides Kashmir must be respected. Pakistan is held responsible for organizing an incursion into Indian territory last summer that led to a vicious confrontation between the two nuclear-armed nations.
The Indian foreign minister, Jaswant Singh, referred with satisfaction on Thursday to Dr. Albright's "reaffirmation of the validity of the Line of Control."
Frank Wisner, who was the American ambassador to India from 1994 to 1997, said Dr. Albright's speech was an indication of America's willingness to talk straight with the Pakistanis.
"Having watched us be careful and nuanced over the years, that was not careful and nuanced; that was blunt," he said. "If this speech does not make clear the explicit difference in the American view of India and Pakistan, I don't know what else you need. A four-and-a-half day visit to India and a four-and-a-half hour visit to Pakistan?"
The estrangement between India and the United States -- two great, multicultural democracies that would seem to have so much in common -- stretches back to the 1950's and the height of the cold war. India, the proud new nation finally freed of colonial domination, chose the path of nonalignment, while Pakistan, its smaller, insecure neighbor, sought to ally with the United States.
Through the years, the Americans grew cozy with Pakistan's military dictators, funneling billions of dollars in military aid that sometimes wound up turned against India. By the early 1970's, India had drawn closer to the Soviet Union. When the Soviets invaded Afghanistan in 1979, India refused to condemn the aggression, while Pakistan was a key player in American support for the Islamic mujahedeen battling the Soviet Army.
With the crumbling of the Soviet Union and India's decision in 1991 to begin loosening barriers to trade and investment, the conditions that had kept socialist India and capitalist America apart were profoundly changed.
Still, old habits of mistrust die hard. India, craving recognition as a global power, often finds what it sees as American arrogance hard to take. In the eyes of many Indians, the American opposition to the nuclear tests seemed the height of hypocrisy, coming from a nation that still has thousands of nuclear warheads.
The former Indian foreign secretary, J. N. Dixit, has described the Indo-American relationship with the Hindi word panga, which roughly translates as prickly, petulant, confrontational.
Mr. K. Subrahmanyam, who recently headed a committee that looked into army intelligence failures for the Indian government, offered a perfect illustration of panga in his contentious reaction to President Clinton's tour of India.
"This visit is purely symbolic of the fact that two years after the nuclear tests, India has done nothing to comply with the stentorian demands of the nuclear hegemonists and still the U.S. president is coming to visit," Mr. Subrahmanyam declared in his own stentorian tones. "In spite of all the rhetoric, the United States accepts reality."
A stream of Americans from Washington institutions have come through Delhi in recent weeks and many of them have been advising the president to brave the thorny task of talking with the Indians for the sake of the rose -- better relations with a country that is the second most populous in the world, with an economy growing at a rate that has averaged more than 6 percent since 1991.
Few expect any developments of earth-shaking importance from the visit. India has already declared that the test ban treaty and its relations with Pakistan are not open for negotiation. Still, given the history, the symbolism of the visit itself may have content.
Like the rituals of a wedding, the ceremonies of a state visit could lay the foundations for a new understanding -- at least that is what diplomats on both sides hope.
Lloyd I. Rudolph, a political scientist at the University of Chicago, said that after more than 20 years of neglect -- the last presidential visit was by Jimmy Carter in 1978 -- the Americans need to come to pay their respects. "You sometimes have to have a cup of tea before people will trust you," he said.

HEADLINE: Ambition Turns to Crisis Control as Clinton Visits the Subcontinent

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
When President Clinton first contemplated visiting India three years ago he was eager to open a relationship with the vastly populated, democratic country that had remained outside the Western fold during the cold war. He was also gripped with the ambition, his aides said, to display the fabric of modern India to the rest of the world.
But the fall of two Indian governments and the nuclear tests of May 1998 conspired against Mr. Clinton's timetable. 
 Now the president is embarking on a five-day, five-city journey to India and a five-hour stop in Pakistan at a time when tensions on the subcontinent are high. A confrontation between the two countries over Kashmir, where their fighters clash on 15,000-foot mountain tops, is seen as the most likely dispute on earth to spark a nuclear clash. In fact, the president hopes that with this trip he can somehow defuse the situation in Kashmir. But he and his aides are pessimistic about the chances for actual progress.
Mr. Clinton will also become the first American president to visit Bangladesh, where he plans to make a day trip. Bangladesh, a democratic Muslim country, is striving to emerge from deep poverty.
It may be an overwhelming task for Mr. Clinton to balance his desire to support the India of trade and technology with his hope of calming the treacherous rivalry between India and Pakistan, both nuclear powers. Complicating the situation considerably is the military government that came to power in Pakistan last October. Mr. Clinton is eager not to endorse that government's hold on power, but he does want to talk with it.
Mr. Clinton is making India the 62d foreign country he has visited, a position down the list that some Indians have noted unhappily, and he arrives almost as a lame-duck president, with little opportunity to capitalize afterward on diplomatic gains.
Overall, some of his aides, as well as experts on the subcontinent, fear that the original intention of displaying India as the economic and strategic power of the region will be undermined by the increasingly strong-willed attitudes of the Indian government toward nuclear weapons, Pakistan and Kashmir.
Mr. Clinton will face an Indian government whose nuclear doctrine calls for the development of a "large strategic Indian capability sometime in the future," said Stephen Cohen of the Brookings Institution, who was one of a group of experts on South Asia who met with the president at the White House on Thursday evening to help him prepare for the trip.
Mr. Cohen added that there were prominent voices in New Delhi calling for further tests because India did not produce a thermonuclear explosion in May 1998. The government of Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee was prepared, he said, to pay the price of Washington's sanctions in order to keep its nuclear arsenal.
After India's nuclear tests, which were followed by tests by Pakistan, the administration initiated a round of talks aimed at persuading India to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty. Led by Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott, the talks extended to 12 rounds with the Indian foreign minister, Jaswant Singh, but, so far, to no avail.
In a speech previewing Mr. Clinton's trip, Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright cautioned that the lack of progress at a time when Russia and the United States were moving toward deeper cuts in their arsenals was a major stumbling block to a fuller relationship with Washington.
"We must accept that significant progress in this area is necessary, before India and the United States can realize fully the vast potential of our relationship," Dr. Albright told the Asia Society here on Tuesday. "We have not yet found a way to create sufficient common ground on these issues."
At a discussion at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace this week, Gary Samore, a member of the National Security Council staff who specializes in nonproliferation, said that in his 15 years working on India and Pakistan, "I don't think the situation has ever looked any worse."
The prospects were bleak, Mr. Samore said, because neither India nor Pakistan really understood the instability provoked by strategic threat of their nuclear weapons and "to make matters worse, both sides are spoiling for a fight" in Kashmir. Another conflict over the territory -- Pakistan and India have already fought three wars there -- carries the "potential spark for a nuclear confrontation," Mr. Samore said.
When Mr. Clinton met with the group of experts from the region at the White House on Thursday evening, he seemed intensely interested in how he could defuse the situation but also worried about the limited prospects for success, several participants said. The group included two former ambassadors to India, Frank Wisner and Daniel Patrick Moynihan, now the senior Democratic senator from New York.
Aside from overcoming the enormous enmity between the two countries, Mr. Clinton must face the fact that India has insisted that it will not accept mediation.
And although Pakistan has said it will accept mediation, Mr. Clinton's clout in influencing the behavior of the new military leader, Gen. Pervez Musharraf, appears limited, his aides say.
In a briefing on Thursday to reporters who will accompany Mr. Clinton, his national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said: "The president is not going to South Asia to mediate the dispute between them. But he will urge them to exercise restraint and resume dialogue."
One fundamental request that Mr. Clinton is likely to put to General Musharraf is for a halt to the Pakistani incursions over the so-called Line of Control, the cease-fire line in Kashmir that divides the territory. The Indian leadership has said there can be no discussion over Kashmir until the Pakistanis take "concrete steps" to withdraw. Last July, Mr. Clinton successfully persuaded the last civilian leader of Pakistan, Nawaz Sharif, to take such steps. But three months later Mr. Sharif was overthrown by the general. Given this history, administration officials said they were skeptical that General Musharraf would do what Mr. Sharif promised.
Nonetheless, Dr. Albright said in her speech that as a start Pakistan must pledge to make no further incursions into the Indian-held part of Kashmir.
"Nations must not attempt to change borders or zones of occupation through armed force," she said, adding that "tangible steps" should be taken to respect the Line of Control.
