HEADLINE: U.S. ENDING A FEW OF THE SANCTIONS IMPOSED ON IRAN

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 17

 BODY:
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright ended a few of America's economic sanctions against Iran today, and declared a commitment to take extensive steps toward ending two decades of hostility "if Iran indicates a desire and commitment to do so."
Her comments describing a map for normalizing economic ties came in a speech today that Clinton administration officials described as their most explicit overture to the moderates who triumphed in Iran's parliamentary elections last month. 
 Without specifying them, Dr. Albright held out the prospect of ending such sanctions as the bans on American investment in Iran's oil industry and the blocking of large loans to Tehran by the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank.
But she made no mention of a resumption of full diplomatic relations.
In Tehran, the Iranian government issued a muted but moderately positive response.
Dr. Albright also acknowledged -- without apologizing -- a variety of American errors in past dealings with Iran, including Washington's support of the 1953 coup that restored Shah Mohammed Riza Pahlevi to power, and of Iraq during its war with Iran in the 1980's.
Nonetheless, Dr. Albright made clear that forces in Iran that she said support terrorism and try to obtain nuclear weapons technology would have to loosen their hold on the security apparatus before there would be a deeper removal of sanctions.
The sanctions ended today are chiefly symbolic, and aimed at small businesses. The United States will end restrictions on Iranian-made carpets -- a law that was widely flouted anyway -- and reduce prohibitive tariffs on pistachios and caviar. Those areas were chosen, Dr. Albright said, "to show the millions of Iranian craftsmen, farmers and fishermen who work in these industries, and the Iranian people as a whole, that the United States bears them no ill will."
But she acknowledged that it would take more than pistachio diplomacy to remove what President Mohammad Khatami -- whose moderation she praised at some length -- calls the "wall of mistrust."
"To date the political developments in Iran have not caused its military to cease its determined effort to acquire the technology, materials and assistance needed to develop nuclear weapons," she said. Nor have the intelligence services chosen "to get out of the terrorism business," she said.
"Until these policies change," she continued, "fully normal ties between our governments will not be possible and our principal sanctions will remain."
Under American law, for instance, Washington cannot support loans for Iran through the I.M.F. or the World Bank until Iran is removed from the State Department's list of nations that support terrorism.
Dr. Albright's speech received mixed reviews in Congress, just as small overtures toward Cuba and North Korea have in recent months. Senator Connie Mack of Florida, a Republican, called the administration's move "unprincipled" and said "American victims of terrorism deserve justice, not pistachios and caviar."
But Senator Pat Roberts, a Republican who represents the farm state of Kansas, said, "A failed U.S. sanctions policy has forced Iran to purchase a substantial amount of commodities from our competitors." He urged a far greater removal of sanctions.
The State Department took some unusual steps to amplify its message in Iran. It faxed advance copies of Dr. Albright's speech to the pro-reform newspapers that have blossomed in Tehran, to enable them to print the text in their Saturday issues.
The Iranian government was also briefed in advance, and afterward the Foreign Ministry spokesman, Hamid Reza Asefi, said, "We welcome the ability to export Iranian foodstuff and carpets and see it as positive," according to a report from the country's official news agency, IRNA.
Here in Washington, however, Hadi Nejad Hosseinian, Iran's representative to the United Nations, said that while his country would find a way to reciprocate for Dr. Albright's gesture, "these steps, as important as they may be, are insufficient" to bring about official talks between the two nations.
The administration has periodically made modest moves to reach out to moderates in Iran, but President Khatami has been locked in a struggle with conservatives who appear to control the security apparatus, and the gestures have not borne fruit.
Dr. Albright's effort to convey a new openness to Iran, without offering many concrete concessions, came after what senior officials said was a long debate in the State Department and the National Security Council.
"Everyone recognized that there had been a massive change in the internal dynamics in Iran," one official said, "but good as the changes have been internally, they have not affected those with the levers of power on the issues of greatest importance to us -- terrorism and weapons of mass destruction."
Another element of that debate, officials said, centered on how Dr. Albright should word her description of America's troubled encounters with Iran throughout the cold war. She chose, in the end, to acknowledge the facts and hint at American wrongdoing or errors of judgment, but to neither apologize nor explain.
"In 1953 the United States played a significant role in orchestrating the overthrow of Iran's popular prime minister, Mohammad Mossadegh," she told the audience, touching briefly and lightly on what almost everyone in her audience of Iranian-Americans knew as Operation Ajax, the Central Intelligence Agency's first major success in overthrowing a foreign government.
"The Eisenhower administration believed its actions were justified for strategic reasons," she continued. "But the coup was clearly a setback for Iran's political development. And it is easy to see now why many Iranians continue to resent this intervention by America in their internal affairs."
Before the overthrow, the Mossadegh government had acted to legalize the Iranian Communist Party, and had also nationalized the Anglo-Iranian Oil Company.
The decision to go ahead with the coup was made by Allen Dulles, the first head of the postwar C.I.A., and his brother, John Foster Dulles, the secretary of state at the time. And it was executed chiefly by Kermit Roosevelt, a grandson of Theodore Roosevelt.
While today's reference to those events fell far short of an apology, it appears to be the closest to one any senior American official has publicly offered.
Dr. Albright also briefly acknowledged that the shah, installed after the coup, "brutally repressed political dissent." And she added, with a reference to the president of Iraq, that "aspects of U.S. policy toward Iraq during its conflict with Iran appear now to have been regrettably shortsighted, especially in light of our subsequent experiences with Saddam Hussein."
Among those in the audience today was Robert C. McFarlane, the national security adviser under President Reagan, who made a secret trip to Iran in 1986 bearing a key-shaped cake and a Bible in a failed effort to get Iran to use its influence to win the release of hostages held in Lebanon by Iranian-backed Shiites.
"It's better late than never," Mr. McFarlane said of today's initiative. "This is not an administration known for risk-taking." He said he assumed that Iran must have made "some private assurances" to the United States about cutting off support for terrorist groups.
Among the issues left deliberately vague in the speech was how to handle financial disputes between the countries that date back to the taking of American hostages in Tehran in 1979. At the time, Iranian assets in the United States were frozen.
Since then, a tribunal set up at The Hague has resolved a number of disputes. But others remain, including for instance, the issue of reimbursing Iran for American military equipment that was never delivered, and the disposition of diplomatic properties in the United States. Iran puts the value of what it terms "frozen assets" -- the United States does not use that phrase -- at upwards of $10 billion, while Washington says the figure is in the hundreds of millions of dollars.
Resolving those disputes would have far less economic impact on Iran than a lifting of the sanctions on oil and development aid.
Washington's Caspian Sea oil policy has been directed at preventing any pipeline from traveling through Iranian territory.
The prohibition on American investment and technology in Iran's oil industry has meant European countries have a competitive edge.

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
Sticking It to the Taxpayer

BYLINE: By MURRAY CHASS; Murray Chass reports on sports for The New York Times.

 BODY:
THIS is the golden age of new stadiums and arenas. They are sprouting all over the country. Public money pays for most of them. Team owners stand in line, hat in hand, waiting for their turn, their rightful dole.
Taxpayers are growing increasingly disenchanted with this public subsidization for the benefit of private businessmen. In New Jersey, one owner wanted to buck the trend. He wanted to build an arena completely with private funds. 
 But he needed non-economic cooperation from the governor of the state, and she rejected the idea. So instead of erecting his arena in Hoboken, across the Hudson River from New York, John McMullen is selling the Devils, his National Hockey League franchise. A entity affiliated with the YankeesNets, Puck Holdings, will pay Mr. McMullen about $175 million, but never had a man been so reluctant to accept twice as much as his team should go for.
"I'm sick about it," Mr. McMullen said recently.
In partnership with Cablevision of New York, Charles Dolan's sports and cable conglomerate, Mr. McMullen was going to build the arena as the centerpiece of a sports, dining and entertainment project that one Hoboken official said would complement the expansion the city is doing on its waterfront. The arena would have been constructed over the train shed at the Hoboken railroad terminal, just as Madison Square Garden was erected over Penn Station in Manhattan.
But the project required the state to grant air rights over the shed, and Governor Whitman has refused Mr. McMullen's request.
"Before the last election," Mr. McMullen said in a recent interview, "the governor said she'd let me go to Hoboken."
But the proposal became embroiled with the Nets' desire to build an arena in Newark, and Governor Whitman opted to support that project.
"If an arena can have two teams play in it, and the Hoboken arena as proposed by John McMullen could have two teams playing in it, we'd do everything we can to grant those air rights," said Pete McDonough the governor's spokesman. "But first off he has to bring us a plan that shows here's where two teams are going to play."
Mr. McMullen counters that since he and Cablevision would have built the arena privately, the need for two teams was not a concern. Two teams might be needed for an arena like the one the Devils and the Nets play in now at the Meadowlands in East Rutherford, but not for the Hoboken arena. According to Mr. McMullen, James Dolan of Cablevision has said it could fill the Hoboken arena for more than 200 nights a year.
"They have excess programming for the Garden and Radio City," Mr. McMullen said.
Mr. McDonough disputed Mr. McMullen's position that the arena would have cost the state nothing. He quoted Rick Mroz, the governor's counsel, as saying the project would require roadway funds totaling from $200 million to $300 million in state and federal money. But Mr. McMullen and Robert Drasheff, director of Hoboken's waterfront development, disputed that claim.
They say that Mr. Mroz is referring to the Bergen Arches, an abandoned railroad right of way that would be converted into a highway running from the Jersey City traffic circle to the area in Jersey City known as Newport City. Three years ago, at Mr. McMullen's urging, senators and representatives from New Jersey got $105 million for the right of way included in the federal transportation bill.
"I knew about Bergen Arches because I drove to New York every day," Mr. McMullen said. "The main purpose of the arches is to separate local traffic from New York traffic headed for the Holland Tunnel. I did it as a civic gesture. Would the arena benefit? Slightly. But we wouldn't need it. I've told them I don't need the Bergen Arches, don't charge me with it, but they keep bringing it up."
Those opposed to the arena also raised concerns about parking in an already congested area, but Mr. McMullen and Mr. Drasheff said that a shipping slip on the waterfront could be filled in and, according to Mr. Drasheff, accomodate 20,000 cars.
In his initial plans, Mr. McMullen proposed that the state pay for the $30 million platform on which the arena would be built. "But when they raised so much objection to it," he said, "I said we'd pay for it."
Mr. McMullen sent Governor Whitman a three-page proposal last September in which he said he was not seeking any state investment in the arena. He included a letter from the Chase Bank saying it was prepared to finance the arena for Mr. McMullen and Cablevision.
Still, Mr. McDonough contends that history shows that the only arenas that work financially are ones that have two teams. Mr. McMullen and Mr. Drasheff counter that the state is too narrowly focusing on the arena and missing the larger picture.
"Hoboken has slowly converted itself into a residential town," Mr. Drasheff said, "so our only industry now is dining and entertainment. We see the arena as the next logical step in that dining and entertainment service business. It brings in a lot of jobs, and it brings in the prestige of a world-class team, a first-class operation and it takes an abandoned space that's been neglected for 40 to 50 years and finally turns it into a profit-making venture for individuals, the state and the city."

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
THE GATES OF THE ALAMO, by Stephen Harrigan. (Knopf, $25.) A comprehensive historical novel that uses its space to tell the story from both the Mexican and Texan sides through a rotating cast of mainly fictional characters.
 
IN AMERICA, by Susan Sontag. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $26.) A daring novel in which, off and on, narrator merges with author and history with imagination in the career of a grand 19th-century Polish actress who knocks 'em dead in California.
 
LEARNING HUMAN: Selected Poems, by Les Murray. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $27.) A cosmopolitan temperament sharpens nativisms and traditional forms in the expansive, energetic work of the closest thing Australia can offer just now to a truly national poet.
 
M: The Man Who Became Caravaggio, by Peter Robb. (John Macrae/Holt, $30.) A biography of the great painter and troublemaker who came to Rome in 1592 and disappeared 18 years later, leaving behind his works and a lot of rumors.
 
MOTH SMOKE, by Mohsin Hamid. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $23.) The rich live at the expense of the poor in the Pakistan of this first novel, whose hero mocks the vulgarity and decadence of the top crust while desperately yearning to join it.
 
THE NATURE OF ECONOMIES, by Jane Jacobs. (Modern Library, $21.95.) The canonized social critic of "The Death and Life of Great American Cities" (1961) contends that economies mimic natural systems in the way they grow, and need to be ecologically approached to be understood.
 
TWO MOONS, by Thomas Mallon. (Pantheon, $24.) A novel that takes on nothing smaller than the vastness of the universe and the wish to be immortal, in the sensitive and somewhat doomed persons of a pair of 19th-century lovers who work for the United States Naval Observatory.
 
ULYSSES S. GRANT: Triumph Over Adversity, 1822-1865, by Brooks D. Simpson. (Houghton Mifflin, $35.) Simpson explores, in this first of two projected volumes, a man dogged by failure, depression and self-doubt until, with the coming of war, he became a national hero and savior.
 
A WALK TOWARD OREGON: A Memoir, by Alvin M. Josephy Jr. (Knopf, $27.50.) Recollections at 84 by a reformist liberal of the optimistic Franklin D. Roosevelt-New Deal stripe who has been a writer, soldier, politician, conservationist and civil servant; he may be best remembered for his advocacy of American Indian causes.
 
WEIRD LIKE US: My Bohemian America, by Ann Powers. (Simon & Schuster, $23.) A music critic for The Times ventures on an elegantly argued piece of social reportage that salvages the mundane, rarely examined details of slacker life and does not hesitate to call it bohemia.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 4; Column 1; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 2059 words

HEADLINE: Somebody's Hero

BYLINE: By Bill Keller; Bill Keller, managing editor of The Times, was based in the paper's Moscow bureau from 1986 to 1991 as a correspondent and then as bureau chief.

 BODY:

YELTSIN
 A Revolutionary Life.
 By Leon Aron.
 Illustrated. 934 pp. New York:
 St. Martin's Press. $35. 
 Has any major figure of our time been so variously caricatured as Boris Yeltsin? In Russia he has been, depending on the moment and the author, a populist spoiler, a hero of democracy, a drunken clown, a traitor to the motherland, a nationalist thug, the slayer of Communism, a stooge of corrupt oligarchs.
Outside Russia, the conventional wisdom has tended to be unfriendly. When Yeltsin emerged in the mid-1980's as the Communist Party boss of Moscow, a rambunctious, crowd-pleasing reformer, Western officials viewed him as an uninvited guest at the Gorbachev honeymoon. "What a flake!" Secretary of State James A. Baker III was said to have remarked after meeting Yeltsin. "He sure makes Gorbachev look good by comparison." To scholars on the left, he was an irksome distraction from the attempt to humanize socialism; to scholars on the right, his origins as a Communist functionary in the hinterlands made him deeply suspect -- a typical provincial apparatchik," was the dismissive judgment of Dmitri K. Simes. He enjoyed a rush of adulation after his iconic photo op in 1991, defying a hard-line putsch from the top of a tank, and he won an infusion of loans with his attempts to create capitalism by decree. But over the past half decade, the Yeltsin persona degenerated steadily. He was the frustrated, fickle and ineffectual prisoner of his own cockeyed democracy, the butcher of Chechnya and finally a walking corpse. When he suddenly resigned at the turn of the new century, after eight and a half years as Russia's first popularly elected president, the send-offs were, at their most generous, equivocal.
In his ambitious and perfectly timed new biography, "Yeltsin: A Revolutionary Life," Leon Aron sets out to reclaim Yeltsin from the cartoonists and establish his importance as the instrument of a profound transformation of Russia. It is a complex and nuanced political portrait, not adoring but unabashedly admiring.
Aron, who emigrated from Russia as a young man in 1973 and now resides at the American Enterprise Institute, cannot always contain his disdain for those who have underrated Yeltsin's performance. These include not only Yeltsin's reactionary adversaries in Russia -- here portrayed in all their vileness -- but the condescending intelligentsia in Russia and abroad, the Western governments infatuated with Gorbachev and a segment of the Western press. Aron's book is therefore likely to provoke some defensiveness from the sort of people who are normally invited to review books about Russia.
One can only hope any fireworks will draw readers to see for themselves, because the book is a godsend. Such a fine, full-blooded political portrait of Yeltsin would, by itself, be important -- for even in the best eyewitness surveys of the Soviet unraveling, Yeltsin is an unfinished character. But the more exciting distinction of Aron's book is the context. He understands in his bones the weird operational milieu of Soviet Communism. He understands how it got that way, how it functioned during the few decades when it functioned, how and why it failed and how on its deathbed it produced such anomalous Communists as Mikhail Gorbachev and Boris Yeltsin. He understands that the end of the Soviet empire was not primarily the work of a romantic popular uprising (although, unlike some scholars, he gives the Russian public its due), nor was it especially a triumph of cold-war containment; it was the result of the inevitable collapse of an exhausted economy propped up by a cynical ideology. Aron understands all this well enough to make it coherent and accessible. Consequently, this book is not just a welcome resurrection of Boris Yeltsin, it is also a superb account of the end of the Soviet experiment.
Aron begins with Yeltsin's political germination 1,000 miles east of Moscow in Sverdlovsk (now Yekaterinburg). Yeltsin, a combative farm boy who studied construction engineering and worked his way up the ladder as the region's development chief, perfected his driven, ardently populist political style long before his name reached Moscow. Out of school, offered the usual postgraduate assignment as a construction foreman, he insisted on first spending a year as a bricklayer, concrete maker, truck driver, carpenter, joiner, glass cutter, plasterer, house painter and crane operator, often pulling two shifts a day. In Sverdlovsk -- and later in Moscow, where he rode the subways and popped up incognito in the shops -- Yeltsin's insistence on seeing for himself schooled his eye for the failings of the system and bought him enormous street credibility.
He was a gifted showman. When he was a construction boss, his favorite stunt was to gather a huge team and throw up a complete five-story apartment building in five days. Such feats of razzle-dazzle won him a measure of official license, which he spent on more meaningful reforms. A favorite, which foreshadowed Gorbachev by years, was an attack on the stifling egalitarian work ethic, using entrepreneurial brigades that were rewarded for performance, not for just showing up. He became adept at initiating experiments that played to the current Moscow fashion, and then pushing them to the brink of heresy.
Adept as he was at the inside game, Yeltsin was the first political figure of national stature to really grasp the politics of public performance. Aron uses the French term bain de foule, bathing in the crowd, to describe Yeltsin's passion for full-immersion town meetings. These open-ended and often shockingly candid evenings of political cabaret added to the Yeltsin legend and forged his connection with an adoring public. By the last years of Leonid Brezhnev, Yeltsin was regaling audiences with megadoses of inconvenient truth -- even, in the cold-war year of 1981, admiring the United States for the tonic of "capitalist competition." Some "typical provincial apparatchik."
In these early chapters, Aron draws heavily from Yeltsin's enjoyable but self-mythologizing autobiography. He has tested Yeltsin's own hindsight at key points by interviewing Yeltsin's contemporaries and scouring local archives, but at times the portrait feels a little rosy.
Yeltsin's reputation reached Gorbachev, who summoned him to Moscow in 1985 as that city's party boss. For the next seven years the political pas de deux of these men became the defining choreography of Russia. At first, Yeltsin's flamboyant testing of the limits made Gorbachev look comparatively safe to the anxious old guard. Yeltsin excoriated the pampered elites (including spoiled intellectuals, who never forgave him). He lashed out at the hard-liners in Gorbachev's Politburo. Gorbachev chided him, then humiliated and demoted him, but never silenced him. Yeltsin was a useful foil.
But as glasnost evolved into fierce iconoclasm, as liberalism fed the hunger for real liberation, as failed economic tinkering led to calls for free markets, Yeltsin was always a long jump ahead. Soon he was denouncing the Communist Party itself, advocating genuinely free elections and private property. Having been down in the engine room while Gorbachev was aloft at the helm, Yeltsin was far quicker to recognize that half measures were failing. Then Gorbachev became his foil.
The book dawdles sometimes in recounting Yeltsin's evolution. Like most biographies these days, this one feels at least 100 pages longer than it needs to be, and at times, although his narrative skill is formidable, Aron seems to be recounting the machinations of plenums and elections and congresses in real time. So skim a few chapters.
Perhaps the most interesting thing about Yeltsin has always been his remarkable agility, his capacity to absorb new information, rub it against his assumptions and change. Unlike Gorbachev, who never really outgrew his faith in benign Leninism, Yeltsin was a lifelong work in progress, much like Russia itself. One of the most engaging chapters accompanies Yeltsin on his 1989 trip to America. You may remember this visit for the cold shoulder presented by the ever-equivocating Bush White House, or for the widely published gossip (methodically debunked by Aron) of Yeltsin drinking sprees. But for Yeltsin, whose ravenous curiosity led him to interview everyone he met and see everything he could see, the trip seems to have been the kind of genuine epiphany other Soviet visitors, including Gorbachev, were incapable of experiencing. The prosperity, the rule of law, the freedom and efficiency he witnessed in America catalyzed his notions about the fraud of Communism.
America confirmed for Yeltsin what he was lurching toward. Getting there, however, proved a crushingly difficult undertaking. The relentless opposition of the tenacious Communists and their neofascist outriders, the squabbling among reformists and Yeltsin's own strategic blunders turned the economic transformation of Russia into a slog and demoralized his miserable public. As the enemies he could see and outwit gave way to dangers "less amenable to a frontal political assault: inflation, depression, poverty, cynicism," Aron writes, Yeltsin succumbed to drink, depression and insomnia. He would rouse himself for one last electoral victory in the summer of 1996, and then devote his waning years to concocting a successor regime he hoped could keep the Communist revanchists at bay. The book went to press before Yeltsin surrendered his office to his prime minister, Vladimir Putin, an enigmatic former KGB agent who, for better or worse, represents Yeltsin's last great gamble.
A biographer who regards Yeltsin as a friend of democracy must contend with the man's authoritarian side. Yeltsin's 1993 battle with an openly seditious Russian legislature, which ended with army tanks bombarding the Parliament building, is rather easily defended. Unpretty as that episode may have been, when the story is fully told there is little question that had the leaders of the parliamentary insurrection and their armed paramilitary prevailed, Russia today would resemble the miserable police state of neighboring Belarus.
A more egregious case was Yeltsin's acquiescence in the catastrophic war against the breakaway province of Chechnya. The second round of that war continues today under Yeltsin's anointed successor. Aron makes no apology for the stupidity and cruelty with which that assault was carried out, although he points out that Yeltsin's resolve to protect the integrity of his country was itself well within the bounds of international law. The unpopular war, Aron says, ended the Russian people's romance with Yeltsin; only by negotiating a hasty withdrawal did he narrowly avert an electoral defeat. Thereafter "Yeltsin looked more and more like a black hole: a giant star exerting enormous gravitational pull on everything around it, but coming to the end of its life, depleted of fuel and incapable of projecting light."
At the same time, Aron argues, Yeltsin passed up at least two opportunities -- in 1991 and in 1993 -- to assume dictatorial powers by popular acclamation. Unlike Gorbachev, Yeltsin turned again and again to the public for his mandates. And he did not merely stockpile political capital; he spent it on noble intentions, the jump-starting of a capitalist economy, and it is only partly his fault that he was not more successful. "A revolution that fails to live up to the fullness of its promise," Aron writes, "is not a revolution that has not happened."
Thanks in large part to Yeltsin, we have a Russia freer, less belligerent, more accommodating of its citizens and its neighbors. A huge if corrupted transfer of wealth into private hands "broke the back of the Russian patrimonial state" and allowed the beginnings of a middle class. We have a Russia in which power derives from the consent of the governed.
Aron concludes that if -- a critical if -- Russia remains on this course, Yeltsin's ultimate place in history will be analogous to that of two other "authoritarian democrats" who broke laws and spilled blood in the course of saving their nations: Abraham Lincoln and Charles de Gaulle. On the strength of this book, that provisional judgment holds up much better than the dismissive stereotypes that went before it.

HEADLINE: True West

BYLINE: By Lauren F. Winner; Lauren F. Winner is the author, with Randall Balmer, of a forthcoming book on contemporary American Protestantism.

 BODY:

Something
 in the Soil
 Legacies and Reckonings
 in the New West.
 By Patricia Nelson Limerick.
 384 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $27.95. 
 Usually, folks outside of the ivory tower don't pay very much attention to academic infighting. But starting in the late 1980's, media outlets not known for their interest in scholarship scrambled to gather copy about the New Western History and its head honchos: Patricia Nelson Limerick, Richard White, William Cronon and Donald Worster.
Limerick's 1987 "Legacy of Conquest" is one of the movement's manifestoes. Breaking with Frederick Jackson Turner's frontier thesis, which had dominated the study of the American West since the 1890's, she portrayed the West not as empty land waiting to be civilized and Christianized by strapping, independent pioneers, but as a region dependent on federal dollars, where Bostonians and New Yorkers clashed with American Indians and Asian immigrants, unchecked business development devastated the environment and boom-and-bust cycles of mining and oil drilling shook up the economy. Hence the brouhaha. As a columnist in The Arizona Republic put it in 1989: "Why can't the revisionists simply leave our myths alone? Westerners -- and most other Americans, for that matter -- are content with our storied past, even if it tends to fib a bit."
In "Something in the Soil," a collection of speeches and previously published essays, Limerick continues to erode the fibs, describing the ecological consequences of the Gold Rush; investigating the 1872-73 Modoc War; knocking John Sutter, the "Father of California," off his pedestal; and doing her best to turn Juan Bautista de Anza, a little-known colonial governor of New Mexico, into a "household name."
Throughout, Limerick demonstrates her trademark concern for the real world. Green-friendly readers will appreciate "Mission to the Environmentalists" and its argument that history can help environmentalists, a fractious and fissiparous bunch, understand themselves, one another and their differences of opinion and behavior. If Limerick's insistent reminders that she has made it as a public intellectual grow tiresome, her point is well taken: a history lesson won't solve all of the West's problems, but contemporary Westerners would do well to draw "perspective . . . from the longer haul of time."
What distinguishes Limerick from other prominent Western historians is her inimitable prose. Limerick boldly breaks all the rules of academic writing. She writes about her own childhood, right down to the church she attended; she tells jokes; she uses game-show expressions in titles ("Will the Real Californian Please Stand Up?"); and she treats readers to irreverent paragraphs like:
"With a little rewriting -+essentially, changing 'Give me your tired, your poor,' to 'Give me your tired, your tasteless, your rich' -- Miss Lazarus's words could appear on the letterhead of any number of Colorado home builder and land development companies. Heaven knows, the shore of California is 'teeming'; and 'tempest-tossed' could be easily changed, with an economy of syllables, to 'earthquake-tossed.' 'Wretched refuse,' of course, has never been the most flattering of characterizations, but it does give Californians some advance warning of the opinion in which they are held by quite a number of Coloradans."
But the last three chapters -- A How-To Guide for the Academic Going Public," "Dancing With Professors: The Trouble With Academic Prose" and "Limerick's Rules of Verbal Etiquette" -+resemble a stylebook. She urges readers to avoid the passive voice, to write in complete sentences and to make sure every paragraph has a topic sentence. Reading Limerick's writing on the West is far more satisfying than reading Limerick's writing on writing. Treasure "Something in the Soil" but don't throw out your copy of "Fowler's Modern English Usage."

HEADLINE: Genetic Codes

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his review of Matt Ridley's "Genome" (Feb. 27), Lee M. Silver, embracing an assertion of the author's, writes that "eugenics laws were examples not of unrestrained science but of unrestrained government." But science of the eugenic era does not merit any such blanket absolution. Eugenic measures were the product of a collaboration between governments and scientists. In the United States, for example, passage of eugenic sterilization laws was promoted by various biologists who proclaimed that the "racial" stock of the country was degenerating as a result of excessive reproduction by the lower classes, including immigrants from eastern and southern Europe. Many states declined to pass sterilization laws despite the biologists, because of objections from religious groups and civil libertarians. 
 Silver invokes government responsibility for the enactment of eugenic cruelties in the past in service of warning against governmental interference with reproductive freedom now and in the future. People should have the right to "use the messages in their own DNA as they see fit," he writes. Of course they should, and without governmental coercion. But consumers don't necessarily possess completely neutral, unbiased knowledge about those messages. Their notions of what they can do with their DNA -- or have done to it, as in the case of Jesse Gelsinger, the 18-year-old who died last September in a gene therapy experiment at the University of Pennsylvania -- are colored by delineations of risks, costs and benefits that are supplied by, among others, biomedical scientists, many of them with professional or economic interests in the matter. The contemporary state of gene therapy should suffice to spotlight the need for effective government regulation over interventions in the human genome. Consumer protection is no less warranted in human genetic manipulation than it is in the introduction of new therapeutic drugs.
 
Daniel J. Kevles
Pasadena, Calif. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: PRACTICAL TRAVELER;
Oil Prices Rise, Air Fares Follow

BYLINE: By BETSY WADE 

 BODY:
THE price of oil is affecting travel everywhere. Surcharges of $20 on a round trip are being added to most airline tickets. Airport shuttle prices are inching up. And although a spokesman for Greyhound Lines says increases in the cost of driving improve the company's business, Greyhound has also added a fuel surcharge. Officials in the hotel industry, noting the possibility that higher prices will bring a downturn in travel, say there could be an impact there, too: inexpensive motels might lower prices.
The increases are unpredictable. Supershuttle, an airport van service in many major cities, has added a charge of 50 cents to its trip prices. But Gray Line, which serves airports in New York, has not, although Lee Gelber, a spokesman, said that the fare for the day trip to the Woodbury Common mall had increased by $1. On Feb. 2, Olympia Bus Service raised its fare from the Port Authority Bus Terminal in midtown Manhattan to Newark Airport from $10 to $11, but created a round-trip fare of $20. A spokeswoman called it a fuel surcharge, but acknowledged that it was unlikely to be withdrawn. This supports the notion that a surcharge is simply an increase that will stay even if oil prices drop. 
 Air passengers are feeling the biggest impact right now. Last week brought turmoil in fares provoked by fuel costs, but even before that, the major lines followed Continental's lead in adding $10 to each one-way fare. But because Southwest Airlines has not -- although it has increased fares slightly -- some other airlines are not adding the surcharge in areas where they compete with Southwest or other discount lines. For example, United's service in California does not have surcharges.
 
Airlines' Policies Vary
My encounter with the fuel surcharge uncovered what appears to be the most eccentric pattern in its application. I went to a Continental ticket counter last month to exchange two senior coupons for a round-trip ticket to San Antonio in April. For those unfamiliar with senior coupons, all the lines sell them to people over 62 for roughly competitive prices; each coupon is good for a one-way flight in the 48 states. My coupons cost $579 for four, and I was expecting to use two -- or about $289 worth -- for my San Antonio trip.
The agent said there would be a $20 surcharge, bringing my fare to $309 for a schedule that required a connection on the way home. This was irritating. I made another choice, a ticket for $355, figuring I would use the coupons when they represented a greater saving.
Not all airlines impose the extra charge on the coupons, I discovered when I examined the major lines' fuel-surcharge policies.
Continental put its $10-each-way surcharge into all domestic markets on Feb. 1. As I found, it adds the charge to senior coupons when they are turned into tickets.
Both American Airlines and Trans World Airlines are adding the surcharge to all their domestic tickets regardless of the competition, they say. Both put the charge into effect Feb. 1; neither adds a surcharge to senior coupons. If the tickets were bought before the increase took effect, it is not added later.
Jim Brown, a T.W.A. spokesman, said that when the line had a fare sale for four days in mid-February, there was no fuel charge on those tickets. There might be such sales again, he said. But when asked if the surcharge was ever going to go away, he said "no comment," as did every other airline spokesperson.
American, T.W.A. and all the others add the fuel charge if the passenger changes an itinerary on a ticket purchased before the surcharge went into effect. This is on top of the regular fee for changing a ticket. The airlines contend that it becomes, in effect, a new ticket.
Northwest Airlines imposes the charge in most markets, according to Dennis Mollura, a spokesman. "In competitive markets," he said, "we do what the competition is doing." Senior coupons are not surcharged.
United Airlines, according to Joseph P. Hopkins, a spokesman, matches Continental and Southwest where it competes with them. Senior coupons are not surcharged.
US Airways levies the surcharge in most domestic markets, but not on the Boston-New York-Washington shuttle. US Airways adds the charge to tickets bought with senior coupons.
Delta also adds the surcharge to most domestic tickets, except where it competes with low-price airlines, according to John Kennedy, a spokesman. The Boston-New York-Washington shuttle is exempted, as are senior coupons.
Southwest Airlines disdains a fuel surcharge; Ed Stewart, a spokesman, said, "A fare increase is a fare increase." On Jan. 25, Southwest increased its ticket prices $2 for a trip of up to 600 miles; $3 for 600 to 900 miles, and $4 for more than 900 miles. The increases are doubled for a round trip.
 
Agents' Complaint
Both the American Society of Travel Agents and an organization called the United States Travel Agent Registry, a group formed in 1995 that says it has 780 member agencies, sent complaints in January and February to the Department of Transportation saying that the airlines' computer fare displays did not show the fuel surcharges, or other added fees, on the first screen. Sam Podberesky, in the department's regulatory division, combined the two complaints, and the department has asked several airlines to respond.
The complaints can be read on the Web at dms.dot.gov. When the "search" box appears, enter the last four digits of the docket identifier: OST-200-6821.
 
Higher Bus Fares
Meanwhile, on the ground, Greyhound increased fares 1.5 percent in late January. "Part is fuel, part is a general price increase," said George Gravley, a spokesman. "We have a lot of trouble raising prices," he said. "But we pick up passengers because of the cost of driving."
Gale C. Ellsworth, president of Trailways, said that its 54 franchised operators were responding individually. "Some are calling it a surcharge," Ms. Ellsworth said, "some are calling it an increase." Peter Pan, in New England, has added 50 cents for any one-way trip, and Adirondack Trailways in New York went up 5 percent across the board.
Gasoline prices for cars have taken a huge swing, from an average of 96 cents a gallon for self-service regular unleaded in February 1999 to $1.37 last month, according to AAA figures. Jerry Cheske, a AAA spokesman, said prices would probably continue to rise. But, he said, the response has been different from 1990, when gas prices rose and in August "tourism almost fell through the floor."
"We don't see the kind of outrage we saw then," he said. The economy is better and people are driving vehicles that use a lot more gas, he said.
If people who drive on their vacations hold back this summer, according to Warren J. Marr, director of hospitality and leisure consultants at PricewaterhouseCoopers, it will affect prices at less expensive hotels but not luxury places. "People who have to do business will still do it," Mr. Marr said, "but there may be more aggressive pricing at the lower-priced hotels by summer."

SECTION: Section 6; Page 17; Column 2; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 984 words

HEADLINE: The Way We Live Now: 3-19-00;
Marriage A la Market

BYLINE: By Jack Hitt; Jack Hitt is a contributing writer for the magazine. His most recent article was about teenage filmmakers.

 BODY:
California voters recently passed Proposition 22, which says that only marriages between men and women are officially recognized, and yet the state legislature already extends some benefits to domestic partnerships. In December, the Vermont Supreme Court ruled pretty much the same thing: gay couples cannot be deprived of the legal benefits enjoyed by married heterosexuals. In both cases, the usual brigade of talking heads bobbed across my television screen screaming that these cases constituted an assault on marriage.
I'll say. This is what marriage has come to? A bunch of pension rollover deferments, tax loopholes and health-care portability abatements? Now, I'm a straight first-time husband with two legitimate kids, and according to America's family-values czar, the thrice-married Representative Bob Barr of Georgia, my love-laced nest is the source of all that is good and true in this world (where are my royalties?) and is now under siege. I happen to think Barr is right. But it's not gay folks I'm worried about; it's Adam Smith. Increasingly, marriage is being recast as just another budget item in everyone's personal finance portfolio. 
 The House just passed a bill reducing the "marriage tax penalty." Prenuptial agreements were once optional instruments for multimillionaires; now legal Web sites instruct us that "every couple should and must have a prenuptial agreement or marriage contract."
In our pop culture, the wife or husband as economic object is now a routine Hollywood plot device. Ever since "Indecent Proposal," that consumerist reworking of the fabled droit du seigneur, and all the way up to the recent "The Bachelor" (Chris O'Donnell must marry somebody by a certain date or lose the big inheritance), the message is clear: next to money, romance is second-rate bunk. Must I mention Rick Rockwell and "Who Wants to Marry a Multimillionaire?" At one point the show's proposed host was none other than Marla Maples.
Increasingly, marriage is being converted into a neo-feudal property arrangement for the Nasdaq gentry. Even dating these days is understood as little more than the discovery period before the big merger. WB's new dating show, "Change of Heart," arranges for a boy or girl who is going out with someone to date someone else and then come on the show to discuss the two before deciding between them. You may recognize this process. It's called comparison shopping.
What is happening to marriage is the culmination of the market's radical reshaping of the culture at large. The invisible hand is tearing away the ideals that once held together most of our institutions. Hospitals used to operate under some unwritten notion of altruism. Now patients are "health care consumers" told to shop among various doctors or "gatekeepers" whose new duties include monitoring the flow of gross costs.
Schools are also undergoing a similar metaphorical shift with a customer-clerk relationship replacing the old student-teacher one. The Dewey principle of public education for all? Let 'em eat vouchers. Even churches have hired market consultants, and now the surging congregations out West gather in huge warehouse temples selling spirituality the way Home Depot moves precut lumber. It makes sense that love would go the same way -- just another failed ideology, like communism, collapsing in the path of the market's indiscriminate force to lay bare the economic decision at the core.
According to the academics, this is where marriage began. Feudal dads chose their children's spouses to upwardly mobilize themselves. Romantic passion is said to be a cultural construction that dates from the 12th-century poetic tradition of courtly love and developed into a new ideal of romance in the court of Eleanor of Aquitaine. Then, the story goes, the growing humanism of the Renaissance and the Industrial Age emancipated men and women to become wild romantic honeys -- like Scott and Zelda Fitzgerald or Nick and Nora Charles.
I've never bought this stuff. Maybe that's how it developed for some Burgundian merchant class. But I spent four college years with my face in a Lewis & Short dictionary translating Latin. Horace's Pyrrha, Catullus's Lesbia. Trust me, romantic love predated the French.
But the public institution of marriage, declared sacred and presided over by the clergy, did not. Despite what Bob Barr may think, marriage was largely a private vow made between two people without witnesses. (For Christianity's first 1,000 years, marriage was even a suspect state, arguably a mockery of God's love and doctrinally inferior to celibacy.) Protestant agitation made marriage into an official public occasion, with licenses, clergy and witnesses. The Catholic Church didn't catch up until the Council of Trent in 1563. The British Parliament did not make marriage a state-sanctioned event until 1753. America's common-law marital tradition is not some hick version of free love but, in fact, the remnant of the oldest form of marriage, the romantic vow.
Have you ever fallen in love? And run around cooing to all your friends like a moon-drunk calf? That fine little moment, I'm willing to bet, has always been at the beginning of most marriages. Recasting the institution as some kind of tax-loophole, Defense of Marriage Act, comparison-shopping, bridal-auction bargain deal is the real threat -- not homosexuals in love. But I don't want you to think I don't set limits. I have kids; I am a father; I draw the line. Precisely because Bob Barr and I agree that love-in-marriage is the bedrock of Western civilization, I would never permit Marla Maples or Rick Rockwell in my house -- or any of their kind, whether it be prenuptially arranged dot-com tycoons or old-school climbers who shed one legal spouse after another, like Pamela Churchill Harriman or, come to think of it, Bob Barr. I've got to think of my children.

HEADLINE: Which One's Audrey, and Why It Matters;
Copying Copies: The Sad Slide From Stardom To Celebrity

BYLINE: By JEFF MACGREGOR; Jeff MacGregor worked in the television industry for 20 years, as writer, producer and network correspondent.

 BODY:
IN those ancient days long before the earth had cooled, when the mighty pterodactyl still ruled the darkling skies, I took my first job in television news. This was 1975, the early Polyester Period of the Cenozoic Era, and the only thing wider than the bright horizon on which I projected my youthful ambitions was the tie I wore to work. It was an age of great social and technological upheaval: American women abandoned the spiritual impoverishment of the home for the spiritual impoverishment of the workplace, and, in response, men began using hair dryers and wearing platform saddle shoes. Microwave ovens delivered bad popcorn in only half the time. Back in Minnesota, we recorded and reported these events with all due dispatch and the appropriate gravity.
That year, technology also brought the widespread use of videotape to television news gathering. Film was laborious and expensive, so we welcomed the convenience and speed of videotape. We were warned by factory representatives, however, of a serious concern with the new medium. "Generational deterioration," they would solemnly intone, speaking directly into the tabletop, bent double by the weight of neckwear the size of lobster bibs, "is a real problem." Unable to nod, we could only murmur our agreement. 
 Generational deterioration describes what happens when you make copies of copies of copies, an effect common in videotape (and the genealogy of Europe's royal families). By the fourth or fifth generation the loss of quality is obvious, and one is left with only a dim facsimile, a blurred and colorless rendering of the original.
A similar phenomenon can be observed in its proper laboratory setting on March 27 when the ubiquitous ingenue Jennifer Love Hewitt essays the title role in the television biopic "The Audrey Hepburn Story." While Ms. Hewitt's charms are considerable, and her various talents have been corroborated by an astonishing number of teen-zine cover stories, the portrayal by a popular young actress of a show business original like a Hepburn, any Hepburn, can only result in lopsided comparisons. It seems to me that the outcome of viewing something like this will be to increase our longing for the genuine article at the expense of our regard for the woman playing her.
That fans of "Roman Holiday" and "Breakfast at Tiffany's" greeted the news of this project with barnyard snorts and eye-rolling of a magnitude unseen since the heyday of Snub Pollard is not a direct attack on Ms. Hewitt. Miscast or not, she will do her best, I am sure, and the movie, like most movies, will be promptly forgotten in any case. What seems to gall people is the potential damage that might be done to their memories, however imprecise, of Audrey Hepburn.
But there is something else at work here, too. Fueling that upset is perhaps the broader exasperation we feel at the explosive growth of "celebrity" and the proportional shrinkage of old school "stardom" that accompanies it; at the casual and unapologetic devaluation of originality; and at the melancholy xerography of most current entertainment. Audrey Hepburn versus Jennifer Love Hewitt competing for America's affections is a fixed fight, certainly, but may be emblematic of a much bigger problem. In trying so hard to earn a buck on the cusp of the Intertainment Age, Hollywood seems to specialize now in nothing so much as its own diminishment.
Before it gave way to new technologies and economies in the 1950's, the old studio system thrived on the gradual assembly of film legends. It could take years to build a John Wayne or a James Stewart or an Audrey Hepburn. The Hollywood bosses of that feudal era understood that what they manufactured was not movies but movie stars. The time and money it took to make one was well spent, because that kind of marquee appeal was a guarantee of moviegoing fannies in the seats. It was a long-term investment, one in which both parties benefited. The studios got their stars, at a price, and the stars, while constrained by their ironclad contracts, usually learned their craft with a schoolhouse rigor unimaginable today. If one looks at the kind of roles assumed by Errol Flynn or Joan Crawford or Spencer Tracy, the breadth and variety of the material they tried (or were forced to try) is stunning.
Today, though, Hollywood is engaged in the bulk manufacture of celebrities -- interchangeable entertainment widgets. The face on that magazine cover seems vaguely familiar and may belong to that guy we saw in that movie that time but, then again, may belong to that other guy in that other movie. That the company that owns the movie also owns the magazine and the magazine show covering them both makes for a closed economy wherein the importance of the individual is superseded by the impersonal necessities of a business done in volume. Hence a generation of actors like Ben Affleck or Jennifer Lopez who are on magazine covers because they are in the movies and seem to be in the movies only because they are on so many magazine covers. Ben Affleck is, I am sure, a nice young man, and somebody somewhere is determined to make him a celebrity if it kills him. Who and why I cannot say. Happily, the likelihood of seeing him in something like "The Jimmy Stewart Story" remains remote, at least for the moment. The part may go to Vince Vaughn. Or that other guy.
This sort of strangely anonymous celebrity, with its high-speed turnover and confusing sub-identities, is not limited to film. In the space of about a month last year, we witnessed the emergence of Britney Spears, Christina Aguilera, Jessica Simpson and Mandy Moore. The music business has obviously perfected the genetic engineering of blonde, sexpot teen-pop singers, and these are the results. In the old days Madonna had to invent herself piecemeal by invoking the ghost of Marilyn Monroe. These four sprang full grown from the MTV laboratories and are virtually identical, right down to the bare midriff and semisuggestive lyrics. I would challenge the scientists who created them to differentiate them (or their songs) in a police lineup. Can't be done.
What is most awe-inspiring about the new age of show business devolution, though, is its copy-to-copy-to-copy rapidity. More channels than ever, with more time to fill with more "content," means more derivative performers in more derivative formats than at any time in history. Digital technology aside, a copy is a copy is a copy, especially if there are more of them.
Witness the current state of television, the great devolver. Who among us can honestly keep the casts of "Felicity," "Popular" and "Dawson's Creek" straight? And why, after all, should we bother? Maybe because we've been booked to appear on "Greed"!
The big story of the last six months has been the triumphant return of the quiz show. ABC's "Who Wants to Be a Millionaire" breathed life into a form long thought dead by the experts. Based on a British show of the same format, it has made an unlikely prime-time colossus of Regis Philbin. Dressed in a manner befitting a stylish Cosa Nostra funeral director, Mr. Philbin sits on the bridge of the starship Free Enterprise, firing questions at chatty contestants and signing their souvenir checks. In its Americanized production, the questions are not very tough (if you got through junior high earth science and have a subscription to People magazine, you can make some real dough), and the appeal of the thing seems to lie in its ready accessibility. It is now on the air 128 nights a week and seems to muscle its way onto the schedule whenever it damn well feels like it.
The theory of waning generations, however, kicked in with the subsequent rollout of NBC's counterweapon, "Twenty One." Not only is this a show trying to capitalize on the first-generation success of "Millionaire," it is likewise a pale descendant of one of television's most (in)famous early hits. Dumbed down as though the whole thing had been poleaxed with the stupid stick, it betrays the initial appeal of the original, which was hard questions asked of sweating contestants in giant soundproof saltshakers. Now the Q & A is remedial multiple choice, the booths look air-conditioned and the only tension arises when the M.C., Maury Povich, tries to crack a joke. He has all the comic timing of a death row chaplain and is far better suited to his talk-show day job supervising teen prostitute makeovers and mouthing pieties about our failing family values. The original "Twenty One" may have been rigged, but at least it was worth watching. NBC is learning this the hard way as the new show's ratings travel quickly south.
In the seat just ahead of it on that downbound bus is the aforementioned "Greed." A Fox show from top to bottom, it has failed to catch fire, maybe because it stole only the elements from "Millionaire" that nobody liked: the music and the set. Or perhaps the audience doesn't think that knowing the five most popular sandwich spreads is worth a million bucks. If Fox knows how to make lemons into chicken salad, though, next month we will all be glued to the set watching "Who Wants to Marry Chuck Woolery?"
The CBS entry in the quiz show sweepstakes, "Winning Lines," was dead on arrival. More complicated than the New York State tax code, the entire show was taken up by Dick Clark's dogged explanation of the rules. Thus ended, in a matter of weeks, the explosive success cycle of prime-time game shows. Only Regis seems destined to endure.
WHAT is remarkable about all this is not that network television resorts to ripping off successful ideas from its competition or its own past but that it can do it so quickly. It has long been axiomatic that imitation is the sincerest form of television, but this season we have witnessed a new achievement in the turnaround time necessary to beat the life out of a defenseless idea.
Television is history's most insistently derivative medium. Our other major pop-cult industries, like film and music, depend on it for the promotion and cross-pollination of their own derivatives. The lookalike morning show books the lookalike actors who are on the lookalike magazine covers plumping the lookalike movies that start this Friday. The next day another actor another magazine another movie. And the next. And the next. The rapidity with which these pale copies track past us diminishes the value of each, including the ones that preceded them, blurring and obscuring even the most authentic. In this way we spiral into ever faster, more meaningless cycles of spin, sales figures and cynicism.
Thus diminished and inured to sensation, we can easily forget why we loved that generation of originals from long ago, from the time before the world grew cold. But if in remembering, or trying to remember, you decide to rent "Roman Holiday" or "Breakfast at Tiffany's" as an act of defiance or absolution or faith, don't forget to thank young Jennifer Love Hewitt for the inspiration.

HEADLINE: In the Region/Westchester;
Demand Continues Strong for Million-Dollar Homes

BYLINE: By MARY McALEER VIZARD

 BODY:
DESPITE recent blips in interest rates and swings in the stock market, the luxury home market in Westchester, which had record sales last year, is still "going strong," said Ebie Wood, a vice president with the Houlihan/Lawrence brokerage concern.
"People don't seem deterred at all by fluctuations in the market," Ms. Wood said. "Last year, the market in million-dollar homes exploded and it just keeps going." So far this year, she said, 22 houses costing $1 million or more have been sold in the northeast section of the county, which includes some of its most affluent areas, among them Bedford, Armonk, South Salem and Pound Ridge. 
 The average price was $2 million, and "the days on the market were 178," Ms. Wood said. "That's really the sign of an active market," she said.
Last year, her office sold 127 million-dollar houses at an average price of $1.7 million, and houses stayed on the market an average of 192 days. "There's definitely a pent-up demand," Ms. Wood said. "People are ready to buy. And they have the money in their pockets."
Another sign that this year is starting out even better than last, Ms. Wood said, is that harder-to-sell houses, which have unusual features, are being snatched up. "One house that was put on the market last summer lingered into the fall and then was taken off," Ms. Wood said. "We just put it back on, and we have an accepted offer."
A record of 403 homes sold for $1 million or more in Westchester last year, Houlihan/ Lawrence reported last month. That was up 33 percent from 308 houses sold in 1998. The number that sold for more $2 million jumped to 89 in 1999, up 41 percent from 63 in 1998. Houlihan/Lawrence's report covers sales reported by the Westchester Multiple Listing Service as well as those in their own offices.
Coldwell Banker Connecticut/New York also reported strong sales of luxury homes in 1999, although its report included sales only in its own offices. It sold 107 houses in the New York region -- which includes Westchester and Rockland Counties -- for $1 million or more last year, up 40 percent from 65 in 1998, said Lisa Harness, a vice president with Previews, Coldwell Banker's luxury properties division.
Dollar sales in that price range last year was $165.8 million, a 54 percent increase from the previous year. "New York homes in the Previews program had an average selling price of $1.5 million in 1999," Ms. Harness said, "compared to $1.25 million in 1998, a 17 percent increase."
Those increases do not mean, however, that house prices are increasing by that margin, Ms. Harness said.
"It just means that a greater number of more expensive houses are in the market now." she said. "We're seeing homes selling for between $4 million and $5 million and that brings the averages up."
In fact, it has got to the point where a million-dollar house is commonplace, Ms. Harness said. "I mean, to be a millionaire today, what is that? People are now buying $3, $4 and $5 million houses and paying for them in cash."
THE market in luxury homes today is similar to the boom years of the 1980's, Ms. Harness said, but with some important differences. "Then we saw 100 percent financing, robbing Peter to pay Paul," she said, "and when the market crashed, many of those people lost their homes. Today with so many cash transactions, even if the market turns down, people won't lose their homes."
The profile of sellers has also changed, Ms. Harness added. "In the 1980's, it was these moneyed people in their 60's who were downsizing," she said. "Now you have people in their 40's who are selling $1 million houses and moving up to even bigger houses. And there's also been more new construction at this price range."
Two years ago, John Ciardullo started building a development called Rock Shelter Road, a 21-lot subdivision, in Waccabuc. On a site spread over 100 wooded acres, he is building four- and five-bedroom colonial and shingle-style homes at $1.5 million to $2.5 million each.
"I thought I'd get yuppies with a lot of money to spend on a house," Mr. Ciardullo said. And that is pretty much what has happened, he said. Now starting on his ninth house, Mr. Ciardullo said that most buyers have been in their "early to late 30's, with young children." And at least one parent commutes into Manhattan, he added.
"But I've also gotten buyers in their early 50's who have just relocated, and some other combinations, such as a widow and her daughter and son-in-law who bought a house," Mr. Ciardullo said. "It's a real mix."
Amanda and Gary Brown were the first buyers at Rock Shelter Road, buying a four- bedroom, four-and-a-half-bath, shingle-style house, with 6,800 square feet, on four acres. "We'd looked all over Westchester," Ms. Brown said. "We looked at houses half the size on three-quarters of an acre in the same price range. And we looked at new construction that wasn't very well built before finding this. The minute we saw it we knew it was exactly what we wanted."
Two years ago, the house sold for $1.3 million, which was "a giveaway at the time," Mr. Ciardullo said. "I lost about $250,000 on it, but I just wanted to get the development going. Today that house would sell for $2 million."
TODAY five houses at Rock Shelter Road are complete, and three are under construction. "I'm starting the ninth house now. I've been building some speculative houses," Mr. Ciardullo said, "because I'm confident they'll sell. Some people don't want to go through the trouble of having a house built. They want something they can move right into."
One of his speculative houses, a five-bedroom, six-and-a-half-bath colonial, is in contract for $2.2 million, the list price. "I had two offers for the house at list," Mr. Ciardullo said. The 7,405-square-foot colonial has a two-story foyer, a columned entry in the living room, four fireplaces, a wood-paneled library and maid's quarters. "The people who are buying it are planning to use it as a weekend home," Mr. Ciardullo said. Their permanent home is in Manhattan.
Even with projects like Mr. Ciardullo's and others in construction, low inventory in the $1 million-plus category remains a problem.
"It's really a problem across all price ranges," said Ms. Wood, "but especially at this price range. We just got two listings in last week, and they're gone. Everything sells immediately if the house is in good shape and priced properly. But even with low supply, buyers at this price range are very savvy, and they won't overpay. If a house is not priced right, it will sit on the market. That's one thing that hasn't changed."

SECTION: Section 2; Page 31; Column 3; Arts and Leisure Desk 

LENGTH: 1501 words

HEADLINE: MUSIC;
Walking Out On Uneasy Success

BYLINE: By DAVID HECHT; David Hecht, a freelancer based in Dakar, Senegal, writes about culture.

DATELINE: DAKAR, Senegal

 BODY:
IN 1985, Angelique Kidjo left Benin in West Africa, poor and relatively unknown. But once in Paris the feisty Ms. Kidjo, a singer who contemporizes traditional music from across Africa, soon became a modern-day Josephine Baker, selling out concerts at the renowned Olympia concert hall. French government agencies were handing her plane tickets and cash even before they granted her French nationality. She lived a comfortable life in Paris's fashionable Marais -- that is until a couple of years ago, when she moved to Brooklyn. "I had to get out," Ms. Kidjo said recently from her brownstone in Park Slope. "France was stifling me."
Paris has been the capital of world music, embracing salsa and bossa nova before they were known elsewhere in the West as well as providing sanctuary for expatriate American jazz and blues musicians. Yet Ms. Kidjo is one of many African musicians who have made careers for themselves there and then expressed about as much appreciation as a love interest of Pepe Le Pew's. "There's an arrogance," said Richard Bona, a singer and bass player from Cameroon who, despite his success in France, has, like Kidjo, moved to New York. "They think they understand my music better than I do." Even Aicha Kone, Ivory Coast's most Frenchified diva, publicly complained recently that some African music made in France "doesn't sound African." 
 Still, leaving Paris for America -- or even returning to Africa -- might not be the answer for musicians seeking more than fame and fortune. The fact is that the music of Ms. Kone, Mr. Bona and Ms. Kidjo continues to exude a distinctly French aesthetic. "With most of it you can tell who colonized us," said Bouba N'Dour, head of Jololi, a new record company based in Senegal and founded by his brother, the well-known singer Youssou N'Dour. "The best African music tries to decide for itself its relationship with the outside world."
Figuring out that relationship is a tricky matter. African musicians have found recognition and financial support in Paris; breaking away from the French influence is not easy. Their intent is not to create a music that is purely African; to do so would leave them without electric instruments and the Western pop-song structure. Given that Western pop traces its roots to Africa, Africans should be able to combine the best of African and Western traditions without sounding derivative.
Afropop, as the music is known in America, has a long relationship with France. Most of it is produced by the more than 150 record labels in France specializing in world music, and much of it is tinged with variete francaise, France's sugary pop music, which in fact has little variety. "Just sample any French-made world music CD's and you'll get the idea," said Saliou Lamine Diop, a young Senegalese record producer based in New York. "There's always the same cheesy French synthesizers in the background."
Non-Western music of all sorts is a part of France's national psyche. "World music gets beyond the injuries of colonialism," asserts a recent article in Label France, a magazine produced by the ministry of foreign affairs, "to the universalism that is dear to the 'France spirit.' " This universalism, supposedly an outgrowth of the French revolution, is the raison d'etre for francophonie, which has come to mean a French government policy of encouraging cultural and economic ties among French-speaking countries. In the cultural sphere, francophonie encompasses the way the French repackage existing cultures and at the same time renew their own sense of nationalism. Critics like Charles L. Miller, professor of French and African American Studies at Yale University, view francophonie as "inherent neo-colonialism."
But Africans have undeniably benefited from French cultural largesse. There are more French cultural centers in Africa than anyplace in the world, and government ministries for culture and foreign affairs have generous budgets to support African artists. The French music industry has a niche for African musicians. "For France, all African culture has in a sense become a part of our own," said Emmanuel Morlet, a foreign ministry official.
It is precisely that attitude that troubles African musicians. They often say their music is being co-opted, manipulated and then marginalized. Despite the influence of variete francaise, "few French musicians know anything about African music," complained Antoine Yvernault, who organizes annual talent competitions throughout Africa for the government-sponored Radio France International. Immigrant communities in France offer a large audience for world music. Yet, in 1997, when more than 20,000 such CD's were available -- roughly a quarter of all current recordings -- they represented less than 2 percent of the music played on local French radio, according to a report obtained from a government agency.
Africans do not all submit blindly to French values, and sometimes they turn the values on their heads. Take soukous, a popular dance music in Central Africa. Frantic Congolese beats provide a backdrop for dancers dressed up in outfits that take French high fashion to ridiculous extremes. The sendup is even more pointed in a slow version of soukous known as zouk-love. Originally from the French Antilles, in the Caribbean, it is blatantly similar to variete francaise. The difference is that the French schmaltzy romantic lyrics are made sexually explicit and the beat is a little less insipid. In zouk-love, the idea is that grandly dressed couples can slowly grind their pelvises together on the dance floor while playfully imagining themselves to be French bourgeoisie.
The outlook for those African musicians who have left Paris is not clear. Leading musicians like Oumou Sangare of Mali and Baaba Maal of Senegal have abandoned their labels in France and signed with British companies. Others, like Cesaria Evora of Cape Verde and Habib Koite of Mali, have signed with American labels. "Koite is getting air play on commercial radio coast to coast," said Dan Storper, the chief executive of Mr. Koite's American label, Putamayo, "and other African artists may also soon cross over."
American tastes in music seem to be opening up. Sales of world music have risen steadily in the United States in recent years. (In contrast, sales of world music made in France have declined recently in America, according to Qualiton, a leading importer of French labels.) In dance clubs, hits from the 1970's by Mori Kante of Mali and Fela Anikulapo-Kuti of Nigeria are now standard remix material. Fela's son, Femi Anikulapo-Kuti, and Fela's former drummer, Tony Allen, are each fusing his so-called Afrobeat style with contemporary Western genres, and both have audiences in the West beyond the traditional world music niche.
For most African musicians, though, trying to fit in in America or Britian may be no more rewarding than trying to fit in in France. Western audiences -- and by extension Western record companies -- have specific tastes, and they often do not conform to African tastes. As a result, African musicians frequently make two versions of their albums, one to cater to an American audience and another to an African one. In the process they are only adding to the confusion about for whom their pop music is intended.
The best Afropop plays to both audiences. Papa Wemba in the Congo, Salif Keita in Mali and Youssou N'Dour in Senegal have all made records that have sold well in the West and they are national heroes in their own countries. Their music approaches the ideal of African musicians: it sells internationally while retaining enough of an indigenous identity to appeal to African audiences.
Mr. N'Dour continues to live and perform in Senegal. He sometimes sings in French as well as English -- like in his unfortunate recent collaboration with Sting. But his best music is undoubtedly made in his native Wolof. His rhythmically playful mbalax style is based on the intensely syncopated, polyrhythmic sabar drumming that every Senegalese grows up with. For native listeners, the fun of the music is guessing where the beat will fall. And while Mr. N'Dour's mbalax is world music, it is also a private joke among Senegalese.
At Jololi, Mr. N'Dour's label, new artists are only marketed locally. "Their first albums are just meant to appeal to Senegalese," said Kabou Gueye, the label's artistic director. "Then maybe later, if it gets popular, we might do a world beat album." But the market in most African countries is small. Thus the lure of France remains strong.
The French mostly dismiss the idea that Africans are fleeing Paris. "Some may leave but more will always come," said Mr. Yvernault. If they sing in French they are eligible for government support, though it may not help their careers. Salif Keita recently made an album of "variete francaise" classics called "Sosie" ("Spitting image"). It was not well liked; those who heard it generally agreed it was his worst.
