SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 2; Column 1; Connecticut Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 1009 words

HEADLINE: The View From/Bridgeport;
City Schools Using Mentors to Slow the Exodus of Teachers

BYLINE: By RICHARD WEIZEL

 BODY:
AFTER working for more than 20 years in auditing jobs in companies such as Sikorsky Aircraft in Stratford, Gary DeBrizzi, 47, decided a few years ago to pursue an old dream -- to become a teacher.
He is now in his third year as a fifth-grade teacher at Paul Laurence Dunbar School in Bridgeport and said he hopes to teach there for a long time. 
 Elena Pelaez, 23, is in just her second year as a Spanish teacher at the Multi-Cultural Magnet School in Bridgeport and said she can envision staying in the Bridgeport schools for the rest of her career.
But in a school district that loses up to one third of its new teachers every year, and in a nation where half of all new teachers quit within five years, according to the National Education Association, the chances of teachers like Ms. Palaez and Mr. Debrizzi being in classrooms here a decade from now are slim.
School administrators across the country, in fact, said there is a national teacher retention crisis, with urban centers being the hardest hit in a booming economy that provides new teachers with the opportunity to earn considerably more money in the suburbs.
Teachers who leave say in their exit interviews that low salaries and the increasingly difficult task of reaching inner-city students who bring serious life problems into the classroom are the leading reasons they don't stay in urban school districts.
But Bridgeport educators are fighting to keep new teachers in the district, and they say they are succeeding. What's making the difference, they say, is a mentoring program that pairs new teachers with veteran teachers who provide professional and personal support every day.
The Peer Assistance Program, which was made possible two years ago with an annual $4,000 National Education Association urban grant that has been renewed twice, is being jointly run with the Bridgeport school system, which provides matching funds. That makes it possible to train mentors, pay workshop and conference fees and hold after-hour social events that provide a vehicle for teachers to stay connected to each other, school officials said.
Both administrators and teachers said the program is already having an impact. They said 45 of 50 new teachers who participated last year are still in Bridgeport, and that the ratio of new teachers who leave after their first year has declined three years in a row.
While 43 of 109 new teachers departed at the end of the 96-97 school year, the number dropped to 33 of 95 in 1997-98 and to 23 of 115 last year. Those kinds of results have national educators studying the program as a potential model for other urban districts.
"There are rapidly growing numbers of people qualified to teach in this country who aren't teaching and that is a major problem we must address and are being addressed in programs like the one in Bridgeport," said Robert Chase president of the National Education Association in Washington, D.C.
Mr. Chase, the former president of the Connecticut Education Association and a Danbury teacher for 25 years, said programs like the one in Bridgeport were "absolutely essential if we are to have enough teachers to put in classrooms by 2007 when school enrollments will balloon to an unprecedented 54.3 million."
Both Mr. DeBrizzi and Ms. Pelaez said the program had greatly helped them.
"I always wanted to teach and was very idealistic when I finally got here after years in corporate jobs," Mr. DeBrizzi said. "The students have a lot of problems and it was very discouraging to realize you couldn't just make things better for them. Having the support of veteran teachers got me through some very frustrating times."
Ms. Pelaez said the program also helped get her through her first year.
"You can have all the confidence in the world as a teacher, but it's pretty overwhelming to suddenly be in charge of a classroom," she said. "Being able to rely on a veteran teacher who has been through it all at a moment's notice for guidance on managing a classroom or preparing a lesson plan can be invaluable."
Ms. Pelaez credits her mentor, third-grade teacher Margaret E. Cunningham, with providing that kind of support.
Ms. Cunningham, who has had two separate teaching stints in Bridgeport over a 35-year period, said, "I think the biggest problem is that new teachers come in knowing their subject very well, but not understanding that the first few years in the classroom can be very tough.
"Having someone to talk to who has been through the same thing can be very reassuring, and can even make the difference in whether somebody stays or leaves."
That kind of support may have helped keep teachers like Shirley Taylor in the system when an "avalanche of paper work" and classroom unrest had the High Horizons Magnet School math teacher thinking about leaving a few years ago.
"The biggest problems new teachers face are getting used to the paper work and keeping pupils calm and focused," Ms. Taylor said. "But those aren't subjects covered in college."
They, are however, subjects covered in the Peer Assistance Program. The program has done that by "providing enough daily support to new teachers so they feel connected to both their students and the school community as a whole," said the program coordinator Mary Lou Weiner of the Bridgeport Education Association.
Ms. Weiner said the program was far more extensive than the state-mandated Beginning Educator Support and Training program that requires new teachers have a mentor in order to obtain certification.
Fran Rabinowitz, executive director of teaching and learning for the Bridgeport school system, said losing new teachers in urban districts like Bridgeport was a complex problem.
"We know it's a tough sell to convince teachers to stay, but what we are doing here in Bridgeport is unique," she said. "The administration is working together with the teachers' union to provide as much support as possible to teachers in their early years so that we at least have a chance to keep new teachers here. And we are seeing results."

HEADLINE: In the Region/New Jersey;
E-Commerce Tenants Spur the Need for Warehouses

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
THE collection of big boxy warehouses that dots the landscape in north and central New Jersey is filling up and growing larger as the wave of leasing and building that washed over the state's industrial sector in 1999 rolls into this year.
The demand is coming from conventional as well as a small but growing number of e-commerce tenants who in response to a soaring economy are opening new centers to meet their expansion needs or consolidating operations to increase efficiency. In turn, most of the 4.1 million square feet of space added last year has been taken, prompting developers to build 5.6 million more square feet over the next 12 months, said Cushman & Wakefield, the national commercial brokerage company. 
 Meanwhile, the boxes are getting bigger and being installed with the latest equipment as distributors try to deliver goods to their consumers in 24 hours, said Jeffrey J. Toia, a senior director at the Garibaldi Group, a commercial brokerage company in Chatham. All these factors are driving the market and, despite the addition of new space, keeping demand ahead of supply, he said.
Stephen P. Jenco, research services manager at the Fairfield office of Grubb & Ellis, the national brokerage company, added: "New construction is not putting a dent in demand for industrial space, which may even be stronger than the demand for offices." His firm put the industrial vacancy rate in the 11-county northern and central parts of the state at 3.5 percent at the end of 1999, down from 4.7 percent in 1998.
Most of the activity is occurring in a few of the state's bigger submarkets. One is the Meadowlands, which continues to attract tenants that need to be near Manhattan. Another is Middlesex County, which has been accommodating companies looking to consolidate, with Edison and the area around Interchange Exit 8A of the New Jersey Turnpike attracting much of the attention. Demand is also gradually pushing south on the turnpike to Exit 7A in Mercer County. Rents in those areas are rising.
Among the projects planned is a million-square-foot warehouse distribution center to be built for Seaman Furniture Company, off Exit 7A in Washington Township. Three speculative projects with 500,000 to almost a million square feet also are expected to proceed in South Brunswick and Monroe, both off Exit 8A and in Edison, which is near Exit 10.
All are being built with, among other things, 32- to 38-foot-high ceilings, so goods can be stacked ever higher on racking systems that tenants install. They will also have ultra flat floors so that forklifts can move through narrow aisles where goods can be packed more closely, as well as truck loading docks on both sides of the warehouse so goods can be received on one side and shipped out the other at the same time.
"Larger buildings seem to be the order of the day as businesses consolidate operations into fewer and bigger warehouses rather than many smaller ones," said Jules Nissim, an associate director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield. He said that 12 tenants were scouring New York, New Jersey and Connecticut for buildings of a million square feet or more, with 14 more needing 400,000 to a million square feet.
But there are fewer places left in the state to develop such large centers. That is one reason that the 7A area, where large tracts of land are available, is gaining attention, brokers said.
That is where Seaman will put its million-square-foot warehouse, which will serve the Woodbury, N.Y., retailer's customers in New Jersey and Pennsylvania, as well as accommodate future growth. The company, with 49 stores in the northeast, plans new ones in Baltimore and Washington.
The warehouse, which Seaman will lease, will be developed by the Matrix Development Group of Cranbury. It will start to rise in two weeks at Matrix's 400-acre Northeast Business Park, which is next to the turnpike exit and close to Interstate 95, linking it to other points along the Eastern Seaboard -- a location that appealed to Seaman.
With this project, 1.8 million square feet of an eventual 5 million feet will be built at the park, reflecting "its maturity," said Alec Taylor, chief operating officer at Matrix, which is also active in the 8A market.
"The interesting thing," Mr. Taylor said, "is that while 7A is well suited to accommodate larger buildings for specific tenants. 8A remains mostly a place for speculative development." He explained that companies often wanted warehouses ready when they decided to enter markets.
This month his company will also start a 500,000-square-foot speculative warehouse at its 900-acre Center Point business park straddling Cranbury and South Brunswick in the 8A region.
"The competition is keen," Mr. Taylor said, "but typically the buildings are substantially leased before they are completed." Asking rents will be $4.75 a square foot a year.
That is on a par with area rents, which rose 21 cents, to $4.78 a square foot, from 1998 to 1999. Though nearly three million square feet was added to the area during that period, its vacancy rate fell to 3 percent from 4.4 percent, according to Grubb & Ellis.
THOSE factors encouraged Opus East L.L.C -- the regional arm of the Opus Group of Companies, a Minneapolis developer -- to enter the 8A market with a 90-acre campus in South Brunswick. It will have 1.2 million square feet in three buildings.
"It's too good a market to ignore," said James J. Lee, senior vice president at Opus East, which has offices in Bethesda, Md. He said his company expected to start construction by this summer on the first 526,400-square-foot building on 40 acres off Exit 8A.
Given the building's size, "we may lose some of the larger deals," he said, but added that "the typical user in the 8A market still wants 200,000 to 300,000 square feet." Rents will be competitive, he said, noting that his company expected to build the two other buildings in the next two years.
On a 202-acre tract in South Brunswick, Heller Industrial Parks, of Edison, has approvals to build nearly four million square feet in five buildings. Jeffrey J. Milanaik, the company's president, said that with much of the speculative building this year concentrated again in the 8A region, he would initially focus on build-to-suit deals at the South Brunswick project. He said he had interest from three users for buildings of 600,000 to 700,000 square feet each.
Meanwhile, he said his company was planning a two-building, 1.2 million-square-foot speculative project at its 410-acre industrial park, on Mill Road in Edison. "Building on speculation there is not a question," he said, adding that two speculative developments his company built over the last five years at the park, totaling 2.3 million square feet, were fully occupied.
Mr. Milanaik said he expected local and county approvals for the project next month and to start construction on the first 960,000-square-foot building in May. It will be designed for tenants needing 200,000 square feet or more, but the space could be divided into areas as small as 70,000 square feet. Rents will be $4.50 to $4.75 a square foot.
Existing warehouses are also being leased, some by e-commerce companies. One is the 348,885-square-foot warehouse on 91st Street in North Bergen in the Meadowlands that Webvan, the on-line grocer, based in Foster City, Calif, leased last month. The transaction is part of the company's expansion into 26 markets.
"We choose big metropolitan areas that will allow us to build a national footprint," said Amy Nobile, the company's public relations manager. She said the North Bergen center would be modeled after one in the San Francisco Bay Area, which is crisscrossed with conveyor belts and relies on a computer system to pack customers' orders.
Webvan is leasing the building from Hartz Mountain Industries of Secaucus, among the largest landowners in the Meadowlands. The Meadowlands covers parts of seven communities in Hudson and Bergen Counties. "This market is clicking on all cylinders," said Emanuel Stern, Hartz's president, adding that Internet companies were contributing to its health. He said that his company's 20 million square feet of space had a vacancy rate of less than 1 percent and that the area's rents had risen to $6 to $7 a square foot from $4.50 to $5.50 two years ago.
In turn, he said his company was negotiating with two tenants to build a distribution center for each and "for the first time in a long time also is considering building a speculative warehouse." Each building will have 300,000 to 400,000 square feet.

HEADLINE: Q&A/Dr. David M. Nganele;
Leading Minorities to Better Health Care

BYLINE: By DONNA GREENE 

 BODY:
DR. DAVID M. NGANELE would like to do in Westchester what he recently began doing in Harlem -- running full-time educational programs so African-Americans and other minorities can get better health care.
Dr. Nganele (pronounced GAN-ih-lay), who received his Ph.D. in physiology from New York Medical College in Valhalla, gave up a job a year ago at Pfizer to start, with its financial support, a health-education program at the Convent Avenue Baptist Church in Harlem. His company, Harmony Health Communications in Harrison, is affiliated with North General Hospital and plans to establish a library on health issues. It is an attempt to overcome more than just financial barriers to good health care. Minorities, he said, distrust the white-dominated medical profession. 
 Dr. Nganele of Mount Kisco was born in Cameroon, where he went to Roman Catholic boarding school. He came to the United States in 1980 when he was 22. After earning his doctorate from the college (where he met his wife, Dr. Charlotte Nganele, a psychiatrist), he earned an M.B.A. from Columbia Business School and in 1990 went to work for Pfizer. There he was part of the team that marketed Procardia, a drug that helps with hypertension. Later, as a senior manager in marketing, he helped market the anti-depressant Zoloft.
Dr. Nganele said the disparities between health care for whites and nonwhites are staggering. For example, blacks die more than six years earlier on average than whites and are more likely to come down with more diseases. Here are excerpts from a recent conversation:
Q. What was your life like growing up in West Africa?
Q. Relative to Cameroon, I was middle class. My father is an accountant and my mother is a dressmaker. So I went to prestigious schools and got grounded well in terms of education. Cameroon is relatively a homogenous society. We have differences in terms of tribal backgrounds, different customs. But we don't have the racial composition that you find in this country.
Q. What was health care like in Cameroon?
A. It's universal. The government pays for health care; the hospitals are free. But there are private hospitals as well, which means if you don't want to go to the government hospitals and you have money you can go to see private physicians and private hospitals. The government also provides free medical education.
Q. How did you get involved on the business side of medicine?
A. I love research and wanted as much education as possible. What took me out of doing basic medical science was that at the time the Reagan administration was cutting back on research grants to academia so you spent a lot of time looking for grants; increasingly, we turned to the drug industry for research grants.
Q. How did you get interested in the quality of health care for African-Americans?
A. After I went to Pfizer and helped launch the drug Procardia, I started understanding the demographics of hypertension. It is a disease that disproportionately affects African-Americans. So I increasingly became aware of the differences in diseases prevalent in this country. I started looking more into it, and as the years went by I realized it didn't just stop with hypertension, that a lot of chronic diseases have a very high prevalence in the minority population. From diabetes, AIDS and others.
Q. Are the disparities in health care between whites and nonwhites an issue of life style or genetics?
A. I started doing research into that, and I realized that maybe it's not that much genetic. We have available information and technology that can make a difference. No one should sit back and say, well, maybe certain groups are more prone to these diseases. As I looked into it, I realized that the African-American community and the minority community don't have as much access to technology and information.
Q. Is a lack of access to health information mainly linked to financial reasons?
A. There are a lot of factors that affect access to health care. One that gets thrown around is insurance. There are two ways to look at that. The data says that 23 percent of African-Americans do not have health insurance. If you turn that around it means that almost 80 percent do have it. So the question is, Are those people who have health insurance making use of it? My feeling is that no, they are not, that a lot of people wait until there is a crisis. And of those people who do not have health insurance, the question is how resourceful are they in getting health care? A lot of resources are actually there for people who do not have health insurance.
Q. What are you trying to do through your company, Harmony Health Communications?
A. This is a medical education company with a mission to educate all the consumers and physicians in how to take care of the minority population. The mission is increasing access to health care. There is a physician-education component and a consumer-education component. The reason there is a physician-education component is because numerous studies have shown if a physician meets a patient with a different cultural background there are issues of communication.
Physicians have to become what is known as "culturally competent." You have to understand that your patient has a background that affects the way they receive medical care. For example, there is a belief in some African-Americans that exercise is stressful. So if somebody comes in with hypertension and you as a physician say to them you need to exercise, for some patients there is a conflict. If you as a physician do not understand that and take time to explain that to the patient, they will walk out thinking you, the doctor, don't know what you're talking about and not take your advice.
Q. What is the consumer-education component of the program at Harmony?
A. This is a big challenge. Patients have to understand how they can help themselves. One of the most significant factors is that the minority community does not trust the medical establishment. In fact, Emory University did a study that showed that 74 percent of African-Americans believe they will be used as guinea pigs by their doctors without their consent. So I looked for an institution that can bridge that gap, and it turns out it's the church. It is the church that across every culture people tend to give unconditional trust. So we need to use the church to help us educate consumers about health care. Ministers in the African-American community have spent a lot of time and energy speaking about the spiritual well-being and social and political issues and economic empowerment. Now they need to get involved in health. They can make all the political and economic gains, but without health that goes for naught.
Q. To what extent are churches involved in health issues now?
A. A lot of churches have realized they need to play a bigger role and have health committees and do health fairs and screening programs. Unfortunately, they're not in that business; they get volunteers and maybe do it once or twice a year. You cannot change a habit this way.
The hope is to get to the point where this becomes a key part of the church's activities. The project that I did at Convent Church, which is a pilot project, actually set up a multimedia health education facility in the church. There is a room that is a health library with books, computers with Internet access, video and audio tapes, a blood pressure machine. It's a room that you can walk into and, regardless of your level of literacy, you can access health information. And the church is open seven days a week. And it's affiliated with North General Hospital, which does screening programs every month, and these programs have been really well attended. These people now have a place where they feel comfortable.
Q. Are the health needs of minorities in Westchester any different from those in Harlem where you have an education program?
A. No, because we have pockets of areas in Westchester with great need -- Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, Ossining, Mount Kisco and others. And the needs are not just with the minority population. Look at the growth of the noninsured. Right now it's at 44 million, and the growth is in the middle class. This means that these people need to learn how to take care of themselves. In Mount Kisco, I am working with my church, St. Francis of Assisi. I have developed a resource guide for what to do when you don't have insurance or are underinsured. And I'm starting to talk to other ministers to develop health education centers in Westchester, as I did at Convent. Convent was a pilot, and we hope to duplicate it around the country.

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 18; Column 3; Long Island Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: X in Electricity Equation: a Non-LIPA Plant

BYLINE: By STEWART AIN

 BODY:
THE promise of a Texas company to generate electricity on Long Island more efficiently, with less pollution and at lower cost is receiving generally positive reviews from the Long Island Power Authority and business leaders. Residents near the proposed site are more cautious.
The company, American National Power, wants to build a gas-fired power plant on a vacant 25-acre plot just south of the Long Island Expressway at Exit 66, in Yaphank. The facility, which could generate 580 megawatts of electricity, would be the first built on the Island by any company other than the local utility. Construction is proposed to begin next year, with completion in 2003. 
 "I think it's an exciting idea," said LIPA's chairman, Richard M. Kessel. "There is obviously a huge need for energy on Long Island, and if this plant was built, it might help us fill out the picture of how we would meet that demand."
The Brookhaven Town supervisor, Felix Grucci Jr., said the proposal "is in concert with what I have been requesting -- alternative and competitive power on Long Island that may bring lower electric rates to the town and all of Suffolk."
The electricity would be "significantly less expensive" than that generated by plants owned and operated by KeySpan Energy, according to Robert J. Charlebois, vice president of American National Power.
KeySpan is currently the only company on Long Island that generates electricity for LIPA. It was created in May 1998 when the Long Island Lighting Company was dissolved and LIPA assumed control of its electric transmission and distribution lines and KeySpan took control of its five power plants.
David J. Manning, senior vice president of KeySpan, acknowledged that "any new generating plant built today will use the most current gas-fired turbine technology." Keyspan's plants were initially oil-fired but were converted to allow them to burn primarily natural gas and now, Mr. Manning said, KeySpan is considering upgrading them.
Mitchell Palley, a vice president of the Long Island Association, said: "This proposal is what energy deregulation means -- the ability of private companies to come in, build power plants and sell electricity at less than current suppliers. If it meets community needs, it is something we would support."
Mr. Kessel noted that LIPA buys nearly all of its electricity from KeySpan. It is able to import no more than 1,200 megawatts of electricity through five connections with suppliers off the Island.
On a very hot day, energy demand can reach 4,200 to 4,300 megawatts. Last July 6, in the middle of a heat wave, the demand reached a record 4,590 megawatts. The system's maximum capacity is 5,100 megawatts.
Bert J. Cunningham, LIPA's vice president for communications, noted that demand had increased 3.5 to 4 percent annually in the last three or four years and that it is expected to continue that pace.
Mr. Kessel said that he had met with Mr. Charlebois and that LIPA is now discussing integrating the electricity generated at Yaphank into the utility's grid.
To help meet energy demands this summer, LIPA awarded KeySpan Energy Construction, a KeySpan subsidiary, a $67 million contract on Feb. 29 to string a 138-kilovolt cable from Riverhead to Southampton by June. Energy demand on the East End has been rising sharply because of housing construction there.
Mr. Cunningham also noted that the utility should be awarding contracts soon to companies that bid on a proposal to build two or three power plants that would generate a total of 225 megawatts of electricity. "The companies would build the plants at their own expense and sell the electricity to us exclusively," he said.
Another request for a proposal (R.F.P.), to lay a 600-megawatt cable under the Sound from New Haven to Shoreham, has been modified, he said, to reduce the initial capacity to 200 to 300 megawatts, but with the possibility of adding a second cable.
"We are looking for flexibility in bringing electricity from off the Island," Mr. Cunningham said. "We felt from the information we developed through the first R.F.P. process that it was better to look at different types of cable technologies and perhaps multiple cables."
Mr. Charlebois said his proposed plant would be a "viable alternative" to the cable. But Mr. Kessel pointed out that if the underwater cable were approved, it would be operational in 2002. The proposed power plant, even if it were built on time, would not be running until 2003.
A decision on the cable will be made by June, Mr. Kessel said. He added that he is confident that even if the cable project is approved, growing demand for power will make the American National Power project a necessity.
Mr. Charlebois put the cost of the Yaphank project, including the land, at about $300 million.
"One of the reasons we like this site is that the closest residence is about 2,000 feet away," he said. "The plant would be south of the Long Island Expressway at the intersection with Sills Road, and the majority of the homes are north of the expressway."
He noted that he has met with some civic leaders and will be sending letters to about 5,000 residents who live within two miles.
"We're interested at the end of the day in designing a project that is as satisfactory as possible," he said. "We are not going to go to areas where we are not welcome."
Connie Kepert, president of the Affiliated Brookhaven Civic Organizations, said that in her meeting with Mr. Charlebois, he promised to come back in the spring with more detailed information about the project's economic and environmental impact.
"It certainly is important to bring competition to Long Island as far as electricity is concerned," she said. "So this is a good thing. But we want to make sure that there are no environmental concerns that become a burden to the town. I know there will be an oil storage facility on the site and I'm concerned about water and air quality. I'd like to see a little more information."
Nanette Essel, co-president of the Yaphank Taxpayers and Civic Association, which represents the neighboring homeowners, raised those same concerns, saying: "It is premature to comment before we have seen all the facts. The devil is in the details and we haven't seen any, so we have to be cautious and wait."
In its literature, American National Power writes that the project would use "clean-burning natural gas, highly efficient electricity generating technology and cutting-edge pollution-control and water-minimization equipment.
"The plant will be designed to meet the Clean Air Act's 'lowest achievable emission rate' and 'best available control technology' standards," the statement continues. "Because of air-cooling technology used at the plant, the generation of a vapor plume will be almost nonexistent."
Mr. Charlebois said the plan calls for two smokestacks no higher than 180 feet. And he said the company would "maintain as much visual buffer as possible." He said also that there would be no odors and that the noise from the generator turbines would not be heard 2,000 feet away.
American National Power estimated that 700 jobs would be created for the construction of the power plant and that another 25 full-time operators would be needed once it is erected.
Supervisor Grucci said that in addition to creating jobs, the project would add millions to the tax base, with much of it going to the Longwood School District.
"At this point the proposal is in front of us, and when the plan becomes more real, the town will look at it," he said. "But it is very much in concert with what we trying to do."

SECTION: Section 14LI; Page 1; Column 2; Long Island Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 2206 words

HEADLINE: A Hiker's Dream, and Sobering Realities

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
TEN years ago, when talk began about a hiking trail that would traverse eastern Long Island, many hikers though it was some kind of joke.
"Everyone was so fixated on mountains back then," said Nancy Manfredonia, one of a handful of early trail visionaries. "People would say, 'What do you mean, hiking on Long Island?' " 
 This spring, 100 miles of winding pineland and coastal hiking trail, stretching from eastern Brookhaven to Montauk Point, is blazed and ready. The trail, called the Paumanok Path, is not continuous yet -- about 20 miles of gaps remain in Southampton -- but the gaps are fewer than ever before, and hikers are not waiting for completion to lace up their boots.
The Paumanok Path is possible only because of major public land acquisitions over the past 30 years, thousands of hours of volunteer work and help from government agencies.
But as it beckons to more hikers, the path is facing onslaughts from a growing number of illegally operated all-terrain vehicles, called A.T.V.'s or quads, and from dirt bikes that tear up fragile trails and shatter the stillness of the woods. And east of the Shinnecock Canal in Southampton, trailblazers trying to fill in the remaining gaps are confounded by a paucity of public land and heavy development pressure that is rapidly consuming remaining open spaces.
Even with the gaps, the path is impressive. From its beginning in Rocky Point it winds through the core of the 100,000-acre Long Island Pine Barrens Preserve and then picks its way eastward through parks and private lands. On the way it passes pitch pines, globally rare dwarf pines, hardwood forests, glacial hills and kettleholes, a maple swamp, freshwater wetlands, grasslands, beaches and bluffs -- some of the most beautiful and environmentally significant lands left on Long Island.
"I see the Paumanok Path as a strand of DNA strewn across dozens of communities," said Tom Stock, a writer, naturalist and retired school teacher from Smithtown who helped blaze the path. "This trail is spectacular. It is the barometer for changing attitudes toward the Long Island environment."
Some trail sections skirt backyards or follow roads. But others are surprisingly remote, beyond earshot of road noise and out of sight of houses, power lines or any sign of civilization. White trail markers painted on trees at close intervals keep hikers from getting lost.
No overnight camping is permitted, so the path must be seen one day-hike at a time, though campsites may be added later. But the main thing lacking is more hikers.
"People just don't know about it yet," said Ms. Manfredonia, president of the Long Island Greenbelt Trail Conference, the principal organization of trails volunteers. "It's still kind of a little secret. Yet we have some of the most spectacular scenery in the world here."
"When you get to Montauk and look out over the ocean on one side and the bay on the other, it is just breathtaking," she said. "I'll take it over a mountaintop any day."
Kenneth Kindler of Mount Sinai, a retired businessman who works full-time on trails, said a Paumanok Path celebration in June he is promoting will bring out hikers and show them where and how to get on the path.
"People don't know how to go about accessing it," Mr. Kindler said. "You could be talking about the Amazon." He maintains a web site (www.hike-li.com) offering trail information.
The trail is also attracting uninvited guests -- the all-terrain vehicle and dirt bike riders. Even though it is illegal to operate the vehicles anywhere but on private land with the owner's permission, A.T.V. riders are ripping up trails and sometimes clashing with hikers.
"These people ignore our postings and ride wherever their machines will go," said William F. Peters, chief of the Suffolk County Park Police. "And right now we are losing the battle against them."
George Fernandez of Ridge, an illustrator and college art teacher who organizes volunteers for trail cleanup and repair, said A.T.V.'s ruin a trail in a hurry.
"They go into areas where there are hills and just tear up them up," he said. "Where there was a trail, they create these gullies three feet deep. It's unbelievable how much damage they do."
Because the Paumanok Path and other trails run through different jurisdictions, law enforcement is coordinated by an 18-agency council, said Lawrence J. Hynes, the council chairman and also director of public safety for Suffolk parks. Mr. Hynes said the council regularly fielded enforcement teams that confiscated A.T.V.'s and dirt bikes in areas where they had been reported.
Under a county law, owners pay a $250 fee, or $500 for a second offense, to get the vehicles back.
But despite enforcement efforts, trail users say that the A.T.V.'s rule some sections of the trail, and that the riders resent the presence of hikers.
"It's like the Wild West out there," said Eric Burke of Ridge, who lives near the path. "You see these little kids, 8 or 9 years old, flying at you on a quad."
While state motor vehicle law bars drivers under 16 years of age, the provision is largely ignored among A.T.V. riders.
Mr. Burke said he has been confronted several times by A.T.V. operators yelling at him to get out of their way. One antagonist, he said, turned out to be his new neighbor.
Mr. Burke said that when he went next door to tell the neighbor that A.T.V.'s were illegal in the woods, the man became enraged and hit him with a crowbar. After treatment for a pelvic injury, he filed assault charges.
While that run-in is an extreme example of the tensions in the woods, there have been other incidents. Mr. Hynes said hikers can call a pine barrens hotline, 1-877-BARRENS, to report illegal riders. "People should not get physically involved," he said. "We ask them to call the hotline number and then let the officers do their job."
Chief Peters of the Park Police said that more than 300 summonses were issued to riders last year. But Mr. Burke said his calls to the Suffolk police had been in vain. "They won't go in there," he said. "I don't even bother to call them anymore."
A statewide group representing A.T.V. users, the New York State Off-Highway Recreational Vehicle Association, is seeking state support for special A.T.V. trails upstate, where legal riding is now limited to designated areas in two state forests.
"I know there is a real problem on Long Island for people who own A.T.V.'s," said Alex Ernst of Ravena, the group's communications director. "The economy is good so they can afford these toys, but then there is no place to use them."
Registration figures for 1997, the most recent year available, showed that combined registrations of 1,568 A.T.V.'s in Suffolk and 703 in Nassau were second only to St. Lawrence County in northern New York.
But Mr. Ernst estimated there are about 14,000 A.T.V.'s in use on Long Island. A.T.V. buyers are supposed to register the vehicles but it is widely acknowledged that many do not, and dealers are not required to assure registration before the vehicles leave the showroom.
"The attraction, in a word, is fun," Mr. Ernst said. "It's a quick, exciting way of getting around in places that you don't normally get to see from the highway."
Hikers cringe at such descriptions. "People can't just destroy woodlands because they want to have fun," said Ms. Manfredonia of the trails conference.
She said that A.T.V. dealers on Long Island don't tell buyers that the vehicles can only be used by permission on private land. "The dealers are not going to do anything to jeopardize a sale," Ms. Manfredonia said.
At an A.T.V. dealership in Riverhead, a salesman who was asked where the vehicles could be used answered, "Anywhere there's not a road." But at a dealership in Port Jefferson, a salesman gave correct information.
Some hikers question why the state Department of Environmental Conservation requires permits for use of its Long Island lands. The permits are free, but require an application by mail.
Mark Lowery, a spokesman for the Long Island regional office of the state Department of Environmental Conservation, said hiking permits are required because of the large number of people using the Long Island properties.
"We have some more specific regulations there than for other pieces of property," he said. "And the permit gives the department the opportunity to put the regulations in the hands of each permittee rather than just posting them."
Ms. Manfredonia said the department didn't require hikers to get permits in other parts of the state and shouldn't require them on Long Island. "It's very difficult for people who are visiting," she said.
But the trailblazers' emphasis is on linking the western and eastern portions of the Paumanok Path.
Steven Biasetti, an environmental analyst at the Group for the South Fork in Bridgehampton, said closing trail gaps of 15 to 20 miles east of the Shinnecock Canal in the Town of Southampton will be difficult. He said private property owners are reluctant to permit trail corridors because of concerns about liability, or in some cases for fear of lost privacy.
A town trails advisory board, of which Mr. Biasetti is a member, springs into action when subdivisions are proposed. If the property has trail potential, the board asks town officials to add trail corridors to the development plans.
The results have sometimes been disappointing. At the disputed Parrish Ponds subdivision, a housing development that the Shinnecock Indian nation claims as ancestral land, the trail corridor is only 10 feet wide and passes near housing lots.
"We try to get a 50-foot-wide easement because otherwise it's just like walking through back yards," said Dai Dayton, president of the Southampton Trails Preservation Society.
Ms. Dayton was not optimistic about closing the gaps. "It is going to be quite difficult in some places," she said. "We may have to road-walk a little bit. But what's in place is very beautiful."
Ms. Manfredonia said the lack of parks and publicly owned lands in Southampton east of the canal complicated the task. "We are lucky on Long Island because we have a great deal of publicly owned land, but very little of it is in Southampton," she said. "So we will need little successes here and there in getting easements."
In East Hampton, the final leg of the Paumanok Path was completed in 1998 and now extends 46 miles from the town's western border to Montauk Point.
Richard M. Lupoletti of East Hampton, a retired school librarian and former president of the East Hampton Trails Preservation Society, said that last year volunteer trail guides conducted 150 free hikes on the East Hampton trails that attracted more than 4,000 people.
Trails in the two Hamptons are generally opened to hiking, horseback riding and, with some restrictions, mountain bikes. Horseback riders who had long ridden the trails were at the core of trail preservation efforts.
A.T.V.'s have left their mark on trails in both towns. "We're alert to the problem and we call the police when we see them," said Mr. Lupoletti. "But it's not stopping us from enjoying our trails."
Mr. Fernandez, a frequent witness to torn-up trails and gouged-out gullies A.T.V.s leave in their wake on trails to the west, said the worst was yet to come on eastern sections. "Out in the Hamptons, their problems are just starting," he said.
Information for the Paumanok Path and other trails is available at the Long Island Greenbelt Trail Conference office in Smithtown (631) 360-0753. A trail information office on Route 111 in Manorville north of exit 70 reopens on April 15.
Permit applications for state-owned lands are available from the state Department of Environmental Conservation at (631) 444-0273. The address is the Sporting License Office, SUNY Building 40, Stony Brook, N.Y. 11790-2356. The three-year permit comes with trail maps.
 
Gimme a P! Gimme an A!
Paumanok, an Indian name for eastern Long Island, probably means "land of tribute." It first appeared in written form in deeds conveying land from Montauk chiefs to East Hampton settlers.
William Wallace Tooker of Sag Harbor, an authority on Indian place-names on Long Island, said in a book published in 1911 that he encountered the word in a deed for Gardiners Island dated 1639, and in many other later deeds.
 "This part of Long Island," Tooker wrote, "was under tribute at this period and previous both to the Pequots and to the whites." A more contemporary description of "under tribute" would be that the Montauks were paying both Pequots -- the Connecticut tribe that now runs the Foxwoods casion -- and settlers for protection, in shells and land.
The many spellings include Paumanack, Pommanock, Pamunke, Pammanach, Pawmanuck, Pammanake, Paumanuck, Paumanacke and Paumanhacky.
The current spelling comes from Walt Whitman in his 1860 poem "Starting from Paumanok," part of "Leaves of Grass." It begins:
Starting from fish-shape Paumanok where I was born,
well-begotten, and rais'd by a perfect mother, . . .
"That poem is what really made the word famous," said Roger Wunderlich, a professor at SUNY-Stony Brook and editor of the Long Island Historical Journal. JOHN RATHER

HEADLINE: A Touch of Gray Is No Barrier To a Job Today

BYLINE: By LINDA SASLOW 

 BODY:
NO one else but seniors would take this job," said Theresa Delaurentis, a representative of REH Marketing, who gets paid $8 an hour to travel to supermarkets throughout the Island and ask shoppers to sample different products. On a recent afternoon at Pathmark in Woodbury, Ms. Delaurentis, a Bethpage resident who acknowledged only that she is over 65, was offering graham crackers to customers as they shopped.
"For me, it's better than sitting at home," Ms. Delaurentis said. "Working is a way to get out and meet people." 
 Another sample-distributor, Mary Kaiser of Syosset, agreed, saying, "I do it both for the money and because it's a social job." She makes $7.70 an hour and works about 22 hours a week.
The spread of seniors in the work force is a new phenomenon, said Pearl Kamer, chief economist of the Long Island Association, the region's largest business group. Although there are no numbers on seniors returning to work in unskilled positions, the anecdotal evidence is strong, she said.
The labor crunch has left many positions in supermarkets, drug stores, fast food chains, bus and taxi companies and retail stores unfilled, Dr. Kamer added, a shortage that has become as acute as that in the skilled and high-tech areas. Unemployment in Nassau was 2.6 percent in December and in Suffolk it was 3.2 percent -- both figures well below the statewide rate of 4.5 percent.
As the pool of candidates for entry-level jobs has shrunk, the faces that were once primarily those of 17- and 18-year-olds are now often of men and women over 60.
"We've never before seen such early retirements," Dr. Kamer said. "In the past, people usually worked until they were 65. But today, many people are retiring in their 50's, and either because of economic need or because they are bored and want contact with the world, they are returning to work.
"I'd say that in this high-cost area, 90 percent of the time there's an economic need to supplement a pension or Social Security."
For Ronald Strasfeld, 69, who works at Edwards in Woodbury, the motivation to get a part-time job was twofold.
"I was bored, and I needed the income," said Mr. Strasfeld, a Syosset resident who for the past year has been greeting shoppers at the store's entrance with a hot-dog cart and a smile. "I retired at 62, after years as a successful textile salesman, and stayed home until last year. Then I lost some money in the stock market and started fighting with my wife because there was too much togetherness. I came to Edwards on a lark, and they hired me."
Mr. Strasfeld now works 25 hours a week, making $7 an hour.
"Like most middle-class people in today's economy, it's impossible to live on my pension, Social Security and savings," he said. "With my rent at $1,600 a month, a new car and high taxes, I need to supplement my income to make ends meet."
Recruitment of older workers has been accelerated by a decline in the number of students available to work, Dr. Kamer said.
"It used to be that if you needed a hamburger-flipper or a cashier, young people who needed money for high school or college were there to fill the jobs," she said. "But as the population on Long Island is aging, there are fewer people in the under-20 category.
"And those students we have are far more sophisticated. They want to pursue jobs that will in some way benefit them in a career. Many are even willing to take unpaid internships in a field of their interest. That automatically cuts out one source of our labor."
Charlie Rex, manager of King Kullen in Syosset, said: "The help shortage is a terrible situation. We are having so much trouble finding and keeping workers. We're looking for anyone -- old or young, it doesn't matter."
Cari Lap, manager of Yogurteria in Syosset, agreed: "We're desperate for help. It's become impossible to find people willing to work for $6 an hour."
Eddie Lasneski, a familiar face at CVS in Syosset, was originally hired to keep commuters from leaving their cars in the CVS parking lot all day.
"I saw a sign on the door, went in and got hired the same day," said the 67-year-old Woodbury resident, who works to supplement his Social Security and two small retirement pensions from years in the fur trade and at Grumman. "I immediately became a Jekyll and Hyde, because while I was in the parking lot chasing people away, I began on my own to greet people as they came into the store. Then once the parking problem was under control, they asked me to stay and work full time in the store. Being a senior carries some weight, out of respect for my age."
While Mr. Lasneski has thought about selling his house and moving from the high-cost Island, his wife does not want to leave her relatives, he said, adding, "I don't want to stop working yet, but I would like to smell the coffee a little more."
In this healthy economy, more options have opened for older people who want to work part time, said Gary Huth, a labor analyst for the New York State Labor Department.
"Any time you have an extended period of low unemployment rates, the effects on the job market include a labor shortage," he said. "In 1991, there was no problem filling every retail job because so many people were out of work. We had stories of engineers working at Home Depot. Companies could afford to be more selective and expect their employees to have higher skills.
"But today, even people without skills have other options aside from entry level or retail, and many of those same companies are able and willing to spend time training these people to upgrade their skills. Consequently, someone whose horizons were formerly limited to a job at a fast-food restaurant now has other options. That leaves the fast-food place with fewer people to choose from."
There are now 218,000 retail jobs on the Island, and seniors are filling many of the vacant positions, Mr. Huth said, adding, "Businesses that previously overlooked the capability of older people have been pleasantly surprised."
For the last six years, Helen Ullman has been a saleswoman at Protass, a luggage, handbag and gift shop in Woodbury Commons. "This job keeps me going," said Ms. Ullman, 66, who commutes from Massapequa Park. "I love the social aspects and working with the customers, but the bottom line is that I need the income. It's not always easy juggling a job, then trying to help my daughter out, taking care of my grandchildren."
At the Island's 13 Home Depots, more seniors are filling jobs, said John Simley, a company spokesman.
"In many cases, it's a natural fit," he said. "What do you do if you've been a bricklayer and you're now 65? You can't still lift bricks, but a job at Home Depot can help maintain a sense of self-worth."
For 72-year-old Marvin Grotell of Jericho, who retired seven years ago as a dental technician, a part-time job at his local Home Depot, one mile from home, is more fun than work, he said. Mr. Grotell, who was hired as a salesperson and horticulturist, works three days a week for $11.50 an hour, unloading and displaying plants.
"I do this because I love it," said Mr. Grotell, who has a degree in botany. "When I'm not working with the plants at Home Depot, I'm usually either in my own greenhouse or at Old Westbury Gardens, where I'm a volunteer gardener."
Efforts to recruit school-bus drivers have also been increasingly answered by seniors, said Barbara Drexler, manager of Hendrickson Bus Company, based in Bayville.
"With this economy, it's been harder to find drivers, despite the salaries that are well above minimum wage," she said. (The pay is $11 an hour for driving a small bus, $13 an hour for a big bus.) "A large percentage of our drivers are now retirees who may have retired early and want to work part time, make decent money and still have time to pursue other activities."
Recruitment efforts are reflected in signs on almost every supermarket, drug store, fast-food chain and super-store, many of which list employee benefits right on the "help wanted" posters. And some companies have taken further steps.
At King Kullen, in addition to advertising in the local Pennysaver and inserting a message about accepting job applications on every cash register receipt, management has contacted the local high schools. "We call the guidance office every week, looking for kids to work here," Mr. Rex said.
Grand Union, which has five Long Island stores, recently sent a mailing directed at homemakers, students and seniors with a job application form attached. CVS managers have been attending senior job fairs and working with county and local agencies related to senior citizens.
But high schools have not been a very fruitful place to look, particularly in more affluent areas. "Many of the kids around here just don't need to work," said Steve McGuiness, assistant manager of Edwards in Woodbury, where the pay starts at $6.50 an hour.
Ms. Lap, at Yogurteria, has a similar problem. "When kids come in to apply for a job, they want to make their own hours and tell us exactly what they're willing to do," she said. "If I tell them that the job includes mopping and sweeping, they look at me like I'm crazy."
One of the biggest problems, Mr. Rex said, is a lack of employee loyalty. "People bounce around from one job to another, because they may get $1 more at one job, 50 cents more at another."
But in contrast to the fickle youth, seniors are far more reliable, Mr. McGuiness said.
One of the longest-working employees at Edwards is Catherine Fiore, 73, a cashier who works about 25 hours a week for $13 an hour and has been commuting to Woodbury from New Hyde Park for the last 29 years.
"It gives me something to do," said Ms. Fiore. "And I really enjoy the people."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
'Redwood Curtain' on Stage in Croton Falls

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

DATELINE: CROTON FALLS

 BODY:
ON the streets of Arcata, a lumber town in Northern California, the playwright Lanford Wilson was startled by living ghosts, hovering in the light of day. "They just stared at me," he recalled in a conversation last October when his newest play, "Book of Days," was in previews at the Hartford Stage in Connecticut.
In New York, the lost silent men might be dismissively called bag men, those faceless street people blended into the contemporary urban landscape, no longer cluttering it, just taken for granted, passed over, even stepped over. 
 In Arcata such vagrants were also disregarded, but the playwright could not shut his eyes. Ever the investigator with the soul, and the gift, of a poet, Mr. Wilson became obsessed with this strange breed, abandoned by society. "The whole town was boiling over with them," he said, and he searched for their stories.
And he identified "them" as Vietnam veterans, which means all their different stories added up to one story, that of a country's shame.
Mr. Wilson talked of the "train walk." Sometimes "they walked down to the tracks onto the oncoming trains," he said. "Since Vietnam 30,000 committed suicide, and there are still over 100 groups around the country who get together to talk about their experiences."
So you thought it was all over. In Arcata, these men lived in the redwoods, and the playwright discovered that the West Coast "was littered with the debris of Vietnam." A master storyteller, Mr. Wilson created one in terms of a fable that would serve as a wake-up call for a forgetful America in 1993. That was the year his play, "Redwood Curtain," opened on Broadway after tryouts in Seattle, Philadelphia and San Diego, and that was just another year in the death of the serious new play on Broadway. "Redwood Curtain" lasted about a month.
In Seattle in 1991, "Redwood Curtain," an intimate play with three characters and lots of big trees, was envisioned as a candidate for Broadway, where it was produced at a cost of just under $1 million, but Mr. Wilson said then, "We'll do it somewhere smaller Off Broadway, and that will be just fine."
At the Schoolhouse here, very small and way Off Broadway, the playwright's alternative is realized, though it is not just fine. On Broadway, the original setting by John Lee Beatty was so monumental it became the play's fourth character without overwhelming it. The towering scenic design was not only a creation of theater art but also as much a visualization of the play's enchantment, exemplified by setting and by the character of the 17-year-old piano prodigy Geri, who is imbued with the gifts of her "very magical culture" (Vietnam) as of the environmental concerns expressed by Geneva, Geri's aunt, caustic social observer and heiress to a family lumber business, which has been overtaken by raiders of the endangered land.
Anyone who is familiar with the works of Mr. Wilson, one of the foremost lyric voices of our time, knows that his plays are far reaching (the cycle of Talley plays, including "Fifth of July"), structurally complex, sometimes just plot heavy and issue oriented.
"Redwood Curtain" is especially fierce to pull off; it is verbose, fusing mystical and very real elements into statements about a country's denial and the redeeming, healing power of music. It winds up with a cathartic musical coda by Erik Satie, a quiet moment of compassion and affirmation, but it's a long pull to get there; 100 intermissionless minutes, that is.
In its original staging, Mr. Beatty's enchanted forest and the performances of Debra Monk, who won a Tony for best featured actress, as Geneva, and Jeff Daniels as Lyman, recluse of the redwoods, justified the production's size artistically, if not economically.
In Lisa Milinazzo's staging at the Schoolhouse, the play's intrinsic sweep is not released from the captivity of its verbiage. In the most difficult role, Ann Hu as Geri is entrapped by the playwright's expository details and the character's precociousness.
Bostin Christopher is a one-note Lyman, the hostile castoff who Geri thinks may be her father. "I don't want people talking to me," he protests. "I don't know how to be with people." "Come home," the searching girl implores. "Don't you know you're a hero?"
Mr. Wilson makes it clear that Lyman represents the wandering, not the homeless, men who are scavengers, eating out of garbage pails, as they did in Vietnam. That's why they come to the forest.
"Army men are trained at great expense to be homicidal," Geneva observes. "My own brother came back a wacko." Yet, Geneva's sharp lines and off-center comic character just lie there, unseized by the actress Ellen David.
Mr. Wilson did not write yet another post-traumatic Vietnam shock play or, for that matter, one about identity crisis. He's too hip for that. As Geneva observes about Geri's relentless quest for finding not only her ancestry but also herself: "I thought we were finished with that in the 60's." His play is about family and memory -- short term, selective or buried. It is about being set free, individually and collectively. And spiritually.
Given the duality of "Redwood Curtain" -- a worldly, moralistic purpose and an other-worldly aura -- the play is a killer by practical standards. Mr. Wilson's apparently unreasonable stage directions were outmaneuvered by a television adaptation in 1995, in which Geri's adoptive father and his wife were written in. Yet, somehow the play was diminished by being so expanded. It is no surprise that an enterprising theater with a mind of its own has taken on a daunting task, a mission improbable.
"Redwood Curtain" by Langford Wilson at the Schoolhouse on Owens Road off Route 22. Performances through next Sunday. Box office: 277-8477.

HEADLINE: Learning the Lessons That Floyd Left Behind

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
WHAT lessons can be learned from Tropical Storm Floyd, a weather event so rare that it will not likely occur again for centuries?
A climate historian, Dr. Jerome S. Thaler, described Floyd as a "300-year storm," and Gov. George E. Pataki described it as a "200-year" event. And while some officials might reason that one can never be adequately prepared for such unusual disasters, Liam Murphy, the county's Director of Emergency Services, thinks otherwise. 
 As Mr. Murphy observed last week, the hard financial fact is that the damage from the storm cost municipalities and school districts in the county more than $13.5 million, according to the federal government. Arguing that the county is regularly hit by northeasters and other extreme weather, Mr. Murphy said no one can afford to forget the lessons from the devastation that Floyd left behind. "And that lesson is to be better prepared next time," he said. "The cost has been heavy."
The village of Ossining was hardest hit, with damage estimates of $1.3 million. Yorktown was next at $922,585; Yorktown Central School District incurred $728,796 in damage. Peekskill reported losses of $672,857. And Westchester's parks had $801,146 in damage.
"We're looking not to just fix things to the way they were, but to fix them so they won't break again," Mr. Murphy said. He cited the Saw Mill River, which he said stayed within its banks only in places where the Army Corps of Engineers had taken long-range storm-control measures like reinforcing the banks, grading and providing proper drainage. For example, the river did not overflow in Ardsley, where work had been completed to remedy past problems that allowed the river to flood the adjacent Saw Mill River Parkway, and in the process, strand cars. By contrast in Elmsford and parts of Greenburgh, where no reinforcement of banks have been done, residents witnessed heavy flooding, Mr. Murphy said.
To pay for storm restoration work, the county is also using $827,000 in federal Job Training Partnership Act funds. The county has hired 55 people who had been unemployed for 15 months or longer and is paying them $9.25 an hour. The workers are also eligible for long-term job training and career placement services.
So far, the new employees have cleared downed trees and branches, repaired pipes, bridges and roadways at 18 county parks, including Wilson Woods, Glen Island and Saxon Woods, and in municipalities like Ossining and Peekskill.
In Ossining, much of the early work focused on reopening roads and getting people back to work.
Even with all that out of the way, Lynn McCrum, director of community development in the village, said that problems remain. "Some residents' backyards are still a mess," he said, and road repair work and stream clearing continues. But he said that, according to federal government estimates, it often takes municipalities 30 months to return to normal after a storm.
Heeding the harsh lessons that Floyd delivered, many municipalities, like Mount Kisco, are taking stock of their resources and their ability to handle future disasters. The village's commercial area was hard hit by flooding, with about 10 stores closing in the storm's aftermath. And although most reopened quickly, two had major damage and were shut for several months.
"Even though we're not supposed to get another storm like this for 100 years, we're developing a plan now to deal with the next emergency, whenever that occurs," Mayor Patricia M. Reilly said. "We can get hit by hurricanes, tornadoes and other things, and we should know who is in charge of what and how we plan to evacuate people if that becomes necessary."
While governments prepare, homeowners would be wise to do the same, Mr. Murphy said. All households should be prepared to survive three or four days by laying in extra supplies of water, nonperishable food, which does not need to be cooked before eating; blankets and alternative sources of heat. "Why go to a shelter if you don't have to?" he said.

HEADLINE: THEATER;
A Master Storyteller's Post-Vietnam Tale

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN

 BODY:
ON the streets of Arcata, a lumber town in northern California, the playwright Lanford Wilson was startled by living ghosts. "They just stared at me," Mr. Wilson said last fall when his newest play, "Book of Days," was in previews at Hartford Stage. In New York, those lost men might be dismissed, faceless street people blending into the contemporary urban landscape.
In Arcata, such vagrants were also disregarded but the playwright could not shut his eyes. Ever the investigator with the gift of a poet, Mr. Wilson became obsessed with the men. "The whole town was boiling over with them," he said, and so he searched for their stories. He also identified them as Vietnam veterans, which means their stories added up to one of a country's shame. 
 Mr. Wilson described what he called the "train walk." Sometimes "they walked down to the tracks into the oncoming trains," he said. "Since Vietnam, 30,000 committed suicide, and there are still over 100 groups around the country who get together to talk about their experiences."
In Arcata the men lived in the redwoods and the playwright also discovered that they were elsewhere in the region. "The West Coast was littered with the debris of Vietnam," Mr. Wilson said. A master storyteller, he created a fable for a forgetful America in 1993. That was the year "Redwood Curtain" opened on Broadway (after tryouts in Seattle, Philadelphia and San Diego) and lasted for 11 previews and 40 performances.
In Seattle in 1991, "Redwood Curtain," an intimate work with three characters and lots of big trees, had been envisioned as a play for Broadway, but Mr. Wilson said "we'll do it somewhere smaller, Off Broadway, and that will be just fine."
At the Schoolhouse in Croton Falls, N.Y., very small and way Off Broadway, the playwright's alternative is realized, though it is not just fine.
On Broadway the original setting by John Lee Beatty was so monumental that it became the play's fourth character. The towering scenic design was not only a creation of theater art but also a visualization of the play's enchantment. A 17-year-old piano prodigy, Geri, is imbued with the gifts of her Vietnamese culture. Geneva, Geri's adoptive aunt, is a caustic social observer and heiress to a family lumber business that has been overtaken by raiders of the endangered land. The third character is Lyman, a recluse of the redwoods.
Mr. Wilson's works are far reaching (the Talley plays including "Fifth of July"), structurally complex, sometimes just plot heavy and issue oriented.
"Redwood Curtain" is especially fierce as well as verbose, fusing mystical and very real elements into statements about a country's denial and the healing power of music. The play concludes with a cathartic coda by Satie, a quiet moment of compassion and affirmation, but it is a long pull -- 100 intermissionless minutes -- to get there.
In its original staging, Mr. Beatty's enchanted forest and the performances of Debra Monk, who won a Tony as Geneva, and Jeff Daniels as Lyman, justified the production's size artistically, if not economically. In Lisa Milinazzo's staging at the Schoolhouse, the play's intrinsic sweep is not released from the captivity of its verbiage.
In the play's most difficult role (Geri), Ann Hu is entrapped by the playwright's expository details and the character's precociousness. Bostin Christopher is a one-note Lyman, the castoff Geri thinks may be her father. And Geneva's sharp lines and off-center comic character just lie there, unseized by Ellen David.
Mr. Wilson did not write yet another post-traumatic Vietnam play or, for that matter, one about identity crisis. He's too hip for that. As Geneva observes about Geri's relentless quest for finding herself: "I thought we were finished with that in the 60's." His play is about family and memory, short term, selective or buried. It is about being set free, individually and collectively as well as spiritually.
Given the duality of "Redwood Curtain" -- worldly and moralistic purpose, other worldly aura -- the play is a killer by practical standards. Mr. Wilson's apparently unreasonable stage directions were outmaneuvered by a television adaptation in 1995, in which Geri's adoptive parents were written in. Somehow the play was diminished by being so expanded. It is no surprise that an enterprising theater with a mind of its own has taken on a daunting task, a mission improbable.
"Redwood Curtain," The Schoolhouse, Owens Road (off Route 22), Croton Falls, N.Y. (914) 277-8477. Performances through next Sunday.

HEADLINE: The Internet May Be Virtual, But the Jobs It Brings Are Real;
Hundreds of Companies Have Moved In. The Trick Is to Keep Them Here.

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE

 BODY:
NEUVIS INC. is one of those shooting star companies specializing in Internet e-commerce business that everyone is talking about. Started last August, the Shelton software company has grown from six employees to more than 200 in half a year.
Sirocco Systems in Wallingford is another. The company, which produces computer hardware and software for communications networks, had four employees in January 1999; now it has 85. 
 The two companies are among hundreds that have sprung up with dizzying suddenness in the software information technology industry, one of the fastest growing parts of Connecticut's economy, and government and economic development leaders want to see more of them.
Mark Prisloe, an economist with the State Department of Economic and Community Development, said information technology revenues are expected to rise from $108 million in 1998 to $1.14 billion in 2003, when the industry will account for 2.5 percent of the state's overall business sales.
"It at least matches the tourism business in terms of gross state product," he said.
Most of the companies are clustered in Fairfield and New Haven counties, extending along the Merritt and Wilbur Cross parkways to Wallingford. There is also a modest group of companies in the outer ring suburbs of Hartford.
The state economic department said that since 1994 information technology companies have had employment growth of 20 percent. That growth is more than three times as fast as the rest of the state's nonfarm economy. Information technology stood at 73,558 jobs as of the first quarter of 1999, out of a total 1.7 million nonfarm jobs. These technology jobs pay on the average $68,146, compared to the $40,926 for the state as a whole.
"I never thought that you'd see Connecticut as a hotbed for e-commerce," Joseph McGee, vice president of public policy and programs for the Southwest Area Commerce and Industry Association in Stamford.
Although there are Internet companies around the state, Fairfield County is becoming the hub. Mr. McGee said about half of the 610 Internet technology companies in Connecticut are located in Fairfield County. He said it was because the county is richly endowed with the assets that make Connecticut attractive for software and information technology companies.
Priceline.com of Norwalk, which runs the Internet site where consumers name their own price for a variety of goods, is probably the most well-known of the state's Internet companies. It has 337 employees and expects to do about $1 billion of business this year.
"This is a company that could not have existed except on the Internet," said Brian Ek, vice president for corporate communications.
Mr. Ek said the two most important reasons why the company is located in Fairfield County is to be near the railroad and interstate highway so employees can commute from throughout the region, thus expanding its reach for technical talent, and because its chief executive, Jay Walker, is from Fairfield County.
Being near the New York airports also helps. "Access to a major airport, I can tell you that was a major factor for us to move to Stamford rather than farther up the line," said Dale Kutnick, chief executive of the META Group, a market consulting company specializing in the information technology industry.
Mr. Kutnick noted that Connecticut also has good schools, and rich cultural and recreational activities, and the state is a lovely place to live.
"A lot of people are shocked at how bucolic Connecticut is once you get outside the cities," he said.
He predicted that teleconferencing technology will make it increasingly unimportant for a company to be located in or near a city. He said some senior employees perform 40 percent of their work at home. This will make it easier for Connecticut to exploit its affordability, compared with more expensive centers of technology commerce like Silicon Valley.
"High tech is spreading. For affordability reasons it's easier to start a company in Connecticut," Mr. Kutnick said.
But the growth in information technology industry has created the same problem that other states in the region have experienced: finding enough high-tech workers to fill all the new jobs that are being created and keeping them here.
"I've had people who have accepted job offers and never shown up for work because they had other job offers," said Keith Reynolds, chief executive of a new company, Chatbroker.com, that is producing specialized customer service Internet software.
State Senator George C. Jepsen of Stamford said between 5,000 to 6,000 information technology industry jobs are unfilled just in Fairfield County. He said the state must entice high-tech talent to move here and develop more homegrown talent and keeping it in the state.
Last October, the state government formed a Software and Information Technology Cluster Initiative, administered by the Connecticut Technology Council, an industry association. The plan is to improve the competitiveness of software and information technology businesses in the state by having them share marketing expertise and work with government, educational and economic development organizations to identify their needs, such as for skilled workers and office space.
At a conference in Stamford last month, Gov. John G. Rowland, Mr. Jepsen and other state government officials met with software and information technology entrepreneurs and heard proposals to help improve the business climate for their industry. From those ideas legislative leaders drafted a bill, approved at a joint hearing on March 3 of the Education and Commerce committees, which includes paying the educational or moving costs for some computer employees who agree to work in Connecticut for five years, similar to how other states create incentives to recruit teachers for urban schools or doctors for rural areas.
The bill would also authorize the creation of special business zones where the state may help develop "smart buildings" that have the sophisticated wiring needed for Internet-related businesses, provisions for state colleges to enter into agreements with companies for training and business development purposes, and would allow the faculty of state colleges more flexibility for moonlighting to persuade them to remain teaching instead of quitting to take lucrative Internet-business positions.
Mr. Jepsen said skilled employees are the most important need of the new technology companies.
"Connecticut has, on a per capita basis, a very highly trained work force, but we need more of those workers," he said.
In fact, when Priceline.com looked for a new location, having had to move out of Stamford because of that city's shortage of commercial space, it chose a building close to Norwalk Community and Technical College expecting to create a relationship with the college and hire its graduates, Mr. Jepsen said.
"We're hearing numbers like 50,000 workers are going to be needed in the next five years" in Internet-related businesses in Connecticut, said Jeffrey Cantor, dean of extended studies and work force education at the Norwalk College.
Mr. Cantor said the college has signed agreements with several technology companies to provide specialized training for employees in networking technologies and software development, and is expanding course offerings in those areas.
While Connecticut has its share of people with computer expertise, that isn't the whole reason for the state's success. Instead, entrepreneurs mentioned its wealth in experienced marketing and managerial executives, its location near several international airports, its financial services and venture capital investors, and its quality of life as other important factors.
The fact that there are already many companies engaged in e-commerce, software development, and information technology creates a talent pool for each new venture.
"There's something of a critical mass building," said Will McEachern, editor of The Connecticut Economy, a quarterly journal published at the University of Connecticut that follows the state's economy.
"If you look under the covers of many of these companies you will find a lot of people who started other companies," said Connie Galley, president and chief executive of Mercator Software in Wilton, whichproduces software that allows other computer programs to work with each other.
"There's a history of R and D companies in this area," observed Arum Gupta, the software entrepreneur who started NeuVis Inc., which makes software for companies that want to sell their products on the Internet. "I think some of the people who work for them have decided to take the jump and start up."
Mr. Jepsen, however, noted that the state had a problem in attracting young men and women with technology skills: it isn't cool. He said the state has more of a country squire image than of a hip, urban lifestyle, and it will have to change its image by providing more night life if it wants to attract and keep recent university graduates.
Another need is for technology incubators. These are start-up campuses, buildings that are wired for fast Internet connections and laid out like lofts, where the high-tech companies can swap ideas and work together at a reasonable cost.
"There's a lot of ideas that are being brainstormed and discussed," he said. "We have to act quickly because speed is a real hallmark of the Internet business."
Ms. Galley noted that the conference in Stamford sent that message to officials who attended. "What I think everyone took home was how fast we have to move, how fast we have to make decisions."
