LENGTH: 2834 words

HEADLINE: J.F.K. Enters the Era of the Megaterminal

BYLINE: By DAVID W. DUNLAP 

 BODY:
AFTER years of failed promises and false starts, it seems that there is a tunnel at the end of the tunnel at Kennedy International Airport.
The tunnel in question will run out to a new kind of building at Kennedy: a midfield concourse that will substantially add to the capacity of Terminal 8, a 57-gate giant for American Airlines that will dwarf its predecessors. In January, workers began disentangling utility lines around the 107-acre site, setting the stage for a seven-year, $1.3 billion construction project. 
 Across the field, in mid-February, the first passengers arrived at the west concourse of the new International Air Terminal. The structural framework of its departures and retail hall -- so vast that Union Square Park could fit under the gently bowed roof -- was topped off three weeks later. And all around these construction sites, looking (and sprouting) like mushrooms, are 326 columns for the AirTrain light-rail system that will link the terminals to one another and to mass transit stations in Queens.
Though Kennedy is still saddled with a well-earned reputation as one of the least hospitable of the world's transportation hubs, the early results of its $9 billion makeover have become remarkably visible.
None of this will untangle the politics. The Giuliani administration wants to wrest control of Kennedy from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey, which runs the airport on a lease from the city, as it has since opening day in 1948. The authority says it has no intention of giving up control.
But the squabbling has not visibly impeded the first significant transformation of the airport since the Eisenhower era, when Terminal City took form, giving each airline its own distinctive architectural presence, rather like a collection of World's Fair pavilions. "They had their logic, and they had their time," said Barry Abramowitz, the assistant director of the aviation capital program at the Port Authority. "We're now past that."
In their place will rise a ring of megaterminals, diaphanous arenas with airfoil roof lines, connected to parking garages and the elevated AirTrain stations.
Terminal 1 opened in 1998 and now serves 11 airlines. It will be eclipsed next year by the International Air Terminal, Terminal 4, which will dominate the field until 2006, when American finishes Terminal 8. That may be rivaled by a Delta Air Lines terminal next to and perhaps linked with Terminal 4.
"Delta wants to make New York City one of its major terminals and destinations in the eastern United States and is committed to developing a very substantial project," said D. Kent Turner, a senior principal in Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, the architectural firm that is working on plans for the area around Terminals 2 and 3.
William Nicholas Bodouva & Associates, the architects for Terminal 1, are working with United Airlines and the new airline JetBlue on the area around Terminal 5 and Terminal 6, which they share.
At the same time, British Airways is expanding and renovating Terminal 7. The $220 million project, designed by Corgan Associates, will add 83,000 square feet of space to the 30-year-old structure, in part by extending the building forward and connecting it to a new parking deck.
In front of Terminal 7, construction crews are erecting one of the elevated sections of guideway for the AirTrain system.
The first 5.3-mile leg of AirTrain is to open in 2002 with service from eight stations around Kennedy to and from the A train stop at Howard Beach, Queens. By 2003, AirTrain is expected to reach Jamaica, Queens, on an elevated guideway along the median of the Van Wyck Expressway.
AirTrain is being designed, built, operated and maintained for the Port Authority by the AirRail Transit Consortium, led by Bombardier Transportation of Canada and Skanska (U.S.A.), a unit of the Swedish construction and development company. The architects and engineers are STV Inc.
Three years from now, travelers departing from Manhattan will be able to reach Kennedy on the Long Island Rail Road or the subway, transferring to AirTrain for a trip around the terminals. Passengers bound for Terminal 4 will get off AirTrain in the building itself, since it incorporates a station on the mezzanine.
EASE of access is a common theme among the projects. As concourses expand to serve ever-larger aircraft, "Kennedy is going to be a place of moving walkways," said Ted D. Kleiner, the program director for the redevelopment of the airport.
Travelers will increasingly find ticket counters set like islands in the middle of check-in areas, rather than arrayed along the back like a hurdle. Broad open spaces, skylights and glass walls will delineate the travel paths -- first to the shopping centers and then to the aircraft gates beyond -- even for those who cannot read the signs.
"The structure will assist the passengers in wayfinding," said Ashok Raiji, a principal in Ove Arup & Partners, the consulting engineers on the International Air Terminal and the British Airways projects.
"You can see the tails of the aircraft sitting out there on the apron," added Gregory Hodkinson, another principal at Arup.
It is no coincidence that every new terminal seems to have a swooping roof. "We want big open spaces," Mr. Hodkinson said. "If you have that, an efficient form is the curve, because you can get the arch action of the trusses. People are drawn by the shape of the roof to get to the other side, which is just where we want them to go."
Clear travel paths contribute to security, said Mr. Abramowitz of the Port Authority. "There's no place to hide without sticking out like a sore thumb," he said. "There's no reason for anyone to dally."
Unless it is to shop. Stores and restaurants are proliferating in the areas between check-in counters and departure gates. "Retailing in the 60's was a modest convenience, not a product of having to arrive two or three hours before a flight," Mr. Kleiner said. "Marketers have found an opportunity that's there to be captured."
Terminals must grow vertically since real estate is such a scarce resource at Kennedy. "Ultimately, you run out of places to park aircraft," Mr. Hodkinson said. The central terminal area is bounded on the north, east and south by runways, including 13R-31L, a 2.8-mile stretch that is the longest commercial runway in North America and a formidable barrier to expansion.
Only on the west could a 40-acre building site be created for American Airlines by realigning taxiways. But even there, much of the new terminal will rise on the site of the old buildings, which must remain in service while construction is under way.
That is also the case at Terminal 4, which is being built in, around and alongside the International Arrivals Building of 1957, a process not unlike performing open-heart surgery on a patient who is simultaneously running a marathon.
The parabolic arch over the old arrivals hall has already been demolished, as has the old west concourse, and the rest of the structure will soon follow.
The current Terminal 8, built by American in 1960, is doomed, although the airline plans to salvage in some form the 317-foot-long abstract stained-glass facade by Robert Sowers. Terminal 9 next door, built for United Airlines in 1959, will also be razed.
The Eastern terminal of 1959 was demolished to make way for Terminal 1, which was developed by Air France, Japan Airlines, Korean Air and Lufthansa German Airlines. Also high on the endangered-species list are Terminal 6, by I. M. Pei & Partners, and Terminal 3, the former Pan Am Worldport, an umbrellalike structure designed by Tippetts-Abbett-McCarthy-Stratton, now TAMS Consultants.
In fact, when the dust clears, only one building may remain from the original Terminal City complex at what was once Idlewild: Eero Saarinen's T.W.A. Flight Center of 1962, now called Terminal 5. Were it not an internationally renowned architectural icon and a designated landmark, there is little doubt that Terminal 5 -- woefully small and outdated -- would have been swept away, too.
Mr. Kleiner said the Port Authority had "accepted the challenge of developing plans which would provide for keeping the most well-known exterior visual image and interior spaces of the main building."
Port Authority planners are not unmindful of Terminal City's positive legacy. "We are trying to recreate that whole verve and excitement that you're entering the world's greatest gateway," said William R. DeCota, the director of the aviation department.
The Giuliani administration believes that little good -- and not enough revenue -- come from the authority's stewardship of Kennedy and La Guardia Airports. "They are two of the worst airports in America, for large airports," Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani said last year. "This is the worst form of a government bureaucracy that is running something that should be run by private enterprise."
In January, four groups responded to the city's search for a private operator to serve as a consultant until 2015 and then take over management of the airports after the Port Authority's lease expires.
One respondent was the group that is now building Terminal 4, a consortium composed of Schiphol U.S.A., the American subsidiary of the Dutch company that runs Schiphol Airport in Amsterdam; LCOR, a New York developer, and Lehman Brothers.
OTHER responses came from B.A.A., the private successor to the British Airport Authority, which operates 14 airports including Heathrow and Indianapolis; Hochtief AirPort, a German company that runs the Dusseldorf airport and is developing a new airport in Athens, and the Zurich Airport company.
"The response reflects a very healthy appetite on the part of the bidders to participate in the running of the airports and the privatization of the airports," said Michael G. Carey, the president of the New York City Economic Development Corporation.
"We're very excited about that," Mr. Carey said. "It confirms that we're going in the right direction."
Not in the eyes of the Port Authority, which opposes wholesale privatization, even though it has handed over many smaller functions to private operators. "The Port Authority has retained control of all the common elements," Mr. DeCota said. "We've operated the airports, in the public interest, as a system."
"People think the Port Authority is ignoring Kennedy, but $9 billion is real," Mr. DeCota said. According to the Port Authority, about $5.1 billion is being spent on passenger terminals, $600 million on cargo terminals, $1.5 billion on AirTrain and $1.8 billion on runways, taxiways, roads, parking garages and utilities.
And even as it excoriates the Port Authority, the Giuliani administration has played a role in the redevelopment, most recently by providing access for American Airlines to the tax-exempt bond market, through the sale of $1.3 billion in bonds issued by the city's Industrial Development Agency. Because proceeds from a municipal bond are exempt from federal, state and city taxes, they carry a lower interest rate, which makes them attractive to borrowers.
Given the uncertain nature of Kennedy's future, American has had to negotiate one lease with the Port Authority and a "mirror" lease with New York City, guaranteeing that its terms of occupancy would continue should the airport revert to municipal control in 2015 or earlier.
The second lease is under review, said Gary J. Pelletier, the project manager in the airline's corporate real estate department.
But the work is already under way. The first challenge is to move utility lines. This is not simply a matter of an electrical conduit here and a gas pipe there, but of storm sewers 12 feet wide. "We're actually relocating culverts," Mr. Pelletier said.
Besides its sheer volume -- at 2.2 million square feet it will be almost 50 percent larger than Terminal 4 -- the American gateway will also be distinctive in the layout of its concourses, which are parallel to the roadway rather than perpendicular.
The first two concourses will form the legs of an H whose crossbar contains the arrivals area on the lower level and the departures hall on the upper level. The third concourse will be an island in the middle of the apron, reached by moving sidewalk through a 420-foot-long tunnel.
Given the height of the water table, about six or seven feet below grade, the tunnel has to be designed to withstand immersion and also to defeat its natural buoyancy.
Construction of the midfield concourse will begin next year. Its opening will permit demolition to proceed on the old buildings. "At one point, you'll have one new and two existing terminals running," said Edmund A. Narbutas, managing principal in the New York office of Daniel, Mann, Johnson & Mendenhall, the architect for Terminal 8.
The midfield concourse is intended primarily for domestic traffic, while the concourse closest to the roadway will serve the commuter jets of American Eagle. The intermediate concourse will have room for 10 Boeing 747-400's at one time. This will allow American to accommodate its partners in the OneWorld Alliance, like Finnair and Qantas, Mr. Pelletier said.
As recently as three years ago, American intended to keep its older terminals and to build a new center concourse at the midpoint between them, where it had earlier built a connecting structure, designed by Murphy/Jahn and engineered by Arup.
That was the first project at Kennedy for Arup, one of a number of architectural and engineering firms that are not widely known by the general public but are very active and influential in airport design.
Arup has worked on some of the largest-scale airport development projects of the late 20th century, including Chek Lap Kok Airport in Hong Kong and Kansai International Airport in Osaka, Japan.
Sir Ove Arup, a Danish engineer, founded the firm in London in 1946, focusing first on the reconstruction of Europe after World War II. Arup attracted international attention in the early 1970's for engineering the audacious Sydney Opera House, designed by Jorn Utson. The firm now has nearly 6,000 employees in offices around the world.
It is associated on the Terminal 4 project with Skidmore, Owings & Merrill and TAMS Consultants, which was also responsible for the concept of the new American Airlines terminal, now being refined by Daniel, Mann, Johnson & Mendenhall.
Terminal 4 breaks the mold by extending far into the central parking area, a suggestion made early on by Paul Fernandez, a Port Authority architect, in part to preserve precious apron space for airliners.
Pushing the terminal forward allowed it to incorporate an AirTrain station that is structurally independent from the building that surrounds it. "When you stand here, you won't feel the train there," said Nancy Hamilton, a senior associate at Arup, as she walked through what will be the customs checkpoint, directly under the tracks.
THE arrivals hall extends under and beyond the elevated roadway leading to the departures hall, meaning that travelers will be greeted by a wall of glass rather than the underside of a viaduct. But they will no longer be greeted by Alexander Calder's 40-foot "Flight" mobile, which used to hang in the International Arrivals Building. That is to be moved upstairs.
Vast as the terminal already is, it has been designed to permit future enlargement. "Who knows what's around the corner?" said Mr. Raiji of Arup. "You have to build with flexibility in mind."
For the moment, Terminal 4 is a crazy-quilt hybrid of the new and old. Although the project is not scheduled for completion until May 2001, the spacious west concourse opened for service Feb. 11 with the arrival of an Air India flight.
As a commercial real estate venture, Terminal 4 is competing for tenants just as an office tower would. David A. Sigman, a senior vice president of LCOR, said the developers expected to sign seven-year leases next week with their first tenants: Sabena, Swissair and TAP-Air Portugal.
Terminal 1, which has been open since May 1998, has seven tenants besides the airlines that built it. They are Air Afrique, Austrian Airlines, Olympic Airways, Royal Air Maroc, Singapore Airlines, Turkish Airlines and Virgin Atlantic Airways.
"We're happy to say we're the cream right now," said August F. Vettorino of Terminal 1 Management Inc.
Although it will end up as the smallest of the new passenger buildings, Terminal 1 affords a preview of the future at Kennedy, with four ticketing islands set into a spacious departures hall. The passport control area and the "sterile" corridor leading to it are suffused with daylight.
There is also a pleasant throwback to the days when observation decks were the rage. The upstairs food court offers views out to the taxiways and Runway 13R-31L. "You can sit and look out airside," Mr. Kleiner said, as a Royal Air Maroc 747 pushed away from the gate, "which you haven't had a chance to do for many years."

HEADLINE: SOAPBOX;
In Times Square, Waiting for Korn

BYLINE: By THOMAS HINE; Thomas Hine is author of "The Rise and Fall of the American Teenager," published last fall by Bard/Avon.

 BODY:
IT'S rare in contemporary America that anyone who has dollars to spend is ever made to feel unwelcome. But, as is often the case, the situation is slightly different for teenagers.
The new family-friendly, media-manic Times Square is beset, an article in The New York Times reported recently, by a new youth problem: truants with money. These are high school and middle school students from New York and its suburbs who skip classes for a day, often with their parents' blessing, to spend a day at the center of their culture. They stand outside MTV's window in hopes of getting on camera while they wait for 'N Sync or Korn to arrive. Or they line up at Virgin to get their favorite stars' autographs on a new compact disc. 
 And some of them, though not very many, get arrested.
As bad news goes, this doesn't seem earthshaking. Their behavior is at worst, mildly mischievous. The really troubled youth -- abused runaways, prostitutes, drug abusers -- have moved to other, less visible places.
The illusion of Times Square is that you can stand there and see the new world taking shape before your very eyes. It is a magnet for the young. And unlike many other contemporary environments, it is a place where they fit in comfortably and have a role to play.
Almost six decades ago, Times Square played an important role in the emergence of the distinct creature we now call the teenager. Frank Sinatra's concerts at the Paramount Theater in 1942, and especially in 1944, tied up traffic on the West Side for weeks, and demonstrated that young people were a significant force in the culture and in the economy.
Even earlier, in the mid-19th century, young people in their teens who made their living as messengers, newsboys and other members of the information proletariat of that era provided the clientele for hundreds of cheap theaters and music halls found throughout the city. (They also provoked a backlash in the form of the New York Society for the Suppression of Vice and its leader, Anthony Comstock. He argued that censoring the amusements of the young would save money on penitentiary-building later.)
In Horatio Alger's novels, the East Side street boy's first step to respectability was to stop going to theaters and use the admission money to open a savings account. The streets of New York aren't as filled with teenagers earning money as they were a century ago, but many young people have jobs. The difference is that we can scarcely imagine that they might save some of the money they make.
It is an article of faith that we consume our way to prosperity, and teenagers are our purest consumers. The money they spend -- $141 billion last year -- has few strings attached. It is spent on cars, clothes and entertainment. The economy depends on the young to embrace new things and keep fashions churning.
In a sense these new truants are doing exactly what today's Times Square invites them to do. It is a little risky to skip school, but they're not likely to be stopped as long as they stay in groups and don't go far from the places that need them to provide excitement. Their energy and their willingness to spend help create the scene that has made New York newly attractive and prosperous. MTV needs them outside that window in order to put on a good show.
Many young people are eager to play this role, and who can blame them? It's almost the only way that people in their teens can exert any power at all.
In the past, people in their teens played responsible roles in the society and were on the threshold of adulthood. Today's teenagers look forward to a decade or more of preparation and waiting, which is a great luxury for some and a burdensome waste of time for others.
Adults mistakenly assume that the "job" of teenagers is to go to high school. It's not. The great task of adolescence is to figure out how to become a valued part of your society, a successful individual. The good news is that there are far more ways to succeed in life than there are to succeed in high school. But the bad news is that we don't have ways to help young people grow up by putting them in contact with people unlike themselves. We don't have ways to allow them to make mistakes that aren't catastrophic to their future. We have bureaucratized youth, then harnessed their inevitable frustration to power a lucrative, commercialized youth culture.
Erik Erikson argued that adolescents want to engage their moment in history. For most though, opportunities to do that are limited because we segregate teenagers in a world of their own. No wonder it seems to many that the coolest, most potent thing they can do is to stand at the MTV window, dodging the truant officers, waiting for Korn.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: NEW YORK UP CLOSE;
More Asian-American Businesses, Yet Few Seek Loans

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE 

 BODY:
For all of New York's famous assertiveness, its Asian-Americans are bringing up the rear when it comes to seeking loans from the federal Small Business Administration.
"The San Francisco and Los Angeles Asian communities are more aggressive than we are in New York," said Justin Yu, secretary of the Better Chinatown Association. "They participate in the political process, apply for government loans and are more involved in the mainstream than we are." 
 In fact, said Aubrey A. Rogers, the director of the Small Business Administration for 14 downstate counties, "in New York City S.B.A. loans to Asian-Americans have been going down," even while there has been an increase in new small businesses started by this group.
The agency hopes a new program will reverse the trend. "We are reaching out by going to business organizations that would more readily get to the community," Mr. Rogers said. "They make a translation of our programs in their language, in their newspapers, and get out the word on a more credible basis."
In the past, the agency has conducted such initiatives among African-Americans, women in business and other groups.
Mr. Rogers said the S.B.A. approved 98 or 99 percent of its applications, which are submitted after a bank has agreed to make the loan. For the 12 months ended September 1998, the S.B.A. approved 359 loans to the New York Asian-American community. But in the following 12 months, the number dropped to 272, despite general agreement that the number of small businesses in that community had increased during that time.
No one knows exactly why these applications for low-interest, federally guaranteed loans have eroded. Mr. Rogers said that, given language differences, "We've heard that they are not comfortable talking to the government."
Paul J. Q. Lee, a local businessman, pointed to a practice common among Chinese business people of lending money to each other through loose business confederations. He also mentioned the perceived complexity of Small Business Administration applications.
"I'm a college graduate and a second-generation American, and I have trouble understanding some of those rules," he said. ERIC V. COPAGE

HEADLINE: Happy What? You Wish!;
Every year, the lies get bolder and the liars get younger.

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
THE invitation last month promised a big birthday bash in a private room at City Hall, a TriBeCa restaurant. The fashion designer summoned nearly three dozen friends from New York, East Hampton and Palm Beach to witness as she blew out the candles on a tarte Tatin, marking what she announced was her 29th birthday. This was to be the last year of her go-go 20's, and she wanted the world to know.
There was just one problem. The birthday girl's arithmetic was off. 
 "How could she be turning 29 when we were in the same class in kindergarten and I'm turning 31," said one of her friends, who asked not to be named to save the birthday girl embarrassment.
The Big Three-Oh is a milestone that many approach with a mixture of ambivalence and dread. It marks the twilight of youth, a bringing down of the curtain on life's first act, and many chose to observe it very quietly or ignore it altogether.
But not so another kind of birthday baby increasingly common in New York. She kicks up as much fuss as possible, inviting friends and acquaintances to a blow-out. It's all a charade, because the real milestone being passed is 32 or 33 or 34, but this celebrator hopes to shave a few years off her age in as public a display as possible.
"A lot of women I know on the Upper East Side wouldn't dream of celebrating their 30th birthday until they are at least 34," said Kristina Stewart, the society editor of Vanity Fair.
Fibbing about one's age is nothing new, of course. Women have long done it, giving rise to the taboo against asking a "lady" her age, and the coy expression "a woman of a certain age," which refers to anyone from 50-ish to 70-ish.
But lying about age seems to have become more aggressive, more elaborate and -- most surprising -- the province of ever younger women, including many in their 20's who would seem to be so dewey with youth that lying should be unnecessary. Yet they do, at ever more tender ages. And men are beginning to join them.
Melissa Peregrin and Kristie Tippner, both 22-year-old seniors at Syracuse University, have already started telling people that they are still 21.
"For so long, we wanted to be older," said Ms. Peregrin, an economics major. "You can't wait to drive at 16. Then you can't wait to leave home at 18. You can drink at 21. But then after 21, it's all about buying beauty cream."
Her friend, Ms. Tippner, an advertising major, said, "I'm already looking at the lines under my eyes in pictures and it bothers me."
Meredith Hanley, another Syracuse student, who is majoring in public relations, is still 21. "I'm going to say I'm 21 until I'm 30," she said. "What's the advantage of being older? Your health declines, your husband leaves you for another woman and you can't find a job."
Somewhere Naomi Wolf, the author of "The Beauty Myth" (Morrow, 1991), is softly weeping. She and countless other feminists have spent decades trying to convince women, men and society at large that a woman's worth transcends appearances. But to hear many young women tell it, those efforts have changed little.
Twenty-something women who fudge their birthdays say they get the message that they must be younger, ever younger, to succeed at love, at work and in the marketplace as a catered-to consumer. And many cultural critics back them up.
"The Girl -- capital T, capital G -- is it," said Susan Faludi, author of "Backlash: The Undeclared War Against Women (Crown, 1991). "It is what is most valued and what is rewarded with fame and fortune, because we live in a visual, entertainment, ornamental culture. What is valued is image and appearance and youth, and it's what makes the consumer culture run.
"Look at Ally McBeal compared to the women on 'Cagney and Lacey.' "They were not conventionally cookie-cutter attractive; they were basically middle-aged and looked it. But now you're supposed to be middle-aged and look like you're 15. Ally McBeal doesn't look like any grown-up lawyer. She looks like a teenager dressed in career-mommy clothes."
Hollywood, our most potent image factory, worships youth on-screen and off. It is an industry that pairs over-50 male stars like Harrison Ford with under-30 love interests like Anne Heche, and it's a town where not long ago a 32-year-old television writer, Riley Weston, famously pretended to be 19 to get work on "Felicity," the WB show dealing with teenagers.
Actresses have always been expected to "play younger" than they really are, so their fictions about age hardly raise an eyebrow. But what is new is how many people in nonpublic walks of life feel pressured to play younger, too.
Deserving some of the blame may be the playground called the Internet. The business pages are full of dot-com wunderkinds who have made a million by age 30. Investment bankers bring home six-figure compensation packages in their mid-20's. So workers in other industries feel pressure to demonstrate that they, too, have achieved impressive success very early in life.
"If you're 27 and doing well, then it's O.K. to say you're 27," explained Stephanie DiIorio, who is in fact 27 and a restaurant consultant in New York. "But if you're not. . . .Well, let's say I could see getting to 30 and being 30 for five years."
Ploys to shave off years and deceive friends, lovers and colleagues have become more elaborate, like the 30th-birthday-party charade. Another ploy, useful to those in the public eye, is to give a fictional age to a newspaper or magazine; the fake statistic is inevitably picked up and repeated so often it becomes part of the record and a fact checker's truth. Taylor Stein, a party-loving young woman about town who until recently ran the restaurant Brown's on East 61st Street, told The New York Times she was 29 for a profile last April. Ms. Stein now admits that she fibbed -- and that she does so regularly when it comes to age. (Ms. Stein still will not reveal her age. "Age is a number; mine's unlisted," she said.)
"I think as your age goes up, your market value goes down, unlike real estate," Ms. Stein said. She admitted the foolishness of the effort: "It's all about insecurity. Do you think two years makes a difference?"
James Tully, 31, an artist in Manhattan, described a woman he dated for a number of years who had a remarkable ability to reverse time. "The first year we started dating she was 27, and her age progressed naturally for three years," he said. "Then all of sudden, when she hit 30, she went down to 28. I kept getting confused because she kept getting younger and younger."
Whenever he tried to pin her down, she would get upset. "She was so insistent, and unless you wanted to invite an irrational harangue, you would leave the subject alone," he said. "In my own mind, I'm keeping track, and she must be about 35 now, though she pretends to hover around 30."
Reached for a comment while driving down a highway in California, the woman insisted she had to pull over before addressing Mr. Tully's version of events. She promised to call back on her cell phone, but never did.
Last year, one group of Manhattanites who were classmates at the Nightingale-Bamford School, the all-girls private school on East 92nd Street, made a pact to collectively revise the year of their graduation. Instead of admitting they graduated in 1986, which pegs them as 31 today, these half-dozen women all cite 1991 as the date they received their diplomas, making them 26.
"It gives us more time," said one of the women in the group, who is single, doesn't work and volunteers on junior charity committees. "When you're not married and don't have a career, New York can be harsh on women. Men can be harsh on women."
Many women make no apologies for lying about their age. If society -- men, the workplace, popular culture -- is going to conspire against them, they reason, then they will make up whatever age suits them. Eve Packer, a tutor who works from her Manhattan home, said she lies always, changing her age each day depending on her mood. "I feel like it's a weapon used against women; it's like a club," she said. "If you're 29, then they look at you like, Why aren't you 19? Or if you're 39, then they say, 'Why aren't you 25?' People size you up by your age."
When Marie Claire magazine recently polled 100 men and 100 women about everyday lies they tell, Michele Lavery, the deputy editor, was shocked by the results. "The degree to which people lie unconsciously is really surprising," she said. The survey found that people lie about almost everything: whether they are working late, if they thought the sex was great, and yes, how old they are.
"Women only lie about being younger than they are, while men lie up and down depending on who they are trying to impress," Ms. Lavery said.
ndre Vasquez, 32, a home attendant from Paramus, N.J., has no qualms about pretending to be 25 to attract younger women. "I tell them I'm 25 so I don't scare them off," he said. "Young girls don't like older men, because they think older men are possessive and like to control young girls. I like them to think I'm o their level."
He eventually reveals the truth. "I tell them after I've been with them," he said. "After I've bought them things. You have to buy them things, then you have them."
Given that lying about one's age is so pervasive, and accepted in some quarters almost as a matter of course, can there be anything wrong with it?
Yes, said Sissela Bok, author of the 1978 book "Lying: Moral Choice in Public and Private Life" (Vintage Books). Lying about one's age puts one on a slippery slope toward more serious falsehoods, she said. "Once a person engages in a series of lies, then they have to keep telling more and more lies to support the first one," said Ms. Bok, who is an interim director of the Harvard Center for Population and Development Studies. "Now that they've started, it bomes very hard to stop."
Although small lies may not not seem to hurt anyone, Ms. Bok said, the liar is frequently the one who suffers. "People trust themselves less if they know others cannot trust them," she said.
Furthermore, Ms. Bok said, it erodes one's credibility on larger matters; once someone learns you've lied about your age, they will be disinclined to trust you on larger matters. All this lying leads to "a knd of pollution to society," she said.
And how old is Ms. Bok?
She hesitated a long moment.
Finally, she answered: "65."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 4; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1291 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Aetna Plans a Recovery; H.M.O.'s May Not Make It

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM 

 BODY:
MAYBE they should call it unmanageable care.
In just four frenetic years, the respected if somewhat stodgy insurance company once affectionately nicknamed Mother Aetna transformed itself into a colossal force in a much-criticized business, health plans. At the end of the rainbow there was supposed to be a gold mine of profits wrung from managing away the inefficiencies and excesses of modern medicine. 
 Instead, Aetna found itself the biggest target in an industry under siege. Its woes raise questions about whether the traditional H.M.O. approach to paying for health care has a viable future.
Last week, under intense pressure from investors who had sent the company's stock spinning downward and brought on the resignation of its chief executive, Richard L. Huber, the company adopted a new candor about its shortcomings and the powerful backlash against its specialty, tightly controlled managed care.
Rejecting a takeover bid by WellPoint Health Networks of California and ING Group, a Dutch financial services company, Aetna's new chief executive, William H. Donaldson, pointed to growing demand by customers and patients for "choice and empowerment."
Mr. Donaldson, an Aetna board member who spent most of his career on Wall Street, vowed to improve relations with physicians and hospitals and "do a better job of meeting the expectations of customers and patients." To that end, Aetna said it would split itself into two separate companies, one for managed health care and one for financial services.
Some analysts said Aetna's troubles portended the demise of stringently controlled health maintenance organizations of the type that Mr. Huber bought from U.S. Healthcare in 1996 to begin Aetna's transformation.
"H.M.O.'s are in a very precarious position," said Larry Feinberg, a partner at Oracle Partners, a New York-based health care hedge fund. "The model we all love to hate will become extinct in the next five years."
Managed care companies like Aetna have come under heavy attack in Congress, the states and the courts. Aetna alone is fending off at least nine class-action challenges to such fundamentals of managed care as the use of financial incentives for doctors who keep costs down.
H.M.O.'s have also found their efforts to contain costs outfoxed by drug companies, whose direct-to-consumer advertising stokes demand for expensive prescription drugs, driving up the health plans' drug costs. And patients are empowering themselves by clicking on an estimated 100,000 health care Web sites (who's counting?) offering everything from solid science to nostrums, and then bombarding doctors with questions that can stretch office visits and spur more tests and prescriptions. For these and other reasons, health care inflation is returning to double-digit territory after several years of restraint.
Meanwhile, enrollees have been voting with their feet for less restrictive types of managed care, which are now growing faster than H.M.O.'s. Empire Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New York said enrollment in its more flexible preferred provider plans rose 16 percent, to 2.6 million in the year ending last January, while membership in its H.M.O.'s fell 10 percent, to 230,000.
The crucial distinction between the two types of plans involves patient freedom. In a traditional H.M.O., tests, treatments and access to specialists are not covered unless authorized by a designated primary-care physician, a plan administrator or, in many cases, both. Preferred provider networks have none of those restrictions, and offer more freedom to choose out-of-network providers for patients willing to shoulder more of the cost themselves.
Many analysts predict a comeback for H.M.O.'s if the economy cools down and taming of the health cost spiral becomes a priority again, because H.M.O.'s are cheaper than other types of plans. According to Kenneth S. Abramowitz, an analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein, the annual cost of coverage for a typical family in an H.M.O. is $7,000; in a network of preferred physicians and hospitals, $9,000; and in traditional unmanaged health insurance, known as indemnity plans, $12,000. Those differences are usually mirrored in the amounts workers contribute from their paychecks toward the cost of coverage.
But while the economy is strong and labor markets remain tight, large employers, which still pick up most of the tab for their employees' care, try to please their staffs by offering a range of health plans of all types. "In boom times, an engineer won't put up with managed care restrictions," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, a health care economist at Princeton, though easily replaceable workers often have no choice, and young, healthy workers who are low on the pay scale still sign up for H.M.O.'s.
Liz Rossman, vice president for benefits at Sears, Roebuck, said 87 percent of Sears employees remained in H.M.O.'s even after the company added a preferred provider network that offered direct access to more doctors. One discouraging feature of the network plan for low-income workers is a deductible for hospitalization or surgery of $300 for single employees and $900 for families.
Employers and health plans are emphasizing choice. Honeywell offers workers a menu of different health plans, plus access to an Internet database describing the credentials and health plan affiliations for nearly every doctor in the country, said Brian Marcotte, vice president for benefits at the company.
After buying U.S. Healthcare and the health plans run by New York Life and Prudential Insurance, Aetna became the nation's largest health insurer, covering 22 million people. This includes 7.8 million in commercial H.M.O.'s, 6.2 million in point of service plans -- essentially, H.M.O.'s that also offer access to out-of-network doctors -- and 4 million in preferred provider networks. There are also 700,000 members in its Medicare H.M.O.'s and several million in the dwindling group that still takes part in unmanaged indemnity or fee-for-service plans.
Like its national competitors, Cigna Corporation and UnitedHealth Group, Aetna can meet the widespread demand for choices. But when it bought U.S. Healthcare for a high price of $2,500 a member, it acquired a hard-driving culture that transformed many doctors into adversaries in lawsuits and in lobbying battles in state legislatures and in Congress.
Doctors were especially incensed by a take-it-or-leave-it rule that required them to treat low-paying Aetna H.M.O. members or give up Aetna members in the more lucrative preferred provider networks.
"Too many of America's patients and physicians are already at the mercy of powerful health insurance giants who offer only 'take-it-or-leave-it' contract provisions," said Dr. Thomas R. Reardon, president of the American Medical Association, in a statement after the WellPoint offer was announced early this month. He said the association was concerned that merging insurance companies would have "too much leverage in their dealings with patients and physicians."
Without naming the medical association, Aetna's Mr. Donaldson told Wall Street analysts last week that the critical "reactions of many groups around the world" were on Aetna's list of reasons for rejecting WellPoint -- along with antitrust and market share problems, WellPoint's smaller size, and the "tentative nature" of the offer, which was conditioned on giving WellPoint a chance to delve into Aetna's books.
The challenge for Aetna, if it is to regain the confidence of investors and secure an independent future, is to discover a way to hold down costs and run its health plans economically without incurring so much wrath from doctors and patients alike -- if such a way exists.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 2781 words

HEADLINE: In Japan, The Legacy Of a Phone Monopoly

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO

 BODY:
THE jackhammers start their work at 10 p.m., and in this case, their rat-a-tat-tat brings a machine gun to mind. For the trench they are digging, which will be home to a state-of-the-art fiber optic cable transmitting data and voices around the globe, lies on the front lines of the battle for the heart and soul of the Japanese economy.
Operating the jackhammers are Japanese construction workers under contract to KVH Telecom, a fledgling telecommunications company financed by a unit of FMR's Fidelity Investments. They are laying a cable that KVH promises will provide better quality, higher speed and cheaper service than anything Japan has ever seen. And in doing so, they are creating a piece of the infrastructure upon which a new Japan will rise after a decade of economic decline. 
 Dictating how the trench will be dug -- and in many ways, discouraging the digging -- are Japanese regulators. They are only the most recent in a line of officials who have single-mindedly promoted the interests of Japanese business -- particularly those of the mighty Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, by many measures Japan's most formidable company and long its telephone monopoly. Their rules, which add months to every project, have made Japan the most expensive telecommunications market in the industrialized world.
On Tuesday, American trade negotiators will meet their Japanese counterparts here in what may be the last in a long series of skirmishes over Japan's regulation of the telecommunications market before the United States takes its case to the World Trade Organization. Other areas like energy, medical equipment, pharmaceuticals and housing will also be under discussion, but the bulk of the talks will be devoted to telecommunications.
Competitors and Washington contend that N.T.T. has considerable advantages beyond having been the only game in town for decades. Government regulation, they say, favors N.T.T. in the way that prices are set, in limiting access to rights of way and in severely circumscribing how various types of telecommunications carriers can do business.
The fight, however, is much more than a trade dispute. "This is not a battle between the United States, foreigners and Japanese, small companies and large ones," said Harumasa Sato, a professor of economics at Konan University in Kobe and a member of the government's Telecommunication Council, an advisory board of academics and experts. "This is a battle between monopoly and competition, old Japan and new Japan, the past and the future."
While similar fights are taking place throughout the Japanese economy these days, perhaps none is so pivotal. After all, it is the development and deployment of telecommunications systems, with their delicate glass fibers and light-speed switches, that is knitting the global economy into a seamless whole and playing a bigger and bigger role in the prosperity of individual economies.
The Japanese insist they are intent on becoming a critical link in the network and are working as fast as is practical to deregulate their market. The Ministry of Posts and Telecommunications refused to make any of its officials available for an interview, saying they were too busy.
And it is, in fact, getting easier to compete here; N.T.T. officials point to the presence of KVH and many other competitors as proof of that.
"I cannot understand why foreign competitors are saying N.T.T. gets preferential treatment," said Kanji Koide, a senior vice president at N.T.T. "The reason they are here is that the Japanese market is a level playing field."
But there is a general backlash against deregulation in Japan, as evidence of the economy's growing openness sinks into the popular psyche. Seeing a packed Starbucks shop on seemingly every corner in Tokyo -- often across the street from a struggling Japanese competitor -- raises fears among many that Japan is losing its identity.
So there are signs of foot-dragging, notably in the telecommunications sector. In 1998, then Prime Minister Ryutaro Hashimoto promised President Clinton that Japan would adopt a method of calculating interconnection fees -- what N.T.T. charges other carriers to hook into its local network -- that would make Japan competitive with other major markets around the globe by this April. Yet now the government says it cannot live up to Mr. Hashimoto's pledge, because dropping fees so far so fast would be "devastating" to N.T.T.
MEANWHILE, practical impediments to competition here have not been dismantled, adding immensely to the costs of any company trying to build a telecommunications system that challenges N.T.T. on its home turf.
Take KVH's trench. Construction costs average around $2,000 a meter, roughly five times what they would be in Europe and 10 to 12 times higher than in Latin America.
Why? The trench must be opened, dug and closed each night. All the soil that is dug out of the trench must be hauled away, and new dirt hauled in to replace it. Each night. The pit must be 55 inches deep, compared with 31 inches in Europe; the greater depth means steel plates must be used to reinforce the trench.
The Ministry of Construction, which imposes these rules, says they are necessary because Japan is earthquake prone and densely populated and its cities ancient.
The upshot, though, is that by the time KVH completes the first 66 miles of its network this month, construction will have accounted for some 80 percent of its costs. "It sometimes feels like we're in the construction business instead of the telecom business," said Akira Tada, KVH's director of corporate planning.
Further, though KVH's goal is to give customers service that bypasses N.T.T., it cannot provide such services without itself doing business with N.T.T.; the phone company, together with local power companies, owns the conduits that feed into buildings here.
So roughly 70 percent of the internal ducts that KVH will use must be leased from N.T.T. at an average cost of $70 a meter. In building a phone system, "speed is very important, and if we use their ducts, we get speed," Mr. Tada said. "We have to pay for speed."
At the end of one year, KVH has completed less than 20 percent of its network, far less than it expected. It has taken MCI WorldCom three years and dozens of bruising battles with regulators and building owners to wire two buildings. After trying to compete with N.T.T. for more than a decade, the Tokyo Telecommunications Network, or TT Net, has captured only 0.8 percent of the nationwide market.
"It's hard to do business here, but still the situation is much better than it was three years ago," said Mirei Kuroda, an executive at MCI WorldCom who recalls being summoned to the ministry at 11 one night when MCI was applying for its license. "But the ministry is still not supportive."
Despite all this, businesses are pressing hard for alternatives, and in doing so are forcing N.T.T. to respond. KVH, MCI WorldCom, Japan Telecom and others are laying loops of fiber optic cable all over Tokyo and Osaka, hooking up to buildings owned by major real estate companies like Mori Building and Mitsui Fudosan.
The buildings those developers own and manage were previously served only by N.T.T., but times -- and tenants -- have changed. Foreign financial service and law firms, proliferating thanks to deregulation in the financial markets here, are demanding high-speed, high-quality, fault-free telecommunications services at a competitive cost.
Mori Building is on the verge of offering its tenants long-distance service using MCI WorldCom's lines; over the longer term, it plans to give them a menu of carriers to choose from.
Hiroo Mori, a director of Mori Building, figures the cost of a long-distance call will drop by as much as 75 percent. "We think this will enhance our reputation and make us more appealing to tenants," he said.
But as Mr. Koide of N.T.T. notes, only business customers -- the most lucrative market for any upstart phone company, whether in Japan, the United States or elsewhere -- will benefit.
"They are only planning to serve customers who use a lot of international service," he said. "We have to provide service to everyone here, even when we don't make a profit."
Indeed, the Japanese consumer has figured hardly at all in the dreams of MCI WorldCom, KVH and the like, largely because the cost of reaching her is so high. N.T.T. is at both ends of 99 percent of local calls, because it controls the critical wires into Japanese homes. That means every time someone using MCI's network picks up the phone and calls someone else here, MCI pays N.T.T. an interconnection fee that amounts to somewhere around 40 percent of the revenue from the call.
Those fees are the core of the fight between the United States Trade Representative's office and Japanese regulators. Tokyo has proposed cutting them by 22.5 percent over four years; Washington wants a 41 percent reduction right away. Neither side is budging.
TO understand how interconnection fees affect carriers, take a look at TT Net, to date the only company attempting to compete with N.T.T. in providing local phone service.
Started in 1986 by Tokyo Electric Power in the wake of N.T.T.'s privatization, it faces few of the challenges that foreign carriers do, because it can use the conduits, ducts and rights of way owned by its parent. For the first decade of its existence, it served business customers and other telecommunications carriers that used its system end to end, capturing almost one-third of the demand for high-speed digital transmission in its service area.
Then, in 1998, TT Net began offering telephone services to households in Tokyo and eight surrounding prefectures, using a high-speed optical fiber network laid alongside the electric company's cables and distribution lines. It priced its service at 9 yen for three minutes, 1 yen lower than N.T.T.'s rate, and came up with some catchy advertising. By the end of last May, it had attracted more than two million customers.
But to complete local phone calls, TT Net had to connect to N.T.T.'s network -- and its profitability plummeted. Net income fell from 2.5 billion yen in 1997 to 300 million yen in 1998, then tumbled to 100 million yen in the fiscal year that ended last March.
"The cost of interconnection is a real and harsh one," said Hiroyuki Tsukamoto, deputy general manager of TT Net's corporate planning department. "It is the center of our problems." TT Net, of course, knew from the start that interconnection fees were high. But it started the service believing that the government planned to cut them this year.
Mr. Koide contends, though, that TT Net's problems are the result of a flawed business strategy and an excessive reliance on N.T.T.'s sites. "Charging 9 yen is uneconomical," he said. "We charge 10 yen and can hardly make money."
To be sure, lowering interconnection fees will be hard on N.T.T., which has been trying to find its footing since being forced by the government last year to spin off its two most promising businesses and carve its remaining operations into three parts.
The Japanese government estimates that its own proposal would slice $4 billion out of the revenues of N.T.T.'s two local phone companies, one of which is already losing money. Any further reduction, it says, would force N.T.T. to either charge its retail customers higher rates -- which would be all but impossible, politically -- or absorb the pain itself, since the law prohibits it from simply eliminating unprofitable service.
"On the one hand, we must provide service to remote regional areas at our own cost, and on the other hand, we are exposed to harsh competition in the more lucrative urban areas," Mr. Koide said. "We feel there's a contradiction in that system."
But Mr. Koide and the government are ignoring the experience of the United States and other countries where interconnection fees have been reduced. Competition has forced prices lower, and regulators have set up mechanisms to ensure that deregulation neither reduced service in unprofitable areas nor hampered the ability of local phone companies to make money.
Plus, the United States and others have raised questions about the numbers used in the model that Tokyo relied on in determining the impact on N.T.T. of cutting interconnection fees.
Depending on who is right, the extra cost to consumers could be as little as 56 cents a month, or a more unpalatable $3.15 monthly. If the costs were absorbed wholly by N.T.T., they could be just $462 million annually -- or as much as $2.5 billion.
While would-be competitors bicker over the costs of traditional fixed-line phone service, Japanese consumers have been voting with their pocketbooks, switching in droves to cellular phones. The cost of wireless phones has dropped 78 percent over the last 15 years; fixed-line phone rates have risen 13 percent in the same time.
The irony, of course, is that the biggest beneficiary of the switch to cellular has been N.T.T. itself. The company has a 67 percent stake in Japan's largest mobile phone carrier, NTT Mobile Telecommunications, or NTT DoCoMo, one of the two companies that N.T.T. spun off as part of its breakup last year.
Demand has been huge for DoCoMo's i-mode phones, which provide Internet access for about $2.83 a month. That is 96 percent less than N.T.T. charges for Internet service over fixed phone lines, a differential that helps explain why only 12 percent of the Japanese population has such service, compared with one-third or more of Americans, for example.
So in spite of the woes of its local phone subsidiaries, N.T.T. is a rich company. The value of its stake in DoCoMo alone is roughly 24.1 trillion yen, or $227.6 billion, and it also holds the majority of NTT Data, the data transmission company that it spun off with DoCoMo last year.
If N.T.T. were to sell just 20 percent of its DoCoMo stake -- which would still leave it in control of the mobile phone operator -- it would pocket some 2.5 trillion yen, or $23.6 billion, after taxes.
Professor Sato, the homegrown critic, likes to daydream about ways the company could use that windfall to promote competition. "N.T.T. could adopt the U.S. proposal immediately using this money," Professor Sato said, referring to the call for a sharp cut in interconnection fees.
"It could even afford to create a special incentive program to encourage early retirement, which would help it to streamline, cut costs and become more competitive," he said.
His argument is simplistic -- liquidating a position of that size would be tricky -- but it now looks like the ruling party may study a similar proposal. And Prof. Sato has a point: Far from emasculating N.T.T. by creating a market value for its component parts, the government gave the company a fat piggy bank it could use to numb the pain of fundamentally reorienting its business.
N.T.T. is not thinking that way. Rather, it is resentful that it was forced to sell even small parts of its prized subsidiaries.
"I would say that we could have done much better with DoCoMo and Data if we had full control of them," Mr. Koide said. "But N.T.T. had no choice in the matter."
FOR all its foot-dragging, N.T.T. can move at lightening speed to cut costs when it is threatened. In the last two months, several companies have announced plans to provide access to the Internet using a technology called A.D.S.L. that ensures higher speed and better quality than the system N.T.T. offers over so-called I.S.D.N. lines.
Within days of the first announcements, N.T.T. said it would lower the price of Internet access. In some parts of Tokyo, it will drop its fixed-rate Internet access charge to 2,900 yen, or $27.36, a month from 8,000 yen, or $75.47. N.T.T. had previously resisted widespread demands for lower Internet rates, saying they would be unprofitable.
"What we consider unfair is that if N.T.T. can afford to lower rates that fast in that business, why can't they reduce interconnection fees?" TT Net's Mr. Tsukamoto said.
Indeed, competitors believe N.T.T. will similarly slash prices for phone service by as much as 50 or 60 percent -- if and when they start to pose a serious challenge.
Of course, the more consumers flock to N.T.T.'s cheaper I.S.D.N. service, the harder it will be for the new, higher-speed technology to make inroads here.
N.T.T. is also starting to introduce the new technology, but given its investment in I.S.D.N., it cannot afford to have it become too popular too quickly.
"It's another bottleneck the Japanese economy must pass through to get into the new world," Professor Sato said.

NAME: L. Lowry Mays

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 4; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1020 words

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
What? A Quiet Texas Billionaire?

BYLINE: By ROBERT BRYCE 

 BODY:
WHEN it comes to Texas billionaires, L. Lowry Mays doesn't seem eccentric enough. Sure, he has a ranch or two, and he takes some nice vacations with a little hunting and fishing thrown in. But he just doesn't live as large as some of his peers. No monstrous mansions, helicopters or yachts. And no trophy wives or stop-and-start presidential campaigns.
Indeed, Mr. Mays, 64, is among the richest but least-known media tycoons in the land. 
 As chairman and chief executive of Clear Channel Communications, however, Mr. Mays has provided his stockholders with gaudy returns, averaging 64 percent a year over the last decade.
The company, based in San Antonio, is already the world's largest owner of billboards and, with its agreement last October to buy AMFM Inc. for $17.4 billion, it will be the world's largest owner of radio stations, too. The deal-making continued on Feb. 29, when Clear Channel agreed to buy SFX Entertainment, a concert producer, arena owner and sports promoter, for $3.3 billion.
The two deals are the latest of the media acquisitions that began in 1972, when Mr. Mays and Red McCombs (now owner of the Minnesota Vikings) bought a struggling San Antonio radio station. For Mr. Mays, buying media properties was always more about considerations like free cash flow than a chance to hang out with celebrities. He soon saw the efficiencies, and the attractiveness for advertisers, to be gained from consolidation.
Mr. Mays now oversees a media empire upon which the sun never sets, from gospel radio in Greensboro, N.C., to billboards in Beijing. Including pending acquisitions, the company will have operations in 32 countries and will own or have stakes in 19 television stations, 550,000 billboards and 110 entertainment venues. It will also own all or part of 1,100 radio stations, although some are being sold to satisfy regulators. For dessert, it will use SFX's agents to handle elite sports figures like Michael Jordan and Andre Agassi.
Even so, Mr. Mays presents himself as a modest sort. "I'm not concerned with how big we are," he said. "I'm not even sure I know what big means." Of course, in expanding the company, he has proceeded with a good deal of calculation. He buys radio and TV stations and billboards in the same market, then cuts costs and sells advertising packages across the three media. With radio stations in most major markets, Mr. Mays can deliver audiences that were once available only on prime-time television.
But Mr. Mays is starting to hear some static. Media buyers have begun complaining about the company's advertising rates, which, they say, have risen in recent months. The higher tariffs have led some advertisers to desert.
Kevin Gallagher, the media director at Starcom Worldwide, a unit of the Leo Group, the ad agency based in Chicago, said he recently advised a client to switch to television. Although Mr. Gallagher would not criticize Clear Channel's rates, he said, "at a certain point radio isn't worth it." Despite his reservations, Mr. Gallagher said Clear Channel offered an attractive one-stop-shopping option combining outlets like billboards and the Internet.
Other criticism comes from outside the industry. Andrew Jay Schwartzman, president of the Media Access Project, a public interest law firm that promotes broad access to electronic media, says Clear Channel's economies come at a cost. "They are done at the expense of local news and public affairs programming," he said.
Mr. Mays says those objections are misplaced. "We are doing more public service work within our communities than we ever have before," he said.
While Clear Channel's growth has caused some controversy, Mr. Mays's personal exploits are unlikely to stir much attention. A Dallas native who speaks with just a hint of a twang, he received a petroleum engineering degree from Texas A&M and an M.B.A. from Harvard. He has been married to his wife, Peggy, for 40 years.
They live in a comfortable, if not lavish, five-bedroom house in San Antonio. On weekends, they often retreat to a 2,000-acre ranch near Spring Branch, 40 miles north of San Antonio, where they raise registered longhorns. They spend much of their free time with their four children and 10 grandchildren. Mark, 36, is Clear Channel's president and chief operating officer. Randall, 34, is its chief financial officer and Kathryn Mays Johnson, 39, is director of communications. Linda Mays McCaul, 38, doesn't work at the company.
As the owner of 30.3 million shares of Clear Channel stock worth about $2.08 billion, Mr. Mays plans to give away much of his fortune. So far, his pet causes have been local or regional, including gifts to Texas A&M and to the M. D. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston. He and his wife have started a foundation that now has $25 million in assets; he hopes it will grow to $250 million. But Mr. Mays isn't ready to focus full-time on philanthropy just yet.
Instead, he is preparing Clear Channel for an assault on the Internet. By the end of next year, Mr. Mays predicted, all the Web sites of the company's radio stations will have streaming audio. That, combined with SFX's concerts, could let it offer pay-per-view concerts over the Web.
Mr. Mays says the Internet will become a growing source of advertising revenue for the company. "We have 110 million people a week listening to our radio stations," he said. "That's damn near half the nation. If we can move a portion of those listeners to our Web sites, we have the power to create more traffic than anyone else on the Net. We will have the most active Web sites in the country," he said.
Given investors' frenzied embrace of Internet stocks, Mr. Mays hopes the company's recent and future moves will help buoy Clear Channel's stock. It slumped after the SFX announcement, as some analysts questioned whether the deal would pay off.
And for Mr. Mays, the chance to hang out with rock stars is not much of a payoff, either. Nor with most of the sports stars. "I'd be embarrassed to play tennis with Andre," he said, but conceded: "I wouldn't mind playing golf with Jordan."

HEADLINE: Good Times Prove Brief for an Irish Factory Town

BYLINE: By BRIAN LAVERY 

DATELINE: MILFORD, Ireland

 BODY:
THE old Fruit of the Loom plant here is a short walk from the center of town, just past an elementary school, on a winding country road lined with stone walls and tumbling yellow gorse bushes. Employees used to joke about how the factory windows overlooked the white and black crosses of the local cemetery. Now the symbolism is too rich to mention without a bitter grin.
The plant is one of four Fruit of the Loom sites that closed last year in County Donegal. More than half of the company's roughly 2,000 Irish employees have lost their jobs in the turmoil that has accompanied its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing in the United States. 
 Because of its remote location in the north of Ireland and its proximity to sectarian violence, Donegal has seldom enjoyed prosperous times. But Fruit of the Loom's arrival in 1987 seemed a godsend. "People saw a light at the end of the tunnel," said Bridie Burns, who worked for 12 years at the principal location, in the town of Buncrana. "There was nothing else there."
Now, the locals' role as a tiny cog in the global economy has hit home. "The rag trade is a risky business," said Jim Sheridan, a county councilor in Buncrana. "People came to terms with the fact that a multinational has a certain life span."
Everything started on the right foot, as Fruit of the Loom acquired W. P. McCarter & Company, a textile manufacturer. John McCarter, who with his brother Willy had taken over the company from their uncle, described the combination as "a very willing and good match" -- a partnership to jump-start the local economy. By maintaining impeccable labor relations and a commitment to local communities, Fruit of the Loom tied itself to the region. It sponsored soccer teams and St. Patrick's Day parades.
Mr. McCarter and his brother were ousted from the company six years later in an episode that Ms. Burns compared to "a death in the family." But workers and union officials attribute the company's woes to vague management issues like poor communication and a failure to motivate workers, not on William F. Farley and his executive team.
"We can't criticize Farley, because he came from America and put this here, and we got 12 good years out of it," said Nuala Lynch, a union steward at the plant in Malin Head.
Only sewing plants have been closed -- leaving behind industrial operations like dyeing and spinning. Nearly all who lost their jobs are women. Now living on generous severance packages, most families have yet to feel the economic impact. But they are anxious about the future.
When she was laid off in January, Eithne Fullerton, 60, had spent 28 years working for the McCarter Company and Fruit of the Loom, earning a little over $300 a week. Her 27-year-old son, Patrick, who has worked at the Buncrana plant since he was 14, sometimes brings home more than $375 a week, but he is moving out soon to get married. Her husband hasn't worked in 18 years, after two hip replacements.
With unemployment in Donegal at 22 percent -- compared with a national average of less than 5 percent -- emigration again threatens to depopulate the region. The Irish government, which owns the closed plants, is busily courting new employers and hopes to retrain residents to work in tourism and information technologies.
Nonetheless, some of the laid-off workers, aware that Irish cities are thriving, say Dublin's efforts are too little, too late.
"We feel that the government have forgotten about this part of the world," said Ms. Lynch, 47, now working part time as a substitute clerk in the post office in Malin. "They promised us the sun, the moon, and the stars, and we haven't seen any one of them."

HEADLINE: Mr. Clinton's Journey to South Asia

 BODY:
With just 10 months left in office, President Clinton today begins one of the most important trips of his presidency. Though India, Pakistan and Bangladesh make up a sixth of the earth's population, no American president has visited this turbulent region since Jimmy Carter in 1978. In part, the long neglect is attributable to the cold war, when Pakistan was assigned the role of front-line ally against the Soviet Union while India got written off as a friend of the Kremlin. Today it is the tensions between these two countries that threaten a nuclear war, and the United States needs to re-energize its approach to their problems.
India is the first stop and showcase of Mr. Clinton's trip, as it should be. Since the acceleration of economic reforms in 1991, India has enjoyed impressive economic growth. Most of its population still lives in hundreds of thousands of small villages, while other Indians are developing software in high-tech centers for export to America. Appropriately, Mr. Clinton plans to visit both of these Indias, and to stop at tourist sites like the Taj Mahal. It has always been odd for the United States not to have a closer relationship with the world's most populous and diverse democracy, and the president's visit can move toward that goal. But while trying to reach agreements on trade, technology transfer and environmental issues, Mr. Clinton must make clear that his greatest interest is to see India and Pakistan reduce the danger of a nuclear confrontation. 
 In Bangladesh, which has also made economic gains in recent years, Mr. Clinton will encounter another reminder of the region's violent past. Like so many South Asian leaders of recent decades, the country's prime minister, Sheik Hasina Wazed, is the daughter of an independence leader. Her father, Sheik Mujibur Rahman, was assassinated in 1975, a few years after he led Bangladesh to freedom in the last India-Pakistan war. Mr. Clinton's visit can lead to further assistance to help Bangladesh fight disease, hunger and overpopulation.
But the trickiest part of Mr. Clinton's trip will come at the end, when he stops briefly in Pakistan. The visit was added in response to Pakistani warnings that a snub would encourage terrorist and fundamentalist tendencies. In a speech last week, Secretary of State Madeleine Albright said correctly that Mr. Clinton's decision must not be seen as a sign of approval for the military coup in Islamabad last year. Mr. Clinton needs to use his brief visit to press for a quick return to democracy and for military restraint, including an end to Pakistan's ties with terrorist and insurgent groups in Kashmir, India's only Muslim-dominated state.
By devoting four days to India and traveling throughout the country, Mr. Clinton may earn enough good will for some frank talk about Kashmir with his host, Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee. There can be no military solution to the Kashmir problem. India can take a step toward eased tensions by reducing its military forces in Kashmir in return for reciprocal action by Pakistan, including withdrawal of insurgent groups it may be supporting. In the nuclear area, both countries need to make progress toward signing a test-ban treaty and curbing deployment of missiles and production of fissile materials.
In his waning months in office, Mr. Clinton has a chance to nudge peace efforts ahead in Northern Ireland and the Middle East. Whether he can do so in South Asia as well will depend in large part on how effectively he handles this week's visit.

HEADLINE: THE NATION: Stock Answers;
Whose Economy Is It?

BYLINE: By FLOYD NORRIS 

 BODY:
THE old economy lives.
Just when the dull old stocks that used to dominate the economy appeared to be dead in the water, they took off with a vengeance last week. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 666 points, or 6.7 percent, for the week. 
 That's the largest weekly percentage gain for the Dow since the summer of 1984, when the average began the big week at 1,114, or only a little more than a tenth of the current level. In points, it is by far the largest weekly leap ever.
That move was welcome for investors who had avoided the technology stocks that have dominated the stock market, particularly during the last six months. Stocks in such industries as banking, insurance, retail and electric utilities were trading at their lowest level in a couple of years, even as the tech stocks zoomed to ever higher levels.
Moreover, stocks that are traditionally sensitive to the economy, like Caterpillar and Goodyear, were trading as if a recession were imminent, even though virtually all the economic numbers show that the boom continues unabated despite four rounds of interest-rate hikes by the Federal Reserve.
The fifth such move is virtually certain to arrive on Tuesday, but fear of the Fed seems to have faded.
One reason it faded is that the latest inflation numbers took on a rosy glow after Wall Street was through interpreting them.
"Outside of oil prices, there is nothing going on on the inflation front," said Bruce Steinberg, the chief economist of Merrill Lynch, who figures that oil prices will start coming down this spring as oil producers step up output.
"Market participants are wagering that Alan Greenspan, faced with continued good news on the inflation front, will recant," said Robert Barbera, the chief economist of Hoenig & Company.
But Mr. Barbera thinks that is wrong. He thinks that Mr. Greenspan, who has repeatedly said that Americans are spending too much, in part because rising stock prices have made them feel wealthier, is worried about the ways in which the stock market has changed over the last year.
Higher rates caused investors in the old economy to worry, but technology stocks have roared back after every plunge. That happened again last week, as the tech-heavy Nasdaq composite fell more than 11 percent in the first three and a half days of trading, then made up most of the losses in the final day and a half.
Meanwhile, consumer spending is running higher than most economists expected and stock market investors are borrowing money at a record rate to finance their investments.
It appears that mutual fund buyers have continued to pour money into the narrow group of funds that buy fast-growing technology companies.
If Mr. Barbera is right, then the Fed is likely to keep raising rates until the new economy stocks finally go down and stay down.
If so, it remains to be seen whether the old economy stocks -- not to mention the old economy itself -- can withstand the onslaught.
