PUB-DATE: March 19, 2000
Correction Appended

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3307 words

HEADLINE: Clown Prince of the Emerald Empire

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
ON Jan. 19, 1934, a fleet of black Packards glided to a stop at the Arsenal at Fifth Avenue and 64th Street, the headquarters of the New York City Parks Department. Robert Moses and his lieutenants bounded out. Within minutes, Moses had fired virtually everyone, and within weeks, he had marshaled armies of relief workers, architects and no-nonsense bosses to begin changing the face of New York City's parks.
Each January, Henry J. Stern celebrates that event with a media splurge he calls State of the Parks. There is live music, a slide show, food and remarks from the second-longest-serving parks commissioner after Moses, namely Mr. Stern. It is a massively self-indulgent display that hints at the complexity of this unusual public servant. 
 Mr. Stern, 64, points out that he will have served only 14 years and 9 months as commissioner in the administrations of Edward I. Koch and Rudolph W. Giuliani (in between, under David N. Dinkins, Betsy Gotbaum held the job), presuming he and the mayor fill out their current term. (Moses was commissioner for 26 years.) If Mr. Giuliani leaves a year earlier to be a senator, Mr. Stern could leave too. In any case, the career of one of the city's most enduring, colorful and visible public servants is winding down.
The two commissioners share qualities beyond longevity, among them an ability to increase the amount of the city's parkland -- only Moses acquired more acreage than Mr. Stern -- and a willingness to use every trick in the book to accomplish their goals.
In the Koch administration, for example, Mr. Stern threw up environmental and other roadblocks to kill plans by Borough President Donald Manes of Queens to hold a Grand Prix road race in Flushing Meadows Corona Park, even though Mr. Koch had signed on to the idea. During the Giuliani administration, Mr. Stern deliberately did not ask the Art Commission for approval of the yardarms -- nautical flagpoles topped by three flags (American, city and parks department) -- that he yearns to erect in every park. Only a lawsuit forced him to grudgingly seek appropriate permission.
But the biggest similarity to Moses may be visible success. With none of the federal dollars Moses cadged from President Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mr. Stern has unleashed thousands of welfare workers, made available by the mayor to do cleaning and maintenance. The parks are cleaner than they have been in years, thanks to a tough new rating system dreamed up by Mr. Stern. He has added more than 1,600 acres of parkland, more than he gained in the Koch administration and four times that acquired under Mayor Dinkins.
Mr. Stern has also quadrupled annual capital spending to $200 million to finance various projects, from a reconstruction of Foley Square in Lower Manhattan to a redo of the Orchard Beach bathhouse in the Bronx. Through complicated machinations, he has figured out ways to use money from the city's capital budget, which is intended for physical improvements, routine repairs and other operating expenses, thereby making up for cuts in the department's operations budget. The department can now replace the shingles on the roof of a parks facility without waiting for the entire roof to collapse and putting a million-dollar dent in his budget.
In addition, Mr. Stern has recruited more than 40,000 volunteers to help out in the local parks. He has passed out 10,000 cards making citizens members of the park family, and he is using events like cocktail parties to encourage young professionals to make city parks their first charity. A sense of belonging is the main objective, although financial contributions are welcome.
His most magical achievement might be planting beautiful trees, shrubs and flowers in 800 traffic triangles and street medians, something no one ever thought of before. His goal is to beautify a total of 2,001 triangles before 2001.
Today, Mr. Stern rules an emerald empire of 28,156 acres that includes 980 playgrounds, 614 ball fields, 35 recreation centers and 14 miles of beaches, staffed by 2,121.
Park advocates applaud the emperor's efforts. But they worry about a deeper, more insidious trend: the steady erosion of day-to-day support for parks. Mr. Stern has not fought the mayor on a succession of cuts in the department's expense budget, not even a $6.4 million slice proposed for the coming fiscal year, the biggest yet. Elizabeth A. Cooke, executive director of the Parks Council, a research and advocacy group, says the effects of these cuts are evident in the city's failure to perform tasks that unskilled welfare workers cannot do, like electrical work and tree maintenance.
Although she applauds Mr. Stern's efficiency and his outreach efforts, Ms. Cooke wonders why he has watched silently as what she considers basic needs go unmet. Is it because of his political loyalty? A bureaucratic mind-set? Her only answer is, "He wants to be commissioner very badly."
 
Captain Quirk Of the Parkship Enterprise
Although Mr. Stern has clearly accomplished a great deal during his tenure, his achievements are often secondary to stories of his eccentricities. In many respects he is a true New York character. He snacks on canned soup and cold peas, offering visitors tastes from his own spoon and appearing genuinely disappointed when they refuse. He falls asleep during phone conversations. He regularly prowls 99-cent stores.
"A lot of folks have the feeling he isn't always there," said David Lutz, coordinator of the Neighborhood Open Spaces Campaign, an advocacy group.
Certainly, Mr. Stern can seem obscure. He has devised a set of heretofore unwritten rules whose numbers he and his aides call out during meetings, to the bafflement of the unknowing. Many, like No. 20D, "the Don Corleone rule" -- "We've all chosen the business we're in" -- emphasize loyalty.
Sometimes the quirkiness has a sharper edge. Mr. Stern has been known to make racial and anti-gay jokes, often with little regard for who may be listening. More seriously, there have been a stream of employee complaints of racial discrimination. This is not uncommon in a large agency.
But now the federal Equal Employment Opportunity Commission is investigating a complaint by agency employees that blacks and Hispanics are victims of a pattern of discrimination, including reprisals for complaining. The case is being handled by the same lawyers who represented the boxer Hurricane Carter in his fight to overturn a conviction for murder. A class action suit is expected to result. Department lawyers say they are cooperating with the investigation and will answer any questions about a suit if and when one is filed.
A lawyer, Lewis M. Steel, said it was extraordinary for 20 employees to come forward at the risk of losing their jobs. "The claim is that the tone is set from the top and that there are certain practices for which the commissioner himself is responsible," Mr. Steel said.
But to the public, such issues usually get lost as Mr. Stern's impish image relentlessly prowls the morning news programs. Perhaps only Police Commissioner Howard Safir gets more publicity than Mr. Stern and his endless publicity stunts, typical of which was an event that involved releasing wood frogs, quail and screech owls into parks where they might once have lived, despite ecologists' complaints that the original environments should have been restored first.
With Boomer, his golden retriever, at his side, Mr. Stern is likely to show up anywhere, anytime, in an odd costume, from matador to toy soldier. He once cut a roll of toilet paper instead of a ribbon to celebrate the first flush of a new restroom.
"What can you say about somebody who dresses up as a tree and brings his own dog?" asked Councilwoman Kathryn E. Freed, a friend and sometime critic of Mr. Stern's.
Mr. Stern's outrageousness was underlined by a remark to a group of Chinese children ogling Boomer: He told them they could pet him but not eat him. One of his oddest habits is bestowing "park names" (he is Starquest) on more than 6,000 people. Given Mr. Stern's generally acknowledged brilliance -- he started school as a third grader and at 22 was the youngest graduate of his Harvard Law School class -- this habit is viewed as a way of calming an overly active mind.
Mr. Stern can also be a fighter. He wrote a law describing the destruction of a tree as "arborcide," an offense that would carry a possible jail sentence, and pushed it through the City Council. He has waged pitched battles against leashless dogs. He is considering the imposition of $1,000 fines for repeat litterers.
 
A Political Pit Bull
First and foremost, Mr. Stern is a political animal. He is also intensely loyal to Mayor Giuliani, to the extent that people not in current favor with the administration may be excluded from ribbon cuttings, even for projects they helped get off the ground.
"I wasn't invited to events at parks I paid for," complained Ms. Freed, an outspoken Democrat. "My name wasn't even on the program."
Because of this loyalty, Mr. Stern also sidesteps some fights that park advocates wish he would address. In addition to meekly accepting the budget he is given, he has not said a word against the administration's attacks on community gardens, a stormy issue around the city. His explanation is that he only fights potentially winning battles and works behind the scenes to persuade the City Council to restore the mayor's cuts.
Of course, Mr. Stern's empire pales before the great Moses machine, which rolled out beaches, pools and playgrounds with ruthless efficiency. Instead, Mr. Stern has presided over a shrinking agency, which now has half the number of employees he supervised during the Koch Administration.
He had hoped for more. Early in his tenure under Mr. Giuliani, which began in 1994, Mr. Stern spoke of returning the parks' proportion of the city budget to 1 percent of the total from about 0.5 percent. He had raised the figure to 0.8 percent during the Koch administration.
He condemned the cuts in the department's budget that had been made under Mayor Dinkins, and said chopping further would be like "performing liposuction on a skeleton." He said the city could not ask private donors to contribute to parks if the government itself was in full-scale retreat. He dreamed of recovering some of the 13,000 acres of the Gateway National Recreation Area the city ceded to Washington in 1974 during the fiscal crisis.
But if he fought for more resources, advocates say it was a very quiet fight. His agency's share of the municipal expense budget stuck stubbornly at less than 0.5 percent of the $37 billion total, even as the municipal surplus swelled in the wake of Wall Street's biggest boom.
Increasingly, private money is sought to fill the gap, following the tremendous success of the Central Park Conservancy, which was created in 1980 by Elizabeth Barlow Rogers. Mr. Stern has tried to replicate the conservancy in myriad different forms, with particular success in Prospect Park but limited success elsewhere.
"The mayor's constant message is that park maintenance, operations and programming should be increasingly dependent on private money," Ms. Cooke of the Parks Council said. "I am sure Henry Stern is as sad as any of us at the degree to which hands have been tied in the Giuliani administration."
Others see Mayor Giuliani as simply continuing a tradition of candidates' giving lip service to parks, then refusing to support them after being elected. "The parks budget now needs to be doubled, yet every other claim on the city trumps park claims," said Linda Davidoff, who as an officer of Citizen Action, an advocacy group, is fighting to change the way parks are financed, probably by a referendum on the ballot.
Mr. Stern's response has been to do more with less, and seize every opportunity.
When Mayor Giuliani briefed commissioners on his workfare program shortly after taking office, Mr. Stern requested as many bodies as he could get. The result has been 4,000 to 6,000 "free" workers, each putting in 28 hours a week.
To compensate for the erosion of his operating budget, he has dipped into capital funds to finance routine repairs. For executive help, he regularly recruits at Ivy League universities and gets wave upon wave of eager, cheap brainpower.
"I can make the parks run pretty well," Mr. Stern said when asked to name his chief accomplishment. "That's what I've done."
Many agree. "He's going to be rated as one of the best," Ms. Rogers said. Anthony Dapolito, who has headed the Parks Committee of Manhattan Community Board 2 in Greenwich Village since the Moses era, terms Mr. Stern "great." Rudy Washington, the deputy mayor who oversees parks, calls Mr. Stern "the master of government."
The mayor declined to comment directly on Mr. Stern's record. But when members of the commissioner's youthful brain trust meet socially with their counterparts at City Hall and grill them about how their boss is regarded, a typical reply is, "The mayor thinks he's really whacked, but he always says he is one of his best commissioners."
Still, Mr. Stern is sometimes kept on a short leash. Mr. Washington personally oversaw the much-praised redesign of City Hall Park and is doing the same thing with East River Park, another mayoral priority. The idea of having the city's Economic Development Agency direct the City Hall Park renovation was seriously discussed, Mr. Stern acknowledged.
 
Stern at the Helm of His Vessel
On a recent Sunday, Mr. Stern spent a typical day wandering the city he has known and loved all his life. He began by starting a race in Central Park. An anxious man approached to talk about owls in the park.
He then climbed into a green Parks Department utility vehicle and headed north. En route, he recounted the story of a life that began with a childhood as the son of emigre Jews from Germany and Russia (his father and mother, respectively), tossing out delicious details about a city that is mostly lost except in cherished myth.
"In September 1940, as war clouds darkened, they sent me to kindergarten at P.S. 152," Mr. Stern said as the vehicle headed to his old neighborhood of Inwood in northern Manhattan, where his father sold tents to would-be urban campers. "Then a sort of strange thing happened. They figured out I could read and write."
Young Henry was put in a precursor to today's special education classes, for "kids who were odd in some way," he said, where a vital part of his personality began to flower. He was charming. "The teacher wanted to adopt me," he said.
So did others. "I hate to use the word mascot," said Solon Beinfeld, a boyhood chum. "But there was a bit of that."
Mr. Stern eventually enrolled in the Bronx High School of Science. His next step was City College, where he was vice president of the student government. He entered Harvard Law School at 19.
When he graduated in 1957, he wrote Robert Moses and asked for a job. "I thought he was the most significant public figure doing important things," Mr. Stern said, "and I wanted to be part of it."
Moses never replied. Mr. Stern believes it had something to do with his Jewish last name. "Unlike Moses, I'm openly Jewish," he said sardonically, alluding to a much-commented-upon issue in Moses's life.
Despite his degree, Mr. Stern didn't want to practice law, and in any case he believed that Wall Street and Park Avenue firms would not be interested in him because he was a Jew, though a largely secular one. One day he told his dentist he was looking for a job. The result was a clerkship with another patient, a state judge.
The judge was a member of the Liberal Party, which Mr. Stern had joined in college. The Liberal identification, to which he has clung through most of his career and which has served him well, helped him land a job in the administration of Mayor Robert F. Wagner, who was eager for Liberal support as he fought the remnants of Tammany Hall.
As secretary to the Manhattan borough president, Edward R. Dudley, Mr. Stern attended community meetings every night and loved it. He became friendly with anti-machine Democrats like Mr. Koch, and the two went to Mississippi in 1965 to march for civil rights. Mr. Stern persuaded Mr. Koch to endorse John V. Lindsay for mayor, earning him a post in the Lindsay administration as executive director of the Parks Department.
In 1973, he ran for City Council, seeking one of two at-large seats. He won one and Robert F. Wagner Jr. the other. They shared an office, sold neckties for charity and delighted in opposing Democratic regulars.
As his vehicle bounced through Bronx neighborhoods near Long Island Sound, Mr. Stern repeatedly called headquarters to report graffiti, as he does roughly twice a day. A shabby traffic triangle was reported as a potential beautification site. Boomer sat at his side, watching everything.
At Orchard Beach, Mr. Stern presided over the annual icy dip by the Polar Bears, those intrepid cold-weather swimmers who once a year leave Coney Island for more northern waters. He seemed to know them all by name, and everyone petted Boomer. (For more than a year, Mr. Stern or an aide carried a clicker to record each pet. But four clickers wore out, press criticism grew and a dog in Virginia with 400,000 pets seemed unbeatable. The clicking stopped.)
His self-guided biography continued with his first stint as parks commissioner under Mayor Koch, who appointed him in 1983. Mr. Stern was not reappointed when Mr. Dinkins became mayor in 1990. Although Mr. Stern has expressed disappointment about that decision, he insists he did not have to be escorted from the commissioner's office to make way for his successor, Ms. Gotbaum, a story her aides tell. He says he just stopped by that day to pick up some things, although does not dispute that he kept a key to a city swimming pool for private swims.
During a subsequent stint as president of the Citizens Union, a good-government advocacy group then headed by Mr. Wagner, Mr. Stern began cultivating Mr. Giuliani, who had just lost the election to Mr. Dinkins. Mr. Stern also introduced one of his aides, Richard Schwartz, to Mr. Giuliani. Mr. Schwartz became one of his top campaign advisers and the architect of City Hall's workfare policy, and Mr. Stern returned as parks commissioner in 1994.
In his own way, he is now striving, or claims to be striving, for a more balanced life. He often arranges his cluttered days to include his wife, Peggy, a pediatrician who runs city health clinics in Harlem.
The Sterns have two sons, Jared, 22, a management consultant with PricewaterhouseCoopers, and Kenan, 19, a sophomore at Harvard. Friends tell of the time Jared returned from college and was picked up in a Parks Department vehicle by his father, who for some reason was dressed up like Louis XIV. After 15 minutes of silence, the young man asked, "Dad, why are you dressed like that?"
Mr. Stern says he would not presume to offer himself as a parks commissioner under another mayor after Mr. Giuliani leaves office. His goal, he says, is to be remembered as "a cheerful reformer." He particularly admires such 19th-century New York reformers as Andrew Haskell Green and Samuel Tilden. Why no 20th-century heroes? "Maybe because I know most of them," he said.
His last stop in the department vehicle was at the Hebrew Home for the Aged in Riverdale, where he visited his 100-year-old aunt, Dora, as he does every month. They time-traveled to a long-ago Stern household full of children and their friends, spirited music and even more spirited debate. Neither thought to mention Robert Moses, who was then bending the city to his dreams.
"Henry was always bright," she said, patting her nephew's hand. "My sister had smart children."

SECTION: Section 7; Page 6; Column 2; Book Review Desk

HEADLINE: Publish or Perish

BYLINE: By Valerie Sayers; Valerie Sayers is a professor of English at the University of Notre Dame and the author of five novels.

 BODY:

THE HOOK
 By Donald E. Westlake.
 280 pp. New York:
 The Mysterious Press/Warner Books. $23.95. 
 DONALD E. WESTLAKE'S new mystery is more than high concept; it is pretty much all concept, and its premise -- that two authors might be crazy enough to commit murder for the sake of a book deal -- may appeal to anyone who follows publishing. In the current conglomerate-induced state of paranoia, murderous thoughts are common.
"The Hook" has two antiheroes: Bryce Proctorr, a best-selling novelist who has a big contract but no manuscript to show for it, and his old friend Wayne Prentice, who has a manuscript but no publisher. Proctorr proposes that he submit Prentice's manuscript as his own; then they'll split the big advance. The only catch is that Proctorr is in the middle of a bitter divorce, and his estranged wife would grab up half his check, too, leaving him with nothing. So he imposes one condition: Prentice must kill Mrs. Proctorr.
The idea of killing a woman he's never met for a half-million dollars causes Prentice some little doubt, but he's been through rough times. His publishing career is at the mercy of the computer: small sales on one book mean a smaller print run on the next, which means yet smaller sales, and so on. He's resorted to publishing under a pen name while pretending to live in Europe, unavailable for editorial meetings and book tours, but now even his pseudonym's sales are falling. As the novel opens, he's investigating the possibility of college teaching -- a low point indeed, since it may land him in the Midwest,
far from his spacious yet economical Greenwich Village apartment. Even this reviewer, ensconced in a Midwestern university, feels his pain.
At a time when rumors about the real identities of some so-called first novelists float through the literary world, the novel's opening conceits are clever. Westlake doesn't play it for the satire, though: he concentrates on building suspense with as many twists and bends as a plot can endure. His characters are no-dimensional, so flat that the extent of their worrying about whether somebody deserves to be murdered can be measured by Prentice's line, "What if she turns out to be a nice person?" Later, getting closer to the bloody deed, he thinks, "There's good and bad in everybody." Maybe a truer thought has never been expressed, but it's hard to believe that this guy makes his living writing sentences. Perhaps to complement Prentice's unwriterly way with words, his wife works for a charitable organization but -- you guessed it -- she's not very charitable. There's no room for moral dillydallying in the Prentice household; it's off to the next plot points.
Some of the conceptual twists, especially those concerning popular writing, are very smart. Midway through "The Hook," you realize that you may be riding a new wave of pop fiction: meta-pop, the genre novel about the writing of the genre novel. One funny bit has Proctorr changing Prentice's word "winced" to "twinged" throughout the manuscript, which pains Prentice and reader alike. In an interview, Proctorr goes on at length about Borges's story "The Garden of Forking Paths," only to admit at the end that he's never actually read Borges, the master of the conceptual story. Book titles throughout -- Two Faces," "The Shadowed Other," "Double Impact" -- call attention to Proctorr and Prentice as psychological halves of one sinister reality.
But the sinister reality is not really explored (too many the concepts, too short the chapters). There are a couple of scenes that suggest what psychological issues are at stake: in one, without realizing he is about to do it, Prentice begins to beat a woman viciously; in the other, Proctorr follows a fan home and must decide whether to outdo his old friend in the woman-bashing department. Both are creepy and effective scenes that get for a brief moment into the heads of two men who have a slightly more serious problem than their latest book contract. In the best mysteries, moments like these resonate and make us contemplate not just the villains' capacity for violence but our own most frightening desires and dances with death.
But Proctorr and Prentice (proctor and apprentice?) have busy, glamorous, best-selling lives to live, and more narrative space is spent on their square footage, their furniture, their entertaining. New York is a concept city in this novel, bordered by Central Park West and the Village, with Connecticut lush on the horizon. A promising detective -- he has the makings of a real character, with at least two dimensions -- pursues the evil writer pair, but he is a working-class stiff and he fades away. Too bad: he's on to the really nasty stuff that can happen when ambitious men find their wives too grasping, too controlling. Donald Westlake is on to it, too, but he is very good at that concept thing he does, gliding along the story's icy surface, so that is mostly where he stays.

HEADLINE: Inspiring Taxi Drivers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The current shortage of taxis (news article, March 17) is a result of many factors, some of which can be alleviated. "Taxi crackdowns" by the police, license suspensions and revocations all take their toll. An applicant for a hack license must now take an 80-hour class that he or she must pay for while being unemployed -- and this includes veteran drivers who might want to return to the industry part time. 
 I drove a taxi full time for 12 years and taught hack license applicants, preparing them for their hack license tests. Were I to try to return to the industry I would be faced with this formidable hurdle. Issuing more medallions for taxis to sit idle is not a solution. Inducing workers to want to drive taxis is.
 
EUGENE WEIXEL
Kew Gardens, Queens

HEADLINE: $1 More for Middle Class

 BODY:

To the Editor:
A March 13 editorial calls for a "much-needed minimum-wage increase." You should define "need." In New York, those who will benefit have an average family income of $42,231 per year. The minimum wage is now a middle-class entitlement. Minimum-wage workers almost always live in homes with other wage earners. 
 If the $1 increase becomes law, the national minimum wage will have risen 45 percent over five years. Worse, Congress is mandating this national labor-cost increase without respect to local economic conditions.
Research shows that after a wage increase, and given price-sensitive consumers, employers seek applicants who have better skills and make fewer mistakes. One study found that teenagers and students, who are perceived as having better skills, crowd out low-skilled adults after such an increase.
 
THOMAS K. DILWORTH
Research Director
Employment Policies Institute
Washington, March 13, 2000

HEADLINE: Compressed Data;
Old-Line Law FirmLinks Up to the New Economy

BYLINE: By MATT RICHTEL 

 BODY:
Anyone doubting the increasingly mainstream status of Internet start-ups need only hear two words: Bob Dole.
The former senator and 1996 Republican presidential nominee offered the opening remarks on Thursday evening at the coming-out party in Washington for EqualFooting .com, a dot-com that plans to create an online marketplace where small businesses would buy industrial supplies, like plumbing equipment and hydraulic systems, from national distributors. 
 What has any of this to do with Mr. Dole?
He holds the title of special counsel at the powerhouse Washington law firm of Verner, Liipfert, Bernhard, McPherson & Hand. The firm represents EqualFooting and is making e-commerce a new focus. Last Thursday's party came after the firm's announcement earlier in the day that it was starting an Internet ventures group.
In the 10 minutes or so that he spoke, Mr. Dole praised EqualFooting and promoted the law firm's efforts to be part of the digital economy.
Indeed, the law firm's courtship of dot-coms demonstrates how little distance is left between the high-technology world, once staunchly unwilling to cozy up to Capitol Hill, and the inside-the-beltway elite, formerly dismissive of the Internet's role in the economy.
Marla P. Grossman, former minority counsel to the Senate Judiciary Committee and now director of Verner Liipfert's Internet group, contends that her firm can wield its influence in Washington to help Internet interests "use the resources of Capitol Hill."
Technology companies "are realizing increasingly that Washington, D.C.'s influence really extends across the nation and its influence has a direct and significant impact on their bottom line," she said.
But while the old-style, old-economy law firm may know Capitol Hill, it may have to come up to speed itself to be a player in the Internet world.
Ms. Grossman cited as one of the firm's dot-com accomplishments the fact that it helped Angie Kim, the president of EqualFooting.com, get a speaking engagement at an e-commerce conference held at Saginaw Valley State University in Michigan. But just how much influence the law firm can exert may depend on whether it can reach beyond the heartland in Saginaw Valley to the heart of Silicon Valley. MATT RICHTEL

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 1; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1237 words

HEADLINE: Bracing Views From a Man Of Mysteries

BYLINE: By FELICIA R. LEE 

 BODY:
There is a scene in the novel "Devil in a Blue Dress" that peeps at the place where Walter Mosley's politics and art meet. Easy Rawlins has been pressed into detective service by DeWitt Albright, a mysterious, sinister man who lures Easy with enough money to make the overdue mortgage payments on his beloved home. Easy is a Negro and DeWitt is white in the Los Angeles of 1948.
"I don't belong to anybody," Easy says to Albright's assertion that he paid him and thus owns him. 
 "We all owe out something, Easy," Albright replies. "When you owe out then you're in debt and when you're in debt then you can't be your own man. That's capitalism."
And so it is that capitalism is the theme of Mr. Mosley's first book of nonfiction, a slim, eight-chapter essay called "Workin' on the Chain Gang: Shaking Off the Dead Hand of History" (Library of Contemporary Thought). The book, published earlier this year, explores a range of issues, including race, culture and global politics.
The unifying thread is the moral and economic stranglehold of capitalism, as seen through the prism of the black American experience. His is a progressive rather than Marxist stance and offers different ways of looking at some old problems, rather than solutions.
"Chain Gang" begins with the idea that the millennium is an artificial marker of human progress. Mr. Mosley looks at such defining events as the enslavement of Africans in the New World, the Holocaust and the detonation of the atomic bomb and contrasts technological advances with our attitudes toward human life over the years.
He argues that although race is still a major problem in America and technology has far outpaced moral growth, the greatest malignancy is the juggernaut of capitalism.
"What black people have experienced as a group for centuries many whites now experience as solitary and alienated individuals," Mr. Mosley writes. "In their various groups white Americans might feel that they belong, that there is a group spirit that looks out for them. But individually they suffer the barbs of bureaucratic indifference and the vicissitudes of corporate whims like everyone else."
Publishers Weekly called the book "an ardent manifesto" and a "provocative declaration of intellectual and political independence." Kirkus Reviews crowned Mr. Mosley "a significant African-American thinker."
The final chapter of "Chain Gang" begins with Malcolm X's line, "You have been bamboozled," from a speech about American society that he made at a Harlem rally.
"And he was right," Mr. Mosley writes. "Black people had been fooled and lied to and broken over the promise of freedom. But the truth is that all Americans have been fooled and broken.
"Democracy and capitalism make strange bedfellows," the essay continues. "In this odd brew freedom becomes a commodity. A price is put upon our only asset, our labor."
Mr. Mosley, who is famous for his five Easy Rawlins mysteries, said he wrote the book to foment and prolong a dialogue about issues dear to his heart. He has always been political, he said, and a nonfiction book on a serious subject was another way to resist artistic pigeonholing.
Mr. Mosley said that he initially chose to write about race in the 21st century but that as he chewed on his thoughts the book turned into something more complex. That should not surprise anyone who understands his fiction, he said.
"I'm one of the only people in America writing now about black male heroes; that in itself is a political act, to see and cast black men in America in a positive role," Mr. Mosley said over lunch at a Greenwich Village restaurant that he frequents. At 48 he is loquacious, easygoing, discernibly smart.
"The other thing is, I write about very real social situations," Mr. Mosley said. "When I write about Easy Rawlins and he goes out to the desert and a guy turns a gun on him, Easy doesn't understand it isn't necessarily about race but because the guy thinks he is going to rob him. But race informs how the guy looks at him, too, and how Easy responds.
"Socrates Fortlow is completely political," he said of another recurring character. "He seeks redemption. He wants to form bonds and hope in the black community."
On the other hand, Mr. Mosley said, "I'm no more political than Mark Twain or Charles Dickens or Herman Melville."
Mr. Mosley, a Los Angeles native who lives in Greenwich Village, has written 11 books. "Devil in a Blue Dress" (1990), his first, created an astonished gasp of pleasure in the literary world and opened the door for other black mystery writers. It didn't hurt that President Clinton called him his favorite writer.
Since Easy showed up, Mr. Mosley's work has been translated into 20 languages and crossed over into movies. In 1995 "Devil in a Blue Dress" became a film starring Denzel Washington. In 1998 Laurence Fishburne starred as Socrates Fortlow in "Always Outnumbered, Always Outgunned" on HBO. A television series based on the Easy Rawlins character is being discussed with ABC.
Mr. Mosley made his debut recently in The New Yorker with a short story about a young man on Wall Street. His first play, about three dysfunctional relationships, will be produced in Hartford in September. He is also working on a series of science fiction stories set in the New York of 2040, and HBO wants another screenplay based on the latest Socrates novel.
Characters like Socrates Fortlow, a 60-ish convicted rapist and murderer living a hardscrabble life in a Los Angeles slum, are imbued with dignity and insight. They seem to reflect Mr. Mosley's delight in subversion, in turning the expected into the unexpected.
He is, after all, the son of a Jewish mother and African-American father who married and made their home in Los Angles when such couples were considered eccentric at best. His parents stayed together until his father died seven years ago. They were crippled by the obvious inequities of being themselves in that time and place, he said, but they loved each other and loved him enough that he finally reached a place emotionally where he could be himself.
Mr. Mosley left behind a job as a computer programmer after the beginnings of a novel floated into his head. It became "Devil in a Blue Dress." That was only a decade ago. Like a lot of people, he said, he took a long time to grow up and discover his real affinities and talents.
"I feel myself as a real, everyday kind of American guy," Mr. Mosley said when asked whether his fiction fans might question his moral or intellectual authority to tackle "Chain Gang." "I can't tell you what to do. I can't answer the problem. I'm just somebody who thinks about it, and I came to the conclusion that our moral and technological potential is severely limited by how much we've bought into capitalism."
What happens, he said, is that people do not see common suffering brought about by economic constraints, but focus on their own victimization. And because blacks have historically been marginalized and many social ills have been presented as minority issues, the white skinhead and the struggling black mother fail to realize that their insurance companies or their bosses are giving them both the short end of the stick.
Mr. Mosley said he placed his hope for political and social change on a younger generation that seemed willing to make the leap to put black people in the center of the American drama.

HEADLINE: The Auction Hullabaloo Reverberates At Art Fair

BYLINE: By CAROL VOGEL 

DATELINE: MAASTRICHT, the Netherlands, March 19

 BODY:
When the doors to the European Fine Art Fair opened here on Friday afternoon, the 198 exhibitors were all smiles, eager to talk about the prized offerings they were placing before some 8,200 visitors who poured into the convention center where the fair is held every March.
But beneath the polite banter, the atmosphere at this, the world's largest art fair, was politically charged. Talk of the unfolding federal antitrust investigation of auction houses in New York was everywhere, and with it speculation about the increase that the biggest of the houses, Sotheby's and Christie's, plan to charge buyers. 
 The effects all this will have on dealers is uncertain. The negative publicity Sotheby's and Christie's have been getting is making the dealers look good, they say. Some already report that they are being offered more goods from collectors who once relied on auctions to sell.
"People are a little uncertain about selling at auction until things get sorted out," said Timothy Bathurst, a director of Artemis Fine Arts, a London gallery that specializes in old master and 19th-century paintings. "In some cases we're being offered things for sale that Sotheby's or Christie's would have normally gotten."
But the situation is double-edged. Amongthe many dealers who have traditionally relied heavily on buying their stock at auction there is concern that they will not be able to buy as much because the expensive commissions these auction houses are charging -- as much as 20 percent on the first $50,000 -- will eat too deeply into their profits.
There is also much speculation about the effects the investigation will have on the spring fine art sales, which are held in New York every May. While the dealers here are secretly hoping to benefit, officials at Sotheby's and Christie's maintain that the May sales this year will remain strong.
"While there are no single big estates like a Whitney or a Ganz, in terms of monetary value our main Impressionist and post-Impressionist sale will be as big as it has been the last few seasons," said Franck Giraud, head of Christie's Impressionist and post-Impressionist art department worldwide.
Officials at Sotheby's estimate their evening Impressionist and modern art sale this May will be impressive too, with $100 million to $135 million worth of art for sale.
In today's strong economy collectors are so hungry for good material they will buy wherever the goods are. "No dealer is publicly gloating about all that's going on," said Nicholas Hall, who runs the New York branch of Hall & Knight. The gallery, which also has a branch in London, specializes in old master paintings. "People are going to continue to buy art regardless of the behavior of the auction houses," he said.
Many of the estimated 70,000 people who will have visited the fair by the time it ends on Sunday are serious buyers. Within the first 24 hours dealers were reporting brisk business. While the fair has always attracted serious collectors because of the quality of its goods, this year's art, antiques and antiquities are particularly impressive. There is a staggering selection of every collecting category from old masters to textiles, jewelry and contemporary art.
Since its began 26 years ago, the fair has been known as the most comprehensive place to see old master paintings. It still is. Among the best is an early still life at Haboldt & Company, a gallery with branches in Paris and New York. Its title is more or less its full description: "Figs on a Tazza With Vine Leaves, a Basket of Grapes, Roses, Irises in a Glass Vase With Cherries, Pears, Plums, Cob Nuts, Peaches and Other Fruit on a Draped Table with Butterflies." It was done circa 1590-1600 by an artist known only as the Master of the Hartford Still Life.
"It is the beginning of still-life painting as we know it," said Bob Haboldt, the gallery's owner. "Perhaps the inspiration came from Caravaggio, perhaps the artist had met Bruegel the Elder, but it's a complete invention. It comes without any baggage of art history."
On a table draped with a white cloth is a well-balanced composition of fruits and flowers that are so alive on the canvas they almost seem in movement. Mr. Haboldt bought the painting in a small auction in Italy earlier this year. A slightly smaller and later version is in the Wadsworth Atheneum in Hartford.
Another rare painting that is attracting interest hangs in Jack Kilgore's booth. The painting, "Madonna With Child and Angels," circa 1607 by the Dutch master Hendrick Goltzius, features the Virgin clad in a bright pink dress gazing down at the child with angels hovering in the background.
"It's unlined and signed on both the back and the front," said Mr. Kilgore, who runs a gallery in Manhattan. "Goltzius was a graphic designer who didn't start painting until 1600 and he died in 1617 so there are only about 40 paintings by him." Mr. Kilgore said he discovered the painting in a German collection.
While the best works here tend to come from private collections, the fair always features many paintings bought in January at the important old master paintings sales at Sotheby's and Christie's in New York. Dealers buy them, have them cleaned and restored in time for the fair and then mark them up for considerably more than they paid for them. The London dealer Richard Green, for example, has a breathtaking Canaletto from the mid-1730's, "The Grand Canal, Venice, Looking East From Campo di San Vio." He bought it at Christie's in January for $6.6 million. He is asking $9.5 million.
French & Company also has its share of recent auction purchases. A painting by Giovanni Segantini, "Springtime in the Alps," for which the gallery's chairman, Martin Zimet, paid $9.5 million at Christie's in November, is for sale for $17 million. Mr. Zimet is also selling Arcimboldo's "Reversible Anthropomorphic Portrait of a Man Composed of Fruit," which is considered an ironic portrait of Emperor Rudolph II. His price is $7.5 million. He paid just under $1.5 million for it at Sotheby's two months ago. "Sotheby's called it an Arcimboldo but we have done extensive research on the painting," Mr. Zimet said.
Every year the fair's section of modern and contemporary art gets stronger. Leslie Waddington, a London dealer who has been the chairman of the event's painting's department, has been bringing in more top dealers from Europe and New York. "As word is getting out, more modern collectors have started coming here," he said. "They aren't people interested in icon-buying; they're educated collectors." On opening day Mr. Waddington said he had sold a painting by Agnes Martin, one by Van Dongen and another by Dali.
Furniture, decorative objects and antiquities were also getting lavish attention at this year's fair. Among the rarest treasures is a tapestry based on a 12th-century legend of the life of St. Anne, dated 1527, which is being shown at the Rudigier Alte Kunst, a Munich gallery. "There are only 11 tapestries of this kind," said Gertrude Rudigier, who added that she found it in a private collection in southern Germany.
Robert Bowman, a London dealer, discovered "Vases of the Titans," a pair of terra-cotta vases by Rodin, at a chateau in France. The vases, which are signed by A. Carrier Belleuse, the owner of the workshop where Rodin was working around 1879, come from the collection of Henri Ardant, who owned the Ardant porcelain factory in France. Each vase is held up by four crouching and intricately carved titans and has a Greek key pattern at the top. Similar examples are in the collections of the Rodin Museum in Paris and the Maryhill Museum of Fine Arts in Washington.
As the crowds poured in and out of Mr. Bowman's booth, he said he was having his best fair ever. "There are several factors that are making this a success," he said. "People are thinking the stock market could crash, and it's a good time to buy art. At the same time the public is beginning to realize that the auction houses are less concerned with expertise and more with making their commissions."

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1296 words

HEADLINE: Presidential Election Could Alter Shapeof Tribune-Times Mirror Deal

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
In the pending merger of the Tribune Company and Times Mirror, the fate of three of Tribune's largest television stations and three of Times Mirror's largest newspapers may ultimately depend on who becomes the nation's next president.
That is because Vice President Al Gore, the presumptive Democratic candidate, favors keeping the current restrictions on companies that own both television stations and newspapers. But Governor George W. Bush of Texas, the apparent Republican nominee, is tilting against the existing rules. Under Tribune's proposed acquisition of the Times Mirror Company, announced last week, Tribune would control newspapers and television stations in New York, Los Angeles and Hartford, once it completed the deal. 
 But a 1974 Federal regulation known as the cross-ownership rule prohibits a company from owning a newspaper and a television station in the same geographic market. Unless revised, that rule would require the companies to either seek a rarely granted waiver or sell the newspapers or stations when their broadcast licenses come up for renewal.
Despite years of lobbying by Tribune and top executives in the newspaper and broadcast industries, neither Congress nor the Clinton administration is expected to change the rule any time soon. Mr. Gore and other officials in the administration say they support the rule because it prevents too much media power from falling into too few hands. Congressional Republicans, including Senator John McCain, who have tried to have it repealed have been blocked by top Democratic lawmakers.
While Mr. Bush has not publicly articulated a position about the rule, his top economic advisers have said it is archaic and unnecessary. And some aides have quietly promised industry executives and lobbyists that a Bush administration would move swiftly to eliminate it.
"We have been assured through reliable channels that the governor would support repeal of the rule," said John F. Sturm, the president and chief executive of the Newspaper Association of America. Shaun Sheehan, Tribune's top lobbyist in Washington, said he, too, had heard that the governor's policy advisers had said Mr. Bush would repeal the rule.
Echoing the position of the broadcast industry's lobbyists, aides to the governor's presidential campaign say they believe the rule is out of date, now that consumers can now get information from a wide array of sources that include the Internet and cable and satellite television.
"There are now so many media outlets that it would make sense to relax it," said Timothy J. Muris, a professor at the George Mason University of Law and a former senior antitrust official in the Reagan administration, who is one of Mr. Bush's top advisers on economic and competition issues.
Although support and opposition over the rule now largely follows partisan lines, the regulation was first adopted by a Republican-controlled agency at a time of concern among antitrust officials about the power, particularly in smaller markets, of companies that owned both newspaper and television outlets.
After it was approved by the Federal Communications Commission a quarter-century ago, television stations in a dozen cities had to be sold. A few newspaper companies were permitted to keep their stations in some larger cities under a grandfather clause and a handful of other companies were treated leniently, as when Rupert Murdoch's News Corporation was permitted to buy The New York Post even though the company controlled a television station, on the rationale that the newspaper might otherwise fail. Nonetheless, regulators compelled Mr. Murdoch to sell another newspaper, The Boston Herald, because his company owned a television station in the same market.
During debate over the Telecommunications Act of 1996, Mr. Gore, as the administration's lead negotiator, managed to save the cross-ownership rule from being repealed. As one of the final compromises that led to passage of the legislation, the lawmakers and the administration agreed that instead of repeal, the F.C.C. would conduct reviews every two years to reconsider the need for the rule. The agency under the Clinton administration has shown no sign of changing its stance.
The different views between the Bush and Gore camps over the cross-ownership rule illustrates one of the many ways that the presidential race could determine enforcement of antitrust and competition rules in the coming years.
During the Clinton administration, antitrust and competition in telecommunications and other industries have been among the business issues subject to the fiercest litigation and lobbying efforts.
The administration has revived antitrust enforcement and brought some of the most significant cases in a generation, including prosecution of a vitamin cartel that resulted in record-breaking fines and, still in progress, the Microsoft case. Clinton antitrust officials have also challenged a series of large and smaller mergers that would have gone unchallenged in the Reagan and Bush administrations, killing many corporate deals and ordering extensive modifications of others.
Mr. Bush and Mr. Gore have provided relatively few specific details about views on antitrust and competition. And while whoever is in the White House sets the overall tone and philosophy, antitrust policies are generally set by the top officials appointed to the Federal Trade Commission and the Justice Department.
Nonetheless, the candidates and their advisers have begun to drop hints that they have significantly different views about the subject.
"I call it yin and yang," said Reed Hundt, a close friend of Mr. Gore and an antitrust expert who has discussed competition policies with the vice president. Mr. Hundt served as chairman of the F.C.C. from 1993 until 1997.
"The Al Gore view is to side with the following constituencies: small companies, start-ups, innovators, and attackers of incumbents," Mr. Hundt said. "The Gore view of antitrust follows in the tradition of Teddy Roosevelt through Thurman Arnold and the current administration. George Bush's view is much more beholden to large companies and incumbents and sees little role for the government."
In his few public remarks about antitrust, Mr. Bush has suggested that he would return to many of the principles of the Reagan administration and the practice of selecting antitrust enforcers whose primary goal would be to combat price-fixing -- rather than to use antitrust laws to protect consumers in industries like telecommunications, transportation and energy that have been significantly deregulated.
"My own personal view is the application of antitrust laws needs to be applied where there are clear cases of price-fixing," the governor said in an interview with The Financial Times last month. Asked whether the laws should be applied to situations beyond price-fixing, he replied, "Well, no."
Aides to the governor later clarified his remarks to say that he was not ruling out other kinds of antitrust enforcement. But they also contended that the Clinton administration had stretched some antitrust laws beyond recognition and that a Bush administration would pursue a far more laissez-faire approach similar to that of the Reagan administration.
The differences were perhaps best summed up in a recent article by Professor Muris, the senior adviser to Governor Bush, about the F.T.C.'s enforcement of monopoly law. The article, which appears in the current issue of The Antitrust Law Journal, criticizes the agency for an overly aggressive interpretation of the Sherman Antitrust Act, and has chapter titles that include "The F.T.C. Is Wrong on the Law," "The F.T.C. Is Wrong on Policy" and "The F.T.C. Is Wrong on the Facts."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Siemens and Mannesmann To Form Car-Parts Venture
Siemens of Germany said its car-parts unit was planning a partnership with Mannesmann's VDO auto-parts business in the face of mounting competition in the car industry. 
 Siemens and Mannesmann's Atecs, which intends to sell shares in an initial public offering, will hold equal stakes in VDO, according to published reports in Germany. Page C11.
 
The Method Behind Gladwell.com
The New Yorker writer Malcolm Gladwell operates his own Web site, which offers all his articles online and excerpts from his new book, "The Tipping Point." But Gladwell.com is not a promotional device. Mr. Gladwell said he started the site in part to interact with visitors who e-mail their comments and ideas, and who also unwittingly offer themselves up as a kind of human petri dish for Mr. Gladwell's interests in science, pop anthropology and technology. C14.
 
Pan Am Workers Win Pension Ruling
A federal judge has sided with employees of Pan American World Airways in a case related to their pension plan and the way it was administered by a federal agency after the airline went out of business. The ruling may lead to an increase in pension payments for some of the 65,000 people who worked for Pan Am when it shut down in 1991. C10.
 
Grappling Over a Documentary
"Beyond the Mat," a documentary on the characters who make their livings in the middle and lower ranks of pro wrestling, opened on Friday in 50 cities. But prospects for the film were greatly diminished, the film's producers say, after a decision by the World Wrestling Federation not to allow television advertising for the documentary during any of the pro wrestling group's programs. C14.
 
A Putin Biography Made in the U.S.
PublicAffairs, a New York company that is fast becoming the publishing house for Kremlin politicians, is preparing to rush into print in May an English translation of the memoirs describing the life of Russia's acting president, Vladimir V. Putin. The original Russian version of "First Person" is still unavailable in Russia, where the country's Central Electoral Commission has barred publication until after the March 26 presidential election. C14.
 
Insurers Tread Carefully With Web
Insurance companies have acknowledged the Internet's potential for simplifying the byzantine process of finding insurance quotes and applying for coverage, but they also note the downsides: consumers, they say, cannot use the Web to speak with real people in real time about the complexities of coverage; and by selling directly to consumers through their own Web sites, the companies risk an insurrection among the insurance agents who have been their bedrock source of revenue. C12.
 
The Beltway Courts Dot-Coms
Bob Dole -- the former senator and presidential nominee as well as a "special counsel" at a powerhouse Washington law firm -- helped hold an event last week that introduced EqualFooting.com, a company that plans to create an online marketplace where small businesses would buy industrial supplies. The law firm's courtship of dot-coms demonstrates how little distance is left between the high-technology world, once staunchly unwilling to cozy up to Capitol Hill, and the inside-the-beltway elite, formerly dismissive of the Internet's role in the economy. C4.
 
Advertising's Other Super Bowl
The Oscar presentation on ABC has traditionally been the second biggest day of the year for advertising, trailing only the Super Bowl. That demand continues this year because there is still no end in sight to the strong demand for commercial time among marketers -- whether dot-com or not-com -- which has intensified their need to break through the clutter. Stuart Elliott: Advertising. C16.

HEADLINE: A Senior Statesman Is Facing the Threat of Youth

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WILMINGTON, Del., March 13

 BODY:
On a tour of low-income housing here, Leon N. Weiner, a prominent developer, turned to the senior senator from Delaware, William V. Roth Jr., and raised an increasingly familiar question.
"People ask me, 'Is Senator Roth, at his age, ready to make another six-year commitment?' " Mr. Weiner, who will turn 80 in May, said. 
 "I'm a year older than you are, Senator, and I wouldn't make it."
Without missing a beat, Mr. Roth, seeking a sixth six-year term this fall, shot back with a smile to his still-active constituent: "Knowing you, Leon, that's a lot of baloney."
As chairman of the powerful Senate Finance Committee, Mr. Roth would be in a position to shepherd some of Capitol Hill's hottest legislation this year, like a China trade bill, tax relief and changes in health care law.
The longest serving politician in Delaware history, Mr. Roth has made a career of getting things done by working with Democrats, like Senator Daniel P. Moynihan of New York, the panel's ranking member.
But at 78 (Mr. Roth turns 79 in July) and facing a stiff re-election fight from Delaware's popular outgoing Democratic governor, Thomas R. Carper, Mr. Roth has become perhaps the Republicans' most vulnerable Senate candidate in campaign 2000. Since last fall the polls have been showing Mr. Carper, 53, with a 10-point lead.
In this state of 750,000 people, which takes pride in its moderate traditions and civil campaigns, voters seemed conflicted over the choice between Mr. Roth's experience and influence and the younger, more dynamic Mr. Carper.
"I'm torn," said Mr. Weiner, a Democrat. "Bill Roth is a sincere, decent and honest guy. If he were a Democrat, I'd support . . . him. But what really bothers me are some of his Republican colleagues, like Jesse Helms and Phil Gramm."
Over a lunch of cream of crab soup and Caesar salad in Dover while on a daylong swing through the state, Mr. Roth defended his decision to run again.
"I think I can make a difference, both because of my seniority and chairmanship," said Mr. Roth, a mild-mannered legislator who revels in being low-key. "This is the most exciting, challenging time to serve. I can have a real, direct impact on those key issues."
He said he was fit, despite a spill he took recently at a White House meeting on China trade. "My foot fell asleep."
 Because the Republican party has term limits for Senate chairmanships, he would have to give up the Finance Committee in 2002, undercutting his argument for seniority. Mr. Roth, a former chairman of the less prestigious Governmental Affairs Committee, could head another panel.
Democrats have already been counting Mr. Roth's seat as theirs. "Clout is the political argument of last resort," said James Jordan, political director of the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee.
Yet, from the banking hub of Wilmington to the farmlands of southern Delaware, the issues facing the Finance Committee resounded with residents here, underscoring Mr. Roth's pivotal role.
When the Senate returns on Monday from a weeklong recess, it will take up a popular bill that Mr. Roth supports that would allow most Social Security recipients, for the first time, to earn as much money as they wanted without sacrificing any retirement benefits.
After an awards ceremony at Beebe Medical Center in Lewes, Del., Peggy Paul, a 64-year-old technician, came up to the senator to urge the measure's passage. "I would have to cut back and I want to continue working," said Ms. Paul, who would lose nearly $8,000 in Social Security benefits under the current law when she turned 65.
The committee has also planned to begin hearings soon on legislation to grant China permanent normal trading relations, a vital step for Beijing's entry into the World Trade Organization. Proponents were hoping a strong vote by the panel would build momentum for accord in the House, where the prospects were dimmer.
Under the agreement, lower Chinese tariffs would benefit Delaware farmers as well as the banks and international chemical companies in the state's northern reaches.
"A lot of people don't understand it doesn't affect our markets," Mr. Roth said. "They already have access to our markets. What it does is give us access to their markets. If we don't get access, then we're handicapping ourselves.
"It would be a major fiasco if we do not act on this," he said. "A vote on normal trading relations may not only be the most important vote of the year, but of the decade."
Answering critics of permanent trade status, Mr. Roth said opening Chinese markets would also enhance democratic values there. "The more they trade, the more they tend to be guided by rule of law," Mr. Roth said. "It's a gamble, but it's the best gamble we have available."
Mr. Roth, perhaps best known for the Kemp-Roth tax cut of 1981 and the tax-free savings accounts that bear his name, has been backing an array of tax cuts, even though their public appeal seems to be waning in the booming economy.
The senator has backed Gov. George W. Bush's proposed tax cut of $483 billion over five years starting in 2002. But House Republicans were able to muster backing only for a smaller package, and prospects in the Senate were unclear.
"Benefits are going to those who are paying the taxes, but a lot of our proposals have been intended to help the working people," Mr. Roth said.
Which was why Republicans this year were slicing up last year's big tax package into more targeted proposals. The Finance Committee would soon be considering a Republican-sponsored bill that would reduce taxes for married couples.
Cutting taxes has not resonated with all Delaware voters.
Ron Marcozzi, a 61-year-old delicatessen owner, said he liked Mr. Roth's three decades of experience, but he wanted to hear from "the other guy" -- Mr. Carper -- because he was frustrated that Republican tax cuts have
been skewed toward the wealthy.
"Whether it's Democrats or Republicans, a little guy like me pays a lot of taxes," said Mr. Marcozzi, a Republican. "It seems the poor can't pay and the very rich don't do their part."
Mr. Roth has also played an important role in forging coalitions on health care legislation. In June 1997 he presided over late-night back-room negotiations that produced a bipartisan agreement to create a new health insurance program for children in low-income families. It was part of a comprehensive budget legislation that the Finance Committee approved by a vote of 20 to 0.
And it has not gone unnoticed here that Mr. Roth supported an increase last year in Medicare's minimum payments for pap tests, to $14.60 from $7.15 a test, insuring greater access to health-screening for female patients.
"If Senator Roth was not the Finance Committee chairman, I don't think we'd have gotten the pap-smear issue resolved," said Dr. V. Raman Sukumar, chief of pathology at Beebe Medical Center, and a registered independent. "Just this one issue will make me think of voting for him."

HEADLINE: SUPREME COURT ROUNDUP;
Weighty Cases Crowd Last 3 Months of the Term

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
With more than three months to go in its term, the Supreme Court on Monday will enter a concentrated period of unusual intensity and potential import. The justices, back from a brief recess, will begin six weeks of hearing arguments in one blockbuster case after another, a series of high-profile appeals that appear drawn from today's headlines and that have already marked the term as a likely landmark.
These questions suggest the scope of what awaits the justices among the two dozen cases they will hear between now and the last week in April, the final building blocks of the 1999-2000 term: 
 Does public prayer before a high school football game violate the separation of church and state?
Are the Miranda warnings still required before the police can interrogate a suspect in custody, or has Congress effectively overruled the 34-year-old Miranda decision?
Can states put into effect their own views of foreign policy by withholding state business from companies that trade with disfavored regimes.
Can states, and by extension Congress, criminalize the surgical procedure that abortion opponents call "partial-birth abortion"?
Do the Boy Scouts have a constitutional right to exclude gay youths and men from leadership roles?
These cases and more -- on the legal threshold for winning an employment discrimination case, on constitutional standards for enhanced sentencing under hate crime laws, on congressional authority to make arson a federal crime, on whether political parties can be required to open their primaries to voting by nonmembers -- are all due for decision by the end of June, the court's goal for resolving all argued cases and finishing its term.
"It's just an amazing term, with no major area of constitutional law that doesn't have the potential for major change," Erwin Chemerinsky, a law professor at the University of Southern California, said in an interview. Noting the high-profile nature of the court's docket, he continued: "I wonder whether the magnitude of this term, the prominence of these cases, will have the effect of making the court more salient as an election issue."
Given that some major cases that were argued three, four or even five months ago remain undecided as this new round of arguments begins, the prospect of an orderly, on-time conclusion to the term strikes many people who follow the court as wishful thinking.
Among the earlier cases that are still undecided are those on the Food and Drug Administration's authority to regulate tobacco products and on the constitutionality of the Violence Against Women Act, as well as a major church-state conflict over federal financing for computer equipment in religious schools.
The justices have all but complete control over which cases to accept but relatively little control over the timing, generally considering new appeals in the order in which they were filed. So the unusual concentration of high-profile cases for the March and April arguments simply reflects the fact that most of them reached the justices' desks during the fall.
What follows is a detailed look at some of the cases the justices will hear in the coming weeks.
 
Football Team Prayer
The court will hear a Texas school district's appeal of a ruling that barred the practice, highly popular in the state, of student-led prayers at public high school football games. The March 29 argument in the case, Santa Fe Independent School District v. Doe, No. 99-62, is likely to focus on whether the students' prayer is truly private speech, and therefore presumably constitutional, as the district and state maintain, or whether the circumstances of the student's selection and performance make the event a form of public worship that the Supreme Court's precedents forbid.
 
Congressional Authority
Pursuing its inquiry into the limits of congressional law-making authority -- thought to be virtually limitless before the court reversed course five years ago -- the court will hear a challenge on Tuesday to a federal prosecution for burning down a private residence. The question in Jones v. U.S., No. 99-5739, is whether Congress intended the federal arson law to apply to a private home and, if so, whether Congress had authority to do so under its power to regulate interstate commerce.
 
Foreign Policy
On Wednesday, Massachusetts will defend its so-called Burma law, which in effect prohibits state agencies from doing business with companies that do business in Myanmar, formerly Burma. Dozens of state and local governments once aimed similar economic weapons against South Africa's apartheid regime. Those went unchallenged, but the federal appeals court in Boston, ruling in Natsios v. National Foreign Trade Council, No. 99-474, found the Burma law to be an impermissible state intrusion into the federal government's foreign affairs power.
 
Miranda
In 1968, two years after the court's ruling in Miranda v. Arizona, Congress tried to blunt the decision by reverting to the "voluntariness" test for the admissibility of confessions in federal prosecutions, with the court-specified warnings unnecessary.
Seven Republican and Democratic administrations refused to apply the law, known as Section 3501, while conservative law enforcement groups tried to bring it to the lower courts' attention. Finally last year, the federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., ruled that Congress was free to overturn Miranda and that it had, in effect, done so. The Supreme Court's conservative bloc has been notably lacking in deference to Congress, so one interesting question for the April 19 argument in Dickerson v. U.S., No. 99-5525, is what stance the conservative justices who have criticized Miranda will now take.
 
Abortion
A federal appeals court ruled last year that the phrase "partial-birth abortion" as used in a 1997 Nebraska law criminalizing the procedure "has no fixed medical or legal content" and was so ill-defined as to be potentially applicable to common techniques used for abortions early in pregnancy. That placed an "undue burden" on a woman's exercise of her constitutional right to abortion, the United States Court of Appeals for the Eighth Circuit held.
As the Supreme Court's first abortion case since 1992, Stenberg v. Carhart, No. 99-830, carries obvious political and emotional freight. One question for the April 25 argument is whether the justices will confine themselves to examining the deficiency the appeals court identified, or whether they want to make a broader statement about the constitutional status of abortion.
 
Boy Scouts
Although the effort of a gay Eagle Scout, James Dale, to regain his place in a New Jersey troop has positioned Boy Scouts of America v. Dale, No. 99-699, as a gay rights case, the court may well not see it that way. The question for the April 26 argument is whether the Boy Scouts have a right, under the First Amendment's protection for freedom of association, to define its own "expressive character" by excluding gay members.
In its most recent relevant precedent, the court ruled unanimously that the Boston St. Patrick's Day parade could not be required to include a group marching under a gay-rights banner. But in ruling for Mr. Dale, the New Jersey Supreme Court noted he wasn't carrying a banner but wanted to remain a Scout.
