HEADLINE: THE 2000 CAMPAIGN: THE TEXAS GOVERNOR;
Bush Calls Himself Reformer; the Record Shows the Label May Be a Stretch

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. and JIM YARDLEY 

DATELINE: AUSTIN, Tex., March 19

 BODY:
With the long march to November under way, Gov. George W. Bush is arguing that his record in Texas proves he is best suited to bring reform to Washington. He has even coined a campaign slogan: "A Reformer With Results."
Without question, Mr. Bush has been a popular governor, yet he is not widely viewed in Texas as a reformer. 
 Unlike Senator John McCain of Arizona, who bucked his own party on issues like campaign finance and tobacco legislation, Mr. Bush is not as confrontational, nor is he usually identified with sweeping change. His record is largely built on compromise and his ability to build coalitions with conservative Democrats.
Mr. Bush's boldest effort at reform -- his 1997 plan to overhaul the state's outdated tax code -- failed badly. The governor won plaudits for his courage but ultimately could not leverage the "political capital" he has promised to use if elected president; he could not win the support of enough lawmakers in his own party.
On other issues, consumer advocates complain that he often describes as reforms actions benefiting the powerful Texas business interests that have supported him, rather than consumers. On the campaign trail, for example, he has portrayed himself as a leader in reforming health maintenance organizations, yet he resisted two important pieces of patients' rights legislation. And his claims about the consumer benefits of tort reform -- a package of bills that sought to curb large jury awards in civil cases -- are disputed.
Even some of the party faithful seem unsure of Mr. Bush's reformer credentials. Only half of Republican voters in the Texas primary last week said public schools had seen significant reforms since Mr. Bush, who has made his education record a cornerstone of his presidential campaign, was elected, according to exit polls by the Voter News Service.
"He's an incremental-change specialist," said Bruce Buchanan, a political scientist at the University of Texas, "sometimes in a partisan way, like tort reform, which is a big business issue, sometimes in a bipartisan way, such as small changes in education."
To be sure, Mr. Bush has found success, particularly in his first legislative session, on initiatives he describes as reforms, like changes in tort laws, stricter welfare rules, a crackdown on juvenile crime and giving more local control to public school districts. Those efforts won Mr. Bush praise from lawmakers in both parties, but all were popular issues before he took office.
"Tort reform and all those things, we were already working on them," said Pete Laney, the Democratic speaker of the Texas House and one of the legislative leaders to forge a bond with Mr. Bush early on. "It was smart politically for him to take advantage of that," Mr. Laney said. "That was great politics for him to use those."
Mr. Laney added that "reform" meant different things to different people. Some of the 1995 tort reforms, for example, reversed changes made in the "reform" legislative sessions of the early 1970's, he said. "Reform is pillage and plunder if you're against it, and it's good government if you're for it," he said.
Dan Bartlett, a Bush spokesman, said the governor played crucial roles in the passage of reforms he campaigned on in 1994, as well as later reform initiatives. Some, like tort reform, might have died had Gov. Ann Richards, a Democrat, been re-elected, he said.
"He is able to reach across party lines to bring people together," Mr. Bartlett said, adding that reforms "are the main reason he almost got 70 percent of the vote for his re-election."
Mr. Bush declared tort reform an "emergency" when he took office in 1995. Business groups had laid the groundwork for the legislation but Mr. Bush's strong support was essential. And many of these groups were among the governor's biggest campaign contributors.
Lawmakers passed seven bills, including a centerpiece measure that reduced the punitive damages for which businesses and other defendants might be liable if a jury determined they had committed wrongdoing. At the same time, the bill raised the level of proof plaintiffs must show to win such damages.
Mr. Bush said the laws helped rid Texas of so-called junk and frivolous lawsuits, but others say the changes shifted the judicial balance.
Reggie James, director of the Austin office of Consumers Union, said, "While it was portrayed as a fight between honest businesses and greedy trial lawyers, the fight was really about businesses not wanting to be held accountable when they harm consumers."
Mr. Bush has credited tort reform with saving consumers and businesses nearly $3 billion in insurance premiums, with the biggest part coming from auto liability rates. But the mechanism for those savings has come not from Mr. Bush's proposals but from a provision introduced in 1995 by a Democratic legislator requiring state officials to adjust rates ahead of time to account for the effects of tort reform, like lower settlements for injury claims.
And some former senior Texas insurance officials contend that the $3 billion claim is false anyway, and that the biggest beneficiaries of the new laws are insurers.
"How they can continue to claim $3 billion in tort reform savings is baffling to me," said Birny Birnbaum, an Austin consumer advocate who served as the Texas Department of Insurance's chief economist during the administrations of both Ms. Richards and Mr. Bush.
Data from the state show that overall statewide premiums for auto liability insurance stayed flat following tort reform, before a slight dip in 1998. But insurers' profits soared because their annual incurred losses were, on average, lowered by more than $600 million through 1998, the most recent year for which figures were available. Five years ago, insurers incurred 70.1 cents in losses for every dollar in premiums; in 1998, losses were 58.2 cents.
Jose Montemayor, the current insurance commissioner and a Bush appointee, said better driving habits and safer cars had played a larger role than tort reform in raising insurance company profits. But he acknowledged that insurers probably had received some benefits from tort reform in 1996 and 1997, until rates were rolled back more the next year.
"We were a little timid on the front end of this in terms of the rate rollback because we really did not have a good feel for the effects of tort reform," Mr. Montemayor said. But he added that "we corrected that, and more than made up for that."
Two years after tort reform, Mr. Bush, arguing that the state taxing system was unfair and outdated, brushed away concerns that he could hurt himself politically and proposed the biggest restructuring in more than three decades.
Texas has property and sales taxes but no broad-based income tax, and while corporations pay a form of income tax, partnerships do not. Mr. Bush contended that the state's booming service-based economy was not paying its share, while homeowners and industries with heavy capital spending paid too much. He also wanted a more stable and reliable source of school financing.
His plan was to reduce property taxes, and pay for it mostly by raising sales taxes and establishing a 1.25 percent tax on a business's net income, depreciation and labor costs, minus its capital expenditures, with the first $500,000 exempt.
The plan drew fire from professional groups, including doctors and lawyers, as well as retailers and other businesses with high labor costs and low profit margins.
Among the expected winners were petrochemical companies, oil refiners and other capital-intensive industries -- not a surprise, perhaps, since Mr. Bush's new business tax tracked closely a proposal offered to the governor by Charls Walker, a former Washington lobbyist who ran a tax-advocacy organization financed mostly by capital-intensive industries that favored the Bush plan.
"It was essentially a hidden sales tax," said Dick Lavine, a senior analyst with the Center for Public Policy Priorities, a nonprofit research group in Austin representing low-income taxpayers. Over all, he said, the plan would take "an already regressive system and compound it."
And other, more powerful people were skeptical. The late Democratic lieutenant governor, Bob Bullock, privately called the plan "dead on arrival."
State lawmakers junked the Bush proposal and assembled an alternative that the governor endorsed, but Mr. Bush was later unable to persuade enough Senate Republicans to vote his way as legislators tried to reconcile differences between the House and Senate versions. Late in the session, Mr. Bush salvaged a $1 billion property tax cut financed by the state's budget surplus. In 1999, Mr. Bush made no effort to resurrect tax reform, instead seeking -- and getting -- more tax cuts.
"Bush could have put his political capital on the line" to get the tax plan passed, said Bill White, the former chairman of the Texas Democratic Party, noting that another governor might have threatened to campaign against dissenting legislators or made a broader appeal to the public. "But he didn't."
Mr. Bartlett, the Bush spokesman, said: "When times are relatively calm, it's difficult to persuade people to change. He understood that going in, and he was ultimately proud of what we did accomplish."
It is the tax cuts, not his failure at tax reform, that Mr. Bush mentions on the campaign trail. He has also taken to boasting about his role in reforming health care in Texas, a role that many in Austin say is greatly exaggerated.
One commercial for Mr. Bush says that while Congress deadlocked over health care legislation, "he passed a patients' bill of rights." But people involved in the process note that in 1995 Mr. Bush vetoed the first Texas patient protection bill, and two years later he considered vetoing the most groundbreaking H.M.O. bill that Texas lawmakers had debated.
"If he wants to say, 'I reformed the tort system,' then that's fair game," said Mr. James, the consumer advocate, "but if he wants to say he reformed health care, that's a different animal. The reforms happened despite him, not because of him."
The 1995 patient protection bill included provisions requiring annual report cards for health maintenance organizations and forced H.M.O.'s to provide necessary emergency-room care. Today, Mr. Bush says he vetoed the bill because of unfair exemptions it gave certain H.M.O.'s. But in his veto proclamation he also mentioned other concerns: "numerous new regulations on managed care organizations," including H.M.O.'s, and higher costs for employers.
Afterward, the governor instructed the insurance commissioner to draft rules that covered much of what the bill did. Consumer groups objected strongly to the veto, but they praised the commissioner's rules. The issue resurfaced in 1997, when the legislature codified those rules and passed an expanded patient-protection package.
The biggest battle, though, was over a bill to make Texas the first state to allow patients to sue for malpractice an H.M.O. that denies necessary care. Mr. Bush warned of a veto, and his resistance brought his staff into conflict with one of his staunchest Republican allies, Senator David Sibley, the bill's sponsor.
On the Senate floor, Mr. Sibley complained about the governor's staff, saying, "I can't make them happy no matter what I do, unless I completely gut the bill."
Mr. Sibley did not back away from that comment in an interview, but he described Mr. Bush as a leader on health care issues, saying he was supportive of the other patient-protection measures passed in 1997.
Some legislators involved have different recollections. Patricia Gray, a Democratic House member who sponsored a bill requiring H.M.O.'s to allow women direct access to their obstetrician-gynecologist without having to see a "gatekeeper" physician first -- a measure Mr. Bush has called important to H.M.O. reform -- does not recall the governor, or his staff, having provided any help on the bill. "I have no recollection of him being involved whatsoever," Ms. Gray said.
That bill's Senate sponsor, Florence Shapiro, a Republican, said Mr. Bush's office did weigh in while the bill was in a Senate committee, and that he was supportive.
In the end, lawmakers overwhelmingly approved the right-to-sue bill, and Mr. Bush, who might have faced an embarrassing override vote had he vetoed the bill, allowed it to become law without his signature. Mr. Bartlett said Mr. Bush became more comfortable with the bill after provisions were added reducing the likelihood of a flood of new lawsuits, including a requirement that disputes first be reviewed by an independent panel.
Kim Ross, chief lobbyist for the Texas Medical Association, described Mr. Bush's evolution on health care issues as a "baptism by fire."
"He was on a steep learning curve," Mr. Ross said. "You have to give him credit for traveling a pretty far philosophical distance in such a short period."

HEADLINE: Essay;
Contrasting Elections

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
The first great test of a new democracy is not only in the way its government tolerates opposition, but whether it is willing to transfer power to that opposition after a fair election.
The new United States faced that test in 1801, after the ruling party of John Adams and Alexander Hamilton had been beaten in the popular vote by Thomas Jefferson's Anti-Federalists. It was touch and go for weeks, as the stunned Federalists tried to make a deal with Aaron Burr to block Jefferson's presidency. Only secret patronage concessions, hotly denied, and Hamilton's personal hatred of Burr caused the party in power to turn over the keys to the Executive Mansion. 
 Taiwan passed the same test last weekend. The party in power ever since Chiang Kai-shek fled China was split by an insurgency. The opposition party, favoring independence, contended vigorously. China warned the free Taiwanese of "blood" in their future if they dared vote for the dissident Chen Shui-bian.
That attempted intimidation put Chen over the top. The old guard, to its credit, will transfer power peacefully. Taiwan thus proves its democratic strength.
Russia is proving the opposite. Late last year, the kakistocracy propping up Boris Yeltsin decided not to risk giving up power. To avert election defeat by the Primakov-Luzhkov party, the ruling Kremlin crew upset the constitutional schedule. Yeltsin suddenly stepped down and named Vladimir Putin, a K.G.B. apparatchik, to be acting president.
By staging this coup, the ruling party was able to have its candidate in office, with all its powers of patronage and media control, at election time. Its anointed new leader received a prestige boost from Britain's Tony Blair and America's Bill Clinton. A level playing field was averted.
To distract the Russian people from high-level corruption, war hysteria was whipped up. Chechens aching for self-rule were designated as threats to Russians in their homes. Power-starved Russian generals were encouraged to pillage at will.
In this way, the ruling clique not only changed its image from puffy Yeltsin to hard-eyed Putin, but changed the subject from venality and economic stagnation to a cost-free victory over the despised rebels.
Needed was only a symbolic bridge connecting fear of the Chechens to anger at truth-tellers in the Russian media. The ruling clique found that in Andrei Babitsky, a Russian Radio Liberty reporter who filed embarrassing facts from behind battle lines.
Babitsky was arrested and "exchanged" by Chechen quislings; when Western interest made his disappearance awkward, the reporter was brought to Moscow on trumped-up charges. Putin, as Election Day neared, then made the connection between the hated Chechens and the beleaguered Russian press by loudly branding the reporter a "traitor." This plainly implied that any pursuit of truth in a war zone is treason.
The Kremlin plan was to call a snap election to exploit war fever. That's how it could renew its power before the extent of Russian casualties became known and the surge of support for the militarist Putin ebbed. But Chechen guerrillas in the mountains have not cooperated; ambushes abound. Polls show Putin popularity beginning to erode, and a quick vote is in the power clique's interest.
Though the Kremlin's choice remains far ahead of his main opponents, the Communist Gennadi Zyuganov and the lonely democratic reformer Grigory Yavlinsky, Putin hopes to avoid a two-man runoff by winning over 50 percent of the votes on March 26. Even if he does, there's this wrinkle in the law: unless 50 percent of eligible voters show up on the first round to vote for all candidates, the election must be repeated.
The Kremlin clique will inflate next week's count by stuffing ballot boxes. But Harvard's Graham Allison reports from Moscow that apathy is rampant; even the Communists had trouble rounding up 150 bodies for a Red Square rally. Apparently many Russians are disgusted at the way they've been had.
We see what comes when rulers don democratic trappings but use every trick to avoid relinquishing power. As Taiwan's party of power bows to the will of a victorious plurality, Russia's party of power perpetuates a fraud on the Russian people. That's the difference between a successful and a failing democracy.

HEADLINE: DECISION IN TAIWAN: THE MAINLAND;
Deep Feeling That Taiwan Is China's Is Put to Test

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, March 19

 BODY:
Mulling over the shocking fact that Taiwan had chosen the independence party, if not independence, in the presidential election on Saturday, a common response of many Chinese in Beijing today was the nervous question: Do you think there will be war?
Many shook their heads at the possibility. Although Beijing's leaders have been silent about the victory of Chen Shui-bian and the state media have run only brief items, every educated Beijinger now seems to know the details from satellite TV and the Internet. 
 The idea that Taiwan will inevitably reunite with the mainland is probably the most emotional, deeply held belief of ordinary Chinese, from college students to retired factory workers. Last week, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji said 1.25 billion Chinese would be willing to "spill blood" to prevent its independence.
But Mr. Chen's victory forced many Chinese to reflect for the first time on the depth of their conviction, pitting their abstract belief that the return of Taiwan is manifest destiny, against their personal self-interest, since war would mean renewed hardship in a country that has only recently raised its living standards.
Late Saturday night the Chinese government issued its only reaction to the victory, a brief, moderate statement, which said in part, "We will listen to the words and observe the actions of Taiwan's new leader, and wait and see in which direction he takes cross-strait relations."
A government poll released last week showed that 95 percent of Chinese approved using military force if Taiwan seeks independence. But today, the emotions behind that figure were complex and contradictory. Although almost every Chinese will say they care deeply about Taiwan, many are personally ambivalent about fighting for the cause -- even if they think a fight is inevitable.
"We strongly believe that Taiwan should return to the motherland; after Hong Kong and Macao, it is the only one left," said a 20-year-old English major at People's University, who gave her name as Xuan. "But we don't support the use of force. That wouldn't be good for anyone."
Ms. Xuan, like many other Chinese, has seen the society change, as China has opened its doors to Western culture and business. Many people watch N.B.A. games and invest in stocks.
They know that a war with Taiwan -- which would almost certainly draw in the United States -- would mean a return to a more austere and isolationist life. Also with more information and even personal contacts with Taiwanese, many mainlanders find it difficult today to demonize the island.
It is hard for non-Chinese to understand the depths of the Chinese devotion to Taiwan, which is born partly of decades of Communist Party propaganda and partly of the humiliations of China's history, when Westerners carved up China for their economic advantage.
"China was divided when it was weak, and now that it is getting strong again, people's nationalist feeling rises and they feel strongly it is time to reunite the country," said Zhang Yunling, the head of South Asian Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences.
As a result, there is a strong conviction here that countries naturally strive to keep every inch of land, no matter the cost. Chinese officials are wont to ask how Americans would respond if Alaska or Hawaii tried to secede. They seem disbelieving when the question is answered with an indifferent shrug.
And for many Chinese today, that deep emotional attachment still governed their views.
"Ordinary people just want to get on with their lives, and whether Taiwan becomes independent has no effect on them," said Wang Wei, a middle-age store manager, who said he watched Taiwan's election returns on a Hong Kong television station with some army friends.
"But," he added, "if Taiwan does take steps toward independence, we'll surely just have to give them a beating."
Others were less quick on the draw and hoped that their government -- most known for its unyielding behavior -- would make compromises.
"I think both sides will have to make adjustments to their policies," said a 22-year-old physics major at Beijing University, who refused to give his name. "After all Taiwan is democratic now, and the people have exercised their own right to chose a president."
Still, he too "accepted that war was inevitable" if Taiwan declared independence. He added:
"The idea of unity is very important to the Chinese people, and we treasure the idea. These ideas have sunk deeply into people's minds, and we just accept them and wouldn't think of changing them."

HEADLINE: DECISION IN TAIWAN: THE WHITE HOUSE;
The U.S. Scrambles to Keep a Lid on Tensions and to Rescue Its China Policy

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 19

 BODY:
For more than a decade, Washington has urged Taiwan to let true democracy flower, knowing that it could eventually lead to the defeat of the Nationalist Party by pro-independence forces and put the island, and even perhaps the United States, on a collision course with mainland China.
But when the moment arrived over the weekend, administration officials conceded, the timing was singularly inopportune. 
 The victory of Chen Shui-bian, the opposition leader who until recently openly advocated Taiwan independence from China, sent White House and State Department officials scrambling today to prevent an escalation of tensions.
And it may well change the calculus for the administration's biggest foreign policy push in Congress this year, getting China into the World Trade Organization, a deal that is ultimately more about security and China's role in the world than about regulating trade.
"Two weeks ago we were focused on the domestic debate here, over the W.T.O. and arms sales to Taiwan," a senior administration official said. "But the landscape has completely changed. And now our primary focus is to manage the cross-strait relations -- and to keep everyone from doing something stupid."
The State Department's top official for Asia, Stanley Roth, and the American delegate to the United Nations, Richard C. Holbrooke, are in Beijing now. Their plan, administration officials said today, is to urge President Jiang Zemin to say little in public and reach out to Mr. Chen, rather than give in to hard-liners pressing to make good on China's recent threats. Their visit will be immediately followed by the arrival of President Clinton's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, on completion of Mr. Clinton's trip to India and Pakistan.
At the same time, the White House searched today for someone to send to Taiwan with a similar message to Mr. Chen about the need to steer clear of statements likely to incite Beijing.
The most likely choice, officials said, is former Representative Lee H. Hamilton, a longtime China hand who now runs the Woodrow Wilson International Center for Scholars. Under the bizarre diplomatic rules of Washington's "one China" policy, no senior American official can officially visit or consult with the island's leaders -- even as the United States gives Taiwan defensive weapons.
Even if an immediate crisis is averted, the ouster of the Nationalists greatly complicates Mr. Clinton's effort to give order to a messy relationship with the United States.
With only 10 months left in office, he wants to persuade Congress to give China permanent trading rights and a voice in the World Trade Organization. Earlier this month, Mr. Clinton argued passionately that the vote marks America's best chance to change China -- through the Internet and the opening of its market -- and to loosen Communist control.
But if Mr. Jiang and his prime minister, Zhu Rongji, decide in coming weeks that Taiwan's new challenge mandates a response, administration officials say, the economic opening to Beijing may be doomed.
"Our hope is that Beijing will maintain the stance that it took immediately after the election on Saturday, a moderate tone," said Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, who is at the center of the W.T.O. debate. But if that tone changes, she said, "there's no telling where this could go."
The administration is already under pressure from conservatives to sell far more arms to Taiwan, to counter Beijing's growing missile threat to the island. Last month, the House voted overwhelmingly to approve the Taiwan Security Enhancement Act, which would establish direct military communications between Washington and Taipei and expand American training of Taiwan's military officers. The administration considers the legislation so provocative to Beijing that Mr. Berger referred to it recently as "the Taiwan Insecurity Act" and has recommended that it be vetoed.
Republicans, led by Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the majority whip, chose it as the first major bill for the year precisely because it would challenge China. And if tensions escalate in coming weeks, it may be appended to the World Trade Organization legislation -- leaving Mr. Clinton with the agonizing choice of letting his major overture to China die, or outraging Beijing by linking its economic role in the world with support for an island it considers, now more than ever, a renegade province.
The long-term American concern is that the suddenly chaotic political landscape in Taipei could put the United States into the middle of a dangerous crossfire.
Washington has been committed to Taiwan's defense since the cold war. In 1996, Mr. Clinton sent two carrier groups to the end of the strait in response to China's firing several missiles into waters near Taiwan before elections that year.
Last week, Mr. Zhu warned that any move toward independence -- or even foot-dragging in talks about unification -- could prompt China to "spill blood."
America's response is to leave China with the impression that the United States would intervene if China made a military move. But that threat is of diminishing value. The Chinese know the American political landscape well -- and Mr. Clinton's aides, in private moments, wonder aloud whether Americans would risk war with the world's most populous nation over the fate of Taiwan.

HEADLINE: Maryland Hostage Siege Drags on Into Third Night

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: DUNDALK, Md., March 19

 BODY:
A former convict with a history of mental illness, hunted in a shooting spree that took four lives, maintained a standoff against the police today, crackling the air with warning gunfire as he held three hostages in this tense suburban neighborhood.
"Come on, Joby, pick up the phone," police officers pleaded over a loudspeaker from an armored car parked near the building where the suspect, Joseph Palcyzinski, known as Joby, had been holed up almost three days. 
 The fugitive's response was a burst of gunfire that shot out the tires of the armored car. Police officers retreated as they kept a four-block-square area of this bedroom community under siege and the standoff headed into a third night.
The 31-year-old suspect had been tracked by the police since March 7, when, the authorities say, he kidnapped a former girlfriend, Tracy Whitehead, and fatally shot two of her friends and a neighbor. Ms. Whitehead escaped unharmed. Police officers would not disclose her whereabouts.
In a subsequent car-jacking, Mr. Palcyzinski killed a woman and injured a small boy, according to the police.
Trackers lost him last week during a hunt through eastern woodlands until he invaded the home of Ms. Whitehead's mother, Lynn, in a burst of gunfire here on Friday night. His hostages include Lynn Whitehead, her boyfriend, Andy McCord, and his son, 10-year-old Brad McCord.
Mr. Palcyzinski, an unemployed electrician with a history of domestic violence and prison and hospital incarceration, has been obsessively following the siege on television, the Baltimore County police said. They asked broadcasters to refrain from inciting him with photos of estranged family members and other reminders of his grievances.
"He's responding constantly to television," said Bill Toohey, the police spokesman, as TV news producers promised cooperation. "Our main strategy is patience, patience, patience," Mr. Toohey emphasized as police officers in military assault gear blanketed the area and warned residents to stay off the streets.
Residents largely complied as Sunday quiet reigned through much of this blue-collar neighborhood. A few neighbors darted from backdoor exits on food-shopping missions.
Police officers have not commented on the question of some alarmed neighbors as to why the Whitehead residence had not been under police guard, since Mr. Palcyzinski was believed to have made threats to kill Mrs. Whitehead earlier this month.
One neighbor, Anna Day, heard gunfire after dawn today and swept up her baby, fleeing the area despite police warnings. "After I heard the gunshots this morning, I said I have got to get out of here," Ms. Day said as she headed to safety with her relatives.
At midday, about 50 people stood watching at the closest police cordon, four blocks from the siege, where the news media worked. The police said there would be no action that might risk the hostages' lives. At one point, some bystanders held hands and joined in prayer.
In an earlier police standoff after a domestic violence complaint in 1992, Mr. Palcyzinski kept the police at bay for 16 hours in Idaho before he surrendered in a tear-gas barrage.
According to Mr. Palcyzinski's friends and family, the fugitive suffers from bipolar disorder, a manic-depressive behavior they say resulted from a severe blow to the head in a school bus accident when he was a teenager. Since then he has served three years in mental institutions and two years in prison, plus several years' probation for incidents usually involving the beatings of girlfriends.
"I was like a bomb waiting to explode," he told one judge in a past hearing in unsuccessfully seeking to plead not guilty by reason of insanity. The fugitive reportedly is currently demanding to make an insanity plea as part of his conditions for surrendering.
The slayings this month occurred days after Tracy Whitehead, 22, pressed assault charges against Mr. Palcyzinski, who then was released on $7,500 bail. She had broken off their yearlong relationship on March 3 and later called the police after she said he bloodied her in a beating.
After making bail, Mr. Palcyzinski obtained a rifle and a shotgun illegally through a friend, according to the police, and went looking for Ms. Whitehead at an apartment where she was staying with her co-worker, Gloria Jean Shenk. Police officers said Mr. Palcyzinski broke into the apartment on March 7 and killed Ms. Shenk, her husband, George, and a neighbor, David Meyers, who tried to subdue the gunman. He kidnapped Ms. Whitehead, who subsequently escaped, and the authorities said he later fatally shot a motorist, Jennifer McDaniel, during a car-jacking as he fled the police.
In the siege here on Lange Street, Mr. Palcyzinski, who the police say stole three fresh weapons last week in a burglary in nearby Essex, has been demanding to talk to Ms. Whitehead. But the police have offered no indication of how negotiations with him have been proceeding. A motorized robot cart has delivered food and, according to some reports, a cell phone demanded by the fugitive.
Ms. Whitehead's sister-in-law, Donna Collins, told the police she talked by telephone with Mr. Palcyzinski in the early hours of the siege and he told her, "I've killed four already, and I'll kill these here, too."

HEADLINE: Power Authority Set to Choose Buyer of 2 Reactors

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
The New York Power Authority is expected to choose today between two out-of-state companies fiercely bidding for the authority's two nuclear plants, setting the stage for what would be the largest sale of nuclear plants in this country.
In recent weeks, the proposed sale of the Indian Point 3 plant, in Westchester County, and the James A. FitzPatrick reactor, in Scriba on Lake Ontario, has attracted spiraling bids and counterbids, analyses and counteranalyses, from the two suitors, Entergy Nuclear, of Jackson, Miss., and Dominion Resources, of Richmond, Va. While each company claims that its offer is superior, this much seems clear: the winning bid will amount to at least $806 million and also represent the largest sale of a public asset to a private buyer in New York State. 
 Entergy has long had the inside track; for months it was the only company negotiating with the authority for the plants, until Dominion made a bigger, unsolicited bid in February. Still, Michael A. Petralia, a spokesman for the authority, said yesterday that the board of trustees would weigh both proposals equally and choose one at a meeting today in Manhattan.
"We expect that the trustees will take action, absolutely," Mr. Petralia said.
Either way, the decision is likely to be subject to much scrutiny and second-guessing.
Last week, the authority released a brief analysis by J. P. Morgan stating that both proposals were excellent and that they "by far exceed any previous nuclear asset sale in the United States in terms of dollars per kilowatt of capacity."
But for months now, numerous state legislators and watchdogs of nuclear power have criticized the authority for failing to make the privatization process as competitive as possible. They say that after the recent radiation leak at Indian Point 2 -- Indian Point 3's privately owned next-door neighbor -- and given the swift deregulation of utilities, such a major decision affecting taxpayers and the environment should be made as prudently and openly as possible.
"This is so important because it is by far, by orders of great magnitude, the largest sale of a publicly held asset in New York State," Assemblyman Richard L. Brodsky, a Westchester Democrat, said yesterday. Mr. Brodsky, who is chairman of the Assembly Committee on Environmental Conservation, said, "There is no reason on God's earth that this deal should close tomorrow."
The New York Power Authority was never really supposed to be in the business of nuclear power; its original mandate was to foster economic development and improve energy efficiency. In the 1970's, though, it became involved in nuclear power after a struggling Consolidated Edison built Indian Point 3, in Buchanan, but sold it to the authority before it opened.
As a result, the authority and Con Edison, which runs Indian Point 2, have described themselves as "mom and pop operators." But in recent years, with utility deregulation taking hold, both Con Ed and the authority have sought to sell their plants to companies that are interested in accumulating nuclear plant sites -- like Entergy, which has five, and Dominion, which has two.
About two years ago, Entergy approached the Power Authority, a quasi-independent agency, about buying Indian Point 3 and the FitzPatrick reactor, said Jerry W. Yelverton, the chief executive of Entergy Nuclear. The two later began negotiations.
On Feb. 14, the power authority announced that it had tentatively agreed to a deal: $638 million for the plants, and $168 for nuclear fuel stockpiles, spread over seven years. In addition, the power authority agreed to pay for most of the costs of decommissioning the plants when Entergy officials conclude that they have reached the end of their useful, or profitable, life.
Yet controversy shadowed the deal. Mr. Brodsky, with fellow Democratic Assemblymen Paul D. Tonko of Montgomery County and Albert Vann of Brooklyn, criticized the Power Authority for not opening the process to competitive bidding. They said that the state, and by extension, all electricity customers, might not be getting the best price. In addition, the legislators, coupled with some nuclear power watchdog groups, complained about the power authority's failure to make public a detailed financial analysis of the bid.
Then came Dominion.
On Feb. 24, the company, which is the parent company of Virginia Power, made an offer for the two plants with an unsolicited bid of $686 million, and $171 million for nuclear fuel stockpiles, for a total of $857 million, or $51 million more than Entergy's offer.
As a result, the New York Power Authority gave the two companies until March 10 to submit new bids. So when March 10 rolled around, each company, naturally, proclaimed its offer to be the better one.
Dominion sweetened the pot by saying that it would pay a total of $946 million for the plants, an increase of $89 million. Dominion also offered its full corporate resources as collateral against any unforeseen decommissioning costs, unlike its competitor, which is relying on its Entergy Nuclear subsidiary, a limited liability corporation, and not the parent company in New Orleans, as collateral.
But above all, Dominion said that it was simply offering more money.
"What you ought to focus on is the dollars that the citizens of New York State receive," said Thos. E. Capps, Dominion's chairman.
Entergy did not change the cash component of its original proposal: $806 million. Instead, it announced a new bid of $1.12 billion through an increase of $314 million in projected benefits like paying more money to decommission the plants and selling more electricity at below-market prices to the authority.
In addition, Entergy said it should be rewarded for the substantial investments in money and time spent on putting together its offer.
"You have to look at the overall, broader package for the state of New York," Mr. Yelverton said.
In the last few days, the two companies have offered competing economic models and projections. The latest have Dominion saying it can provide $1.52 billion in cash and speculative benefits and Entergy up to $1.42 billion.
The power authority, meanwhile, has tried to stay out of the fray, releasing only the analysis by its consultant, J. P. Morgan. But one thing that should be noted, Mr. Petralia said, is that either offer would pay off the remaining $316 million in debt on Indian Point 3. (The FitzPatrick plant is paid for.)
"Whatever is decided is going to be a tremendous benefit to the state," Mr. Petralia said.
To date, few nuclear plants have actually changed hands, and when they do, it is usually from one private company to another. Moreover, out of the 100 or so plants still operating in the country, the power authority sale may well be the first one involving the privatization of a publicly run nuclear plant, said Edward Smeloff, executive director of the Pace Law School Energy Project.
So the fate of the power authority's plants may well provide a road map on what may eventually happen with the two Millstone plants in Connecticut, as well as to the beleaguered Indian Point 2 plant.
"I think it's important because it gets New York State out of the business of owning a nuclear plant, and I think that, from a large policy perspective, is the right thing to do," Mr. Smeloff said.

HEADLINE: Shards of Misery, Not Far From Clinton Stop in Bangladesh

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: DHAKA, Bangladesh, March 19

 BODY:
The wretched squatter colony known as the Kawran Bazaar Bustee straddles Dhaka's main railroad line, the relentless iron wheels of the trains rolling within feet of the flimsy hovels of scrap metal, thatch and muslin.
The slum's only open space is the narrow lane between the two tracks, so working parents often think it wise to tie up their small children rather than to let them wander. Three months ago, Hanufa, age 3, was slow to heed the dangerous chugging of an oncoming engine. Her head wounds have since healed but her right hand was torn off at the wrist. 
 Asiya Khatun is the girl's grandmother. She has lived beside the trains for 20 years, making her home in a filthy lean-to barely a yard square. A small crowd huddled near her on a recent day as she assessed her life. "We have nothing, and we are nobodies," she concluded, with the others nodding in agreement as if they had just heard a concise rendering of perfect truth.
About a third of Dhaka's nine million people live in some of the world's most miserable slums, grafting themselves to empty patches of precious land. The Kawran colony is unusual in that it is not only near a busy railway but also within 200 yards of a five-star hotel, the place where Bill Clinton and the American entourage will freshen up when they arrive here on Monday. He will be the first American president to visit Bangladesh.
Except for televised images of its reiterating and incomparable floods, this nation -- the eighth-most-populous on the planet -- does not often come to America's attention. It is perhaps best known as the pet cause of George Harrison, the former Beatle, who in 1971 had a hit song with the unusually sober rock lyrics: "Bangladesh, Bangladesh/ Where so many people are dying fast/And it sure looks like a mess/ I've never seen so much distress."
That lament accompanied the country's difficult birth after a war of independence against Pakistan. Three decades later, Bangladesh remains one of the world's poorest nations. The per capita income is $289. A million villagers each year lose their homes to fickle rivers that engulf their land. Democracy suffers prolonged malfunctions, in part because the two women who run the main political parties hate each other down to the bone.
And yet in most ways Bangladesh is now decidedly in less of a mess, with the poverty rate drifting down and economic growth rates inching up.
Indeed, many here fear that President Clinton is coming not just to shake hands but to make money. It seems that Bangladesh is sitting on a small fortune in natural gas.
"We're calling this the Persian Gulf East," said Forrest E. Cookson, an American economic consultant who has been involved in a study of the potential profits from the gas.
That is hyperbole, but initial exploration by foreign oil companies does show that Bangladesh may have not only enough gas for its own needs but a sizable surplus as well. The amount of the abundance is uncertain, however -- and that poses a problem. Big corporations are willing to bore more wells, but in turn they want guarantees that they can maximize profits by selling any oversupply to gas-needy India, the colossus next-door.
Bangladeshi leaders are wary of such deals. Their own experts guess the gas reserves to be modest. And if a glut does exist, they argue that it should be used at home, converted into fertilizer or electricity rather than sold to a neighbor thought to be overbearing. The United States government, it is presumed, sides with its oil giants.
"Colonial exploitation is a fact of our lives," said Serajul Islam Choudhury, an English professor and well-known social commentator. "People here think America is the new East India Company. Mr. Clinton is the company's big man."
American officials quietly insist otherwise, saying Mr. Clinton is simply making a day trip here while in the neighborhood in advance of five days in India and a short pause in Pakistan.
But the apprehensions are understandable. A recipient of $1.5 billion a year in international aid, disaster-prone Bangladesh is used to being treated as a beggar and not courted for its purse.
Mother Nature has exhibited the full arc of her mood swings in this country. On one hand, Bangladesh possesses the world's largest delta landscape with bountiful rivers that crisscross in lengthy braids. The earth is ever-enriched by alluvial silt. The greenery is lush. Farmers manage to feed 128 million people -- almost half the population of the United States -- packed into a country slightly smaller than Wisconsin.
But the water knows no master and is often a deadly conduit. Bacteria in ponds have been prolific killers. In response, the government and Unicef and other aid groups convinced villagers to sink tube wells to tap the underground aquifer. But that drinking water now turns out to be tainted with dangerous levels of arsenic. Millions of people are slowly poisoning themselves sip by sip, with the authorities confounded about what to do.
In the long, wet summers, snow melt from the Himalayas and monsoon rains hits the rivers with such force that it alters the contours of the channels, and then the Darwinian laws of real estate take effect. Where the poor once had homes, there is now river. And where there was once river, there is now virgin land, inevitably gobbled up by the rich.
"Look out there," said Abdul Ahad, a bony, bare-chested man covered from the waist down in a skirt-like wrap called a lungi. He was pointing into the brown calm of the Jamuna River at a spot about a quarter mile offshore. "Four years ago, that's where my home was, mine and 200 others and a school too. The river ate them."
His village is Jafarganj, a place with houses of thatched walls and cement floors located about 60 miles west of Dhaka. Each summer, the vagabond river swallows more of the village, although the size and timing of the bites are hard to predict. Some people who think they are safe for another year suddenly see their homes licked away by the current.
"Who wants to live with such uncertainty?" asked Rowshan Ara, a woman with three young children at her side. "But we cling to what we have for as long as we can."
Victims of the rivers take refuge with relatives or settle along the fringe of the dirt roads. Or they go to Dhaka, the capital, living in slums like the Kawran Bazaar Bustee, some clinging to deeds for land that has been submerged for generations.
Shirin, who uses only one name, says she was brought to Kawran when she was 6 months old. She is unsure of her own age, but her two daughters are 2 1/2 and 1. She lifted a blue plastic curtain to display a tiny cave of a home with walls of blankets and burlap. Flies were doing their primitive dance above a husk of coconut.
"I can sometimes get work as a maid," she said. "But when I am gone, I worry about my children. My cousin is here, but she is busy."
There is a fish market near the slum, and the odor of the rotting catch is powerful. For income, people sometimes buy a few fish, cut them up and try to sell the pieces for a profit. Others pull rickshaws, earning about $1 a day.
Between the train tracks, mothers cook over fires fueled with wood chips. Children play games of carom. There is water to fetch, but it is expensive at 4 cents a pitcher. The privacy of an outhouse costs about the same.
On Feb. 23, there was a police attack on the squatter colony, part of the government's occasional effort at slum clearance. "I asked them where they expected me to go," said Beauty, an old woman with a squint that made her eyes look like two brown peepholes. "They told me to go back to my village, but I am from Laskshmipur and everything there was taken by the river. The only thing left are small islands of sand. What should I do, eat the sand?"
Life is a day-to-day struggle, and yet many in Bangladesh are escaping poverty. The nation has become known for its plenitude of nongovernmental organizations, many made rich by foreign donors, which are credited with impressive gains in health care, population control and the empowerment of women. They have helped peasants buy income-producing farm animals.
The government itself has made sincere efforts, though most analysts say political leaders are easily distracted by self-interest. "You can say this is the kind of nice Islamic country that America likes -- doesn't host terrorists, doesn't force women to wear veils -- but the political parties are corrupt Tammany Hall patronage machines," a Western diplomat said.
"The purpose of the parties is to make sure their businessmen get the contracts and the loans -- and to make life impossible for the political opposition."
The Awami League and the Bangladesh Nationalist Party have little in the way of policy disagreements, and yet they steadfastly attack each other with profanity, street violence, general strikes and boycotts of Parliament.
"This country is accomplishing many things, and the future has such promise, but this is despite the politicians and not because of them," said Muhammad Yunus, the managing director of the Grameen Bank. "Our politicians are stuck with their own history and are always settling scores."
The leader of the Awami League is the current prime minister, Sheik Hasina, daughter of the nation's first elected leader, Sheik Mujibur Rahman. He was gunned down in his home by a handful of renegade army officers in 1975 along with his wife, brother, three sons, two daughters-in-law, a grandson and several other close relatives.
The leader of the Nationalists is Khaleda Zia, the widow of Gen. Ziaur Rahman, a military dictator who praised and rewarded the confessed killers of Mrs. Hasina's father. The dictator was assassinated by army officers in 1981.
After 16 years of military rule, democracy returned to Bangladesh in 1991. The Nationalists won that year's election, but Mrs. Zia's ability to govern was limited when the Awami League took to the streets in a prolonged campaign of agitation.
Mrs. Hasina became prime minister in 1996 and now faces the same tactics. The Nationalists and several smaller parties are boycotting Parliament. General strikes are enforced by thugs who pull people from their autos as they try to get to work.
"It's the politics of tit for tat, the country be damned," said Mahfuz Anam, editor of the English language newspaper, the Daily Star.
Mrs. Zia, 54, takes issue with such remarks, refusing to share any blame for the country's troubled governance. She is not a taciturn woman. Asked about the state of democracy in Bangladesh, she replied with a 67-minute filibuster against her opponents.
Later, she admitted to hating Mrs. Hasina, but stressed that this deep loathing was nothing personal. She disagreed with those who suggest the welfare of the impoverished nation suffers because of a private feud.
"My differences with Hasina are all political," she said, sitting before a huge portrait of her late husband. But then she thought a while longer. And anger rose in her throat.
"I went to her daughter's wedding when I was prime minister and I was not properly received," she said bitterly, waving her index finger. "She did not even come and sit with me."
Mrs. Hasina, 53, likewise declaimed the notion of a private grudge. "Why should I hate her?" she said, sitting in an office decorated with paintings of her father. Her government has successfully prosecuted many of her father's killers. She has renamed an extraordinary number of public structures in her family's memory.
"There is no personal clash or enmity with Khaleda," the prime minister repeated, sloughing aside the very suggestion. "I am the daughter of the father of the nation. Who can match that? When my father was head of the country, her husband was just a major."

HEADLINE: Clinton Begins Visit to India, But First Comes Bangladesh

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, March 19

 BODY:
President Clinton, accompanied by his daughter, Chelsea, but not by the first lady, Hillary Rodham Clinton, arrived to a low key welcome here tonight for a state visit that the administration hopes will set the foundation for a new relationship with India.
Before getting down to business here, however, Mr. Clinton is to pay a one-day visit to Bangladesh, the first by an American President to that country. 
 A 21-gun salute boomed as the president and Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright walked down a red carpet on Monday to an arrival ceremony, where they were greeted by Prime Minister Sheik Hasina and President Shahabuddin Ahmed, The Associated Press reported from Dhaka, the capital. Thousands of people waving American and Bangladeshi flags lined Mr. Clinton's motorcade route.
Security concerns apparently led to an unusual last-minute change in plans for the Monday itinerary.
Shortly after the president arrived in New Delhi, the White House announced that because of "concerns raised by the Secret Service" he would not make a planned visit to the Bangladeshi village of Joypura.
Officials declined to elaborate on the statement beyond saying that for security reasons, the trip to the village 20 miles northwest of Bangladesh's capital, Dhaka, had been canceled. Bangladesh does not have a recent history of violent incidents.
Mr. Clinton was to have taken the presidential helicopter to the village, spending about 90 minutes there in a primary school for girls and meeting with women who have successfully started small businesses with loans from the Grameen Bank. The bank, which was founded in Bangladesh, has been seen as a world model for that type of tiny economic development loan. Mr. Clinton will meet with some of the women and children from the village at the American Embassy in Dhaka.
Mr. Clinton is the first American president to visit India in 22 years. The last visit -- by President Carter, who made some unflattering remarks about the government before an open microphone -- did not go so smoothly.
This time, and with those memories faded, each side appears determined to make a good impression.
Chaotic and congested New Delhi was being scrubbed and scoured today, with curbs freshly whitewashed and new red gravel laid on sidewalks. Lilies and dahlias were being hastily arranged at the gates of the memorial to Mohandas Gandhi, where Mr. Clinton will pay homage.
In public, Mr. Clinton and the Indian leaders are set to proclaim a friendship based on shared values of democracy and economic interests, a case the president will probably make most passionately in his scheduled address to the Indian Parliament.
In private, Mr. Clinton will attempt to walk the delicate line of letting the Indians know that the United States strongly disapproves of their nuclear weapons but without appearing to scold his hosts, who are sensitive to what can be perceived as big brother hectoring them.
The Indians got a taste of what was on Mr. Clinton's mind when he said at a nuclear nonproliferation conference in Washington last week: "There are those in the region who hope we will simply accept its nuclear status quo and move on. I will not do that."
The Clinton administration has pressed India to sign the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, and Mr. Clinton will stress this again with Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, Clinton aides said. Indian officials say that the United States is hardly persuasive in demanding that India adhere to a treaty that the United States Senate failed to ratify last fall.
Mr. Clinton will also try, his aides say, to make headway with the Indians on Kashmir but without playing a mediating role, which the Indians reject. The president recently called South Asia "the most dangerous place" on earth, a conclusion drawn from the dispute over Kashmir between India and Pakistan, two hostile neighbors with nuclear weapons.
Mr. Clinton will urge the government to consider a dialogue with Pakistan, and on Saturday he will give a similar message to the military government in Pakistan during his brief stopover there. At the moment, relations between the two countries are so sour that there is no official dialogue and scant contact between citizens, Clinton administration officials have said.
Much easier for Mr. Clinton will be his acknowledgment of the Indian the high-tech industry and the contributions it has made to the American computer world.
Mr. Clinton will also make note of the efforts by the Indian government to reform the economy, which has been choked by high tariffs and state-run management. The United States sees considerable prospects for American business in India. In the coming years, $250 billion will be spent in India on power-generating equipment and $100 billion on telecommunications, said a former American ambassador to India, Frank Wisner.
"The visit is a terrific opportunity for the United States to root itself in the region, to get some traction on the issues to create a privileged position for us as we go forward," said Mr. Wisner, who is now in private industry.
In a newspaper column welcoming Mr. Clinton, Uday Bhaskar, the deputy director of the Institute of Defense Studies and Analyses in New Delhi, was more cautious. He wrote in today's Sunday Times of India that India and the United States were moving "a bit gingerly, like two porcupines trying to be friends."
Expectations should not be too high, Mr. Bhaskar said. But if all goes well, he added, "the Clinton visit and the entourage that accompanies him will be able to realize the potential between natural but currently wary allies."

HEADLINE: Known as Poacher, New Jersey Is Faced By Rival to the West

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

DATELINE: BETHLEHEM, Pa.

 BODY:
After years of luring Manhattan jobs and companies across the Hudson River with promises of cheap real estate, lower taxes and tax breaks, New Jersey now finds that an interloper on its western flank is wooing manufacturers, distributors and back offices to the Lehigh Valley of northeastern Pennsylvania.
Dozens of companies based in New Jersey have moved at least some of their operations across the Delaware River to a 30-mile stretch of corn fields, turkey farms and dormant steel mills encompassing Easton, Bethlehem and Fogelsville. 
 Improving on a page from New Jersey's playbook, Pennsylvania state officials and the Lehigh Valley Economic Development Corporation are offering even cheaper real estate, even lower taxes and even more tax breaks.
While New Jersey has chased blue-chip marquees from the New York Yankees to the New York Stock Exchange, the Lehigh Valley has opened its network of 42 industrial and corporate parks to all companies large and small, well known and obscure.
Fully one-third of the 216 companies that moved to Lehigh Valley or expanded there over the last four years were from New Jersey or New York.
"The hunter has become the hunted," said Linda Dow, a real estate consultant for Insignia/ESG who has advised clients like Aiwa America Inc. and Organon Inc. on moves to the Lehigh Valley. "Many Fortune 500 companies are now considering the Lehigh Valley as a true alternative, not just a stalking horse for a better deal in New Jersey."
The companies may not be as glamorous as Goldman, Sachs, and few companies are moving their headquarters from New Jersey, but they are moving other operations.
After scouring New Jersey for a new regional distribution center, Aiwa, the consumer electronics manufacturer based in Mahwah, N.J., took a look at the Lehigh Valley, where it found helpful officials and a less expensive deal.
The company moved into a new 407,000-square-foot building in Allentown in May 1999 and pulled out of three smaller distribution centers in its home state.
The Vertek Corporation, a software and computer network provider based in Murray Hill, N.J., opened a $6.5 million service center in Bethlehem in 1999 that is expected to employ 170 people. The company received $600,000 in job training grants and tax credits from the state.
Organon, a pharmaceutical company based in West Orange, N.J., opened a small distribution center in Allentown in 1986 and has expanded three times, most recently in 1999 when it added a packaging plant.
Russell Stanley, of Red Bank, N.J., opened a manufacturing plant in Allentown in 1999 for plastic drums used by the food and drug industries.
"We've targeted northern New Jersey and New York and specific industries," said Sara Anderson-Greer, vice president of marketing for the Lehigh Valley Economic Development Corporation. "We're actively marketing the area, meeting with site advisers and building an infrastructure to accommodate them."
Welcome to the war between the states. It makes little difference that the governors of all three states are Republicans. Like their counterparts in California, Alabama and Minnesota, the governors and the local development corporations are chasing jobs and political glory.
No one has made a more concerted effort than Gov. Tom Ridge of Pennsylvania and officials in the Lehigh Valley, where even the giant Bethlehem Steel works, where 30,000 steelworkers once labored over the coke ovens and steel furnaces, is being converted into a 1,600-acre office and industrial park.
The parks allow companies to build almost immediately after signing a deal for office space, a warehouse or manufacturing plant. Employers can then tap into a network of a dozen technical schools, colleges and universities in the valley for trained employees. Local economic development officials and the governor's "action team" aggressively court companies, acting as promoters and expediters.
Bill Bachenberg, founder of DBS International, which designs and supplies computer hardware for business customers, recently moved his company to Bethlehem from Flemington, N.J., after he received a $1.05 million low-interest loan from the state to buy an existing building. As it turned out, three-quarters of his staff already lived in Pennsylvania.
Like the owners of many small and medium-size businesses in New York and New Jersey, he had felt ignored by officials who were more interested in large employers with hundreds of employees.
"Here, the local government welcomed us with open arms," said Mr. Bachenberg, whose company has 30 employees. "We closed on the purchase of our building in the morning, we had a building permit by noon and they started renovations that afternoon. In New Jersey, we'd still be waiting for a permit."
For a variety of reasons, taxes, real estate and labor costs are lower in Pennsylvania. State officials have added further enticements or "tools," ranging from tax credits and job training to cash grants from the governor's discretionary opportunity fund.
Companies that move to one of the year-old Keystone Opportunity Zones, like the one in Lehigh Valley, may not have to pay any state or local taxes for up to 12 years.
According to local real estate executives, the state is close to deals for two major projects, offices for a major pharmaceutical company with about 350 jobs and an old-line insurance company, both based on the east side of the Delaware River.
"I think we've got a toolbox that's as good as anybody's," said Sam McCullough, secretary of the Pennsylvania Department of Community and Economic Development. "We're doing our best to make sure Pennsylvania gets its share or more. We're trying to create an environment that makes it easier and much more profitable to move into Pennsylvania."
Gerald Janssen, senior vice president at the New Jersey Department of Commerce and Economic Growth, was not fazed.
"We bump into them at different economic forums nationally," Mr. Janssen said. "They're aggressive, but all the states are aggressive and looking for their fair share of jobs. We don't see anything to be alarmed about."
He said the state had done very well with its own toolbox of incentives, which he said was one reason the investment banks from Manhattan had been building back-office space in Jersey City.
New Jersey's Business Employment Incentive Program offered new and expanding companies steep rebates on employee income taxes, which are often worth millions of dollars, though many corporate executives complained that New Jersey did not offer subsidies to existing businesses with fewer than 300 jobs.
The Regional Plan Association, antitax groups and many economists contend that special tax breaks or subsidies are not a major factor in the decision of any company to relocate and are therefore a waste of resources. Aiwa, for instance, did not get any tax breaks. A company may move to be closer to its customers, its employees or a generally lower-cost environment.
"The subsidies can turn out to be giveaways," said James Hughes, dean of the School of Planning and Public Policy at Rutgers University. "In many cases, you're providing a bonus for someone who would've taken the same course of action anyway."
Some state officials agreed but argued that the competition for jobs was so fierce that they could not unilaterally disarm.
"Unless you can have an armed truce among all the states," Mr. Janssen said, "everybody has to continue to do it."
So, like big-game hunters, Pennsylvania and New Jersey officials swap tales about the trophies on their respective walls: Pennsylvania attracted 216 companies to the Lehigh Valley alone in the last four years, which accounted for 21,000 jobs and $1 billion in investment.
New Jersey counters with numbers showing that 116 companies moved to the state in 1998 -- 50 from New York and 17 from Pennsylvania -- and were expected to generate 10,600 jobs.
Many of the companies are remarkably similar to those moving from New Jersey to Pennsylvania: manufacturing and distribution centers, as well as the investment banking jobs in Jersey City.
Corporate border-hopping dates from the early 1900's, when silk manufacturers in Paterson, N.J., fled to Pennsylvania one step ahead of union organizers.
But the opening of Interstate 78 in 1989 provided a fast entryway to the Lehigh Valley, and when the economy picked up in the mid-1990's, New Jersey companies began barreling down the highway to Allentown and Bethlehem, where the industrial parks had been under construction for years. New York is 90 minutes away; Philadelphia, 60 minutes.
"I don't think the patterns of development would be a heck of a lot different if we abolished each and every subsidy," Mr. Hughes said.
Many builders expect even more interest from New Jersey companies when Pennsylvania extends Route 33 from Interstate 80 to Interstate 78.
"I consider the Lehigh Valley an extension of the New York metropolitan area," said Jim Petrucci, an industrial developer active on both sides of the Delaware River. "The ready land is the single most important economic tool. If you can come in and build quickly, it presents a tremendous opportunity."
Liberty Property Trust, a national developer, has built eight million square feet of space in Lehigh Valley, the horizontal equivalent of the World Trade Center, and more is on the way.
"I think the distribution market is going to continue to grow," said Peter Eppy, executive vice president of SJB Properties, a developer active in the Lehigh Valley as well as Jersey City and Parsippany, "and i think the office market will be a big growth area."

HEADLINE: SCIENTIST AT WORK/Birute Galdikas;
Saving the Orangutan, Preserving Paradise

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA DREIFUS 

 BODY:
Of the three young women recruited in the 1960's by the paleontologist Louis Leakey to study great apes, Dr. Birute Galdikas, now 53, is the least known. Dr. Leakey's first disciple, Dr. Jane Goodall, who discovered that chimpanzees made tools, has become an international scientific celebrity, and Dr. Dian Fossey, who lived among the gorillas of Rwanda and was killed there in 1985, was played by Sigourney Weaver in the movie "Gorillas in the Mist."
But the story of Dr. Galdikas, who quietly devoted herself to the study and preservation of the Indonesian orangutan, remains largely unknown. 
 "That's because I have a name nobody can pronounce and because I've been in Borneo all these years, tracking an elusive and solitary animal," Dr. Galdikas, whose name is Lithuanian (pronounced bi-ROO-tay GALD-i-kus), said on a recent morning. She had come to New York for several days to take the middle of her three children, Jane Galdikas, 15, to museums and the theater.
Dr. Galdikas also is giving a lecture at 7 p.m. next Tuesday at the American Museum of Natural History in New York.
Still a resident of Borneo, Dr. Galdikas recently became an Indonesian citizen because "the orangutans are Indonesian and because someone in the government suggested it would be helpful."
But she flies regularly to North America to teach at Simon Fraser University in Canada and to oversee her charity, the Orangutan Foundation International of Los Angeles.
Q. Give us a report on the state of the world's orangutans?
A. They are poised on the edge of extinction. It's that simple. We're still seeing orangutans in the forest; they are coming into captivity in enormous numbers. You just know that there can't be that many left in the wild.
Q. How did the orangutans come to be so threatened?
A. The main factor was that until 1988, Indonesia had a forestry minister who was a real forester. In 1988, he was replaced by a forestry minister who was an agriculturist, a promoter of plantations. That signaled a shift in government policy from selective logging to clear-cutting of the forest. For orangutans, clear-cutting is a policy of extinction. If you selectively log, some animals will survive. But with clear-cutting, the habitat is gone. If that weren't enough, in 1997, there were these horrendous fires that devastated the forests.
Moreover, the last three years have been a period of intense political upheaval: an economic crisis, ethnic strife, student riots, President Suharto's resignation. After President Suharto stepped down in 1998, there was a vacuum of power in the center. Once people in the provinces understood that, some felt they could do whatever they wanted. And what some of them wanted to do was log the forest. So throughout Indonesia, places that had, more or less, been protected, became besieged.
At first, only local loggers came in. When nobody stopped them, the bigger commercial loggers followed. Suddenly, there were no more protected parks.
 Q. Is this true too in Kalimantan, Borneo, where you have your research station?
A. Yes, though in the National Park where I work, we're doing what we can. We're trying to set up patrols of local men to go out with park rangers so that when they come across illegal loggers, they don't feel totally intimidated. We're working with the Indonesian government to set up new wildlife reserves at expired logging concessions. And of course, we're doing what we always have: saving wild-born orangutans who've been captured by humans.
We have a hospital for 130 orangutans. We have an orphanage for the babies. Eventually, they are released to the wild, though with the fast-disappearing habitat, it's always tough to find a safe place for them.
 Q. Tell us what you've learned about orangutans in the nearly 30 years you've been studying them?
A. Well, we've gotten a picture of a very long-lived primate who probably lives 60 to 70 years in the wild. They use a wide variety of foods in the wild, about 400 different kinds, because food is generally scarce for them. The males come and go. They're very, very competitive. Probably very few males are successful at actually impregnating females. And the females seem to get pregnant about once every eight years. Also, they're very smart. When orangutans have interactions with humans, they use tools at an incredibly rapid pace.
 Q. Based on what you've seen, do you believe that orangutans can learn language?
A. I think orangutans can learn how to use language at the level of a 3-year-old child. I had a student in 1978, Gary Shapiro, who came to Camp Leakey and he taught an adult female, Rinnie, sign language. He could not believe how fast she learned it. Rinnie took the tutoring personally. One day, Rinnie took Gary by the hand and tried to seduce him. Gary pushed her away. She thereafter lost all interest in signing. Interestingly, my son, Binti, who was then 2, picked up signing from watching Gary and Rinnie together -- though Binti thought that you could communicate with all orangutans through signs. For a while, he went around and signed with all the animals, even those who'd never been taught sign language.
 Q. Did Binti speak orangutan?
A. He could interpret what they meant. He moved it and he felt it. His whole body posture would be like an orangutan.
Q. Did Binti identify as an orangutan?
A. It was heading in that direction. A friend, a psychiatrist came to Camp Leakey in 1979 when Binti was 3 and said, "You know, you should get him out of here. He really needs to be with kids his own age and to go to pre-school." I knew that Jane Goodall's son, Grub, had been through something similar and they sent him to boarding school. So I sent Binti to live with my ex-husband, his father, Rod Brindamour, in Canada. Letting Binti go with his dad was very, very hard. But he had no people his own age and size at Camp Leakey. All he had were orangutans and gibbons. Binti's first friend was a gibbon and she really liked him. This was when he was a baby in a crib.
 In fact, Binti, right now is in Indonesia, working as a volunteer. He's 23 and doesn't want to do this work professionally, but he does want to help. None of my other kids -- Jane, 15, and Fred, 17 -- want to do this, either. They see how hard it is.
 Q. How did you meet your second husband and the father of your two younger children, a Dyak named Pak Bohap?
 A. He worked at Camp Leakey. The first time I laid eyes on him, I saw him in profile, and it was like I was punched in the stomach. I couldn't take my eyes off of him. He was such a handsome man. I was driving and I almost went into a ditch. I was married at the time. After that, I avoided him. I just didn't want to go close.
 Q. How were you able to transcend the barriers of race and culture to make a marriage with a Dyak?
 A. It was possible because the Dyak are probably the most egalitarian people on the planet in the ways of men and women. This is what an anthropologist told me long before I married Pak Bohap. The astonishing thing to me is how comfortable we are. And the fact that we come from different religions and world views, actually keeps the marriage fresh and interesting.
Q. Are you still together?
A. Oh yes. He hates it that I travel so much.
 Q. What's your take on this revival of Darwinism in the social sciences?
A. I don't like the misuses of it. The interaction between environment and genes is so complicated that to use genetic arguments, one has to be careful. Like the recent thing about rape now -- where people are saying that human rape is not about violence, it's about sex, it's just a reproductive strategy -- that's baloney. Maybe it is about reproductive tactics, but it's also about social control.
Q. Orangutans rape, don't they?
A. In Orangutans, rape is about sex. That's all it is. I mean, they don't beat up the female. They don't kill her. Once it's over with, it's over with. Most orangutans that are raped are of childbearing age. With humans you have 90-year-old nuns and 3-year-old girls getting raped. So, there's something other than sex going on with humans.
Q. Getting back to orangutans, when you see what is happening to the animals you've spent your life studying, what do you feel?
A. I feel like I'm viewing an animal holocaust and holocaust is not a word I use lightly. The machine of extinction is grinding away. The destruction of the tropical rain forest in Borneo is accelerating daily. The consequences of this destruction for the orangutans will be final. And if orangutans go extinct in the wild, paradise is gone. And we'll never have it again.
 
http://www.nytimes.com
