HEADLINE: A Comeback for a Man of Freedom;
Nostalgic Epic by Andrzej Wajda Strikes a Chord in Poland

BYLINE: By ALAN RIDING 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 20

 BODY:
Few movie directors have better captured their country's yearning for freedom than the Polish filmmaker Andrzej Wajda. Yet when freedom finally came to Poland a decade ago, the audience for his movies evaporated. He remained a cultural icon, a powerful witness to Communist oppression, but many Poles were now more worried about the future than the past. And, if anything, they preferred to be distracted by American films.
Mr. Wajda could of course afford to rest on his laurels, even finding time to serve as a senator in the first post-Communist government. His place in modern movie history had long been secured through such classics as "Ashes and Diamonds," "Kanal," "Man of Marble," "Man of Iron" and "Korczak," films made between 1957 and 1990 that variously championed the cause of freedom through the changing prisms of the Nazi occupation, Soviet oppression and the Holocaust. 
 At the Academy Awards ceremony in Los Angeles on Sunday, he will receive an honorary Oscar in recognition of his life's work as a director whose films, in the words of the academy's board of governors, "have given audiences around the world an artist's view of history, democracy and freedom, and who in so doing has himself become a symbol of courage and hope for millions of people in postwar Europe."
Yet now, at 75, Mr. Wajda (whose full name is pronounced AHN-dray VY-duh) has made an unexpected comeback. With his latest movie, already seen by six million people in Poland, he has just scored the biggest box office hit of his long career. Even more surprising, he has done so not with a tale of Poles' struggling to adapt to the market economy but with a screen adaptation of "Pan Tadeusz," or "Mr. Thaddeus," an epic poem written in exile in 1834 by the great Polish libertarian Adam Mickiewicz.
The venture was not without risks. Mickiewicz's hymn to patriotism and freedom is taught in Polish schools and, as such, is associated with required reading. While it touches on love, betrayal, land, murder and war, its plot is also immensely complex, revolving around a long-standing feud between the Soplica and Horeszko families, who in the end bury their differences in order to fight their common Russian oppressors. Furthermore, the film has retained Mickiewicz's rhyming verse.
But its success has demonstrated that Mr. Wajda is once again in tune with Poland's mood, this time with its new yearning for a national identity rooted in an idealized past.
"There is this feeling now that there is a paradise in our past, in our imagination," he explained through an interpreter during a visit to Paris. "On a daily basis there is the reality, the brutality of the free market, the difficulty of finding work, the importance of money. All this has created a need for people to plunge into another world, in our language, with our symbols. 'Pan Tadeusz' is a film of great nostalgia."
He said that many people who never go to the movies had lined up to see the film. "I was told of some old women who insisted on sitting in the front row so they could hear all the dialogue, as if they were in a theater," the director said with a smile. He was even more surprised by the turnout among young people. "I thought they might be put off by the verse," he said, "but I think it reminded them of rap music."
Whether a film with such powerful local roots can find a large audience outside Poland is more in doubt. It has been well received by Polish-Americans in the United States and, before its release in France this week, Mr. Wajda visited communities of Polish descendants in Lille and Lyon. But foreign critics who are unable to appreciate Mickiewicz's verse or respond to its romantic patriotism have tended to view it as a highly stylized costume drama.
Mr. Wajda seems unperturbed. He said he made the film principally for Poland. "I think I have things to say, but they are only important if I say them from Poland," he explained. "We cannot tell a story about a man and a woman without dealing with all our history. It would be nice to make a love story without all this history, but it's not possible."
One significant side effect of the movie's success has been to bolster Poland's confidence in its culture: last year, "Pan Tadeusz" and Jerzy Hoffman's "With Fire and Sword," a 17th-century epic, which has drawn seven million spectators so far, demonstrated that locally made films can compete with big-budget fare imported from Hollywood, even the likes of "Titanic" and "Star Wars."
"Under Communism, it was easier to have a big audience," Mr. Wajda said. "We had 3,500 movie theaters; today there are only around 800. In Communist times, cinema was like propaganda, so tickets cost nothing; now they cost the same as in Paris. Television, which used to be very bad, is now competition. There are several networks, plus satellite channels, so you can see almost all movies on TV."
While movie attendance in theaters tumbled, the American market share rose to close to 90 percent by the mid-1990's. And a Polish movie industry that had been producing over 100 movies per year went into crisis. "People wanted entertainment," the director said, sipping a cup of tea in a hotel near the Arc de Triomphe. "Young people were not interested in the past. For them, even 'Man of Iron' and the Solidarity movement seemed to be from the Middle Ages. I made films I had been unable to make under censorship, but there was little public for them."
But finally, it seems, Polish moviegoers tired of a single diet of American movies. And as the Polish economy grew, easing the daily struggle to survive and opening the possibility of Poland's membership in the European Union, Poles began to reflect afresh on their country's place in Europe. "Pan Tadeusz" fits into this pattern: in both the poem and the film, Poles are looking to Napoleonic France in the West to save them from czarist Russia to the East.
With the past no longer taboo, Mr. Wajda next plans to tackle the infamous massacre at Katyn Forest in the Soviet Union in 1940, when thousands of captured Polish Army officers -- among them, the director's father -- were taken to the area and murdered by the Soviet Army. "It will be not so much a war film as a film about a system of lies," he said. "For a long time, the rest of the world said nothing, and we were left alone with this 'secret.' "
If this film is made, it will represent another crucial piece of Mr. Wajda's cinematic history of Poland, one that began with his 1950's trilogy about World War II -- "Generation," "Ashes and Diamonds" and "Kanal" -- and subsequently covered Poland's struggle for independence in the 19th century and under Communist domination. "With my films, you can reconstruct the history of Poland from Napoleon to Solidarity," he said, referring to the political movement that began in 1980 with the Gdansk shipbuilders' strike, which he celebrated in "Man of Iron."
Mr. Wajda has been well placed to do this because, unlike his younger colleague Roman Polanski, he chose not to leave Poland. After World War II, when he played a role in the resistance, Mr. Wajda recalled a brief period of democracy that ended in 1948, "when it became clear that we were in a totalitarian regime that would last an eternity." By the time he emerged from film school in the mid-1950's, however, Stalin was dead and some artistic freedom was permitted. Until martial law was imposed in Poland in 1981, he learned to work in this twilight zone.
"I couldn't do everything I wanted," he said, "but everyone in Polish cinema was united, and we were good at negotiating with political authorities. They also needed our films because they won prizes in the West and showed there was political freedom in Poland. It was a game on both sides. And this game enabled us to make films that strengthened the national identity. The people who supported Solidarity were the same people who saw our films."
Between 1982 and 1988, with martial law enabling the Warsaw government to suffocate all freedom of expression, Mr. Wajda made some films in France and Germany, including "Danton," starring Gerard Depardieu. But he did not formally go into exile, and he avoided taking public political positions. "We were very defeated; we saw no future," he said. "It was in our heads from 1945 that the Soviet Union could only collapse through atomic war, so the Soviet Union could exist forever."
Thus, while the demise of Communism in Poland occurred through negotiations rather than sudden unrest, no one was truly prepared for it, not for the political freedom or for the inflation and unemployment brought by the market economy or for the invasion of American popular culture. For Mr. Wajda, this transition may be the final chapter of his history of Poland.
"The problem is that no one knows how to express it," he said. "Who should be the hero? Let me tell you an anecdote. There's an old soccer stadium which has become an open-air market for Poles and Russians. A Russian comes up to a stall where a Polish girl is selling notebooks. He says, 'How many do you have?' She says, 'How many do you need?' He says, '10,000.' She says, 'I'll have them tomorrow.' Now that is a dialogue that has never existed in Polish cinema. Today, she knows she can find them."

HEADLINE: To Adopt a Village

 BODY:

To the Editor:
The village of Sheri Ram Reddy Guda ("Unwired Villages Mired in the Distant Past," front page, March 19) is one of 500,000 villages in India whose poverty is too familiar. But now, when India has a rapidly growing middle class and a widening elite of the ultra-rich, we must wonder if there is an economic and moral mechanism that will bridge the gap between the ridiculously rich and the abysmally poor. 
 Is it simplistic to suggest that affluent individuals adopt individual villages like these and mentor them out of their misery? Might a well-publicized, successful example of such an adoption prompt similar efforts on a large scale?
"Wiring" is no longer essential when a wireless phone in every village is such a cheap option. And development of small, local, stand-alone electric generators would enable isolated, long-stagnant rural economies to be electrified without the staggering costs of global wiring.
 
LAWRENCE CRANBERG
Austin, Tex., March 19, 2000 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasuries RiseIn Quiet Day Of Trading

BYLINE: By Reuters 

 BODY:
Long-term Treasury bond prices rose yesterday in thin trading as weakness in technology stocks encouraged some safe-haven buying in Treasuries while expectations of higher rates made shorter maturities less attractive, analysts said.
Dealers said a major Federal Reserve policy-setting meeting scheduled for today kept most traders on the sidelines. 
 The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 1/32, to 103 15/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, was unchanged at 6 percent.
Dealers said yesterday was one of the quietest days in recent memory, and price movements were exaggerated with so few players in the market.
"It's probably the quietest day we've had this year," said John Roberts, head of governments trading at Barclays Capital. "Tokyo was closed for Spring Equinox Day; London was quiet. It's been quiet here all day."
The Treasury Department said yesterday that it would buy back more government debt in the second half of April.
Buoyed by budget surpluses, the department said in January that it would buy back up to $30 billion of debt this year. It has already conducted two buybacks, each of $1 billion face value of bonds, focusing its repurchases on older 30-year bonds that pay higher coupons to investors.

HEADLINE: Slipping in Polls, Fujimori Courts Peru's Indians

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: PUNO, Peru, March 19

 BODY:
Slipping in the polls and besieged by international criticism over campaign irregularities, President Alberto K. Fujimori has been fighting off altitude sickness, putting on Indian garb and cutting ribbons across this Andean country in a flourish of pork-barrel politics.
Visiting this 12,000-foot-high city on Lake Titicaca today, Mr. Fujimori never asked the people for their votes, even though presidential elections are only three weeks away. But the message was implicit, and the photo opportunity was golden. 
 The Aymara-speaking Indians here shouted out their support as Mr. Fujimori removed his oxygen mask and strutted to the podium. Scores of officers from the national police smartly marched by, as row after row of new, shiny police vans rotated their emergency lights in unison to welcome the nation's leader.
"We Peruvians have had to travel a long, difficult road these last 15 years against terrorism and hyperinflation," Mr. Fujimori told the audience of 300 police officers and Indian residents. "With great pride and satisfaction, I hand over these vehicles so you can fight delinquency and we never have to go back to the days of insecurity."
In the last few weeks, Mr. Fujimori has raised the minimum wage 18 percent, to $118 a month, and handed tiny pieces of property to more than 150,000 peasants and urban squatters at bargain-basement prices. He has set in motion the procurement of 1,400 tractors for nearly 1,000 communities and begun a huge dike-building project to make the cragged highlands bloom.
And as he did here today, the president is distributing a new fleet of 1,700 Land Cruiser police vans across the country just in time for the presidential and congressional elections on April 9.
To soften his image, Mr. Fujimori recently lifted government emergency powers in the last remaining rural areas where, to fight terrorism the military had the right to detain suspects without bringing charges and to enter houses without search warrants. But for all his efforts, a growing number of political experts are saying the man who has in 10 years in power reduced a vicious and expanding Maoist guerrilla army to a mere band of marauders and a 7,500 percent annual inflation rate to single digits may not win an outright majority and avert a runoff.
In a nationwide poll of 1,505 people last week by Datum International, Mr. Fujimori was favored by 39.6 percent. Alejandro Toledo, the director of a business school, was second, and catching up, with 25.2. Seven others are running well behind.
Experts note that the 61-year-old president did much better than polls predicted when he won his first election in 1990 and re-election in 1995 and that he could still pull off a victory next month.
But Mr. Toledo, who has strong Indian features and promises to be "the president of the poor," appears to be the strongest opponent Mr. Fujimori has ever faced among the poor Indian voters. They have in the past been drawn to Mr. Fujimori, who is of Japanese descent, in part because they see his Asian features as similar to theirs.
Mr. Fujimori's image of invincibility has been damaged in recent weeks by the widespread perception that he has lost control of his campaign and that the election process is badly flawed.
After mounting evidence that Mr. Fujimori's campaign workers forged a million signatures to place him on the ballot, one of the four parties that is backing him withdrew from the campaign last week along with two congressional candidates allied to the president. As the scandal has grown, the national electoral commission dismissed a senior official to ward off contentions that the election was fixed.
With its extensive aid program here, what the United States says carries great weight. And the Clinton administration has been highly critical of the election process in recent weeks. When Prime Minister Alberto Bustamante met senior State Department and White House officials on March 7, he was warned that a fixed election would have grave effects on relations between the two countries.
Two days later, a spokesman for the State Department, James P. Rubin, made headlines here with a checklist of demands to clean up the campaign. He called on Lima to "implement a directive that makes clear that the misuse of state resources for electoral advantage will be severely sanctioned" and to "investigate reports of harassment of opposition candidates and domestic election monitors and take action against those responsible."
Since then, opposition candidates have been given additional television time, and the government has set up a telephone line for complaints about campaign irregularities. Still, several newspapers and television stations widely believed to take their direction from Mr. Fujimori's intelligence service continue to circulate scurrilous reports about the opposition candidates, particularly Mr. Toledo.
In an interview today on his presidential plane, Mr. Fujimori took a conciliatory tone and promised a free election. "Some of the critical observations have been correct," Mr. Fujimori said. "It's possible that there has been harassment and that vehicles of the state have been used to benefit official candidates. We need to correct that when it happens."
He conceded that it was possible he would not win an outright victory on April 9, adding, "It's up to the people to decide."
As Mr. Fujimori's caravan left Puno for a tour of the countryside, he ordered the local police to stay in the city and patrol in the shiny new vans.
With only a handful of aides and a couple of bodyguards, he stopped the caravan at an Indian village, Jechuyo Pamaya, to inspect a rudimentary dike system dug on a hillside under government direction. Mr. Fujimori's new pet project, designed to stop rainwater from flowing down the mountains and to create an underground reserve from which to grow high grasses and trees, is a throwback to Inca technology.
Between gulps of air from his oxygen mask, Mr. Fujimori climbed a rocky hill as 30 awestruck Indians whispered to one another in Aymara and put out their hands to touch the president. They threw confetti into his hair to celebrate the arrival of an honored guest.
"You see this grass, it is going to grow this high!" the president said as he reached to his waist. "Better grass means better cattle and better milk and better nutrition." The Indians nodded and pleaded for a tractor.
Seferina Quille, 60, a peasant woman who was wearing a purple hoop skirt and tall felt hat and carrying a blanket full of potatoes on her back, said she was thrilled by the visit. "I'm going to vote for the president," she said in Aymara, "because he builds roads and schools for us."

HEADLINE: What Now for Beijing and Taipei?

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: TAIPEI, Taiwan, March 20

 BODY:
With a few tantalizingly parallel sentences today, the president-elect of Taiwan and the president of China captured the exasperating and probably intractable differences in their views of Taiwan.
"We can talk about 'one China' as long as it is not a principle," the victorious candidate, Chen Shui-bian, said to Taiwan reporters today. "As long as we are treated as equals, there is nothing we cannot discuss." His advisers regard the statement as a creative concession that may entice Beijing into talks. 
 In Beijing, President Jiang Zemin repeated the formula that his government sees as generous: "The one-China principle must first be recognized. Under this precondition, anything can be discussed."
On such wordplay are matters of war and peace decided across the Taiwan Strait -- or, more prosaically, the matter of whether the two sides can even sit together, as they have not done for years, to negotiate whether packages can be sent across without detouring through Hong Kong.
Around the world and among a decent share of Taiwan's people, there is fear that the election of Mr. Chen, who long advocated a declaration of independence from China but recently backed away on the ground that a formal declaration was not needed, could lead to a military attack by China.
Given all the concern, Mr. Chen and his advisers are surprisingly upbeat. They say he will not only avoid provoking a Chinese attack, but may also be able to coax China into a friendly dialogue as well as new agreements to deepen economic ties and perhaps even a peace treaty.
"I'm optimistic," Chiou I-jen, a top adviser to Mr. Chen who ran his presidential campaign and is the Democratic Progressive Party's representative to Washington, said in an interview. "If both sides can maintain a certain vagueness, then negotiations could carry on."
Mr. Chiou is going next week to Washington, where he will discuss Mr. Chen's strategy with American officials who are worried about possible tensions across the strait but who publicly hailed Mr. Chen's democratic election and the chance for, in President Clinton's words, a "fresh start."
Some experts question the assumption that China will want to seek any common ground with the chief of an independence-minded party.
"I think the optimism from the Chen people and the American government, this idea that they have a new beginning, is extremely dangerous," said Andrew Nathan, an expert on East Asian politics at Columbia University, who observed the election here. "The Chinese simply don't trust Chen Shui-bian. They think his ultimate goal is to cheat China."
Beijing knows that Mr. Chen is in a weak position at home, having won with 39 percent of the vote in a three-way race. He will also be overseeing a divided government, with the legislature still under the control of the Nationalist Party. And Mr. Chen's advisers and a leading opposition expert on cross-strait relations both said Mr. Chen could not even begin to pursue talks with China until he forged a broad consensus domestically, which at best will take many months.
In addition, Chinese leaders have little incentive to cooperate and make Mr. Chen look good, said Mr. Nathan, who predicts four years of serious cross-strait tensions after Mr. Chen becomes president on May 20.
Countering such pessimism, Mr. Chen is fond of evoking the opening to China by the arch-anti-Communist Richard Nixon, saying that perhaps he, too, could make a breakthrough where his predecessors could not.
Mr. Chen and his staff have been buoyed by the initial signs since his election on Saturday.
Mr. Chen has avoided provocative statements, deliberately not uttering, for example, the phrase state-to-state relations, which the outgoing president, Lee Teng-hui, used last summer to the outrage of Beijing.
He has offered to exchange visits with Chinese leaders and discuss removing Taiwan's restrictions on economic ties, a longtime mainland goal. He said he was resigning from the Democratic Progressive Party's executive committee -- a way, perhaps, to dissociate himself from contentious statements in the party platform and from the party's hard-liners.
Though the leaders in Beijing had to be dismayed by Mr. Chen's victory, they halted their pointed vitriol of the week before, so far saying only, "We will listen to your words and watch your actions."
In interviews and speeches in the last two days, Mr. Chen and key advisers have described a strategy that they think may be more attractive to Beijing than what Mr. Lee had to offer.
Essentially, it involves being willing, as Mr. Lee never was, to take up China's offer to discuss Taiwan's status under the principle of "one China."
Mr. Lee accepted in theory that Taiwan and China might loosely unite in the distant future -- after the mainland became a democracy. But he said discussion of such fundamental issues was premature and must be kept aside while practical matters like trade and fishing rights were discussed. For the last several years this impasse prevented any formal negotiations.
The problem is that Mr. Chen does not even pay lip service to a future political link, although he says he will discuss anything including reunification.
That general willingness, from someone who has zero interest in reunifying, is made possible by Mr. Chen's final condition -- the trump card that enables him to agree to almost any dialogue. Any important change in Taiwan's status that is proposed, he insists, must be decided by the democratic will of Taiwan's people.
"We insist on parity and that any ultimate resolution must have the consent of the people," said Mr. Chiou, the adviser to Mr. Chen.
Beijing has already rejected that condition. In February it issued a policy statement deriding the notion that one group -- like the residents of Taiwan -- should vote on a sovereignty issue concerning "all the Chinese people including Taiwan compatriots."
Still, Mr. Chen's advisers say that when Beijing is ready to talk and nurture better ties -- as it was for a time in the early 1990's, even though the meaning of "one China" was not quite agreed on -- the different assumptions can be played down.

HEADLINE: The Murky Tale of Taiwan: Island With an Unruly Past

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

 BODY:
While the United States, China and most countries around the world hold that Taiwan is a part of China, the connections across the Taiwan Strait historically have been tenuous.
Chinese officials often say that Taiwan has always been part of China, but in fact for most of history nobody paid much attention to the island, which was inhabited by non-Chinese peoples who are ethnically and linguistically closer to today's Indonesians than to Chinese. 
 Chinese fishermen and farmers settled along Taiwan's coastal areas in the 16th and 17th centuries but it was Holland that first established an administrative structure on Taiwan, which it seized from the native people in 1624. In 1683, Taiwan came under Chinese imperial rule but was mostly left to its own devices.
Only in 1886 did China declare Taiwan a province and begin to pay attention to the island. In 1895, Japan defeated China and seized Taiwan. Taiwanese leaders sought independence sought support from foreign powers, but no one responded.
It was the Japanese who built schools and modernized the economy.
As many elderly Taiwanese see it, Japan did far more for Taiwan than mainland China ever did. President Lee Teng-hui, for example, spoke Taiwanese as his mother tongue and learned Japanese before he learned Mandarin Chinese (schoolchildren all had to learn Japanese), and he still sometimes speaks Japanese with his wife. Indeed, President Lee has less of an accent in Japanese than in Mandarin Chinese.
The only time in the 20th century that mainland China ruled Taiwan was from 1945, when Japan gave up the island after World War II, until 1949, when Chiang Kai-shek's Nationalist army was defeated by the Communists and fled to Taiwan. The memories of those four years are dominated by the Feb. 28 incident of 1947, when Nationalist troops massacred countless thousands of protesting Taiwanese.
The Nationalists, dominated by mainlanders who insisted that their exiled Republic of China on Taiwan was the legitimate government of all China, tried to remake the island in the mainland's image. The street names in Taipei are based on mainland cities and provinces, and children were forced to speak Mandarin rather than the Taiwanese or Hakka dialects they spoke at home.
But even now, Taiwan's culture bears a heavy Japanese influence and the Mandarin on Taiwan is modestly different from that of the mainland. There are even dictionaries to translate from Taiwan Mandarin to mainland Mandarin. Taiwan uses traditional characters while the mainland uses simplified ones, and a mainlander may have difficulty reading a Taiwan newspaper.
In the Shanghai Communique of 1972, the United States stated that "all Chinese on either side of the Taiwan Strait maintain there is but one China and that Taiwan is a part of China. The U.S. Government does not challenge that position." That fell well short of the United States committing itself to the conclusion that Taiwan is necessarily a part of China. Over the years American officials steadily drifted from that formulation to simply stating that Taiwan is a part of China. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: Restoration In Search Of a Revival;
Furnishings Chain Hurt By Its Own Strategy

BYLINE: By LESLIE KAUFMAN 

 BODY:
When the home furnishings chain Restoration Hardware was preparing for a public stock offering in June 1998, it appeared to be the rare case of a retail concept that could remake its market. Although the chain, with just 43 stores, was tiny compared with its competition, its founder, Stephen Gordon, was hailed as a new Ralph Lauren -- a man with an instinct for translating the aspirations of the moneyed into real stuff.
Instead of offering standard fare like taupe sofas and glass coffee tables, Restoration recreated products from an era before the mass market. Items like restrained beige-and-navy plaid Woolrich camping blankets and tarnished half-moon brass drawer pulls, it hoped, would evoke shoppers' nostalgia for a simple yet craft-rich and elegant past that they had never actually experienced. 
 "They created a mix of traditional plus whimsy that was really very unique," said Wendy Lieberman of WSL Strategic Retail, an industry consulting firm.
Despite its early promise, though, Restoration has had trouble becoming a mass-market player. Over the last year, sales in stores open a year, a standard measure, were flat. More worrisome, for the fourth quarter of 1999, which included the important Christmas season, sales in Restoration stores open a year or more actually fell 5.8 percent. Earnings are expected to be off 18 cents a share for 1999.
This unhappy performance has scared investors. As the Federal Reserve raises interest rates and the housing market cools off, the stocks of all manner of home products retailers have taken hits. But Restoration's woes have been particularly severe. Its share price has plummeted from a high of $37 in July 1998, to $5 yesterday, nearly one-quarter the initial offering price of $19.
The company's troubles may not be fatal, but they certainly have forced it to slow down. In hopes of putting matters right, it cut by half the number of stores it planned to open this year and rethought some of the basics of its strategy.
What went wrong? High on its own buzz, the company expanded at breakneck speed, more than doubling the number of stores, to 94, in the year and a half after the stock offering. That fast growth put a great strain on a company that was just feeling its way and on a not-ready-for-prime-time management team.
"Essentially this is a case study of a company coming to market too soon, a premature I.P.O.," said Shelly Hale, an analyst at Banc of America Securities in San Francisco. "The growth prospects the company had identified were way too aggressive. They just did not have the systems and people to support it."
Restoration is still small. In its last fiscal year, it did just short of $300 million in sales, while rivals like Bed, Bath & Beyond, Pier 1 Imports and Williams-Sonoma, owner of Pottery Barn, each topped $1 billion.
Executives at Restoration Hardware are almost eager to take responsibility for the debacle. "Most of the wounds were self-inflicted," said Walter Parks, the recently appointed chief administrative officer and spokesman. "But when you are in the middle of the storm you don't realize that there might be some shortcomings."
The staff is also pleased to analyze its mistakes -- within limits. It sees the company's errors as part of the growing pains of a naive but solid operation, which in 1995 had only five stores, all in Marin County, Calif.
Company managers agree, for example, that Restoration's original inventory system, which called for all furniture to be kept at stores instead of at a central warehouse, was a disaster. The advantage of such a distribution system is that it allows customers to have instant gratification when buying a sofa, something very rare in the business.
Because of the bulk of the average item, logistics for furniture sales are a critical part of the business. The problem was that unless Restoration could gauge demand with precision, some items could accumulate where they were not needed while other items ran short. This was exactly what happened. The most popular stores did not have the merchandise they needed, while the least-trafficked ones were clogged with leather chairs and cherry dining tables.
Perhaps Restoration is willing to discuss its inventory problems in detail because last summer the chain finally moved to a centralized system, suggesting that such problems could eventually be solved.
But Restoration's most public misstep had less to do with inventory systems than with poor judgment. In February, it ran its first-ever real sale, steeply marking down its mission-style oak and cedar bedroom furniture. It knew it would lose money on each chest of drawers sold but thought of them as loss leaders, believing it would make up the revenue from increased store traffic.
The problem was that demand for these exceptionally popular items quadrupled. And instead of letting customers fight for the few pieces on hand, the company decided to fulfill every request, even if it meant placing special orders from the factory. Not only did that decimate profits for the duration of the sale, it put unanticipated demand on the factories, causing backlogs on other lines of furniture. "We probably will not do a sale again," Mr. Parks said.
But while the company may acknowledge that it was structured poorly, it does not concede that its staff was in over its head -- something that even its allies say is true. "They've really grown, and not everyone there could rise to the occasion," said a sympathetic Mitchell Gold, chairman of Mitchell Gold Inc., which supplies Restoration Hardware and many of its competitors with upholstered furniture. "Sometimes a staff that's comfortable ordering $1 million worth of goods freezes up when they need to order $10 million."
At Restoration's headquarters in Corte Madera, Calif., however, Mr. Gordon and his staff are fiercely loyal to one another, and no one has been dismissed. In Mr. Gordon's view, the problem was not that his people were in over their heads but that there were not enough heads to do the job. "We sure did have a year where we hit a wall in terms of having enough talent on board to execute to the level we had put ourselves up to," he said. "We were coming to the point where people were fracturing, coming apart."
Mr. Gordon's response has been, finally, to fill positions that most companies his size take for granted: executive vice presidents for merchandising, stores and administration. While analysts hope this will help, they still question whether it is enough. They argue that many executives, including Mr. Gordon, are taxed beyond their abilities.
Part of Restoration's marketing charm is the often semiautobiographical descriptions on each piece of merchandise. Juice glasses at Pottery Barn have tags that simply list style, size and price; at Restoration, juice glasses come with this essay:
" 'Pop,' my wife's granddad, was a pretty incredible guy. He worked hard, played hard, always remembered everyone's special occasions, still toiling away into his 80's . . . all-around a fine human being. We inherited Pop's juice glasses and use 'em at our house for all but the 'on the fly' breakfast. In tribute to him (and 'cause we think the glasses are swell) we've reproduced these spry 50's glasses for all the world's juice vessel needs. Pop, being a lover of free enterprise, commerce and the making of a buck, would be proud to oblige. Bottoms up."
Although his company is struggling mightily, Mr. Gordon still writes the copy for each and every tag himself -- nearly 1,000 the last year, by his own estimate. Mr. Gordon defends the practice. "From the outside," he said, "I could see how someone would worry, 'Do we have some guy holed up at home chain-smoking and writing copy?' Nothing could be further from the truth. But if you don't have a compelling product, you have an empty vessel."
But some would argue that even with its products, Restoration has not been smart enough. Competitors like Pier 1 and Crate and Barrel stock up on midrange $30-to-$40 items like pasta serving plates and matching bowls and table linens -- high-margin items that easily add up to entice $100 out of a consumer's pocket. Better still, such sundries change seasonally -- reindeer prints at Christmas, rosebuds in spring -- and give a mall browser reason to come in every few weeks.
Restoration, meanwhile, is skewed with products at the lower and higher ends. And the low-priced gimmickry -- retro items like Moon Pies, marshmallow sandwiches at $9 a dozen, or Mr. Bubble bubble bath, at $3.50 -- is also hurting. "People love to buy the tchotchkes, but when that is all they buy, they are not spending enough to cover the cost of labor," said Janet Kloppenburg, an analyst with Robertson, Stephens.
In addition, the chain's merchandise, while stylish, changes little season to season and year to year. The same batteryless Russian flashlight that made a splash two years back can still be found on Restoration's shelves, as can the mint-flavored tennis balls for dogs to fetch and freshen their breath. "They are more curators than sellers," sighed David Brooks, who wrote a laudatory article about the chain in The New Yorker in 1998 and subsequently become an unhappy stockholder.
While cognizant of these criticisms, Mr. Gordon is only partly moved by them. Although acknowledging that Christmas would have been better with more midpriced items, he insists that is not necessarily the key to increasing sales. He still trusts his instinct to pick a product that resonates with the consumer regardless of price. "When we see an idea that we love," he said, "we will go with it."
Mr. Gordon insists that the problem is not what his company is selling, but its failure to give customers what they want when they want it. And he insists that whatever logistical mistakes Restoration Hardware has made along the way, it has not lost its magic touch with the public. "The consumer is no less passionate today than they were in 1998," he said, "and ultimately passion for the brand is really what it is about."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology Shares Again Hit Hard; Nasdaq Loses 3.92%

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Technology stocks suffered another broad, steep drop yesterday as the Nasdaq composite index fell for the fourth day in the last six sessions.
Biotechnology shares were among the biggest losers, though investors were not selling these or speculative Internet issues to get out of the market. Continuing a pattern of late last week, proceeds from the sales were redirected into blue-chip companies, including a number of time-tested technology producers, like Intel, Hewlett-Packard and I.B.M. 
 "The trend in the Nasdaq composite is definitely down, but it needs a pullback," said Kenneth M. Sheinberg of S. G. Cowen. "A retracement back to the 4,200 level would not be the worst thing that could happen."
By the close of trading, the Nasdaq index had settled at 4,610.00, its low point for the day, down 188.13 points, or 3.92 percent. Since March 10, when it reached a high of 5,048.62, the index has declined by nearly 9 percent. Even with the recent swoon, it is up more than 13 percent so far this year.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 85.01 points, or 0.8 percent, to 10,680.24. Hewlett-Packard, Intel and AT&T were among issues that led the index higher. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index slipped 7.84, or 0.54 percent, to 1,456.63. Reflecting the drubbing of biotechnology and smaller technology companies, the Russell 2000 index slumped 25.57 points, or 4.45 percent, to 549.20.
Market breadth, too, depended on which sectors one considered. On the New York Stock Exchange, declining issues exceeded those advancing, 1,574 to 1,384. But on the technology-laden Nasdaq, matters were markedly worse, with 2,944 issues declining and 1,280 rising.
"The euphoria over anything virtual is being tested again," said Philip S. Dow, a managing director at Dain Rauscher Wessels in Minneapolis. "This is the year when competitive forces are going to show who the winners and losers are going to be."
There was no real news that led the market lower. Indeed, traders said that the week's most anticipated event -- today's meeting of the Federal Reserve's Open Market Committee -- has already been taken into account by the stock market.
The widespread consensus is that Fed policy makers will approve another quarter-of-a-percentage-point increase in short-term interest rates.
Still, the traders said people are skittish about potentially bad news, particularly about first-quarter earnings. "We are in the nasty preannouncement period on earnings," said Michael Molnar, a managing director in retail sales and trading at Salomon Smith Barney.
Worries about what companies might say -- and what the news can do to stock prices -- were apparent early, after MicroStrategy, a highflying inventory-management software manufacturer, said it was restating its 1998 and 1999 financial results downward and that its current-quarter results would fall short of analysts' expectations. In an extraordinary plunge, MicroStrategy shares fell 140 yesterday, to 86 3/4.
"MicroStrategy affected the psychology, and injected a little more sense of urgency to sell some of these stocks," Mr. Molnar said.
Biotechnology issues, hit hard last week, were beaten down again yesterday. Amgen fell 5 1/8, to 58. Immunex lost 23 7/8, closing at 150. Genentech dropped 16 3/8, to 176 1/8. And Millennium Pharmaceuticals slumped 32 3/4, to 141 15/16.
But some companies that reported very good results were also punished. Lehman Brothers foreshadowed what is expected to be a good quarter for Wall Street firms, announcing earnings that were higher than estimates. But its stock fell 3 5/8, to 87 13/16. Other Wall Street firms scheduled to report this week also slumped. The Goldman Sachs Group dropped 3 1/16, to 113 7/16. Morgan Stanley Dean Witter shed 1 1/16, to 87 11/16.
Well-known semiconductor and computer stocks were among the technology-related shares that posted gains. Intel, which introduced two faster versions of its flagship Pentium III microprocessor yesterday, rose 5 1/8, to 135. Hewlett-Packard, another Dow component, was up 6 3/16, at 144. I.B.M. closed at 112 3/4, up 2 3/4. And Dell Computer climbed 1 1/4, to 57 11/16.
AT&T rose to 56 7/8, up 3 11/16.
Prices of oil service stocks fell sharply as the price of crude oil dropped to a three-week low. Schlumberger dropped 4 1/16, to 70 1/4. Smith International fell 3 3/4, to 65 5/8. And Halliburton dropped 2 3/16, to 36 3/16.

HEADLINE: Campaign Briefing

 BODY:

THE REPUBLICANS
 
BUSH REPORTS SPENDING -- Gov. George W. Bush of Texas spent $13.1 million in February, more than half of it on television and radio advertisements in the crucial primary contests that helped him become the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, the Bush campaign said yesterday. By the end of February, Mr. Bush had spent a record $63.2 million, more than double the amount spent by his main rival, Senator John McCain of Arizona. The Bush campaign has raised a record $73.8 million from nearly 196,000 individuals. Although Mr. Bush himself did not attend any fund-raisers in February, the campaign raised $3.2 million and had $10.6 million in the bank on Feb. 29, the campaign said. Nearly all of that was spent before Super Tuesday, March 7. Don Van Natta Jr. (NYT)
 
THE DEMOCRATS
 
GORE'S FINANCES -- Vice President Al Gore's campaign, meanwhile, announced that it had $4.1 million in the bank on March 1 and expected to receive $7.3 million more in federal matching funds in the next few weeks. Campaign officials said Mr. Gore would continue to raise money over the next several months until he reached the spending limit for the primary period, about $44 million. Mr. Gore spent $6 million in February, less than half of Gov. George W. Bush's total. But Mr. Gore's competition from former Senator Bill Bradley was much less acute than that posed to Mr. Bush by Senator John McCain. John M. Broder (NYT) 
 
A PITCH FOR McCAIN VOTERS -- At a rally of cheering students and Democratic Party workers this afternoon, Vice President Al Gore again exhorted Republican and independent backers of Senator John McCain to join his campaign. "John McCain was right, and George W. Bush was wrong," Mr. Gore told the audience at Lincoln Land Community College in Springfield, Ill. Mr. Gore said that he agreed with Mr. McCain that Mr. Bush's economic plan was "fiscally irresponsible" and that anyone who would propose such a plan did "not understand the role of the president of the United States." He added: "John McCain could add and subtract. He could also demonstrate the courage to advocate reform, as Bill Bradley did, as I did. The voice that John McCain made heard is a voice I want to honor in the remaining seven and a half months of this campaign." Jo Thomas (NYT)
 
THIRD PARTIES
 
BUCHANAN FILES COMPLAINT -- Accusing the two major parties of conspiring to keep a hammerlock on the televised presidential debates this fall, Patrick J. Buchanan filed a complaint with the Federal Election Commission, contending that a "grossly unjust" format is blocking the Reform Party from participating. Mr. Buchanan, who hopes to win the party's nomination, contended that the Commission on Presidential Debates acted arbitrarily in ruling that only nominees with at least a 15 percent popularity rating in five national opinion polls are eligible for the debates. "Our political opponents are the ones deciding our fate," Mr. Buchanan declared, noting that the debate commission is filled with major party appointees. Mr. Buchanan has said that he is not optimistic about redress from the election commission, which is controlled by major-party nominees, and that he expects to have to file a federal court challenge for a place in the debates. Francis X. Clines (NYT)
 
THE HOUSE
 
CHALLENGING BOBBY RUSH -- Representative Bobby L. Rush, who ran unsuccessfully for mayor of Chicago last year against Richard M. Daley, now faces a strong challenge as he tries to keep his seat in Congress. Mr. Rush, a former Black Panther leader who left the Chicago City Council for Congress in 1992, faces three opponents for the Democratic nomination in the Illinois primary today, including Barack Obama, a state senator who has won the endorsement of The Chicago Tribune. Mr. Obama, 37, a civil rights lawyer, was the first black president of the Harvard Law Review. The other two candidates in the race are Donne Trotter, a state senator, and George Roby, a retired police officer. Dirk Johnson (NYT)
 
ILLINOIS GOVERNOR OSTRACIZED -- Beset by scandal and criticized for taking liberal stands, Gov. George Ryan of Illinois, a Republican, is now being treated as a foe by some politicians in his own party. Bill Brady, who is running for the congressional seat left open by the retirement of Thomas W. Ewing, has run commercials tying his opponent in today's Republican primary, State Representative Timothy V. Johnson, to Governor Ryan. The governor has been beleaguered by a bribery scandal dating from his tenure as the Illinois secretary of state and has been attacked by conservatives for raising taxes, supporting gay rights and declaring a moratorium on the death penalty. Mr. Johnson ran an advertisement with a testimonial from a Republican governor -- Jim Edgar, who preceded Mr. Ryan in office. Dirk Johnson (NYT)

HEADLINE: Pataki Planning Tax Breaks for Some Web Companies

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
It has become a commonplace situation: a corporation threatens to move its headquarters out of New York City. City and state officials, eager to prevent the defection, hand out tax breaks worth millions of dollars.
In the last six years, about 50 major companies have taken advantage of the city's and state's retention incentives, receiving at least $2 billion in tax relief. 
 Now, however, the Pataki administration has proposed a new tax break, intended not for the blue-chip companies that have dominated the New York City economy, but for a vital segment of the fast-growing Internet industry.
Under the proposal, so-called Web-hosting companies that provide the infrastructure of the Internet -- the computers, the fiber optic cables, the climate-control equipment -- would be able to avoid paying a state sales tax on their costly equipment. Server computers, owned by the customers but maintained by the Web hosts, would also be exempt from sales tax.
The tax cut has been embraced by the Democratic leadership of the Assembly. But it has drawn criticism from tax policy analysts on both ends of the political spectrum, who say it is unwise to single out certain industries for favored treatment.
New York's Internet industry is expanding at a breathtaking rate. Today, it employs more than a quarter of a million people, more than double the 1997 level, according to a recent report commissioned by the New York New Media Association, a trade group.
Yet despite this explosive growth, officials of both parties say the sales tax exemption is needed to prevent the Web-hosting companies, also known as Internet data centers, and their customers from being lured to other states.
"Other states across the nation are competitive in trying to attract these jobs," said Kevin C. Quinn, a spokesman for the State Division of the Budget. "The governor wants to make sure that New York remains one of the most attractive states for new media companies to locate and expand."
As tax cuts go, this one is relatively small. The state estimates that it would result in an annual revenue loss of $9 million, Mr. Quinn said. And it is only the latest in a series of selective tax breaks given out over the years. Some, like the elimination of sales tax for the hardware used to design and develop computer software, have been aimed at certain sectors. And some have gone to individual companies.
But the Web-hosting tax break carries considerable symbolic value. For several years, Internet entrepreneurs complained that government officials had failed to recognize their contribution to the New York economy. Those days seem over, an indication of the new-media entrepreneurs' growing political influence.
In New York City, the Giuliani administration has not drafted special tax measures for new media, but it has ingratiated itself with the new-media industry by proposing several measures intended to help all small businesses, like the elimination of the commercial rent tax.
Industry advocates have also complained in recent years that New York's academic institutions have not played a big enough role in training the work force of the new economy. Moving toward that goal, the Graduate Center of the City University of New York recently created a program that would draw upon faculty members and students on all 17 campuses to help develop software to be used by Silicon Alley.
On the state level, the Pataki administration's proposed tax break would help offset the disadvantages of doing business in New York, where real estate and utilities are more costly than elsewhere, said Brian Horey, the president of Equity Growth Management, a venture capital company that invests in Internet enterprises.
The measure would benefit companies like Global Crossing, a telecommunications company that operates a Web-hosting center in Manhattan. The company estimates that the equipment in its center cost $60 million and that the value of the equipment it houses for its customers is $120 million.
But Frank J. Mauro, executive director of the Fiscal Policy Institute, a liberal research institution in Latham, N.Y., said that the success of the new-media industry in New York demonstrated that special tax breaks were not necessary. "This is a tax break for something that is going to happen anyway, that is happening," Mr. Mauro said.
If a company chose its location based on where tax policies were less burdensome, Mr. Mauro said, then the Internet industry would be flourishing upstate, not in New York City.
Some of these reservations are shared by Brian D. Backstrom, the vice president of Change-N.Y., a conservative anti-tax group. Mr. Backstrom said that while any tax cut was better than none, it would make more sense to lower taxes across the board rather than selectively.
"It's not the most effective job-creation policy," Mr. Backstrom said. He has philosophical objections as well. "Any company in any industry can now knock on the governor's door, threaten to move and virtually be guaranteed a tax break or economic development subsidy of some sort," he said.
Sheldon Silver, the Assembly speaker, who is a Democrat, agrees in part. "As an overall policy," he said, "if we weren't competing with other states, it would always be better to lower everything across the board." But he said New York needed the tax break to prevail in the intense battles for new-media business.
In Virginia, a state that has aggressively sought Internet business, America Online got $18 million in tax breaks last year in exchange for opening an Internet data center in Prince William County.
Michael Mazerov, a senior policy analyst at the Center on Budget Policy and Priorities in Washington, said that Virginia, in effect, paid AOL for something it would have done even without the incentive.
Theoretically, the Internet data centers could be anywhere, but most customers want personal contact with the people they depend on. Web-hosting companies offer them regular software updates, duplicate power sources and backup capabilities, protecting them from service interruptions. Mr. Mazerov said that while many states were eager to win Internet business, most were not offering tax incentives.
But New Jersey, which has poured millions of dollars into programs to attract and retain high-tech companies, has a $40-million-a-year tax incentive program for start-up companies, and has exempted telecommunications companies like CNBC from paying sales tax for its equipment. "Quite frankly, we would like to keep sales tax exemptions as limited as possible," said Bernard Kornmehl, the assistant New Jersey state treasurer for tax policy. "The more you have, the more you narrow your base, and that will result in less revenue."
Connecticut, which has been gradually lowering its corporate business tax, is no longer inclined to modify its tax laws for the benefit of specific industries, said Ellen R. Schneider, a spokeswoman for the Connecticut Department of Revenue Services.
But Michael D. Freedman, Global Crossing's lobbyist, said that in the current climate, in which companies like his were besieged by incentives from other states, New York's tax proposal showed that the state was not tied exclusively to the old economy.
"New York," he said, "is standing out on the information highway and showing a little leg."

HEADLINE: Pondering Greenspan's Next Moves

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 20

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve is all but certain to raise its benchmark interest rate by another quarter of a percentage point on Tuesday, to 6 percent. That much Alan Greenspan has made clear in his public statements.
What is less clear is the central bank chairman's thinking about the forces that are driving him to tighten monetary policy. 
 In Congressional testimony and speeches, Mr. Greenspan has left economists and investors scratching their heads by seeming to assert that the increase in the growth rate of productivity -- almost universally considered to be the most unambiguously positive development in the nation's recent economic history -- is now to be blamed for causing inflation.
And although the riches generated by Wall Street's bull run have been reaped by relatively few people, Mr. Greenspan seems to have concluded that the stock market is the primary channel through which inflation is being transmitted throughout the economy. Never mind that even Mr. Greenspan cannot find much inflation.
It may be months or years before it will be possible to judge whether Mr. Greenspan is doing the right thing for the right reasons. Some economists think the Fed chairman is taking a straightforward situation -- an economy that is growing too fast for its own good -- and overanalyzing the causes.
Others think Mr. Greenspan is creating an elaborate justification for raising rates to mask a desire to bring down the stock market. And it is possible that Mr. Greenspan is deliberately sowing confusion to keep investors off balance and avoid a further run-up in stock prices.
The markets seem to have picked up his basic message that Tuesday's rate increase is unlikely to be the last, given the persistent strength of the economy. And while aspects of his thinking remain veiled, interviews with economists and Fed officials, as well as a close reading of Mr. Greenspan's statements over the last few months, help to bring his views into focus on critical issues including productivity, the stock market and the scale of the changes the economy is undergoing.
Yes, Mr. Greenspan sees the surge in productivity growth as a root cause of the imbalances that threaten the long expansion. By driving up profit expectations, productivity growth drives stock prices higher, leaving investors feeling rich and willing to spend. In the short run, at least, the growth in demand exceeds the growth in the economy's ability to provide offsetting increases in supply, creating the potential for inflationary bottlenecks.
But Mr. Greenspan has also tried to point out that the same productivity-driven forces that send stock prices and consumer spending up have a countervailing effect that helps dampen the economy.
Because increased productivity implies higher rates of return on investment, productivity improvements lead to a rise in demand for capital to take advantage of those returns. That in turn puts upward pressure on interest rates in the financial markets, slowing growth.
"Although Chairman Greenspan has taken a lot of flak for posing the inflation threat in the context of productivity's demand-side effects, the chairman's larger point often seems overlooked," economists at Salomon Smith Barney wrote earlier this month. "The most basic source of upward pressure on interest rates is the market itself."
That leaves the Fed in the role of validating what the bond market is already doing: making it more expensive for corporations and consumers to borrow money. Mr. Greenspan's favorite indicator of interest rates is not the yield on government securities, but the Standard & Poor's BBB corporate debt rate, adjusted for inflation expectations. By that figure, rates are up a full percentage point over the last year or so.
Indeed, Mr. Greenspan, who is viewed as all but omnipotent by investors around the world, seems to see his role in the current climate as merely surfing in the wake of the debt markets rather than leading them. That implies that, barring a surge in inflation or a sharp drop in the unemployment rate, Mr. Greenspan is likely to stick to his preference for incremental quarter-point rate increases rather than grabbing the attention of the markets through half-point increases.
"Market forces, not the Federal Reserve, are driving up interest rates to close the gap between supply and demand for funds," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee last month. "We at the Federal Reserve are acting in conjunction with the market and responding to it."
Mr. Greenspan sees the stock market as the mechanism through which productivity gains are transformed into wealth and increased demand. But if he is to be taken at his word -- and some investors have their doubts -- he does not seem to be worried so much about any particular market index as he is about aggregate wealth creation across the economy, including the substantial wealth being generated by rising home values. When they look at stocks, Fed officials tend to watch the Wilshire 5,000, which captures the broad movement of nearly all equity capital.
Mr. Greenspan has not shown much concern either about the way in which "old economy" Dow Jones industrial stocks and "new economy" Nasdaq stocks often seem to be moving in opposite directions, as they did again today, with the Nasdaq down sharply and the Dow up.
The Fed chairman seems to have concluded that the upheaval in the market represents a perhaps understandably confused effort by investors to determine where returns are highest at a time of mind-boggling technological change.
Investors in technology companies in particular, "not comfortable dealing with discontinuous shifts in economic structure, are groping for the appropriate valuations for these companies," Mr. Greenspan told a conference in Boston earlier this month.
More than most policy makers, Mr. Greenspan has a keen sense of history. In the last few years, he has frequently described the current combination of healthy growth, low inflation, low unemployment and surging productivity as "unprecedented in my half century of observing the American economy."
But lately, Mr. Greenspan has gone even further, stating that technology is driving the economy into a transformation so fundamental that there is nothing to compare it to.
This type of economy is "one that none of us has ever seen before, and indeed it may be unprecedented in our history," Mr. Greenspan told the Senate Banking Committee last month.
"The type of policy we have to devise has to reflect the nature of how the new economy is working," he said. "A number of the old tools which we relied upon don't have relevance to this."
Translation: Even Mr. Greenspan is not sure that traditional monetary policy can be counted on to work as it has in the past, disconcerting, perhaps, to those who assume the Fed chairman has it all under control.

HEADLINE: Hall of Justice, Source of Conflict;
Dispute Rages Over Future of Vacant Bronx Courthouse

BYLINE: By NINA SIEGAL 

 BODY:
Yolanda Garcia wants justice. She also wants the massive 1914 Beaux-Arts structure that Justice, the statue, is sitting on.
The statue's seat is the historic Bronx Borough Courthouse, a hulking trapezoidal building that stands out like an oblique monolith in the Melrose neighborhood that surrounds it. 
 The building, with its ornate interior, terrazzo floors, marble staircases and granite facade, has gone through a couple of inglorious incarnations since it stopped serving as the hub of Bronx civic life in the 1930's: first and unofficially as an adjunct courthouse and sometime storage building, second and unofficially as a pigeon coop.
In 1978, it was abandoned by the city. Then, in 1993, the pigeons were chased out and the doors locked for good.
But when Ms. Garcia, the executive director of Nos Quedamos (We Stay), looks at the shuttered courthouse, she sees the center of Melrose's rebirth. Nos Quedamos, one of the grass-roots groups responsible for large-scale urban renewal in Melrose, has been trying to secure the courthouse as a kind of town center since 1993.
But the city has twice sold it to private developers, who never actually redeveloped the site. Now, the second set of private owners has put the courthouse on the market for $1.8 million, after buying it two years ago for $300,000.
The sale has triply infuriated neighborhood advocates like Ms. Garcia and Bronx political leaders, who maintain that the property, which was designated a historic city landmark in 1981, never should have been sold to private developers in the first place.
So Nos Quedamos has once again set its sights on reclaiming the building, hoping to persuade the landlord to sell it to them for about $300,000, which the group plans to raise privately. It wants to renovate the courthouse and reopen it as a community center to serve families returning to the neighborhood, with a public library, a small museum and community meeting rooms for various events.
In her battle to reclaim the building, Ms. Garcia takes inspiration from Lady Justice.
"If you look at her," Ms. Garcia said, "she's not standing, she's not blindfolded, and she doesn't have a scale. She holds a sword.
"She's in the Bronx, after all. She knew she had to defend herself."
For the city's part, Denise Collins, a spokeswoman for the Department of Citywide Administrative Services, said that it was not uncommon for the city to sell landmarks and that the courthouse was simply too costly to maintain.
Edward Skyler, a spokesman for Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, declined to comment on the building's status.
Henry Weinstein, secretary of Liberty Square Realty, a real estate development company based in Queens, which bought the courthouse two years ago, said his company had advertised the building for $1.8 million, but he was not yet certain if they would sell it. He said he was considering a variety of options, including leasing some of the space to television studios that have expressed "strong interest" in using it to shoot dramas based in New York.
"If we don't figure out anything else, we'll probably use it as a warehouse, clean it out and rent it to someone," he said.
Fernando Ferrer, the Bronx borough president, criticized both the Giuliani administration and Liberty Square for failing to make good on promises that the building would be restored and reopened.
"The administration made all of these big promises that this was going to be redeveloped," Mr. Ferrer said. "Now, he's trying to sell it. Why? Because he can't do it. It turns out this guy is nothing more than a speculator. Let's see -- should we give a real estate speculator a $1.5 million windfall for speculating on our property?"
Ms. Garcia said the last thing neighborhood residents want on the property is a warehouse. Nos Quedamos is building about 1,700 new housing units on 65 development sites on the 35 contiguous blocks as part of a sprawling urban renewal project called Melrose Commons. She envisions the courthouse, on East 161st Street and Third Avenue, near the eastern edge of Melrose Commons, as its hub.
So does Mr. Ferrer, who said that since the administration of Edward I. Koch, he had regularly asked the city to lease him part of the courthouse for his headquarters.
"If we got that back," Mr. Ferrer said, "that whole Third Avenue corridor would experience a revival: coffee shops, restaurants, dry cleaners, all the services people need in the area."
He said development of Melrose was the last frontier of revitalization of the South Bronx. The neighborhood was, in a sense, also the borough's first frontier. Since its conception, the Bronx Borough Courthouse has been a symbol of the borough's struggle for its own identity.
At the turn of the last century, Bronx residents had to travel to Lower Manhattan to settle legal matters, because the borough was not an independent county. But the borough president at the time, Louis F. Haffen, felt so confident that it would be granted county status that in 1905, he asked Michael J. Garvin, an engineer, and the Beaux-Arts painter and architect Oscar Bluemner to design a structure that might accommodate a county court system.
The gamble paid off. When Bronx County was finally born, on Jan. 1, 1914, the elaborate inaugural ceremony was held at the newly completed courthouse.
The courthouse quickly became a hub of Bronx civic life. But because it had only one courtroom, and the Bronx's population exploded rapidly, it was supplanted by a new court on the Grand Concourse and operations were transferred to other civic courts in the 1930's and 40's.
The building was briefly used as storage for Works Project Administration artwork, said Lloyd Ultan, the Bronx borough historian. It was also used as an adjunct courthouse. But throughout the 80's, it was vacant and became an enormous pigeon coop.
In the early 1990's, Nos Quedamos and other neighborhood groups pressured the city to seal the building's windows, repair its roof and bolt its doors to protect its interior.
Ms. Garcia said they then raised about $6 million to support a library, a small museum and after-school programs at the building, provided they could secure a lease. When the city ignored their pleas and put the building up for sale, Nos Quedamos joined the bidding, but lost out to Liberty Square.
Mr. Weinstein of Liberty Square said he was somewhat perturbed by Ms. Garcia's persistence. "They feel they have some divine right to that building," he said. "I know they live in that neighborhood, but people live in a lot of neighborhoods."
He said that he and Benjamin Klein, the president of the company, bought the building because they were enchanted by its architecture, just as they did with several other historic buildings they had bought in Brooklyn, like the Old Town Printing building and the Knox hat factory.
"We wanted to figure out some viable development strategy to bring the building back to its former grandeur," Mr. Weinstein said. In response to the accusation that he had purchased the building simply to make a profit, Mr. Weinstein laughed. "There are plenty of things I could have put my money into, like Microsoft stock, that I could have made more money from."
The company continues to seek retailers or other businesses that would like to develop the space, but has not had much luck.
Mario Procida, president of Procida Realty and Construction Corporation, has put money into the area -- enough to renovate 265 condominiums three blocks from the courthouse in 1994 -- and is working on another housing development, Plaza de los Angeles, 35 three-family homes with Peter Stand and Magnus Magnusson, and Nos Quedamos.
He said the perils of building in the neighborhood were no different today than they were two years ago, when Liberty Square bought the courthouse.
Mr. Weinstein said he would be happy to work with Nos Quedamos to come up with a development plan to suit both groups. "We're very curious, because we would like to work with them if there's some way of working with them," he said. "But I feel they're not taking legitimate steps to develop this building. If they want to develop it, I'm the one they have to come to, not somebody else."
Ms. Garcia said she had made at least 10 phone calls to Liberty Square since they advertised the property, and said she had given the owners the blueprints for their plan, but the company had not responded.
Ronald Shiffman, director of the Pratt Institute Center for Community and Environmental Development and a former city planning commissioner who has been involved with the courthouse issue, said he was confident Nos Quedamos would get another shot at developing the property.
"It doesn't seem like anyone who buys it privately will be able to generate enough income to offset the costs of renovation," he said, "so eventually it will come back to the city's hands. And it will probably come back when there's a more sympathetic administration."
For the time being, the courthouse remains shuttered. On the back facade, three heroic French faces stare out across a barren highway leading to the Throgs Neck Bridge. The combined forces of pollution and rain have made black streaks like tears down the faces.
"It's one of the great tragedies of the world," said Michael Henry Adams, a historic preservationist who has studied the building. "It was intact and beautiful so recently. And now it's undergone this protracted neglect because people are squabbling, and the community is suffering and the building is suffering."

HEADLINE: Foreign Affairs;
This Is a Test

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN 

 BODY:
Four years ago, I pointed out that no two countries that both had McDonald's had ever fought a war against each other since they each got their McDonald's. I drew from that what I called "The Golden Arches Theory of Conflict Prevention," which stated that once your country became a McDonald's country, it meant your people didn't like to fight wars anymore; they preferred instead to wait in line for burgers. 
 The Golden Arches Theory had nothing to do with the power of burgers. I was simply using it to illustrate that while globalization and economic integration -- symbolized by the spread of McDonald's -- could not end geopolitics and war, they were clearly having a restraining effect on aggressive nations (in addition to classical military deterrence), because the costs of war for globalized nations were now so much greater.
Well, the Golden Arches Theory is now about to get its first real test: China versus Taiwan. These are two separate countries, each obsessed with asserting its own national identity, but each now woven to the other -- and to the rest of the world -- by a web of economic interests (and 578 McDonald's) so profound and far-reaching that if this web can't restrain them, then nothing will.
Consider the following: Some 40 percent of all Chinese exports go to the U.S. Over 25 percent of China's G.D.P. comes from foreign trade; Taiwanese companies have invested $40 billion in factories on Mainland China; China is fast becoming one of the most Internet-wired countries in the world. Taiwanese factories are the leading suppliers in the world of 13 key parts that go into every computer or Internet router. In many cases, Taiwan is the only supplier of certain key computer parts. The whole global computer supply chain would be disrupted by a war over Taiwan. (Bye-bye, Nasdaq.)
In short, it's hard to find two more globally, and mutually, dependent countries. But it's also hard to find two countries more viscerally committed to their own particular national identities and to the flourishing of their own particular roots and branches. Communist China covets Taiwan -- in order to complete the historic reunification of China now that Hong Kong and Macao have been reintegrated. And Taiwan's election has brought to power there for the first time a leader who represents the yearning of Taiwanese to govern themselves and to never again be ruled by others.
China can't shoot Taiwan without shooting itself. Taiwan can't pull away from China without pulling its own economy down. And any sharp move by either will destabilize the world. That's what globalization is all about. Think about it: Americans will not (and should not) stand by and watch Taiwan, a country shaped in our own image, be snuffed out by Beijing. A China that invades Taiwan is a China that can forget about selling goods in America for a long time. It's a China that can forget about joining the World Trade Organization.
Will rationality prevail? The problem with Beijing, Taiwan and Washington, says the China scholar Mike Oksenberg, is that "each assumes that economic rationality will prevail in the other two capitals, and that the other two will understand the political pressures in its own capital and therefore cut it some slack."
That's a dangerous assumption. China scholars note that when China's progressive prime minister, Zhu Rongji, threatened Taiwan last week against making any move toward independence, there was a certain pleading quality to it -- almost as though Mr. Zhu was saying: "Don't you guys understand? I'm sitting on a powderkeg." The whole scene echoed that day in 1989 when the Chinese leader at the time, Zhao Ziyang, went to Tiananmen Square and pleaded, with tears in his eyes, for the students to leave, because he knew what demons lurked inside his own Politburo.
Well, those demons -- those Chinese leaders whose motto is "When in doubt, use force" -- are still there. But China has become a real McDonald's country since. And this is a test of whose logic will prevail. There is a war just waiting to be fought in the Taiwan Strait. But there is also a Nobel Peace Prize just waiting to be won there -- waiting for the statesman who can persuade the parties that precisely because they can't live without each other, they have to find a new way to live with each other.
I repeat: This is a test.
