HEADLINE: Carmakers to Alter S.U.V.'s to Reduce Riskto Other Autos

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 20

 BODY:
Acknowledging for the first time that sport utility vehicles pose special dangers to other motorists in crashes, automakers say that they are modifying the designs of these vehicles to make them less hazardous.
General Motors says it will make the 2002 Oldsmobile Bravada, GMC Envoy and Chevrolet Blazer with steel rails up to 2 inches lower inside their underbodies than in current versions, to reduce the risk of their overriding cars' bumpers and doorsills. Ford Motor plans to do the same for its Explorer, Expedition and Lincoln Navigator over the next two model years. 
 DaimlerChrysler says it is making several changes to the Dodge Durango's front end for the 2002 model year to make it less likely to override cars in collisions.
Foreign automakers are also designing their sport utility vehicles to make them less likely to kill or injure occupants of other vehicles in crashes. When the Toyota Sequoia goes on sale this autumn, it will be equipped with impact-absorbing hollow bars below the bumpers to keep it from riding over cars in collisions. Ford recently added that feature to its huge Excursion as well.
Nissan has just reinforced the bumpers on the 2001 Pathfinder, with the goal of spreading the force of an impact over a wider area of the struck vehicle, and plans further changes in coming years. Honda and Mitsubishi say they also plan design changes, although they declined to release any details yet.
Some of the changes, like the bars on the Toyota Sequoia, are being made purely for the safety of other motorists. Engineers say some of the other changes are partly for safety and partly to improve fuel economy, ride and handling: midsize G.M. sport utilities like the Envoy, for example, will no longer share underbodies with pickup trucks, so they can be built with lower, lighter, less stiff frames that provide a more cushioned ride. Other changes are being made not to the sport utilities but to cars, like adding side air bags.
Even sport utility vehicles with the alterations will continue to pose risks to other motorists. They will remain considerably heavier than cars. And they will still have high hoods that cause more damage and injuries when striking cars from the side. Current sport utilities are almost three times as likely as cars to kill the other driver in a crash.
But after bitterly denying for three years that the design of sport utility vehicles made them unusually deadly to other motorists, auto industry officials now say that their designs cause up to half the extra deaths, and are swiftly making changes.
"As the vehicle mix between pickups, minivans, vans, S.U.V.'s and cars has shifted in the U.S., automakers have recognized the importance of vehicle-to-vehicle crash compatibility," the Alliance of Automobile Manufacturers, the Washington-based trade group for domestic and foreign companies, said in a statement. "Tremendous progress has been made in a very short time."
The manufacturers' safety engineers say these changes will not affect the safety of occupants of sport utility vehicles. Mounting the heaviest, stiffest parts of sport utility vehicles lower in their underbodies, probably through new suspension designs, should make the vehicles more stable and less prone to rolling over, they say.
Sport utility vehicles have fewer impact-absorbing "crumple zones" and roll over more often than cars when they strike curbs, guardrails and other automobiles. So occupants of sport utility vehicles have roughly the same overall death rate as car occupants, despite faring well in head-on collisions with cars.
A federal study estimated last year that the designs of sport utilities were causing almost 1,000 unnecessary deaths a year in other vehicles. Dr. Hans Joksch, a longtime University of Michigan traffic safety expert who oversaw that study, estimated that the design changes now being made would eventually save 100 to 300 of these lives annually. But this improvement in safety will take time, he cautioned, because so many sport utilities have already been manufactured without the design changes and will remain on the road.
Automakers plan to mount the stiffest, heaviest, most dangerous parts of sport utilities' frames lower in the vehicles without affecting their ground clearance. This will require suspension changes, including adjustable-height suspensions in some models that will automatically lower the vehicles' bodies except when four-wheel drive is engaged at very low speeds. This could add up to $1,500 to the cost of models like the Lincoln Navigator, on which profit margins approach $15,000.
Maintaining ground clearance will allow off-road enthusiasts to keep using them for traversing swamps and mountain trails, and will insure that sport utilities continue to qualify for more lenient fuel-economy regulation than cars, using a regulatory exemption for off-road vehicles.
Automakers have concluded that small sport utility vehicles, like the Jeep Wrangler and Jeep Cherokee, pose less risk to other motorists, and are not changing them.
Automakers are also modifying pickup designs, with Ford and Toyota adding the same bars below the bumpers of the Ford Super Duty and Toyota Tundra that they are putting on the Excursion and Sequoia.
The auto industry's once-monolithic opposition to rules governing vehicles' overall design has shattered in recent months. Toyota, Nissan and Renault have begun calling for international regulations to make passenger vehicles more compatible in crashes. General Motors, Ford and DaimlerChrysler say that some coordination of design is needed but that this can be done by forming industry partnerships, although G.M. and DaimlerChrysler say that there may someday be a role for government regulation, too.
If automakers start sharing information about the height, stiffness and shape of future models, without actually sharing the vehicles' design and appearance, more progress can be made in improving vehicle safety, said Terry Connolly, G.M.'s director for North American vehicle safety. "Some sort of long-term guidance is going to be necessary," either from an industry group or from governments, he said, adding that G.M. had recently finished extensive computer modeling and crash tests of what happens when sport utility vehicles, pickup trucks and vans hit cars, and had voluntarily shared the results with many other automakers.
Shinichi Kato, Toyota's executive vice president for worldwide vehicle development and a powerful member of the Tokyo-based automaker's board, said regulations would make it easier for his company to decide how best to address the problem. "Compatibility is not something that is covered by vehicle regulation; eventually, it will be involved in regulation," he said in an interview.
Federal regulators, who performed their first crash test of a sport utility vehicle into a car in 1998, say they do not yet know enough about vehicle compatibility to draft regulations. But Dr. Ricardo Martinez, who was the nation's top traffic safety regulator for six years before stepping down last autumn, said that there had been an extraordinary change in attitudes in the auto industry, and that automakers could now be trusted to make design changes even without regulation.
Dr. Martinez said that when he began warning about the dangers of sport utilities in early 1998, "the industry was so upset you would have thought we shot their dog."
The auto industry is also helping the federal government pay for medical research into ways to care for survivors of crashes involving different types of automobiles, particularly car occupants hit from the side by sport utilities. Dr. Jeffrey Augenstein, the medical director of the government's Miami-based Crash Injury Research Engineering Network, said hospitals around the country were starting to report more injuries to the head, neck and heart during side-impact crashes because of the high front ends of sport utility vehicles and pickups.
Emergency medical teams in the Miami area are now being told to bring all survivors of serious side-impact crashes to trauma centers, particularly if they have been hit by sport utilities and even if the survivors, unaware of internal bleeding, insist that they are fine. Preliminary results from this experiment show that it is already saving lives, and it may be expanded nationwide, Dr. Augenstein said.
Design changes in sport utility vehicles reflect a recent effort by automakers to understand how vehicles of different sizes and shapes interact in crashes. During the Society of Automotive Engineers convention here two weeks ago, there was a full day of presentations of technical papers on the problem by researchers from all over the world. A similar number of papers was presented last year; by contrast, no such papers were presented as recently as the convention in early 1997.
Helen Petrauskas, Ford's vice president for safety and environmental engineering, said that with seatbelt use increasing and drunken driving on the decline, incompatibility between vehicles in crashes was one of the most serious safety issues still facing the auto industry, and could be addressed to a significant extent through design changes. "We have made considerable progress, and we will make more," she said.
Sales of sport utility vehicles soared through the 1990's, with growth peaking in 1996. Automakers have been more cautious in switching factories over to production of sport utility vehicles since 1997, when safety and environmental concerns began to be raised about the vehicles. The big vehicles' share of the market has been gradually leveling off since 1996 as a result, despite very low gasoline prices in 1998 and early 1999 that otherwise might have stimulated sales slightly.
Much higher gasoline prices this year have not yet slowed sales, mainly because sport utility vehicles are bought mostly by upper-income families for whom an extra $10 a week is not a big problem. Changing an automobile design takes at least one year and often two or three; the sport utility changes are a result of extensive research showing safety improvements are possible, rather than a response to rising gas prices, auto engineers said.
Engineers at the convention predicted that as designs improve for new sport utilities, concern would shift to the millions already on the road with less safe designs.
Alan Thebert, a retired G.M. safety engineer and chairman of the auto engineers' crash testing committee, warned at the convention that the problem of used sport utilities is "going to get worse, and we do have to be aware of it and do something about it."

HEADLINE: Student Drug Death, Arrests and Illnesses Shock College in Hartford

BYLINE: By PAUL ZIELBAUER 

DATELINE: HARTFORD, March 20

 BODY:
By 7:30 a.m. last Friday, the first day of spring break at Trinity College, a small private school atop a gentle hillside here, had already begun spinning terribly out of control.
The police had just picked up William B. Bachman, a Trinity senior, after he ran his car into a fire hydrant, and took him to a West Hartford hospital to be treated for possible drug ingestion. Within hours, Mr. Bachman's roommate, Joshua B. Eaves, arrived, also with what looked like a drug-induced illness, the police said. At 12:24 p.m., a third roommate, Josh Doroff of Harrison, N.Y., was carried unconscious by three friends into the hospital's emergency room, where doctors pronounced him dead. 
 In their dormitory room minutes later, the police found a fourth roommate, Clement Kaupp 3rd, lying unconscious, also apparently suffering from an overdose of drugs. After spending three days in critical condition perilously close to death, Mr. Kaupp regained consciousness today, and his condition had stabilized, the police said.
By all accounts, Mr. Kaupp, 22, of Mendham, N.J., is lucky to be alive. According to one of the three surviving roommates, the four had begun celebrating their weeklong vacation by taking various amounts of heroin and prescription drugs, including Xanax, an antianxiety medication; Valium; butalbital, which is prescribed for migraines, and sleeping pills, said Dr. Mary McCormick, the administrative director of the Connecticut Poison Control Center. The police say the men may also have been drinking.
"You take any one of those drugs and they will depress the central nervous system," Dr. McCormick said. "You introduce alcohol to that mix and you've got a pretty potent combination that could induce a coma."
On Saturday, Mr. Bachman, of South Natick, Mass., and Mr. Eaves, of Dowington, Pa., were arrested on felony drug possession charges, according to State Superior Court records. Mr. Eaves was released after he posted a $20,000 surety bond; Mr. Bachman, who was also charged with driving while intoxicated, paid a $25,000 bond in cash, records show.
Both men are to be arraigned on March 31 in Superior Court, a spokeswoman in the court clerk's office said. Mr. Kaupp, who was "up and walking around" by this afternoon, is likely to face felony drug charges, Sergeant Huertas said.
If the death of Mr. Doroff, a popular senior majoring in economics, stunned Trinity's 1,900 students, most of whom are now on their spring break, news of their drug-laden night of partying has left school officials issuing urgent calls to students to stay away from drugs and alcohol.
On Saturday, less than 24 hours after Mr. Doroff was pronounced dead, college administrators sent out urgent e-mail and voice mail messages to all students, and mailed letters to each student's home address, informing students and their parents about the incident, said Linda S. Campanella, Trinity's senior vice president.
Officials also sent employees Saturday to each of the college's 990 dormitory rooms to check on students, even waking them to ensure that they were all right.
The Hartford police and the Hartford state's attorney are investigating where and how the four students acquired the drugs. A weekend search of their living quarters, in a red-brick high-rise south of the Trinity campus, revealed residue of several substances, said Sgt. Norberto A. Huertas, a commander in the major crimes department of the Hartford police. He would not elaborate, but he did say, "Heroin was involved in this incident."
Today, in several interviews on and off the Trinity campus, students said drugs were a common ingredient at many parties.
"There's a lot of recreational drug use on campus," said Michelle Fabiani, 18, a freshman from Wallingford, Conn. "Trinity is kind of like a rich kid's school, so kids may have more money to buy drugs." Tuition is $31,380 a year.
Ben Fay, a former Trinity computer science student who is now a pharmacy technician in Hartford, said Ritalin, a stimulant, had long been popular at the school, either as a study aid or as a recreational drug. "They just sort of chop it up and snort it like cocaine," he said today.
Mr. Fay said that three years ago, when he was a freshman, he caught a student trying to sell Mr. Fay's cache of 100 five-milligram tablets of Ritalin stolen from Mr. Fay's room. The pills went for $5 apiece.
But Trinity officials, who have begun efforts in recent months to crack down on alcohol-related infractions on campus, said drugs had not been a problem among students, almost all of whom live on campus.
"A dreaded possibility became reality," Ms. Campanella said. "I don't want to sound defensive, but this is something that could have happened on any campus."
"I think other campuses and other towns will pay attention to this," she added. "Kids here and everywhere feel a certain invulnerability, and they take risks. These kids took a veritable cocktail."
Mr. Doroff is the second Trinity student to die in the last seven months. Last September, Herme Ortiz, 17, a freshman, died from head injuries after a fistfight with another student as they were leaving an alcohol-free party on campus.
The police said their investigation into how Mr. Doroff died had been frustrated by the refusal of his three roommates -- Mr. Bachman, Mr. Eaves and Mr. Kaupp -- to discuss what happened.
"We're not getting any cooperation from these kids at all," Sergeant Huertas said.
On Saturday, Mr. Doroff was buried in Mount Vernon, N.Y., said a spokeswoman for his father, H. Frank Doroff, an executive vice president for merchandising at Bloomingdale's in New York City.
Jeffrey Sherman, the president of Bloomingdale's and a friend of the Doroff family for a decade, described young Josh as polite, athletic and intelligent, from a close-knit family, and a man who did not, as far as anyone knew, dabble in drugs.
"In all of those years, I've never known this to be a problem with Josh," said Mr. Sherman, whose three sons attended the Rye Country Day School with Mr. Doroff.
"There clearly was no sign of any of this to me, he said. "Any parent would have been proud to have Josh as their son, which just adds to the shock of it all."

PANEL ESTABLISHED FOR STEEL DISPUTE

BYLINE: By Elizabeth Olson 

 BODY:
The World Trade Organization has agreed to set up a dispute resolution panel to settle Japan's complaint that United States antidumping penalties for steel imports violate global trading rules. The United States imposed penalties against Japanese hot-rolled steel imports, which Washington said were sold in the American market at prices so low they threatened domestic producers. Efforts by Japan and the United States to resolve the issue failed, and Japan asked for W.T.O. intervention. The panel will have six months to arrive at a finding. Elizabeth Olson

HEADLINE: U.S. Welfare Limit May Put Thousands in Albany's Care

BYLINE: By RAYMOND HERNANDEZ 

DATELINE: ALBANY, March 20

 BODY:
As tens of thousands of welfare recipients in New York face the prospect of losing their eligibility for federal benefits next year, new figures indicate that many who remain on the rolls are unable to support themselves, meaning that the state may ultimately have to pick up the huge costs of providing for them.
More than 40 percent of the families on welfare in New York have been on the rolls for five years or more, the new state figures show, posing the most daunting challenge yet in the state's ambitious drive to push people off public assistance into self-sufficiency. 
 Many of those who remain, state figures show, also have serious problems, like poor education, mental illness, alcoholism and drug addiction, making them difficult to employ, even in these robust economic times.
Over the last five years, the state has achieved one of the sharpest caseload reductions in the nation, slashing the number of people on welfare by 539,000, or 42.6 percent, with a series of new policies intended to nudge them into jobs. Roughly 726,500 parents and children remain on the rolls. But now, with the most employable people already off the rolls, state officials are facing what they acknowledge may be the toughest test of the welfare policies championed by everyone from President Clinton on down to Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani.
The emerging portrait of New York's welfare population comes at a crucial time. The national welfare overhaul adopted in 1996 limits recipients to no more than five years of federal aid. That means that tens of thousands of recipients in New York could lose their federal benefits starting in late 2001. Nationwide, there are 6.8 million individuals on the federal rolls, and they too face the same time limits.
The situation has led some state officials and experts on poverty issues to conclude that the most challenging task lies ahead in the overall effort to reshape welfare in New York. It also increases the prospect that New York taxpayers will have to pick up tens of millions of dollars in welfare costs once the federal time limits take hold, because state law says the state cannot simply let those people fend for themselves.
"New York has done an awful lot to help families get off the welfare rolls," said Karen Schimke, the executive director of the State Communities Aid Association, an advocacy group for the poor. "But the ones who remain on the rolls are very difficult to serve if the goal is to make them self-sufficient. The question is what is New York going to do about them."
It is not as though the state has not been preparing for this. Over all, the state is spending 21 percent more per case than it did in 1995; put another way, the state spends $11,300 a year on a mother and two children today, compared with $9,300 for the same size family five years ago. Much of the increase is for child care, a critical component in helping single parents obtain and keep jobs.
In addition, the state is providing other benefits to encourage recipients to keep working. For instance, in the past welfare recipients frequently lost their government subsidized child care after leaving the rolls, but now the state provides coverage for up to a year after their cases close.
The state is also permitting recipients to earn more money before being dropped from the welfare rolls. State records show that in late 1995, 6 percent of families with children who received federal assistance also had some earned income, but that now 15 percent have earned income. For those who were earning money, the average amount has risen to $629 a month now, from $476 in late 1995.
The state has also expanded its earned-income tax credit, so that low-wage earners can keep more of their income before beginning to pay taxes. In fact, New York has the most generous earned-income tax credit in the nation, according to the State Communities Aid Association, which is based in New York. State officials estimate that, when combined with a similar federal earned-income tax credit, the state's credit is worth $2 an hour for a person with a full-time minimum-wage job.
New York welfare officials say that these policies enable recipients to establish a firm footing in a job before they are removed from welfare and left to fend for themselves. "We are ramping people up into the economy," said Daniel Hogan, the executive deputy commissioner for the State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance. "It used to be that when a recipient earned a certain level of income, they were dropped from the rolls and sometimes left on their own. But that's no longer the case."
All in all, New York's caseload continues to decline at a remarkable rate; an average of 2,600 cases, or 7,800 individuals, came off the rolls monthly in 1999. But state and local officials are increasingly seeing recipients with a variety of problems that make them difficult to employ.
The state cannot describe in great detail the scope and range of the problems plaguing those individuals who have been left on the rolls. That is largely because much of the information is supplied by the recipients themselves, who are often reluctant to talk about issues like domestic violence, drug abuse and alcoholism.
But the information state officials have gathered is troubling to many advocates for the poor. More than half of those on the rolls lack a high school education; 14 percent of those on the rolls got no further than completing junior high school. At least 25 percent of the total are estimated to have drug or alcohol abuse problems that could interfere with their ability to hold a job. And 8 percent of the total have sought treatment for mental illnesses, although state officials believe that figure does not reflect the prevalence of such problems.
It is recipients with such problems that will be the greatest test of the new welfare policies, especially over the next year and a half, as the federal time limit nears. In New York at this point, there are 226,000 families on Temporary Assistance to Needy Families, the main federal welfare program, who face the five-year lifetime limit on benefits. As a rule of thumb, each family represents three welfare recipients, typically a mother and two children.
Of those families, 52,000, or 23 percent, have been on welfare less than a year, according to state figures, and 79,000, or 35 percent have one to five years on the rolls.
Then comes the remarkable statistical bulge: 94,000 families, or 42 percent of the total, have been on welfare for five years or more, indicating a large problem. The federal law does allow the state to exempt 20 percent of its caseload from the five-year limit at the time they take effect in late 2001, but many experts say that will not be nearly enough.
In the end, New York does not intend to abandon needy people who exhaust their eligibility for federal assistance. Instead, it will place them in a locally and state-financed program known as Safety Net. But state and local officials worry about the future cost of that program, given that the caseload could ultimately increase. In 1999 alone, the program cost state and local governments roughly $500 million, paying benefits to 133,000 people.
The state acknowledges that it must come up with new ways of serving the more troubled recipients.
The governor, for example, has asked the Legislature for an additional $36 million a year for drug and alcohol treatment, which would bring the total amount the state spends on such services to $48 million annually. The state is also seeking to provide $125 million to help local caseworkers shift from the traditional job of processing welfare applications to a more complicated one: assessing what services they need to get jobs and stay off public assistance.
The state has even created a new agency that is charged with consolidating a host of benefit programs, from traditional welfare grants to child care and transportation. The goal is to replace handouts with programs for training and jobs.
Mr. Hogan, the executive deputy commissioner for the State Office of Temporary and Disability Assistance, summed up the state's task this way: "We have a philosophical and fiscal incentive to reduce the caseload. Not only is it the right thing to do, but we recognize that the federal support will be ending."

HEADLINE: Big Day Spoiled for Bangladesh Villagers

BYLINE: By BARRY BEARAK 

DATELINE: JOYPURA, Bangladesh, March 20

 BODY:
Of all the distant villages, in all the poor countries, in all the third world, President Bill Clinton was supposed to visit theirs.
And, sitting on a cane stool under a 150-year-old banyan tree, with songbirds trilling and the press taking notes, he was to talk with the peasants of Joypura. 
 It was to be Mr. Clinton's rare chance to hear from people of the Bangladeshi soil and, in turn, their implausible opportunity to rub elbows with a man of global power.
But at the last minute, today's visit was canceled -- and the villagers, plucked from obscurity only to be thrust back again, were crushed.
"It is terribly sad because we were expecting so much," said Rokeya Begum, a young mother. "We thought he would talk to us, and we would get to know each other. We thought he would hear our problems and he would tell us the solutions."
The bad news arrived before dawn as people were doing the final preening after weeks of preparation. Security was said to be to blame. The United States Secret Service had decided that the 28-mile excursion from Dhaka, the capital, by helicopter, would be dangerous. "We had specific information which led us to conclude that travel to the village was inadvisable," said Samuel R. Berger, the White House national security adviser.
Mr. Clinton also canceled a stop to the National Memorial where world leaders traditionally pay homage to the three million people killed in Bangladesh's war of independence against Pakistan in 1971. Despite the American claims of security problems, Bangladeshis are likely to be insulted by the perceived slight.
This sudden shift in scheduling provided an ominous start to the president's five-day visit to South Asia. Bangladesh was supposed to provide an untroubled destination before the president went on to India, where he arrived tonight, and Pakistan.
But if Bill Clinton could not go to Joypura, the Americans enthusiastically counterproposed, Joypura could come to him. Buses with hundreds of villagers -- mostly women and children were brought to Dhaka. The people were happy for the journey, but it was not the same.
In the last few days, 10,000 people had flooded into Joypura -- four times the village's population. It was simply amazing for them all to imagine the president of the United States actually among them, walking beside the haystacks and the cow sheds and the duck ponds.
"I am so sad now," said Alam Ali, who was using a crowbar to tear down a modest grandstand that had been built near the banyan tree. "This whole area would have grown rich. Bill Clinton could have made this happen. He is a very great man, you know."
The president is presumed to be the bearer of the magic wand of American wealth. And, indeed, before the day was over, he announced several aid packages to Bangladesh, including $97 million for food and $8.6 million toward the reduction of child labor. People in Joypura seemed to believe that he would hear their hopeful words and see their hard work and come away determined to rescue them from the undertow of poverty.
Muhammad Yasin Sheik, 45, had trekked from a nearby village, holding the useless deed to his perished land. Last year, the mighty Jamuna River had changed course and swallowed his farm. He hoped that Mr. Clinton would take pity and give him money. "We are starving," he said plainly. "Bill Clinton can do something about that."
Unlike most others, who spoke only Bangla, Mr. Sheik knew some English. He pointed to the white prayer cap on his head, showing he was a religious man.
"We always pray to Allah that Bill Clinton remains in good health," he said eagerly. "And we also pray that his wife, who is in an election, wins a great victory."
Joypura had been selected for the president's first visit to Bangladesh because there were success stories here. This is a storm-ravaged nation of 128 million people with a per capita income of only $289. But the nation's war against poverty is not without its share of victories -- and many of them are owed to some of the world's most innovative strategies.
The Grameen Bank pioneered the idea of microcredit, small loans given to the poor without a demand for collateral. The amounts are usually $200 or less, and they are generally used to start up a simple home business like as the purchase of a milk cow.
Grameen began in 1983, the idea of a Bangladeshi economist, Muhammad Yunus. Today, it has 2.4 million borrowers, mostly women, in 39,000 villages. The repayment rate is 98 percent.
In 1986, Mr. Yunus was invited to Arkansas by Bill Clinton, who was then its governor. He wanted to set up a similar banking scheme in the state. The two became friends.
Joypura has several dozen Grameen customers, among them Nasima Akhter, who last borrowed $160 to buy a rice paddy, which she then sold at a $60 profit.
"I wanted to tell President Clinton of my success," she said, holding her 7-month-old baby in her arms and standing in a home with walls of corrugated metal.
The Bangladesh Rural Advancement Committee is one of the world's largest nongovernmental organizations -- and it too is busy in Joypura, starting a school.
The children had been eager for the president to visit so he could hear them recite, to watch how they were the first in their families going up the staircase to an education. The school had been scrubbed. A new toilet had been built with a shiny blue metal door. It was padlocked, yet unused, with a virgin urinal awaiting distinguished guests.
"I am very utterly disappointed that Mr. Clinton will not see all that we have done for our village," said Harun ur-Rashid, a gaunt, clean-shaven man. "We have installed electricity. We have become people of the world. Mr. Clinton should see this."
Indeed, it is Mr. Clinton's loss, for Joypura, like most Bangladeshi villages, is stunningly picturesque. The trees are what make these hamlets so special, the lush mix of bamboo and palms and mangoes and banana. Gauguin would have been inspired here.
Osman Ghani, a young farmer in a green shirt and skirtlike wrap garment, was another who bemoaned the fickle destiny that kept the president away. He had walked seven miles in the morning to be here when the big moment arrived. He had thought of little else for weeks.
"Bill Clinton is the most important man in the world," Mr. Ghani said emphatically. "It would been the most memorable event in my life to see this great man."
This remark led to an obvious question. What then instead would have to serve as unforgettable? The farmer thought this over until finally the answer came to him. He looked at the other villagers at his side as if they too knew his mind. He spoke with certainty.
He said, "For me, the most memorable event in my life was the day I walked seven miles and almost saw Bill Clinton."

HEADLINE: New York Power Authority Postpones Decision on Sale of Two Nuclear Plants

BYLINE: By DAVID W. CHEN 

 BODY:
The New York Power Authority postponed choosing a buyer for its two nuclear plants late last night, saying that it was unable to resolve an assortment of tax and finance issues related to what would be the largest sale of nuclear plants in United States history.
The power authority has been weighing competing offers for the Indian Point 3 plant in Westchester and the James A. FitzPatrick reactor in Oswego County, on Lake Ontario, between Entergy Nuclear, of Jackson, Miss., and Dominion Resources, of Richmond, Va. Entergy had initially offered a package it said was worth $806 million, only to be upstaged by Dominion, which offered a package it valued at $857 million. 
 But last night, after an unexpected 11-hour marathon meeting in Manhattan, largely behind closed doors, the five-member board of trustees said, with a trace of fatigued frustration in their voices, that it would be best to postpone a decision until next Tuesday. Although members said that much progress had been made, they could not resolve one key issue: the tax consequences of transferring two publicly run facilities to a private company, particularly when the plants are decommissioned in the future.
"The potential exposure in taxes to the power authority is anywhere from $100 to $400 million," said Michael A. Petralia, a spokesman for the authority. "We're talking about a significant amount of money. Now you can see why this took 11 hours."
The drama last night was further heightened by the fact that Dominion had said that its offer would expire at midnight. Last night, the power authority asked for an extension, but Dominion was noncommittal.
"Right now, we're unable to comment," Mark Lazenby, a spokesman for Dominion, said after the meeting.
No matter what happens, though, it may be reasonable to expect that something unexpected is probably in the cards given the way things have played out to date.
On Feb. 14, the power authority announced that it had reached a tentative deal with Entergy for a package that Entergy valued at $806 million. But even before that announcement, state legislators and watchdogs of nuclear power had criticized the agency for failing to make the process as open or as competitive as possible.
Then on Feb. 24, in a surprising twist, the power authority received an unsolicited bid from Dominion for what Dominion said was $51 million more. So the stage was set for a bidding war.
In the next few weeks, Entergy and Dominion sweetened their proposals, highlighting statistical projections and economic intangibles on everything from the value of a new regional office in White Plains, to paying more money to decommission the plants.
Power authority officials had originally predicted that yesterday's meeting would go rather smoothly, just like most board meetings, which typically last an hour. Instead, what happened was that the board huddled in a series of private meetings to discuss legal and financial issues for about 11 hours -- leaving reporters, representatives from the two bidders and other interested parties waiting.
When the board finally met in public last night, members listened to a financial presentation from Harris Kretsge, a vice president at J. P. Morgan Securities, which acted as a consultant to the authority.
According to J. P. Morgan, Entergy was offering $647 million in present-value dollars, and Dominion $727 million, for the plants, nuclear fuel stockpiles and other guaranteed terms. But factoring in certain contingencies -- like possible revenue-sharing profits -- resulted in a maximum potential of $747 million for Entergy and $786 million for Dominion.
But most important, he said, the value of each proposal would be at least four times more than the value of any previous sale of a nuclear plant, based on the dollars per generating capacity -- or, to use a car analogy, the amount of value per horsepower. "Either transaction is terrific," Mr. Kretsge said.
Even so, the board hit an unexpected stumbling block over the issue of taxes and finances, particularly over the money needed to decommission the plants. The power authority is supposed to pay for most of the costs of decommissioning the plants when they are deemed to have reached the end of their useful, or profitable, life, and so far, that decommissioning fund is worth around $630 million.

HEADLINE: Realty Company Sues State For Blocking L.I. Land Deal

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The largest commercial land owner on Long Island has sued the state's economic development agency over the company's aborted attempt to buy a 655-acre property at the Pilgrim State Psychiatric Facility in Brentwood for $32 million.
The lawsuit by a subsidiary of the Reckson Associates Realty Corporation of Melville claims that the state agency led by Charles A. Gargano had abruptly and improperly scuttled the deal for the prime tree-lined parcel last November, nearly a year after selecting the company as the highest bidder for the land. During that time, Reckson said it had spent millions of dollars helping the state resolve myriad problems related to the site, the largest tract of undeveloped land on Long Island. 
 The lawsuit claims that despite years of planning, the agency, the Empire State Development Corporation, had mistakenly included in the sale a power plant, a maintenance building, a day care center and a newly built outpatient center that were critical to the operation of the adjacent Pilgrim psychiatric hospital. Reckson was working to resolve the mistakes when the state suddenly killed the sale, amid complaints by losing bidders and an investigation by the Manhattan district attorney.
"We think we were used," said Donald Rechler, chairman of Reckson. "It cost us millions of dollars, while it enriched the state. They kept us on the hook for almost a year."
Reckson, which is seeking $20 million in damages, is also demanding that the state return its $3.2 million deposit without forcing the company to give up any legal rights.
A spokeswoman for the Empire State Development Corporation, Joanna Rose, said it was the agency's policy not to comment on lawsuits.
The Pilgrim land sale has been something of an embarrassment for the Pataki administration. In 1997, Gov. George E. Pataki and Mr. Gargano announced plans to sell 6,484 acres at 20 state psychiatric centers, including the Pilgrim site. The state eventually put only 12 parcels up for auction and sold fewer than four. Pilgrim was the largest and most valuable, because it straddles the Long Island Expressway and the Sagtikos Parkway and was ideally suited for housing, and retail and office buildings.
"It's a highly visible and very valuable piece," said David Pannetta, a vice president of Oxford & Simpson, a real estate broker on Long Island. 'It's unfortunate that it got tripped up the first time."
Earlier this year, the state put a smaller 460-acre parcel at Pilgrim up for sale. Real estate executives said the bids for the property, which are due in April, would be for far less than the original $32 million deal.
Several companies that made offers for the Pilgrim property the first time had complained last year that confidential bidding information had been leaked to a rival bidder, Louis R. Cappelli, then a partner in the Reckson bid. At the same time, the district attorney's office in Manhattan scrutinized the land sale as part of a broader investigation into allegations of political favoritism by Mr. Gargano and the Empire State Development Corporation.
In its lawsuit, Reckson said it had never sought, obtained or used any confidential information. The sale is still under investigation. Daniel J. Castleman, chief of investigations for the district attorney's office, said, "We don't comment on any allegations in civil lawsuits."
Mr. Rechler said he would probably submit a new bid for the property, although probably not with Mr. Cappelli. But two other bidders from the first round -- Jerry Wolkoff, a Long Island developer, and Margaret Miller, president of Miromar Development, based in Montreal -- were not sure about their plans.
"We're not happy about this whole thing," Ms. Miller said. "It should have gone to the second-highest bidder. And we were definitely the second-highest bidder."

HEADLINE: Cablevision Considers Rebuilding Madison Sq. Garden

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
The Cablevision Systems Corporation, which owns the New York Knicks and the Rangers, says it plans to demolish Madison Square Garden and build a new arena on the same site, or over the nearby rail yards on the West Side of Manhattan.
The Garden, which is between Seventh and Eighth Avenues at 33rd Street, is the country's busiest sports arena. But Cablevision said that it needed a new fan-friendly arena like the ones in Atlanta, Boston and Los Angeles that would enable the company to generate more revenues. 
 "We think that New York, being the No. 1 sports market in the U.S., deserves to have the very best, in terms of an arena," said James L. Dolan, chief executive of Cablevision and chairman of Madison Square Garden. "It has been the best, but it's beginning to age. We want to explore all the possibilities, but I do think we're going to end up with a new Garden."
Mr. Dolan said yesterday that he hoped to make a final decision on the fate of the 32-year-old Garden by the end of this year. If the company builds on the current site of the Garden, the Knicks and the Rangers could play at the Nassau Coliseum or the Meadowlands in New Jersey during construction.
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani first broached the idea of building an expensive new Madison Square Garden. In a speech more than 14 months ago, the mayor suggested building a new Madison Square Garden and a football stadium over the rail yards near 11th Avenue and West 33rd Street that would be linked to the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center.
The mayor said the project could be financed in part by Cablevision's selling the old property for a hotel and office towers, as well as with tax revenues from the new project. Since then, Cablevision has been exploring the idea of building a new arena, a proposal reported yesterday in Newsday.
Neither Mr. Dolan nor Anthony P. Coles, the deputy mayor for planning, were willing to discuss what public subsidies might be involved in the project. A new football stadium and a new Madison Square Garden have recently surfaced as elements of a proposal to hold the Olympics in New York City in 2012.
Although team owners have customarily demanded public assistance, Mr. Dolan said, "It's possible we'll be able to do it without any help at all."
Under a tax exemption, the Garden has not paid any real estate taxes for 18 years. Last year, Cablevision held 691 sports events, concerts and circuses at the arena and reaped $140 million in profits.
"It's the most active arena on the planet," said Mark Ganis, president of Sportscorp, a sports consulting company in Chicago. But it is not the most profitable, Mr. Ganis added, because Madison Square Garden does not have the same kind of premium seats and merchandising opportunities as do newer arenas.
"Economically, it is far from what it could be," Mr. Ganis said. "I believe Cablevision has made up for the deficiencies by jacking up ticket prices to ridiculous levels. A new arena should result in more corporate sponsorship and luxury revenues, thereby reducing the need to increase ticket prices beyond the astronomical levels they are today."
A front-row seat at a Knicks game costs $1,500. But even for lesser seats, it cost a family of four an average of $455.26 last year to attend a Knicks game, twice as much as in Denver, Orlando, Cleveland or Detroit, according to Team Marketing Report in Chicago. A Rangers game cost the same family $368.27.
In the last decade, demands by team owners for subsidized and increasingly profitable arenas and stadiums have reduced the life span of sports facilities. At Continental Arena in the Meadowlands, fans enjoy good sight lines and a well-run operation, but the team owners view the 19-year-old arena as antiquated because it does not have more luxury boxes or retail opportunities.
"It's all about profitability," said Robert A. Baade, an economist at Lake Forest College in Illinois and an expert in sports and government subsidies.
"These owners want every new revenue stream," he said. "The concern now is, what's the next new item that might render this current generation of stadiums and arenas obsolete?"
But Mr. Ganis, an owner of the Minnesota Vikings football team, said that Cablevision did not need a public subsidy to build a new Garden. "The primary reason for a new arena is to increase revenues," he said. "It's not like you have to build an arena to get a team, nor is there a compelling reason to build a new structure, as there is with Yankee Stadium."
Cablevision inherited a long-running tax break worth nearly $9 million a year in 1995, when it bought Madison Square Garden, the Knicks and the Rangers from Viacom Inc.
In response to threats to move the Knicks and Rangers out of New York City in 1982, Mayor Edward I. Koch granted the owner of the teams at the time, Gulf & Western, what was described as a 10-year property tax break worth about $50 million. But the legislation did not impose a time limit on the subsidy, which has swelled to a total of $128.7 million since 1982.
Paramount Communications, which owned the Garden in the late 1980's, considered moving to the West Side rail yards but found that option too expensive. Instead, the company spent $200 million renovating the Garden and building a 275-seat restaurant and 88 luxury boxes.

He was Charles Dolan, chairman of Cablevision. His son James L. Dolan is chief executive of Cablevision and chairman of the Garden.

HEADLINE: Herman B Wells, 97, President Of Indiana U. in a Crucial Era

BYLINE: By ANDY NEWMAN 

 BODY:
Herman B Wells, the president of Indiana University during 25 years of steady growth and social change, died on Saturday at age 97 at his home in Bloomington, Ind., not far off the campus of the university that was the center of his life for more than 70 years.
Under Mr. Wells's leadership, Indiana University's student body grew from 11,000 to more than 30,000 (it now stands at 90,000 students, spread across eight campuses). 
 Mr. Wells was quietly devoted to progressive causes. He ended a host of segregationist practices at the university and urged the basketball coach, Branch McCracken, to recruit Bill Garrett, who in 1948 became the first black to play a varsity sport in the Big Ten.
He defended Dr. Alfred C. Kinsey, the head of the Institute for Sex Research at the university, against calls for his dismissal, and argued for the right of scholars to pursue their quest for truth without harassment.
Mr. Wells, a stout, jolly man who loved to cook and entertain, was also determined to make the university a cultural center for the Midwest.
When the Metropolitan Opera Company first performed on a college campus, it was at Indiana University in 1942, performing "Aida" to a capacity crowd of 3,800 from 108 cities and towns in 5 states. Mr. Wells called the concert "an event without precedent in the cultural life of Indiana."
Herman B Wells -- the B was his entire middle name -- was born in Jamestown, Ind., on June 7, 1902, the only son of a banker, Joseph Granville Wells, and a former teacher, Anna Bernice Harting Wells. His parents gave him his extremely brief middle name because they wanted to keep a tradition in his mother's family of middle names beginning with the letter B but could not agree on which name to give Herman.
Mr. Wells enrolled in the University of Illinois but transferred to Indiana after one year and, he said, fell in love with the place. After graduating in 1924, he worked in a bank, then obtained his master's degree at the University of Wisconsin. He returned to Indiana as an economics instructor in 1930.
In 1935, he was appointed dean of the university's business school, and in 1937 he was named president.
After retiring from the presidency in 1962, Mr. Wells taught business administration, was named the university's first chancellor -- a largely honorary title that he kept until his death -- and served as president of the Indiana University Foundation, which oversaw fund-raising for the university.
Mr. Wells was also active in affairs of state. Near the end of World War II, he was a special adviser on liberated areas for the State Department, and he served as an observer for the Greek elections in 1946. He was a delegate to the United Nations General Assembly in 1957.
In 1958, Mr. Wells was the head of a national commission that produced a report, "The Contemporary Challenge to American Education," urging the United States to double its spending on education over the next 10 years. In 1964, he led a group that studied New York's state university system and advised the state Legislature to cut red tape and give educators a freer hand.
Mr. Wells, who did not marry, left no immediate survivors.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

CORRECTION-DATE: March 23, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An obituary on Tuesday about Herman B Wells, former president of Indiana University, referred incorrectly to an athlete he had urged the university to recruit. Bill Garrett, who played basketball for Indiana in 1948, was not the first black player of a varsity sport at a Big Ten college. Conference records give that distinction to Julian Ware, who played basketball for the University of Wisconsin from 1900 to 1902.

HEADLINE: RETRO KITCHEN;
Sundays With Ravioli: Where Have They Gone?

BYLINE: By ALEX WITCHEL; This article is part of an occasional series that focuses on writers' memories of food and drink.

 BODY:
IT may have been my first love -- before Clark Gable, before Bobby Sherman, even before Jonathan Mink in the second grade.
Meat ravioli. 
 My fixation began with a prototype more appropriate to a Jewish girl, meat kreplach, which my grandmother fried and served with applesauce. But growing up in the era of checkered-tablecloth Italian restaurants, I soon established a pattern of gluttony by ordering -- and finishing -- two portions of meat ravioli from the children's menu. By the time I was in first grade, my parents figured it was cheaper to pretend I was 21.
The last time I remember ordering meat ravioli was in the mid-80's at La Boheme in Greenwich Village. It was delicious, with its tomato and meat sauce and thin topping of toasty mozzarella, like ravioli and pizza in one.
I haven't seen it since.
"Have you noticed that no one serves meat ravioli anymore?" my friend, Suzanne, asked recently. A native Tennessean who moved to New York in the 60's and immediately fell in love with all things ethnic, she was the only one who shared my fixation, except for a Jewish friend whose parents took him for Italian on the rare Sunday nights they skipped Chinese.
I assured her I had noticed (it's been off the menu at La Boheme for years) and decided it was time to take action. I asked two Italian-American friends for recommendations, both of whom said they had grown up with cheese ravioli and looked askance at the notion of meat.
But meat's what I remember most vividly. We used to go out to dinner every Sunday, my mother's weekly emancipation, and when we went for Italian, we drove to one of a few places near where we lived in Passaic, N.J., either Bob's or Pompeii or Giuliano's. The last was a dark restaurant where my mother would order a cocktail, delivered from the even darker bar in the next room, while my brother and I each had Cokes (only one!) which we had to make last. My father drank wine and gave us a sip, but who wanted that when you could have Coke?
Then, as the adults started in on plates of antipasto filled with stinky anchovies and slimy peppers, they gave us quarters so we could each pick songs from the jukebox (Pompeii's was the coolest, boasting selections like "Pretty Woman"), and when we were done fighting over whose songs went first and got back to the table and still didn't drink our Cokes, my ravioli would finally appear. It came nestled in its individual silver pan, casserole style, and I would cut through the steaming layers with a fork, which felt like opening 10 presents at once.
There was no mozzarella on top then, just Parmesan cheese, if you wanted it, which I never did. It smelled awful, which was why I never ordered cheese ravioli, convinced it would smell the same. And anyway, I didn't want anything to interfere with the way the meat inside the pasta tasted different from the meat in the tomato sauce, and I made sure each bite had some of both, until, alas, the pan was empty.
And what that really meant was that the weekend was over and there was school the next day. And even though we got pennies to throw in the wishing well at Giuliano's, that was it. Finished. The meal, the weekend, all of it. We had no choice but to face the doom of school.
With the taste of those Sundays in my mouth, I sat down and called 52 Italian restaurants in Manhattan, looking for meat ravioli. Eight had it. Eight! Almost every restaurant had cheese ravioli. Some had pumpkin. Or butternut squash, shiitake mushroom or smoked salmon. I even found rabbit and venison ravioli in truffle broth. But old-fashioned meat ravioli in a tomato-based meat sauce? Sorry, Signora, no.
Not one of the eight restaurants was in Little Italy. I called every one I could find, with no luck. At Il Palazzo, a waiter told me that no one carries it anymore. "People don't trust meat filling as much as they did," he said. "Most restaurants buy it frozen, so I wouldn't order it unless it's a special. Cheese you can whip up quickly. Meat takes longer."
Andrew Raffetto, president of the Raffetto Corporation, a family-owned business in SoHo that supplies restaurants and stores with ravioli, said: "Everyone now wants pumpkin and lobster. We still make meat for our store on Houston Street, with my grandfather's recipe from Genoa. We sell a nice little amount, and around Christmas and Easter we sell 10 times as much. But it ain't what it used to be. Grandma passed away, the kids moved to the suburbs, and over the years we've sold less and less."
But I ate my meat ravioli in the suburbs. Where did it go?
I asked a few Italian chefs, who told me that meat ravioli, like other stuffed pastas, was originally a labor-intensive feast-day dish in certain regions of Northern Italy. First the stuffing is made, then the pasta, then the individual pieces are filled and cooked, and mixed with the sauce -- cooked separately -- that accompanies the dish.
But in America this tradition, like so many, changed to fit the immigrants' new circumstances, which meant a drastic shift in ingredients. Lidia Bastianich, who with her son, Joe, owns Felidia and Becco in New York and Lidia in Kansas City, is at work on a series about Italian-American cooking for PBS. She makes the point that, as with meatballs, which were not cooked with sauce in Italy, but began to be here to improve the flavor of lackluster tomatoes, ravioli was also transformed, from the festive to the ordinary.
"I think with ravioli, the idea of it sort of got switched here through commercialization," she said. Certainly, most Americans learned to think of meat ravioli as nothing more complicated than opening a can of Chef Boyardee.
In some Italian households, though, the dish became a way to use up odds and ends. As Mario Batali, the chef at Babbo and Po, said: "The classic meat ravioli of our childhood was based on the economics of the kitchen, using leftovers. That was how Grandma stretched the meat." Though Mr. Batali does not make a traditional meat ravioli at Babbo, he makes something called Angel's Pyramids, a larger variation that is filled with either braised lamb, pork shoulder or brisket, and served in butter and sage. "After braising it for days, I don't want to mask the nuance of the stuffing with a tomato sauce," he said.
I see his point, though I also agree with Tony May, the owner of San Domenico and Gemelli, when he says: "A standard recipe is no longer of interest. A chef who cooks ravioli standing on his head, that's of interest." (For the record, neither of his places serves meat ravioli, either.)
I began my search at Gino on Lexington Avenue at 60th Street, a restaurant I love. Michael Miele, the chef, assured me that meat ravioli was on the menu, though I'd never noticed it before. There it was, Homemade Ravioli, which I had always assumed was cheese. It was served on a plate, not in a pan, and I found it only ordinary. I spent most of the meal snitching the excellent sausage and peppers from my husband's plate, instead.
Next, I tried Gene's on West 11th Street, with dismal results. The ravioli were undercooked and had the consistency of cardboard, one step up from a school cafeteria.
Maybe this quest was hopeless, I thought, trudging back to the subway with heartburn. Here I am, trying to recreate a phantom taste from childhood with food my mouth might no longer crave. After all, everyone's tastes change. Maybe even the best meat ravioli wouldn't thrill me now.
But that night I went to Pietro's, the Italian steakhouse on East 43rd Street. Meat ravioli is available as an appetizer or entree, and it was quite good. The winy-tasting Bolognese sauce was more sophisticated than what I remember, but the dish was satisfying enough to order again.
My spirits rose. Until I went to Da Tommaso, on Eighth Avenue at 53rd Street. Ravioli there is made with a sauce of sun-dried tomatoes, peppers and white wine. Sun-dried tomatoes and meat ravioli? For heaven's sake! The ravioli themselves were tasteless, the entire enterprise misconceived and depressing. I quit halfway through.
My luck was not much better at Via Oreto, on First Avenue at 61st Street, or Nanni's on East 46th Street. Via Oreto made the ravioli to order after I called ahead, and it was adequate, though salty. Nanni's serves meat ravioli as a lunch special every Wednesday, but when I sat down at 1 p.m., I was told that all 20 portions had sold out by 12:15. I wasn't sure I believed it, and with flashbacks of sun-dried tomatoes, wasn't sure I cared.
At Villa Mosconi, on Macdougal Street at West Houston, the veal parmigiana was very good, and the staff couldn't have been nicer. My friend, Suzanne, couldn't have either. She came with me and hid her disappointment when the ravioli tasted like paste.
So I was relieved that she agreed to try again the following night when I discovered meat ravioli nirvana at Bravo Gianni on East 63rd Street. When I had called, the chef, Gianni Garavelli, answered the phone. I had asked my standard question, "Do you have meat ravioli on your menu?" and he said: "I am making once in a while on Sundays. I can make if you want."
I wanted. "The ravioli has a very particular taste," he said. "It's been distorted in the United States, where the press has encouraged people to sell invented dishes as authentic food. In Italy I learn the authentic way. I make for my family, but it's a very laborious dish."
That Sunday, Mr. Garavelli sat down at the table with us. "I learned this from my sister Clementina, who lives near Genoa," he said. "In the meat sauce there is also spinach, borage and Swiss chard, and you cook that with beef, veal, chicken gizzard, sausage, sweetbreads and brains."
He saw the look on my face.
"Knowing that might take away the poetry for many people, but that's the way it's supposed to be done," he continued. "And the dough is very thin. The beauty of ravioli is the most fine pasta, because the edge is double. The meat sauce with it is a ragu. Are you ready?"
It was too late to back out now. I smiled bravely. Bring on the brains.
The minute he presented a copper pan filled with ravioli, my bliss began. The smell was heavenly. The pasta was supple, almost springy, the filling divine. I didn't care what was in there; it was light and tasty, and I only wanted more. The sauce was old-fashioned enough to qualify as what I remembered, while revealing a complexity I could appreciate only after decades of eating and cooking. I suddenly couldn't remember the other taste; there was only this taste, the only one that had ever mattered. It was the romance novel of meat ravioli, the true love that had eluded me for so long.
Mr. Garavelli looked at us from across the room, and I saw him smile. This man had accomplished what I had assumed was impossible: the perfect adult rendering of a childhood memory, Cokes and wishing wells not required. When I realized I didn't have to go to school the next day, I thought I might cry.
After unabashedly stuffing myself, I took the scant leftovers home. The next morning, I woke up and devoured them before I even made coffee. I looked at the empty container for about two seconds before picking up the phone to make another reservation.
"Do you want to come into the kitchen before and see how I make?" Mr. Garavelli asked.
I considered it. "No, I don't think so," I said, finally. "But have you ever thought about getting a jukebox?"

HEADLINE: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK;
The Joffrey Takes Leaps in a Battle for Survival

BYLINE: By ANNA KISSELGOFF 

DATELINE: CHICAGO, March 18

 BODY:
Mankind battles Fate with a capital F in "Les Presages," the epic ballet by Leonide Massine that the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago has just performed so magnificently as part of its season here.
As Tchaikovsky's Fifth Symphony rumbled to its climax, as happiness vanquished evil and temptation onstage, Massine's famed allegorical vision of 1933 became suddenly a metaphor for the Joffrey's own triumphant battle for survival. 
 Five years after severe financial problems pointed to the possible demise of one of America's most popular ballet troupes, its move from New York (involving a legal reorganization and name change from Joffrey Ballet to Joffrey Ballet of Chicago) offers a lesson in rescue strategy.
When the Joffrey took over rented studios and offices in downtown Chicago in October 1995, its $9 million budget had been cut to $5 million and its dancers to 30 from 40. It had repeatedly canceled seasons in New York, where it has not been seen since 1994.
Things look very different now. On the artistic side, not only performances but also a rehearsal of George Balanchine's "Square Dance" over the weekend reveal a stunning new perfection in classical style. Gerald Arpino, the Joffrey's artistic director, beams when asked if he and his ballet masters (Mark Goldweber, Cameron Basden and Charthel Arthur) have recently concentrated on toe work. But this is still the Gerald Arpino whose choreography has always been more concerned with spirit than steps. No, he suggests, technique is not the only goal. "I want them to dance from the inside," he says, pointing to his heart.
With typical Joffrey gumption and considerable help from an expanding group of supporters in Chicago with high-powered civic connections, the company has not only survived but acquired a presence here that it never had in New York.
"Chicago has embraced the Joffrey," said Lois Weisberg, the city's cultural affairs commissioner, noting that several factors worked in the company's favor. Bereft of a world-class ballet company that would match the reputation of its major arts institutions, the business and arts communities here have been energetic on the company's behalf. The Joffrey's new chairman is C. Steven McMillan, the president and chief operating officer of the Sara Lee Corporation.
The troupe was familiar to Chicago, having picked up a following here since it began performing here in 1957. "They were held in high esteem," Ms. Weisberg said. "They were not perceived as interlopers. It was not Joffrey Ballet of New York but Joffrey Ballet of the world."
Mayor Richard M. Daley attends performances and "is extremely interested in the Joffrey," Ms. Weisberg added. "He knew its reputation."
Interest at the top helps. The Joffrey is about to acquire a building in the downtown Loop area, a gift from Commonwealth Edison. The $20 million renovation for studios, offices and retail space is expected to receive some help from the city through its tax-increment financing program, by which the city provides incentive money for development in anticipation of being repaid with increased real estate taxes.
It is the Joffrey's good luck to arrive in this revitalized theater district in the Loop just as other arts organizations (including the Goodman Theater) also move in, along with a potential audience drawn by apartments recently converted from offices and factories.
"I'm a Chicagoan," Mr. Arpino, a longtime resident of Greenwich Village, said with a straight face and then added convincingly, "I gave up my apartment in New York."
Once dependent on touring, the Joffrey has identified itself with Chicago by working to increase its presence here. The company's budget has climbed back to more than $9 million, with no deficits. In New York the Joffrey could afford an orchestra at City Center, but even this weekend at the landmark Auditorium Theater the music was, for economic reasons, on tape. Nonetheless, the company's five-week "Nutcracker" season employs an orchestra and brought in $2.1 million last winter.
The company performs in the Chicago area for 10 of its 37 work weeks, which include rehearsal. There is also a concerted outreach program with middle schools in the city. Since 1997 the company has had a summer residency in Telluride, Colo., and has resumed international touring, with stops in Egypt, Turkey and Israel.
Despite significant progress, Mr. Arpino has no immediate plans for performances in New York. While the company is still rebuilding, intense scrutiny might not help. "What has happened is a miracle," he said. "We're a legend now and I'm holding back. In New York we would be expected to be what we once were."
These remarks seem to imply that the company is not at full strength in terms of repertory, number of dancers and finances. All true, which makes the high artistic level of the dancing and production values during the weekend's performances all the more surprising. In addition to "Les Presages," which was a major Joffrey revival in 1993-94, the program included its well-known staging of "L'Apres-Midi d'un Faune" by Vaslav Nijinsky and the company premiere of Balanchine's "Prodigal Son."
What Mr. Arpino really means is what the company's staff and supporters here all insist upon: that the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago is a new company, and that its reason for being is to maintain the continuity of vision of the Joffrey Ballet, founded in 1956 by Mr. Arpino and Robert Joffrey, who died in 1988.
"We're trying to do in 10 years what other organizations do in 40," said Bruce Sagan, a regional newspaper publisher and businessman who has been president of the Steppenwolf Theater Company and has been prominent in supporting cultural groups in Chicago for decades.
"The first thing was to survive," Mr. Sagan said. "That meant we couldn't run deficits and that means you have to make choices and set priorities. I too would like an orchestra with performances, but that will come.
"The effort so far has gone into controlling the cost of everything so that Gerry Arpino can rebuild the repertory and get new dancers."
In 1995 few in the dance world would have bet on the Joffrey's future. The troupe was deeply in debt (with a deficit of $1.6 million) and it was perceived as a touring company based in New York.
Jack R. Lemmon, executive director of the Joffrey Ballet of Chicago, credits the New York board of the former company with a strategic decision. "The company needed to reinvent itself," he said. "It was a touring company that occasionally performed in its home city. Now it is a resident company in Chicago that still does national and international touring."
Like Ballet Theater and New York City Ballet, with which it had been ranked, the Joffrey had its home in New York. But whether New York could support all three companies was in question. The company did, however, have board members from Chicago and the Midwest, and it was this group that advocated a reorganized entity in Chicago.
On the artistic side, the turnaround has been even more significant. Predictions were dire after the 1993 Joffrey premiere of "Billboards," a rock ballet to music by the Artist (still Prince at the time).
Mr. Arpino remains unapologetic for "Billboards," and despite the occasional scorn of critics the ballet is credited in large part with saving the company and keeping its dancers performing.
Nowadays the repertory picture has changed. In addition to the return of Mr. Arpino's own works and of 20th-century classics previously performed by the Joffrey, there have been premieres by Laura Dean and young choreographers like Randy Duncan, formerly a dancer in the Joseph Holmes Company.
Last fall there was also the company premiere of "Frankie and Johnny," a landmark 1938 work by Ruth Page and Bentley Stone, pioneers of American ballet in Chicago in the 1930's and 40's. Other firsts for the company that Mr. Arpino plans to present are Antony Tudor's "Lilac Garden" and Martha Graham's "Appalachian Spring."
Mr. Arpino admits that "in the first year here when we had to survive, I let the styles go down." But a visit with the three former leading Joffrey dancers who have served as ballet masters in the last two or three years does much to explain why the company's 32 dancers now look so stylish and technically strong. Eleven are from the former company, with Deborah Dawn the senior ballerina, the best-known. But some who were relatively new to the company in 1994, like Calvin Kitten, Davis Robertson and Maia Wilkins, among others, have developed into strong and striking dancers.
The highlight on Thursday and Friday was certainly "Les Presages." Ms. Basden's staging, based on the original Joffrey revival by Tatiana Leskova, does a fabulous job of making a historical curiosity come alive to modern audiences.
The ballet's interest lies less in its allegorical duel between a generic hero and a gnomic Fate figure than in the movement choruses that Massine borrowed from German modern dance in the 1930's.
Ms. Basden does wonders not only in featuring the women's strong toe work but also in the clarity she has achieved in the swiftly moving contrapuntal patterns.
But now, as was not true before, the soloists in each movement give Massine's once-surprising Neo-Classical choreography a forceful projection. They included Ms. Wilkins, Ms. Dawn, Domingo Rubio and Leticia Oliveira, and alternating as Fate, Mr. Robertson and Guoping Wang.
"The Prodigal Son," although familiar at City Ballet and other companies, is atypical Balanchine, his last experiment in a Constructivist style. Mr. Kitten is too pure a classical dancer to adjust immediately to its grotesque aspects. But by his second performance on Friday, he made his very young rebel persuasive. Trinity Hamilton also did better as the Siren on the second night, preserving her marvelous loose-hipped cool.
When the Joffrey revived "Faune" in 1979 its minimalism and potent sensuality were mesmerizing. Against an approximation of Leon Bakst's woodland backdrop, lighted brilliantly by Kevin Dreyer, the Faune still eats his grapes, scares off seven nymphs and satisfies himself with a celebrated autoerotic climax. A new literalism crept into Mr. Robertson's performance at the end on Thursday. On Friday it was markedly toned down by Mr. Rubio. Both were marvelously intense. As in the good old days, a program at the Joffrey was unlike any other.

HEADLINE: Text of Fed's Statement

 BODY:
Following is the text of the statement by the Federal Open Market Committee, the Federal Reserve's monetary policy panel, after its decision yesterday to raise short-term interest rates:
The Federal Open Market Committee voted today to raise its target for the federal funds rate by 25 basis points, to 6 percent. In a related action, the board of governors approved a 25 basis point increase in the discount rate to 5 1/2 percent. 
 Economic conditions and considerations addressed by the committee are essentially the same as when the committee met in February. The committee remains concerned that increases in demand will continue to exceed the growth in potential supply, which could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's record economic expansion.
Against the background of its long-run goals of price stability and sustainable economic growth and of the information currently available, the committee believes the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future.
In taking the discount rate action, the Federal Reserve Board approved requests submitted by the boards of directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Cleveland, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago, St. Louis, Minneapolis, Kansas City and San Francisco. The discount rate is the rate charged depository institutions when they borrow short-term adjustment credit from their district Federal Reserve Banks.

HEADLINE: Three Firms Invest $40 Million In Times Company's Digital Unit

 BODY:
The New York Times Company, which plans a public offering of a new class of stock in its Internet business division this spring, said yesterday that three venture capital firms had invested $40 million in the division, Times Company Digital.
The investors are Flatiron Partners, Highland Capital Partners and Chase Capital Partners, a unit of Chase Manhattan Bank. The firms acquired three-year debt that will be convertible -- after the offering -- into the Times Company's new Class C shares, which will track the performance of Times Company Digital. 
 Details about the investment, including the interest rate to be paid on the debt and the conversion price for the shares, were not disclosed.
Jerry Colonna, managing partner of Flatiron Partners, and Daniel Nova, managing general partner of Highland Capital Partners, also agreed to join a new advisory board for the digital division, the Times Company said. Other members of the board from outside the company are Red Burns, the chairwoman of the interactive telecommunications program at New York University, and Mark Walsh, the chief executive of VerticalNet Inc.
The members of the advisory board from the Times Company are Arthur Sulzberger Jr., chairman; Russell T. Lewis, president and chief executive; Howell Raines, editorial page editor of The New York Times; and Martin A. Nisenholtz, the chief executive of the digital division.
The company filed a registration statement for the stock with the Securities and Exchange Commission on Jan. 28, but the offering cannot be made until it is cleared by the S.E.C. and approved by shareholders at a meeting scheduled for April 27.

HEADLINE: U.S. to Urge Letting Iraq Double Money For Oil Gear

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 21

 BODY:
The United States will propose doubling the sums Iraq may spend on spare parts for its decrepit oil industry, neglected during almost 10 years of sanctions, diplomats said today.
Under an American-sponsored resolution to be circulated for discussion among Security Council members in the next day or two, Iraq would be permitted to raise to $600 million every six months -- $1.2 billion a year -- instead of the current $300 million every six months. 
 The money is raised through the "oil for food" program, which allows Iraq to sell oil to meet the needs of its civilians. The increase was recommended by Secretary General Kofi Annan in a report to the council this month because the sanctions have left the equipment in such poor shape.
The plan, generally expected to be voted on by the council on Friday unless there are unforeseen objections, is being introduced as members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries prepare to meet in Vienna next week to discuss the possibility of increasing oil production so that record high prices will decline.
Iraq has oil reserves second only to Saudi Arabia's, experts say. Since December, the Iraqis have been permitted to sell as much oil as they wish under the United Nations-supervised program. Some of the proceeds pay for goods needed by civilians, who have been living under sanctions since 1990, and for public services like water and electricity.
Today an official Iraqi newspaper attacked oil-exporting countries thought to be willing to increase production to ease costs for the United States and other countries. "The United States policy of blackmail must be rejected," said the paper, Al-Jumhuriya, which as with all Iraqi papers is government controlled.
Yet Iraq has been straining its pumping and pipeline operations to take advantage of the higher prices, although it cannot sustain such a high level for long, Mr. Annan's report said. It described Iraqi oil installations as hazards to the safety of workers and the environment.
The report was based on a technical survey of the industry requested by the council in December and carried out in January by an independent group of oil experts from Saybolt International BV of the Netherlands.
Diplomats are not concerned that allowing Iraq to double the money spent on spare parts for oil production will cut into the food, medicine or other purchases for the population because with oil prices high, income has also risen and if additional oil is pumped, additional civilian goods can be imported. In the last three years, Iraq has earned $20 billion in supervised oil sales, with a third of that going to compensate victims of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in 1990.
But even with added money, Iraq says, it cannot upgrade its oil industry effectively as long as the United States and, to a lesser extent, Britain, block critical contracts for spare parts or related oil equipment in the Security Council sanctions committee.
