HEADLINE: Trying a Stern Hand on a Mediocre School District

BYLINE: By ANEMONA HARTOCOLLIS 

 BODY:
When Michael A. Johnson first visited Intermediate School 192 in southeastern Queens last month, he found students capering down hallways and shouting out of windows during class.
Every day, more than 100 students were late, and 15 to 17 teachers were absent. The fluorescent lights were dim. The computers were not connected to high-speed wiring. 
 Two weeks later, Mr. Johnson strode through the door again, wire-rim glasses flashing. An anxious deputy flitted out of the shadows with the good news: "Mr. Johnson, 38 students late this morning."
"How many teachers absent?" Mr. Johnson asked. "Two," came the reply.
A no-nonsense engineer turned principal, Mr. Johnson is now the acting superintendent of District 29 -- one of the first appointments made by the interim chancellor, Harold O. Levy -- and his job is to take one of the city's most middle-class black school districts and turn it around. The schools in District 29 perform near the citywide average on standardized tests. But considering its affluence -- it covers well-groomed neighborhoods of single-family homes like Rosedale and Laurelton -- it should be doing much better, Mr. Johnson said.
What is worse, he said, the longer students stay in the district's schools, the more their performance deteriorates.
A lot is riding on whether Mr. Johnson succeeds. If he improves the district, he could demonstrate that a single strong leader working with traditional methods of instruction can have an impact in neighborhoods bogged down in mediocrity. If he fails, he could add to the disillusionment over the promise of public education.
In District 29's case, mediocre scores have also put the district on the front lines of the war over school vouchers. It is the former Congressional district of the Rev. Floyd Flake, pastor of Allen A.M.E. Church, and Mr. Flake has used the district as ammunition in his campaign for vouchers.
In 1993, Mr. Johnson founded the Science Skills Center, a high school at the foot of the Manhattan Bridge in Brooklyn. As principal, he offended his fellow school reformers by demanding that his black and Hispanic students, many from poor families, take the SAT's and Regents tests that are more commonly expected of upper-middle class children bound for college.
His students did well: 86 percent of his 11th graders passed the English Regents examination in 1998, compared with 40 percent of those in schools with similar economic and racial demographics.
"I came from a school that was just about all black and it was a high-achieving school," Mr. Johnson said. "There is a culture to good-schoolness. You can assert that in any setting, albeit superficially at first. But it will take root."
Mr. Levy knew of the Skills Center by reputation, and recognized a kindred spirit in Mr. Johnson, right down to his swashbuckling manner and a shared penchant for pinstripe suits and crisply starched shirts.
Mr. Levy appointed Mr. Johnson on Feb. 11, after suspending the elected school board because it could not agree on a permanent superintendent. Leroy Comrie Jr., the president of the board, said he believed the board had been suspended because it had opposed plans to build a junior high school on the site of Creedmore Psychiatric Center.
About 2 percent of the district's 27,000 students are white, 75 percent are black, 12 percent are Hispanic and 11 percent are Asian. Only 32 percent of the district's eighth graders passed the state's English test, compared with 36 percent for the city, and just 14 percent passed the math test, compared with 23 percent for the city.
Mr. Johnson says he is determined to avoid district politics and to focus on education. Two weeks ago, he took a reporter on a tour of three schools, to demonstrate his approach.
At I.S. 192, he told how he had taken walkie-talkies away from the assistant principals, who had been, he said with disgust, behaving more like police officers than educators. He brought in about 25 teacher trainers and administrators to supervise the staff. As he peeked into classrooms the other day, many of the regular teachers were sitting in the back of the room, while Mr. Johnson's staff modeled lessons for them.
At the next school Mr. Johnson visited, P.S. 131, one of the district's best, he asked the principal, Walter J. O'Brien, what he needed. Mr. O'Brien did not hesitate. Many of his immigrant students, he said, are bright enough to test out of English language classes very quickly, then "get clobbered" on the state's standardized tests. Mr. O'Brien asked for a summer-school program to perfect their English. Mr. Johnson was thrilled. "I can almost guarantee you'll get it," he said.
But at the next school, P.S. 36, Mr. Johnson was once again shaking his head in dismay. Through the door of one classroom, a teacher could be heard yelling "Zip it! Zip it!" to the children. Another teacher had locked the classroom door. In another classroom, the children were working in near darkness. The teacher said they had just returned from lunch and she had forgotten to turn on the lights.
The principal introduced the woman who heads the school's leadership team. "What are you working on now?" Mr. Johnson asked politely. The woman could not remember.
Mr. Johnson asked the principal, Cynthia M. Hunter, what she needed. She said she needed another paraprofessional to walk children to the bathroom. "How about academics?" Mr. Johnson prodded. The principal said 300 of the school's 523 students had received letters warning that they were at risk of being assigned to summer school. She expected 150 of them to have to go.
Mr. Johnson suggested that she send all 300 nonetheless. "I would have 150 in a program to meet the standards, and 150 in a program to push them above," he said.
The principal said she liked the idea, but would not be in a position to carry it out. She had "opted out" of summer school, she said, under a provision of her union contract. "Who will be taking over your school?" Mr. Johnson asked. "I don't know," the principal replied.

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
NETHERLANDS: 3 APOLOGIES -- The government apologized to Jews, Gypsies and Indonesians for a "chilly" official response in the past to their claims to property seized during and after World War II. Prime Minister Wim Kok said the government had to face up to "mistakes and shortcomings" made in the 1940's and offered $180 million, in addition to past restitutions, to the Central Jewish Congress. Gypsies received an extra $13 million. Indonesians who sided with the Dutch during Indonesia's fight for independence in 1949 were offered $110 million. Marlise Simons (NYT)
 
GERMANY: BERTELSMANN JOINS FUND -- Bertelsmann, the German media company that owns Random House, said it would contribute to a $5 billion fund to compensate Nazi-era slave and forced laborers, but declined to say how much. The company is in the process of revising its corporate history in the light of evidence that it did not, as it previously contended, oppose Hitler's regime. Contentious talks on how the fund should be divided will resume here today. Roger Cohen (NYT) 
 
NETHERLANDS: CROAT HANDED OVER -- A Bosnian Croat accused of war crimes was handed over to the United Nations tribunal in The Hague, where he arrived with a psychiatrist and other medical personnel. Mladen Naletelic, 54, a former military commander, was indicted for persecution, torture and murder of Muslims in Bosnia in 1993 and 1994. The new Croatian leadership, in contrast to past governments, accepted tribunal doctors' findings that he was well enough to stand trial. Marlise Simons (NYT)
 
IRELAND: ORANGEMEN IN DUBLIN -- Northern Ireland's Orange Order, whose summer parades of men in bowler hats and orange sashes regularly plunge the province into turmoil, has been invited by Dublin officials to march there in May. "We have the right of free assembly here," Lord Mayor Mary Freehill said. A Sinn Fein spokesman compared Ms. Freehill's action to "the state governor inviting the Ku Klux Klan to march in Alabama." Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
CHILE: PINOCHET IN HOSPITAL -- Gen. Augusto Pinochet, 84, entered a clinic for tests after fainting in his residence outside Santiago. The clinic would not comment on the condition of the former dictator, who returned to Chile on March 3 after spending 16 months under house arrest outside London on a Spanish warrant charging him with human rights violations. Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
COLOMBIA: REBELS BLACK OUT CITIES -- Power was cut to a huge swath of central and northeast Colombia, including the capital, Bogota, and at least six other cities, after a wave of sabotage attacks by Marxist rebels opposed to a selloff of the state power industry. At least eight of the country's 32 provinces, including oil-producing regions of the northeast, were hit by the cuts. The privatizations were ordered by the International Monetary Fund as part of a $2.7 billion loan deal. (Reuters)
 
MONTSERRAT: VOLCANO IS NEW THREAT -- The newly active Soufriere Hills volcano hurled glowing rocks high into the sky, setting off fiery avalanches and shot a thundering ash cloud as high as 30,000 feet, scientists said. The explosion sent a new coat of ash over parts of the island's northern "safe zone," where residents have been living since the volcano began erupting in 1995. Since then, 7,000 of the 11,000 residents have left for other Caribbean islands and Britain. (AP)

JAPAN: EX-AIDE ADMITS HARASSMENT -- The former Governor of Osaka, Japan's second-largest city, admitted for the first time in court that he had groped a 21-year-old campaign worker last year. Until now, Isamu Yamada, a former comedian who still uses his stage name, Knock Yokoyama, had denied accusations of sexual harassment while agreeing to pay a large civil settlement. Mr. Yokoyama resigned after his indictment for sexual molestation. Calvin Sims (NYT)

He also announced on a visit to Kauswagan that the mayor would go on leave after accusations by residents that he fled when guerrillas of the Moro Islamic Liberation Front occupied the Kauswagan town hall last week in fighting that left at least 21 people dead. (Agence France-Presse)

Albright and other officials for a "lack of honesty" and "ignorance of the geography of the region." The statement appeared aimed less at the moves announced by Dr. Albright than at remarks she made later in India that made note of divisions over policy toward the United States between Iran's democratic reform movement and a hard-line faction associated with the ruling clerics. John F. Burns (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
COMORO ISLANDS: COUP ATTEMPT FOILED -- The army foiled a coup attempt and a son of a former president was in custody, officials said. Shots rang out in Moroni, the capital, but no casualties were reported. Officials said they believed that the action, the 19th coup or attempted coup since independence from France in 1975, was led by two sons of the islands' first president, Ahmed Abdallah, who was assassinated in 1989. They said one son, a former agriculture minister, had been arrested. (Reuters)
 
ZIMBABWE: SQUATTERS STAY PUT -- White farmers whose properties were illegally occupied by war veterans in a demand for land reform said there was no indication that the police had acted to evict the squatters within 24 hours, as ordered by the High Court on Friday. The court said that if the squatters refused to leave, the police were to forcibly remove them after 72 hours, a deadline that expired late Monday. (Agence France-Presse)

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
An international design agency's name becomes a shadow of itself in a move to bolster its identity.

BYLINE: By Jane L. Levere 

 BODY:
A LOW-PROFILE international design and image firm, Desgrippes Gobe & Associates, which has high-profile clients like Air France, Coca-Cola and the Limited, is creating a new identity for a client it has known forever: itself.
The 29-year-old, 165-person agency, which had $25 million in revenue last year, will be renamed d/g* (the asterisk represents a star) effective April 4 as part of a campaign to heighten awareness of the agency's services. 
 The company, which has headquarters in Paris and New York and offices in Brussels, Tokyo and Seoul, South Korea, has also created a logo made up of four symbols that represent its disciplines: a star represents its marketing and design expertise; a bull's eye with the letter "C" at the center represents the firm's consulting practice; a building represents its architectural expertise; and an eye represents its interactive capabilities. The campaign also includes a redesigned Web site at www.dga .com.
Marc Gobe, president of the New York office, said Desgrippes Gobe had decided to rename itself because it found that although its original name "reflected the identity of the founding designers, it was not always easy to pronounce or remember."
"It also failed to communicate our evolution into an international organization and our capabilities," he added.
Central to d/g*'s work is its concept of emotional branding, which involves analyzing the visual and emotional responses a good or service generates. For a brand to be successful, the firm believes an emotional bond must be developed between the buyer and the product. The agency uses its research to develop strategies that clarify or solidify the images of its clients' brands, which strengthen that bond.
Companies whose brands d/g* has helped revamp include Brooks Brothers, Reebok, Intimate Brands' Victoria's Secret and Abercrombie & Fitch. Ann Taylor hired the agency to design its flagship store in Manhattan; among d/g*'s innovations were a dressing room fitted with business equipment and a central staircase in the front of the store, designed to create a homelike feeling. In addition, d/g* has done more traditional image consulting for companies like Coca-Cola. During the Atlanta Olympics, it designed a can for Coke that featured the word "always" in five languages.
One of the agency's newest image consulting clients is Ohio State University, for which it is developing a vision for a university of the future. And it is coming up with a new identity for Air France, involving aircraft interiors, uniforms and redesign of the airline's Web site.
Branding is also central to d/g*'s interactive strategy. Mr. Gobe, for one, expects that the Internet-driven economy will ultimately be driven by brands. "Consumers will be empowered to make their own decisions, set their own price, design their own product," he said. "They'll be able to create or break the reputation of a company, through chat rooms, in just five minutes. Word of mouth will become global, not local."
"Before, there was a delay between the introduction of a product and consumers' response to it," Mr. Gobe added. "Now companies will get immediate feedback."
Peter Levine, who heads up the agency's consulting practice, said the four main elements of traditional offline retailing today are entertainment, information, personal service and ease; he suggested all four would ultimately have to be "reconfigured and translated for the Web."
When this occurs, he predicted "bricks-and-mortar retailers will have to raise the bar as well, to make the live shopping experience more special."
The agency's branding theories, particularly as they apply to the Internet, generally won the support of Clive Chajet, a New York-based consultant who was once chairman of Lippincott & Margulies, a leading brand and corporate identity firm.
"There's no question that the future on the Internet belongs to established, recognized brands because the transaction between the seller and buyer will be direct," he said. "There will be no salesperson telling you how wonderful the product is. So all products will have to be presold. Brands will be known and understood for what they offer."
However, Jim Nail, a senior analyst at Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., questioned the d/g* emphasis on emotions in e-commerce. "Today, brands on the Web are all about how quick and easy it is for a consumer to find what he's looking for; d/g* is going about it backward," he said.
"Offline, you can't deliver an experience to someone until they walk through the door of your store," he added. "Emotional branding is used to try to draw people to the store in expectation of delivery of the brand's promise. But online, the delivery of that promise is one click away. So the emphasis has to be on delivering that satisfying experience first. Out of that experience comes the emotional connection to the brand."
Mr. Chajet questioned d/g*'s decision to change its name to initials, eliminating the names of its two founders. "Adopting initials as a corporate name is a passport to anonymity," he said.
Roger van den Bergh, a New York-based designer specializing in corporate and brand identity, also called this move risky because "in their 29 years in business, everyone knows them as Desgrippes Gobe.
"I'm not sure this will help their long-term name recognition," he added.

HEADLINE: Trade Deficit Rises to Record $28 Billion

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Swollen by a huge bill for foreign oil and a voracious spending spree by prosperous American consumers, the nation's trade deficit jumped to a record $28 billion in January, the Commerce Department reported yesterday. Exports sagged, breaking a streak of seven consecutive advances.
The latest deficit, $3.4 billion above the December level and 25 percent larger than the 1999 monthly average, suggested that the booming American economy is still overwhelming the forces that would narrow this imbalance, mainly a rebound in the economic performance of other nations that buy American goods. 
 "The U.S. economy continues to grow more quickly than its trading partners -- and oil prices have gone up a lot," said Catherine L. Mann, a senior fellow at the Institute for International Economics in Washington.
The Federal Reserve yesterday announced its fifth interest-rate increase since June in an effort to prevent overly rapid growth, which ran at a 5.9 percent annual pace in the final three months of the year, from driving up inflation.
William C. Dudley, a senior economist at Goldman, Sachs, said he had been prepared to raise his gross domestic product estimate for this quarter but decided after digesting yesterday's figures to stick with a still rapid rate of 5 percent.
The widening in the January gap between what the United States buys from abroad and what it sells there occurred on both sides of the equation. Imports jumped $1.9 billion, to a record $112.1 billion, while exports fell $1.5 billion after expanding every month since May.
Economists expressed no alarm about the results, which have repeatedly been weak for January in recent years, suggesting more than the usual imprecision in the way the Commerce Department adjusts the data for recurring seasonal swings. But they did express concern about the decline in exports, which if sustained, could cast doubt on the strength of economic recovery from the Asian financial crisis of 1997-1998. Japan, for example, slipped back into a recession in the October-December 1999 quarter and continues to show mixed signals about recovering in the current quarter.
The American deficit with Japan did shrink in January, to $5.6 billion from $7 billion, but the deficit with China climbed to $6 billion from $5.6 billion. Figures on trade with individual countries are not adjusted for seasonal variation.
With China back as the No. 1 source of the American deficit -- perhaps now on a sustained basis -- it may be a bit harder for the Clinton administration to persuade Congress to grant it normal trade relations on a permanent basis as part of a deal under which the United States would support China's admission to the World Trade Organization.
Falling exports and rising imports contributed about equally to the widening gap with China.
The deficit with Asia's newly industrialized economies -- Hong Kong, South Korea, Singapore and Taiwan -- widened to $2.5 billion in January from $1.8 billion in December, while it narrowed with Western Europe to $3.6 billion from $3.9 billion.
The trade gap with Canada, the biggest United States trading partner, jumped to a record $4.3 billion from $3.4 billion, and the deficit with Mexico, the other member of the North American Free Trade Agreement, doubled to $1.8 billion, the report showed.
As for oil, the import bill leaped to a record $7.9 billion, more than double the $3.5 billion of January 1999, when prices had fallen so sharply that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries collaborated with non-OPEC producers to curtail production to raise prices.
Both the volume and price of oil imports rose for the month, with the per-barrel price put at $23.18, the highest since the eve of the Persian Gulf war in December 1990 when it hit $25.75. The December 1999 price was $22.67.
The administration has been lobbying intensely for a production increase by OPEC, which is to meet on Monday.
Besides importing $919 million more oil, the United States raised its purchases of foreign cars by $677 million and its purchases of computers, telecommunications gear and other capital goods by $207 million.
The Commerce Department, on revision, narrowed the overall American trade deficit for December by $900 million, to $24.6 billion from the $25.5 billion originally reported.

HEADLINE: US Airways Vows to Shut Down if AttendantsDisrupt Flights

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
The 10,000 unionized flight attendants at US Airways are threatening an unusual walkout this Saturday, saying they will disrupt flights on 49 of the airline's busiest routes.
The flight attendants want to maximize pressure on the company with a strategy that they have called Chaos -- Create Havoc Around Our System. 
 In response, US Airways, the nation's sixth-largest airline, plans to take an unusual step of its own, saying that unless a contract is reached by Saturday, it will suspend all operations, rather than let the flight attendants whipsaw the company and its customers.
In a statement, the airline said, "Chaos by any name is Chaos, and US Airways will not operate under the threat of constant disruption."
Any decision by US Airways to halt operations, industry experts said, would be the first time that any airline closed itself down in the face of a job action.
Suspending operations would inconvenience the 150,000 passengers US Airways flies each day and would create the greatest disruption in the eastern third of the nation, where the airline controls 36 percent of the regional market. Such a shutdown would affect flights ranging from US Airway's New York-Boston-Washington shuttle as well as the company's routes to Europe.
In another unusual twist, the company has promised to continue paying its 30,000 workers who are not flight attendants for as long as is feasible during a shutdown.
The union is barred from taking any job action until a mandatory 30-day cooling-off period ends at 12:01 a.m. Saturday.
The strike threat is already hurting the airline, with travel agents reporting that they are steering consumers to other airlines and that many US Airways passengers have switched their reservations.
"There are people who are completely canceling their trips," said Helene Singer, owner of Singer Travel in Reading, Pa. "We're advising people that US Air will not be flying, and people are rebooking on other airlines."
After seeking a refund on her US Airways flight scheduled for Friday night, Rita Gance, a nurse from Reading, Pa., reluctantly canceled a trip to visit her mother in West Palm Beach, Fla.
"I'm really disappointed," she said. "I looked at tickets at other airlines, but the prices were ridiculous."
Stephen M. Wolf, the company's chairman, and Rakesh Gangwal, its chief executive, have joined top union officials in Washington this week for intense negotiations, helped by the National Mediation Board.
Neither side was willing to predict the likelihood of a strike. But union officials said flight attendants, borrowing a page from the partial subway and air strikes often carried out by European transportation unions, were ready to disrupt the 49 routes by picketing or not showing up.
The union has listed the routes it says it will disrupt, saying it would not make every flight on those routes a target but would instead keep the company guessing about which flights would be affected. Among the routes listed are are New York/La Guardia-Orlando, New York/La Guardia-Tampa, Boston-Orlando, Pittsburgh-Chicago/O'Hare and Philadelphia-San Francisco.
Lawrence Nagin, the airline's executive vice president and general counsel, said the company felt compelled to shut its operations because it was worried that the union action would strand or delay thousands of passengers and that customers would lose hard-earned confidence in the airline. "We are not going to subject our customers to the uncertainty of chaos," he said.
Mr. Nagin said the 49 designated routes accounted for 21 percent of the airline's 2,000 daily flights, but would affect passengers on many other flights because of the airline's hub-and-spoke system. The union has indicated that it will expand its action beyond the 49 routes if the dispute drags on.
The company blames the Association of Flight Attendants for rejecting a contract formula similar to those accepted by the airline's pilots, mechanics and other main unions.
In an effort to reduce what industry analysts say are the highest costs per seat mile among major airlines, US Airways is demanding that the flight attendants accept a formula that would link the attendants' pay to the average of their counterparts at the nation's four largest airlines plus 1 percent.
But the flight attendants, whose contract expired in 1996, assert that the airline's version of a parity formula would cut their pay and fringe benefits by 5 percent. Union officials say the other unions had a chance to help define their parity formula, while the flight attendants have not been given that opportunity.
"People are pretty angry at the company," said Cynthia Kain, a union spokeswoman. "They feel these are good economic times and they're being left behind."
The flight attendants have not had a raise since 1996 and their annual pay ranges from $17,145 to $36,918.
The flight attendants are in a tight spot because many workers in US Airway's other unions are questioning why the attendants would refuse to accept the formula they accepted.
"All the employee groups represented by the other unions at the company have entered into an agreement based on this concept, and we think it's a fair solution and an important factor in enabling US Airways to be competitive in a very competitive industry," Mr. Nagin said.
The flight attendants' strategy has been carried out once before, when sporadic job actions forced the cancellation of a half dozen Alaska Airline flights in 1993.
In February 1999, a sickout by pilots created havoc for American Airlines. At the peak of the 10-day sickout, a fourth of the airline's 9,200 pilots called in sick, forcing the company to cancel more than half of its 2,250 daily flights.

HEADLINE: Ivan Hirst, British Officer Who Revived VW, Is Dead at 84

BYLINE: By PHIL PATTON 

 BODY:
Maj. Ivan Hirst, the British Army officer responsible for getting the Volkswagen factory running again after World War II in what is now Wolfsburg, Germany, died March 10 at his home near Marsden, in Yorkshire, England. He was 84.
Without his efforts, Volkswagen probably could never have shifted from its failed dream of producing a people's car for the Third Reich into the economic powerhouse that built the Beetle, the symbol of German recovery. 
 "Anyone who drives a VW owes a lot to Major Hirst," said Ryan Lee Price, editor of VW Trends magazine, a publication for Beetle owners.
Ivan Hirst was born March 4, 1916, in Saddleworth, England. He studied at the University of Manchester and worked for a time in his family's optical instrument business.
He turned a youthful interest in motor vehicles into an assignment in the tank repair service for the British Army during the war.
Part of the Duke of Wellington's Regiment, he was evacuated at Dunkirk after the fall of France in 1940.
Later transferred to the Royal Electrical and Mechanical Engineers, he returned to Europe as head of a tank repair group in Brussels.
It was from there that he was ordered in August 1945 to the former "Strength Through Joy" City, a sprawling forced-labor factory between Berlin and Hanover. The city was soon renamed Wolfsburg.
Captured by the Americans, the mile-long, bombed-out plant Hitler had built was then turned over to the British.
The plant's last wartime products were parts for V-1 rocket bombs and stoves for soldiers on the Eastern front. The work was done by about 15,000 slave laborers, prisoners of war and others.
Sent to the plant without orders, Major Hirst found the workers still there and on his own initiative decided to use them. In his repair and motor pool service, he found fearful ex-Nazi administrators, refugees from the Soviet sector 15 miles to the east and former slave laborers mingled suspiciously in an economy where the prime currency was American cigarettes.
The slave laborers were soon sent home.
Major Hirst recalled in a 1962 magazine article that he and his commanding officer, Col. Michael McEvoy, who had driven an early version of the Volkswagen in 1938, spray-painted army green one of the few Beetles around and drove it to their local headquarters.
In September 1945 the two officers persuaded the British military to place an order for 20,000 vehicles to serve local troops and officials.
Without that order the machinery in the plant would probably have been disbursed among the occupying powers and the factory shut forever.
Major Hirst scrounged steel and other rare materials to keep the plant going.
By 1946, 8,000 workers were producing 1,000 vehicles a month.
In January 1949, Major Hirst helped recruit Heinrich Nordoff to take over management of the company, and he led VW until 1968.
Major Hirst left in August 1949 when the company was set up as a trust run by the new West German government.
Mr. Nordhoff later said that "by one of the ironic jokes history is sometimes tempted to produce, it was the occupation powers who brought Hitler's dream into reality."
In another twist of fate, after 1945 the British motor industry proceeded to decline while the German automobile industry that Major Hirst helped revive flourished, leading the so-called German economic miracle of the 1950's.
Sir William Rootes, a longtime leader of the British auto industry, told Major Hirst his factory would collapse within two years. A formal engineering evaluation of the Volkswagen undertaken by the British military also found little potential, declaring "the vehicle does not meet the fundamental technical requirements of a motorcar."
"It is quite unattractive to the average motorcar buyer, is too ugly and too noisy," he continued, then added famously, "If you think you're going to build cars in this place, you're a bloody fool, young man."
"It was by no means a perfect car," acknowledged Major Hirst in a 1999 BBC interview, "But in its time it was a damn good little car."
In 1972, the original Beetle surpassed the Model T as the most- produced car ever; to date, about 22 million have been made and limited production continues in Puebla, Mexico.
William Bowman of St. Louis, a collector of old Volkswagens, was one of a group of Beetle fans who visited Major Hirst last summer.
"He was sharp as a tack and had wonderful stories," Mr. Bowman recalled of an evening spent with the major in a pub in Marsden.
"He couldn't understand why we thought what he had done was such a big deal," Mr. Bowman said.
A familiar figure at the pub, with his clipped white mustache, ascot and pipe, Major Hirst reminisced until nearly midnight.
After leaving the army, Major Hirst worked for the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development in Paris. He retired in 1975 and his wife, Marjorie, died some years ago. He had no children.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
The FedHas No Surprises and the Market Has a Reason to Rally

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
The no-surprises Federal Reserve Board gave investors just what they were expecting yesterday: a quarter-point increase in short-term interest rates. The full-of-surprises stock market delivered a smashing gain on the news, with two of the broadest indexes closing at new highs.
Before the midafternoon announcement that the Fed had pushed the Federal Funds rate to 6 percent, stocks had been adrift. After the news, they took off, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rising 2.56 percent to end the day at a record of 1,493.87. The Wilshire 5000 index, which represents the entire stock market and is an index that the Fed chairman Alan Greenspan reportedly watches, closed at a high of 14,346.22, up 2.1 percent on the day. The Nasdaq rose 2.21 percent. 
 Strategists said the market's reaction reflected two things. First, investors were relieved that the Fed had not chosen to be more aggressive and raise rates by one-half point. In addition, investors seemed to greet the quarter-point rise as medicine the Fed must administer to keep the long economic expansion healthy.
"The conventional wisdom is rate hikes are bad for the stock market," said Jay Mueller, economics strategist at Strong Capital Management in Milwaukee. "But I think the market recognizes that good monetary policy means you sometimes have to raise rates. The Fed had to do this."
Nevetheless, given that the Fed is almost as concerned about excessive speculation in the stock market today as it is about a resurgence in inflation, the blistering moves in stocks probably disappointed Mr. Greenspan. The gains also indicate, to some, that the central bank is a spectator rather than an actor in the drama playing out in the financial market.
"The Fed's just not in control," said Stephen S. Roach, chief economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "The economy is surging at a rate that is clearly excessive and while there's been some rather frenetic rotation in the stock market, wealth creation is still open-ended. The Fed in my view is staying incremental with a very blunt instrument, the Fed funds rate, that is inappropriate for dealing with the problems that it's facing."
Other tools available to the Fed that might cool things down include raising the initial amount of money that investors must put up to buy stocks on borrowed money -- known as the margin requirement -- or increasing the amount of reserves that banks must have on hand as a percent of their deposits. A higher reserve requirement means less money will be available for loans, which would slow economic growth.
Even as stock investors celebrated the Fed's vigilance against inflation, their enthusiasm made it more likely that the central bank will push through additional rate increases this year. Rising stock prices, said William Dudley, chief economist at Goldman Sachs, make it harder for monetary policy to bring the economy back down to earth. "The financial markets are not doing a lot of tightening for the Fed," Mr. Dudley said. "The logical conclusion is that the Fed will have to do more than people anticipate." Currently, the Wall Street consensus is that the Fed will raise rates another half point and be done with it, a view Mr. Dudley considers too optimistic.
For now, most investors applaud Mr. Greenspan's incremental moves even in the face of a rapidly growing economy. "The only explanation of why the Fed is moving so gingerly with these quarter-point moves is that either they see the signs of a slowdown already evident in the shape of the yield curve, the price of oil, the leveling of single-family housing starts, or they believe that the lag is long between the beginning of a monetary tightening and its showing up in the real economy," said Stefan D. Abrams, chief investment officer for asset allocation at Trust Company of the West. "Greenspan thinks he's on a glide path here to a soft landing and he doesn't need to take more aggressive steps."
Among the biggest beneficiaries of yesterday's move were some of the old investor favorites: General Electric rose $10.1875, to $151.125, and Microsoft advanced $5.375, to $102.75. Even bank stocks rallied, which is not normally the case when rates rise because such increases are a drag on profits. The Philadelphia Bank stock index rose 4.4 percent yesterday.
Even the bond market reacted favorably to the rate increase. Prices rose across the board, pushing down yields on the 30-year bond to 5.97 percent from 6 percent Monday.
Biotech stocks continued to decline with the American Stock Exchange biotech index falling 2.3 percent. It is down more than 35 percent from the peak set two weeks ago.
Yesterday's move in stocks did not surprise Mr. Dudley, who noted that historically, Fed tightening episodes have not been all bad for equities. "On average, since the 1960's, the stock market has gone up when the Fed tightens because the Fed usually tightens when the economy is strong," he said. "What ends up stopping bull markets is inflation because that causes the Fed to shift to a truly hostile stance. Stock markets fear inflation, not Fed tightening per se."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Fed Raises Interest Rates In Effort to Slow Economy
The Federal Reserve clamped down a bit more on the economy, raising interest rates by a quarter-point in an effort to prevent an outbreak of inflation. It was the Fed's fifth quarter-point rate increase since June.
The move was no surprise to economists and investors, who had heard repeated hints over the last month from Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, that he intended to stick to his policy of raising rates in small, steady steps until the economy slows. Page A1. 

The stock market shrugged off the news and moved higher. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 227.10 points, to 10,907.34. The Nasdaq composite index rose 101.68 points, to 4,711.68. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index climbed 37.24 points, to 1,493.87. C16.
 
Profit Rises 67% at Goldman Sachs
Goldman Sachs Group reported that a surge in revenue from trading stocks, bonds, oil and other commodities pushed its fiscal first-quarter net income up 67 percent, easily surpassing analysts' expectations. The earnings were $887 million, compared with $532 million in the period a year earlier, when the firm was still a private partnership. Investors bid up the shares to $118.25, a gain of $4.8125. The decision hands the question of national tobacco regulation back to Congress. A1.

HEADLINE: MORE INOCULATION AGAINST INFLATION

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve clamped down a bit more on the economy today, raising interest rates a quarter percentage point in an effort to prevent an outbreak of inflation.
The move was no surprise to economists and investors, who had heard repeated hints the last month from Alan Greenspan, the central bank's chairman, that he intended to stick to his policy of raising rates in small, steady steps until he saw signs that the supercharged economy was throttling back. 
 The stock market, which some analysts consider Mr. Greenspan's main target in raising rates, shrugged off the news and moved higher after the Fed's announcement this afternoon. Apparently relieved that the central bank did not raise rates a half-point, the Dow Jones industrial average gained 227.10 points, to 10,907.34. The Nasdaq composite index closed at 4,711.68, up 101.68 points.
It was the Fed's fifth quarter-point rate increase since June, and it lifted the benchmark federal funds target rate on overnight loans between banks to 6 percent, its highest level in almost five years.
The central bank also raised its discount rate on loans to banks from the Federal Reserve system a quarter of a percentage point, to 5.5 percent.
The moves put immediate upward pressure on rates paid by consumers and businesses. Banks began raising their prime lending rates a quarter-point, to 9 percent, which will lead to slightly higher rates on many home equity and small-business loans as well as credit cards.
The Fed's decision had a less direct effect on mortgage rates and corporate borrowing costs, which are largely set in the bond markets. Those rates have moved up the last year as the Fed has tightened monetary policy and are likely to continue doing so as long as Mr. Greenspan remains on inflation alert. Yields on the 30-year government bond continued to fall, creating an unusual situation in which the Fed's short-term rates were higher than the market's longest-term rates.
In a statement, the Fed's policy-setting Federal Open Market Committee said it had raised rates again for the same reason it had done so at its last meeting in February. It said, in effect, that growth was running stronger than the economy could sustain over the long run without creating inflationary bottlenecks.
"The committee remains concerned that increases in demand will continue to exceed the growth in potential supply, which could foster inflationary imbalances that would undermine the economy's record economic expansion," the statement said.
The committee suggested that further rate increases were likely if the economy did not slow substantially by May 16 -- the next time it meets. The committee, the statement said, "believes the risks are weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future."
There is little evidence so far of any broad-based surge in inflation outside of the sharp rise in oil prices.
But the economy has been growing at rates well beyond what most economists think can be sustained over the long run without generating inflation. The economy grew 6.9 percent in the last quarter of 1999, and analysts think growth in the first three months of this year could be about 5 percent. Consumer spending in particular remains robust.
Mr. Greenspan has traced the danger facing the economy to the stock market. His argument -- which is being questioned on Wall Street and in Washington -- is that the recent upturn in the growth rate of productivity, or output for each hour worked, is leading investors to expect higher corporate profits and therefore to bid up stock prices.
Higher stock prices, in turn, are leaving investors feeling wealthy and willing to spend, driving up demand for goods and services. In Mr. Greenspan's view, demand is growing faster than the economy can produce supply. The imbalance between demand and supply has been contained so far through two safety valves: declining unemployment, which is providing the workers needed to produce more goods and services, and imports, which are filling the gap between demand and what domestic companies can produce.
Mr. Greenspan's point is that the safety valves cannot be counted on much longer to absorb the strains being generated by strong demand and that interest rates must rise until demand falls to a level that the economy can meet.
Mr. Greenspan has warned repeatedly that at its current pace, the economy will soon run short of workers, putting upward pressure on wages and ultimately prices. The unemployment rate in February was 4.1 percent, just a touch above its 30-year low.
The Fed chairman has also warned that the nation is approaching the limit of how much it can afford to import. His point was underscored today by the release of monthly trade figures for January, showing a deficit of $28 billion, another record and well above what economists had projected.
Mr. Greenspan has insisted that the goal of monetary policy is not to drive stock prices down. But he has made clear that in his view the pace of wealth generation stemming from the long run-up in stock prices will have to be tempered if demand is to be restrained -- a distinction that is lost on many analysts.
"The whole issue of whether he is targeting the stock market is a hot question," said Bill Cheney, an economist at John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance in Boston. "It seems to me perfectly clear that he is targeting it, and he merely has to deny pro forma that he is doing so."
Mr. Cheney said he thought Mr. Greenspan was basically right that the wealth being generated by the stock market was the source of much of the excess demand in the economy.
Other economists think that Mr. Greenspan has it all wrong, or that he is focusing attention on the stock market to avoid being criticized in an election year for slowing the economy when there is no concrete evidence of inflation.
"If the Fed were to literally threaten to raise the unemployment rate and slow growth, it wouldn't be a great political posture to take," said Brian S. Wesbury, an economist at Griffin, Kubik, Stephens & Thompson, an investment firm in Chicago.
There is also sharp disagreement among economists about how much momentum the economy has and how much more rates will have to rise to erase any threat of inflation.
"We're going to see some slower growth numbers pretty quickly, good numbers on inflation, and within three to six months, you'll start hearing talk about actual Fed easing," Mr. Wesbury said.
But other analysts said the slowdown could still be a long way off and that the Fed might have to raise rates sharply this spring and summer to bring the economy under control.
"Thus far, the core cost and price data have been so benign that the Fed has been able to conduct a gradualist policy, hoping to change behavior through a slow cash flow squeeze on companies and individuals," said Ian Shepherdson, an economist at High Frequency Economics, a consulting firm in Valhalla, N.Y. "But if inflation is beginning to accelerate, however slowly, Mr. Greenspan will at least have to consider taking more drastic action."

HEADLINE: PRO FOOTBALL;
Jets Say Johnson Is No Longer on Trading Block

BYLINE: By JUDY BATTISTA 

 BODY:
With an exchange of bluntly worded statements that offered a glimpse into an increasingly fractious relationship, the stalemate between the Jets and receiver Keyshawn Johnson solidified yesterday.
Coach Al Groh said the Jets would no longer listen to trade offers involving Johnson, at least for now. But Groh also said that the team would not renegotiate the disgruntled star's contract anytime in the immediate future. 
 Four hours later, Johnson's agent, Jerome Stanley, responded with a statement of his own, implicitly criticizing the Jets for using the news media to communicate their stand during the contract impasse. Stanley also said that the Jets should not blame their difficult salary-cap situation for their reluctance to give a more lucrative contract to Johnson, who has two years remaining on his current deal.
"Keyshawn Johnson has consistently avoided using the media as a tool to communicate on any contractual matter," Stanley said in a statement. "Despite the coach's comments regarding Keyshawn's contract, the kind of contract comment no Jet coach has ever made, Keyshawn will maintain his policy. He feels that the fans don't want to, or need to, hear about his contract.
"As for the Jets' economic duress caused by the salary cap, that duress will still be there in 2001 and beyond. Keyshawn would like to continue to help lead the Jets to his goal of winning a Super Bowl for the much-deserving Jets fans."
The Jets had no response to Stanley's remarks. If taken at face value, Groh's statement means that Johnson is off the trading block. But in confirming what National Football League officials have been saying for two weeks -- that the Jets have neither the room under the $62 million salary cap nor the desire to renegotiate Johnson's deal -- the Jets have also put the onus on Johnson to decide whether to end the impasse and report to the team's off-season workouts, which began Monday without him. It is highly unlikely that Johnson will report and has told one teammate that he would not.
Johnson, who has two years remaining on his six-year contract, makes about $2 million a year -- well below the going rate for a receiver of his caliber. He is believed to be seeking as much as $10 million a year, with a possible $15 million signing bonus thrown in.
Stanley has privately told the team that Johnson could hold out from summer training camp if he does not get a new deal.
The Jets traditionally have not renegotiated contracts that have more than one year remaining. The team reiterated that position yesterday, stressing that a reworking was not feasible without making wholesale changes to the roster.
"The Jets have reworked numerous contracts this winter to get under the salary cap and yet continue to be under extreme economic duress with regard to the salary cap and its affect on the overall roster," Groh said in his statement. "After due consideration and in light of the fact that Keyshawn has two years remaining on his contract, our organization remains unable to address the contract of Keyshawn in the near or foreseeable short-term future."
Groh also addressed for the first time the trade rumors that have run rampant since early in the month. The Jets, fearing a protracted and divisive holdout, had spoken to at least six teams about a deal involving Johnson, but the coach said yesterday that the team "will not entertain any trade offers at this time."
Groh's statement could represent an effort by the Jets to build leverage if they ultimately decide to listen to offers for Johnson at the coming owners' meetings, which begin Sunday.
The Jets, in insisting publicly that they are not interested in unloading Johnson, could be hoping to avoid a fire sale in which they would receive less than equal value for Johnson, a two-time Pro Bowl selection. Several teams have expressed interest in Johnson -- most notably the Baltimore Ravens, who hold the fifth pick in April's draft -- For a team that lost a high-profile coach during the off-season, the organization likely reconsidered what would have been a very unpopular trade.
In the statement, the Jets said they would address Johnson's contract situation "at the appropriate time," presumably when there is just one year left on his contract. But the Jets, in careful language, also seem to say that they were prepared to move on, with or without Johnson.
"Keyshawn Johnson's nonparticipation in the off-season program in no way affects our decision-making process involving fielding the most competitive team for the immediate and long-term future," Groh said.

HEADLINE: Suspect's Death Ends Siege; Hostages Are Safe

BYLINE: By FRANCIS X. CLINES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 21

 BODY:
Three hostages were rushed to freedom tonight in a Baltimore suburb as the police broke in on a fugitive murder suspect and shot him to death, ending a harrowing four-day siege that terrorized the Dundalk neighborhood.
The fugitive, Joseph C. Palczynski, a former convict with a history of mental illness, was shot by the police who broke into the apartment after seeing two of the hostages run for freedom after the suspect fell asleep. 
 Mr. Palczynski had been the subject of a furious manhunt since March 7 when, the authorities say, he shot to death three people after he angrily confronted his former girlfriend, Tracy Whitehead, for bringing domestic abuse charges against him.
Two of the hostages, Lynn Whitehead and her boyfriend, Andy McCord, climbed from a window in the darkness before 11 p.m. as the fugitive slept on a couch. Their 12-year-old son, Bradley, was left behind, asleep in the kitchen as Mrs. Whitehead, who is Tracy Whitehead's mother, rushed to find police assistance.
Within minutes, the police in paramilitary gear rushed the house on Lange Street and gunfire erupted. They rescued the boy and shortly thereafter announced an end to the siege.
"Joseph Palczynski is dead," declared a police spokesman, Bill Toohey, at the end of the siege, which had exhausted the working-class neighborhood as residents in a four-block-square area were trapped in their houses.
The 31-year-old suspect, accused of killing four people in the past two weeks, had been lost by police officers in woodlands until he invaded the suburban home last Friday in a burst of gunfire.
Mr. Palczynski, an unemployed electrician with a history of domestic violence and prison and hospital incarceration, had been obsessively following the standoff on television, according to the Baltimore County police. At the request of the police, news broadcasters had gingerly tried to avoid inciting him.
Soon after his death was announced, a television station released what it said were tape recordings of telephone calls that Mr. Palczynski had made during the siege in which he complained that the police negotiators had prevented him from talking to Tracy Whitehead. In a desperate tone, the voice described as Mr. Palczynski's says: "All I want to do is talk to Tracy. I love her dearly. I did not mean to kill those people."
The fugitive fatally shot two of Mrs. Whitehead's friends and a neighbor who came to their aid on March 7, according to the police, and then killed a woman during a car-jacking in his flight from the police.
Mr. Palczynski's friends and family said he suffered from bipolar disorder, a manic-depressive behavior that they say resulted from a severe blow to the head in a school bus accident when he was a teenager.
Since then he had served three years in mental institutions and two years in prison, plus several years' probation for incidents usually involving the beatings of girlfriends.
The siege ended after four anxious days in which the suspect repeatedly shot at armored police cars and into the air around the apartment amid sporadic negotiations with the police. He had been armed with at least three weapons, and as the siege continued neighborhood life was reduced to the breaking point.
Cheers could be heard from one corner of the neighborhood when the slaying of Mr. Palczynski was announced.
The Whitehead family was jubilant in the midnight rain as they rushed to the police headquarters to greet the hostages. At least four dozen police officers had been stationed around the apartment, with sniper scopes and listening devices trained on the scene.
Officials, pleased that the three hostages were not harmed, said the one casualty beyond Mr. Palczynski was a neighborhood dog that threatened the police and had to be shot.
"Bradley's looking forward to playing baseball," Mr. McCord told a relative as they celebrated the end of the siege.

HEADLINE: U.S. and India, Trying to Reconcile, Hit Bump

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Wednesday, March 22

 BODY:
The United States and India opened what they called an era "of new beginnings" on Tuesday in an effort to rebuild a relationship that President Clinton said had been neglected for more than two decades. But a series of encounters, including a sharp rebuke of the president in the evening, showed that the opening chapter was spiked with surprises.
Against a backdrop of a massacre of 35 Sikhs in the Indian-held part of Kashmir just before Mr. Clinton's arrival on an official visit, the Indian prime minister, Atal Behari Vajpayee, and the president signed what they called a "vision statement." It defined their common interests while pointing out that they disagreed on India's possession of nuclear weapons. 
 In an address to the Indian Parliament today, President Clinton appealed to the government to give up its nuclear arsenal, saying that most of the world was moving toward the elimination of nuclear weapons.
Speaking forthrightly but with what he called "respect for the great nation of India," Mr. Clinton said, "Only India can determine whether it is safer today than before the tests." India tested nuclear weapons in May 1998, followed by similar tests conducted in response by Pakistan.
"Only India can know whether it can afford" such weapons, he told the Parliament. "These are questions that others may ask but only you can answer."
Then in a sterner tone, Mr. Clinton added: "In a nuclear standoff, nothing is so dangerous as thinking there is no danger."
During the cold war, he said, the former Soviet Union and the United States had come "all too close to nuclear war" despite a good understanding of each other's intentions.
Mr. Clinton then urged India to take the lead in starting a dialogue with Pakistan over the disputed territory of Kashmir.
"I believe India has a special obligation to show its neighbors that democracy is about dialogue," he added. "Engagement with your adversaries is not the same as endorsement."
Mr. Clinton's address was received with some scattered applause but the impassioned plea about nuclear weapons was received with attentive silence.
After talks with Mr. Vajpayee on Tuesday, President Clinton said relations between the United States and India were "too important to ever fall into disrepair again." Thus, the two countries said, the joint statement was a device to lay the foundation of a relationship without letting precise issues slow the process.
But by Tuesday evening, the tensions inherent in forging an Indian-American friendship surfaced when India's president, Kircheril Raman Narayanan, rebuked Mr. Clinton in a toast at a state dinner.
Standing before Mr. Clinton at a long banquet table, Mr. Narayanan scolded him for his description of the Indian subcontinent "as the most dangerous place in the world today."
The president has publicly used that term twice in the last two months to describe a situation where India and neighboring Pakistan have nuclear weapons and are also at the edge of a conflict in Kashmir.
But Mr. Narayanan, in a rare display of blunt talk at a black-tie diplomatic affair, said that the description was "alarmist."
"It has been suggested that the Indian subcontinent is the most dangerous place in the world today and Kashmir is a nuclear flash point," he said. "These alarmist descriptions will only encourage those who want to break the peace and indulge in terrorism and violence."
Mr. Clinton did not reply to the chiding, sticking in his toast to his theme of friendship.
The president's day began here on Tuesday with a formal review of Indian armed forces assembled in the courtyard of the colonial-era presidential palace, Rashtrapati Bhavan, and then moved on to a wreath-laying ceremony at the memorial to Mohandas Gandhi.
Mr. Clinton then drove through roads swept clear of people to Hyderbad House, a former princely residence, for his meeting with Mr. Vajpayee, whose policies on nuclear weapons, more assertive than those of Pakistan, have won growing respect among educated Indians. Mr. Vajpayee, the 72-year-old white-haired leader of the Hindu nationalist Bharatiya Janata Party, and Mr. Clinton had not met before.
Because the Indian leader is not considered an easy conversationalist, there was some uncertainty among administration officials about how the talks would proceed. Afterward, an administration official said that the "tone was good but it would be misleading to say that there was a brisk and free flow of ideas."
The measured atmospherics in the encounter with the prime minister combined with the sharp comments by the Indian president seemed to underline the difficulty of Mr. Clinton's undertaking to improve relations with India without having the United States appear to be a lecturing superpower.
From the time India first tested nuclear weapons, Washington has tried to convince the government here that maintaining a nuclear deterrent is not helpful to peace in the region. But India, striving to be more than just a regional power, sees its nuclear weapons as the right of an emerging major power that is a neighbor not only to Pakistan but also to China.
At the ceremonial signing of the "vision statement," Mr. Vaypayee warned that India had limited tolerance for the violence in Kashmir, which it accuses Pakistan of masterminding. "We have the means and the will to eliminate this menace," the prime minister said.
The Tuesday statement itself included a summary of the differences on nuclear weapons, saying: "The United States believes India should forgo nuclear weapons. India believes that it needs to maintain a credible minimum nuclear deterrent in keeping with its own assessment of its security needs."
"Nonetheless," it said, "India and the U.S. are prepared to work together to prevent the proliferation of nuclear weapons and their means of delivery. To this end, we will persist with and build upon the productive bilateral dialogue already under way."
In elaborating on the statement, the Indian prime minister said he had repeated in the private meeting with Mr. Clinton India's commitment not to conduct further nuclear explosive tests and not to be the first to use nuclear weapons.
In replying, Mr. Clinton recognized that India was not close to signing the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty, a position that Washington has been urging on the government without success since the 1998 test. The president said he hoped that the "democratic process" in India would lead to the eventual signing and ratification of the treaty by India, just like, he added, "I hope the democratic process will ultimately produce a ratification of the test ban treaty in America."
The joint statement touched on two other nuclear issues with which the administration has had only limited success with the government here. In a round of talks with the Indian foreign minister, Jaswant Singh, Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott has failed to persuade the Indians to join international talks aimed at ending the production of fissile materials for nuclear weapons.
The statement said only that the two countries would "work together" for an early start of the talks. On the question of export controls for nuclear-related materials, the statement said that both the United States and India would "continue to strengthen" such controls.
The killings in Kashmir on Monday night, which American officials said appeared intended by Pakistani-backed insurgents to draw Washington into a mediation of the dispute between India and Pakistan, presented Mr. Clinton with an opportunity to emphasize his prepared message of restraint.
The president made clear before coming here that he was not planning to mediate the Kashmir dispute -- a role that the Indians reject but the Pakistanis want.
But Indian officials interpreted a statement by Mr. Clinton as an embrace of their position that Pakistan must stop infiltrating Kashmir with militant fighters before talks can start. Mr. Clinton sounded as though he was saying just this when, in his joint appearance with Mr. Vajpayee, he said that talks between India and Pakistan could not be expected "unless there is an absence of violence."
White House officials quickly tried to clarify Mr. Clinton's intent, saying that because the United States was not a party to any talks between India and Pakistan it could not set any preconditions.
But a senior administration official said the Indians should take heart from "the message of support" that Mr. Clinton delivered against the violence in Kashmir.
The president summarized his position on Kashmir in four points. Both sides, he said, should exercise restraint, show respect for the Line of Control, which is the de facto border dividing Pakistani-held and Indian-held Kashmir, renew their dialogue and "stand against violence."
In a limited economic gesture to mark Mr. Clinton's visit, the White House said a $25 million program to help reorganize India's financial markets, suspended with other nonhumanitarian aid after the 1998 nuclear tests, would be resumed.

HEADLINE: Mind-Set: Only the Svelte Need Apply

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA

 BODY:
Lynnda Collins has a hunch that she lost her job of 12 years because of her age, 51, and weight, 325 pounds, even though her former employer, the Geac Computer Corporation of Canada, told her that she was just one of many employees in its Atlanta division laid off last summer.
Hundreds of thousands of Americans lose their jobs every year, but with unemployment at its lowest level since 1970, most bounce back quickly. For obese people like Ms. Collins, though, finding a new job is not so easy, no matter what their qualifications. They live in fear of rejection for their physical appearance, and they are generally less experienced in job hunting than their slimmer colleagues because they are less likely to test the market while they are employed. 
 Over the last 26 years, Ms. Collins, who is 5-foot-6, has held four jobs. "Once I get a job, I keep it," she said.
Since she lost her position as regional contract manager for Geac, Ms. Collins says she has had only a handful of interviews and no offers. Local recruiters who spot her resume online are enthusiastic about her prospects until they meet her, she says. "You can just see this wall come down," she said. "Their eyes get cold. They get formal and polite, ask general questions, then I'm out the door."
Recruiters say publicly that their companies have policies against discrimination of any kind, but they acknowledge privately that an applicant's weight does matter. "Appearance is always a consideration, particularly at higher levels," a manager of a national recruiting firm said. "Executives are always in front of big groups."
It is not as though the people doing the hiring are all that trim. One in five adults is obese, according to a telephone survey by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, up from just one in 10 a decade ago. Other federal surveys put the figure at one in three. According to a study by Dr. James Rippe of Tufts University, an even higher portion of senior executives at Fortune 500 companies -- 36.5 percent -- are obese.
But management's attitude is sometimes based on the considerable health risks associated with obesity. Obesity is second to cigarette smoking as the leading preventable cause of death, and it contributes to an estimated 280,000 deaths a year, according to government statistics. Every week, millions of workdays are lost to illnesses that result from obesity; the cost to employers in lost productivity and absenteeism is more than $47 billion a year, one study says.
Costs are only part of the reason that employers discriminate against overweight job applicants, says Mark V. Roehling, an associate professor of management at the Haworth College of Business at Western Michigan University in Kalamazoo. "People are reacting negatively on many other levels," he said. "One is just the gut reaction."
Employers are more likely to discriminate against people because of their weight than because of their sex or their race, Mr. Roehling says, and they do so at every step, from hiring to setting compensation to firing. Moreover, he says, although state and federal laws forbid discrimination against women, ethnic minority groups, old people and the handicapped, they provide little protection against weight discrimination. Michigan is the lone state where weight is a protected characteristic under a fair-employment law.
Overweight workers are "the folks left behind" in the longest economic expansion in United States history, said Walt Winstrom, a lawyer who runs the Obesity Law and Advocacy Center in San Diego. Mr. Winstrom, who is 5-foot-10 and weighs 350 pounds, added, "We're dealing with an entire mind-set of which seeking employment is only part of how we deal with issues of discrimination every day."
Perhaps the most dreaded ordeal for an overweight applicant is the personal interview. A Midwestern marketing executive named David K., who stands one inch shy of 6 feet and weighs 350 pounds, recalled the humiliation he endured a few years ago as his chat with a potential employer in New York was wrapping up.
"The only chair that was available for me to sit in was an old chair with arms that would have been fine for someone with a waist size of up to maybe 44," said David, who asked that his last name not be used. "But mine was about 52. I felt wedged in. It made me very self-conscious. As the interview finished, I stood up and took the chair with me. I just wanted to get the hell out at that point."
In mid-February, Ms. Collins was asked in for an afternoon interview with Georgia-Pacific for a position similar to the one she had at Geac. On the big day, she slept in to make sure she would be alert. She ate a light brunch of cereal and toast, wary of the butterflies sure to come, and spent a leisurely morning at home with her 8-year-old dog, Sami, a corgi mix.
It was time to get ready.
"The whole time, I'm trying to think about other things so I won't get the jitters," Ms. Collins said later. She showered, applied a touch of makeup, put in contact lenses and ran a comb through her short, sandy-brown hair with hints of gray. As she slipped on her only suit, a gray wool with black shell from Lane Bryant, she let her mind wander. She thought about Sami, about the winter cold she was fighting off, about choir practice at church the next evening -- anything but the interview.
"If I allowed myself to think about the interview, I've talked myself into believing it would be a waste of time before I even get into the car," Ms. Collins said. "By the time I get there I'd be totally dejected."
At Georgia-Pacific, she was pleased to see that the woman who was to interview her was overweight. "I remember thinking, 'Maybe this is a place I might be judged on by my ability, not on my appearance,' " she said. The interview went well, but weeks went by and then the company told her it had hired someone else.
But all was not lost. Her part-time employer, a lawyer, recommended Ms. Collins to a colleague who was looking for a full-time paralegal. The position pays about half of her previous salary at Geac. Still, it beats the $300 a week she has been making. "I try to be hopeful," Ms. Collins said. "I go through spells when I'm hopeless and I cry a lot."
Meantime, her debt is mounting. As a single woman and the only child of deceased parents, she has no one who can come to her aid. Sometimes, she says, she can't bring herself to face the bills.
"I feel myself heading down a path that my credit rating is getting ruined," she said, her eyes welling up with tears.
"I'm scraping by. I can probably keep going for a while, but I fear that I'll lose everything."

CORRECTION-DATE: March 30, 2000, Thursday

 CORRECTION:
An article on the Workplace page on March 22 about the difficulties faced by overweight Americans who seek employment misspelled the surname of a lawyer who runs the Obesity Law and Advocacy Center in San Diego and misstated his weight. He is Walter Lindstrom, not Winstrom. He weighs 240 pounds, not 350.

HEADLINE: NEWS WATCH;
Flat Panel Display Prices Are Expected to Drop

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
Thin is in, again. After rising in 1999 in the aftermath of the Asian economic crisis, prices for flat-panel displays are going to fall steeply this year and next as supplies increase, according to speakers at the DisplaySearch Flat Panel Display conference this week in Austin, Tex.
For example, said Ross Young, president of DisplaySearch, a market research firm, Dell Computer plans to cut the price of its 17-inch flat-panel display this spring to $1,799 from the current price of $2,299. The Dell 1700FP liquid crystal display monitor has a viewing area that is equivalent to a conventional 19-inch cathode ray tube monitor, but it takes up only a fraction of the desk space, consumes less power and does not emit harmful electromagnetic fields. 
 Even at the lower price, the 1700FP L.C.D. will cost about three times as much as Dell's best 19-inch conventional C.R.T. monitor.
Supplies of flat-panel displays fell in 1999 even as demand remained strong, in part because of reduced investment in manufacturing during the Asian economic downturn two years ago. But now many new manufacturers, particularly in Taiwan, are increasing production. That will lead to an oversupply of flat-panel displays later this year and rapidly declining prices until the market stabilizes, probably in 2003, Mr. Young said.
Meanwhile, demand for other kinds of flat-panel displays is growing, for notebook computers, cell phones, digital organizers like the Palm Pilot, Internet appliances, smart watches, medical devices, electronic books and even high-definition television sets, according to conference speakers. PETER H. LEWIS

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan Remains at Odds With U.S. on Telephone Deregulation

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 22

 BODY:
After two days of meetings, the United States and Japan failed to reach any agreement today on further deregulation of the telecommunications market here and extended their talks to a third day.
Other areas of the Japanese economy are also under discussion -- drugs, medical equipment and construction, among others -- but it is the telecommunications debate that has become heated because its outcome has important implications for future economic growth here. 
 The United States contends that Japan is hurting itself economically by not creating the basis for more competition in its telecommunications market, the most expensive such market for users in the industrial nations. The Americans have successfully framed the debate as multilateral, affecting not only United States companies but their European and Japanese competitors.
Even the Keidanren, Japan's traditional business lobby, has sided with the United States, not to mention blue-chip Japanese companies like Sony.
"Persistence in the old ways threatens to transform Japan into a fading giant," Richard W. Fisher, a deputy United States trade representative, told journalists here on Tuesday.
Washington is demanding an immediate 41 percent reduction in the fees that telecommunications companies pay to hook up to the network owned by Nippon Telegraph and Telephone, the former government-owned telephone monopoly that is a member of the NTT Group. NTT controls more than 99 percent of local phone traffic.
The fees, according to the Japanese government, eat up as much as 40 percent of the revenue of NTT's competitors.
But the government says it can cut the fees only by 22.5 percent over a four-year period, contending that a more aggressive move would deal a crushing blow to NTT. The election year presents a further complication because the ruling party's popularity is waning, and NTT and its subsidiaries employ 224,000 voters directly and probably as many indirectly.
The United States is threatening to take the matter to the World Trade Organization if some agreement is not reached by the end of the month, an escalation of the dispute that the Japanese want to avoid in advance of a meeting of the leading industrial nations in Okinawa in July.
"There is a wide gap between the two sides on the so-called reduction rate," said Akitaka Saiki, a spokesman for Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi, referring to the interconnection fees. "I think the Japanese negotiators are trying to persuade their American counterparts of the difficult domestic circumstances surrounding NTT."
Mr. Saiki said the reductions demanded by the United States could force NTT to reduce employment and increase management turmoil at a company where opinions are divided over strategy. NTT has already begun an overhaul aimed at reducing the work force by 21,000 and curtailing investment over three years, but the job cuts are regarded by many as cosmetic since they will be achieved through attrition.
The Japanese government is having trouble making its case, however, because NTT is an extraordinarily rich company, owning controlling stakes in the NTT Mobile Communications Network, or NTT DoCoMo, Japan's largest mobile phone company, and the NTT Data Corporation.
The regulators are further hampered by their own efforts to make a case to politicians for supporting sharply reduced interconnection fees. Having convinced politicians that any further reduction in the fees would hurt NTT and its callers, the regulators are now unable to easily change their stance.

HEADLINE: Fed Chief Sees Abuses in Loans to the Poor

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, added his voice today to the criticism of a growing practice by some mortgage and home-equity loan companies of seeking low-income borrowers and charging them excessively high fees and interest without adequate disclosure.
The practice, called predatory lending by its critics, can damage poorer neighborhoods, Mr. Greenspan said in a speech to a meeting of the National Community Reinvestment Coalition. 
 Mr. Greenspan said the Federal Reserve was concerned about "abusive lending practices that target specific neighborhoods or vulnerable segments of the population and can result in unaffordable payments," loss of homeowners' equity and foreclosure.
It was the first time Mr. Greenspan had spoken publicly on the subject. Other federal banking regulators have criticized the lending practices recently, but the remarks by the central bank chairman raised the profile of the issue.
The Fed oversees many Wall Street investment banks that have raised money for consumer finance companies, but the lenders themselves are mostly regulated by the states. Legislation to curb predatory lending has been proposed in California, Illinois, Maryland, Minnesota, Missouri and New York.
In some cases, consumer finance companies have taken advantage of people with low incomes or damaged credit histories, many of them minorities, who cannot obtain conventional loans and are desperate to become homeowners or raise cash by borrowing against their homes. Congressional hearings have indicated that aggressive sales tactics and excessively high interest rates are increasing.
"The Federal Reserve is working on several fronts to address these issues," Mr. Greenspan said.
Among other things, the Fed has convened regulators from various agencies -- including the Departments of Justice and Housing and Urban Development, the Federal Trade Commission and bank regulatory agencies -- to develop methods to deal with predatory lending. The group is exploring options like stricter enforcement of rules and new legislation.
A consumer advocate welcomed Mr. Greenspan's remarks but said action was needed.
"Congress knows predatory lending is a problem. The Clinton administration knows this is a problem. Now the chairman of the Federal Reserve himself is saying this is a problem," said Frank Torres, the legislative counsel for Consumers Union. "So when are we going to see laws, regulation, and enforcement to put a stop to it? Actions speak louder than words."
Industry officials maintain that finance companies provide a valuable service to consumers who have low incomes and poor credit records that prevent them from qualifying for normal loans.
"I don't think any responsible person condones taking advantage of others," said James McLaughlin, the American Bankers Association's director of regulatory affairs. But, he maintained, it is difficult to determine at what interest rate loans become unfair. "This could have the effect of drying up credit in many of the areas that are seeking credit today," Mr. McLaughlin said.
