HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: By Terence Neilan

 BODY:

THE AMERICAS
 
CANADA: SMOKING BAN VOIDED
British Columbia's Supreme Court struck down one of the toughest anti-smoking rules in the country, a total ban on smoking in bars and restaurants. The court ruled that the provincial Workers' Compensation Board had not adequately consulted with the public before imposing the rule on Jan. 1. The ban resulted in hundreds of layoffs from bars and restaurants, and prompted one rural city to try to join neighboring Alberta. James Brooke (NYT)
 
MEXICO: U.S. MILITARY WELCOMED
The chairman of the joint chiefs of staff, Gen. Henry H. Shelton, received an unusually warm welcome from the armed forces during a two-day visit. The defense minister, Gen. Enrique Cervantes Aguirre, decorated him with one of the country's highest military medals, saying he had "distinguished himself for his respect for our country and its men in arms." Mexico's military long regarded the United States as a potential invader, but in recent years the two countries have cooperated in the drug war. Julia Preston (NYT) 

EUROPE
 
BULGARIA: THOUSANDS PROTEST
More than 6,000 people from all over the country marched in central Sofia to demand higher wages and protest against rising unemployment. The protesters waved trade-union flags and carried banners reading "We want jobs, we want bread," "Unemployment, poverty, corruption -- how much longer?" and "We have already hit bottom . . . or have we?" Students dressed in black, above, joined the march, saying they were "mourning the plight of impoverished Bulgaria." (Reuters)
 
BRITAIN: 'HATE CRIME' ARRESTS
In a series of dawn raids, the London police arrested 62 people on "hate crime" charges ranging from bias-related assaults to the publication of racist material. A spokesman for the force, condemned in an official report last year as "institutionally racist," said, "Our aim is to create a hostile environment for those who, because of racism or prejudice, wish to undermine communities and destroy the principle of justice for all, regardless of color, race, creed or sexual orientation." Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
CZECH REPUBLIC: CEMETERY POSTPONEMENT
The government postponed a decision about what to do with a 13th-century Jewish cemetery unearthed during excavations in Prague for an insurance company parking garage. The government said it was studying a new proposal from Prague's Jewish minority to preserve the graves on the site, building some kind of bridge over them and allowing the company to build above them. Steven Erlanger (NYT)
 
GERMANY: MAKING AMENDS TO GAYS
Lawmakers proposed making amends to a long-neglected group of Nazi victims: thousands of men sent to concentration camps for being gay. The governing Social Democratic and Green parties introduced a bill to acknowledge Nazi persecution of gays and ask the government to review whether to annul convictions under a Nazi-era anti-gay law that remained on the books until 1969. (AP)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
YEMEN: ARAB SUMMIT SOUGHT
President Ali Abdullah Saleh has sent out envoys in an attempt to convene an Arab summit meeting. Abdullah Ahmad Ghanem, the parliamentary and judicial affairs minister, has traveled to Syria and will also visit Lebanon, Jordan and Iraq. (Agence France-Presse)
 
AFRICA
 
CONGO: U.N. WARNING
The Security Council, alarmed by a new rebel offensive in Congo and reports of "significant" rearmament and training on both sides, demanded that the combatants stop hostilities or face the possibility a peacekeeping force will not be deployed. The council will get a report next week from Under Secretary General Bernard Miyet, who has just returned from a visit there. Barbara Crossette (NYT)
 
UGANDA: FIRE INQUIRY
A senior police official said investigators suspect that the victims of a fire that killed hundreds of members of a Christian cult were not covered in gasoline, as first thought. The official told the state newspaper that they think an explosion or series of blasts ignited the fire that killed more than 330 people. Henri E. Cauvin (NYT)
 
MOZAMBIQUE: NEW PLEA
Facing a new flood surge after nearly two months of rains that killed at least 490 and caused hundreds of thousands to flee their homes, Mozambique appealed for $100 million for rehabilitation, as aid agencies flew assessment missions up three rivers expected to flood a third time. (Reuters)
 
ASIA
 
PHILIPPINES: A JOKE TOO FAR
President Joseph Estrada's newly named chief of staff, Aprodicio Laquian, apologized and resigned after making a joke about his boss's late-night drinking parties. He had said that as "the only sober person in the room" he could hide drunkenly signed decrees until "the beautiful light of the morning." Mr. Estrada accepted the resignation, saying, "I didn't find it funny." Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
NEPAL: NEW PREMIER
Girija Prasad Koirala was sworn in as prime minister, the fourth time he has headed the government since democracy was restored to Nepal in 1990. Mr. Koirala, left, took the oath of office from King Birendra at the head of a 25-member cabinet. He succeeds Krishna Prasad Bhattarai, who was forced to resign after a rebellion in his party. He had been prime minister since general elections last May. (AP)
 
MALAYSIA: ANWAR TRIAL ADJOURNS
The sodomy trial of former Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim, which had resumed after a two-week recess, adjourned again as the judge continued to consider the politically touchy demand by the defense to call to the stand Mr. Anwar's most prominent accuser, Prime Minister Mahathir Mohamad. Seth Mydans (NYT)

HEADLINE: Halifax Journal;
Lively City Lets Ghosts of Deadman's Island Rest

BYLINE: By JAMES BROOKE 

DATELINE: HALIFAX, Nova Scotia

 BODY:
With bay views of sea gulls, seals and sailboat regattas, a wooded peninsula here named Deadman's Island seemed just right for luxury condominiums, tailored for one of Canada's hottest real estate markets.
Without any grave marker or historical plaque to raise questions, developers moved their blueprints through city channels, pleading ignorance about the colorful name attached to the two oceanfront acres. 
 Then a neighborhood group pored through old British Admiralty logs, concluding that Deadman's Island held the unmarked graves of almost 400 people, including 183 American prisoners from the War of 1812.
"How many people want to live with 400 ghosts in the basement?" asked Graham Read, who was elected to the Halifax Regional Council on a platform of stopping a plan to build 60 condo units at the site, now a piney knoll. Last month, the council voted to spend $140,000 to buy the disputed two acres for a city park. Luxury developments are being planned for nearby, off the tiny peninsula.
The fight is a reflection of the growing pains in Halifax, a booming city that is sometimes called Canada's Seattle.
In January, a $2 billion natural gas project went on stream in the province, injecting new jobs and big salaries into Halifax, an 18th-century British Navy port. With eight colleges and Canada's highest Internet usage rate, the city has a thriving service economy.
Housing prices rose 5 percent last year, Canada's fastest rate. On Deadman's Island, half-acre lots were to be marketed for $175,000. But to some neighbors the wooded lots were not empty.
With orange construction stakes already hammered into the soil, the Northwest Arm Heritage Association stepped into the fray (the Northwest Arm is the name of the secluded bay where the peninsula is).
British military records, the association found, indicate that about 400 people were buried on the peninsula. In addition to the 183 American sailors and soldiers captured during the War of 1812, there were 104 African-Americans who died of smallpox after escaping slavery at that time. There were also 9 Spanish and 66 French military prisoners from the Napoleonic wars and 37 Irish immigrants who died of typhus in 1847 after fleeing the potato famine.
As modern Nova Scotia diversifies from its English-Scottish roots, members of the ethnic groups buried on Deadman's Island now have powerful constituencies.
"Irish?" Mayor Walter R. Fitzgerald of Halifax spluttered to a local newspaper reporter when he first heard of the ethnic breakdown. Speaking of plans to make the peninsula a city park, he said, "I'll tell you, we're going to do it for sure now."
Support for preservation also came from the city's black community, which is largely descended from African-Americans who escaped Maryland's plantation system, arriving here on British Navy vessels during the War of 1812.
While Halifax's most prestigious cemetery is the burial site of Sir Robert Ross, who burned down the White House, few people today crow about victories in the War of 1812. Nova Scotians now like to cultivate good relations with their southern neighbors from what these Canadians call "the Boston states." Given the mild winters and pleasant summers, real estate agents peddle Nova Scotia's southern coast as "Cape Cod 50 years ago."
Last year Halifax, attracted a record 73 cruise ships, carrying 108,000 tourists. This summer, with 150 "tall ships" expected in July, the city expects cruise traffic will jump by 50 percent.
"Tourism is a big moneymaker," Mayor Fitzgerald said of an industry that brings almost $500 million a year to this 250-year-old city. "With the number of American tourists coming into Nova Scotia, Deadman's Island could be part of the tour."
Tour buses already take visitors to a cemetery that holds many steerage class victims of the Titanic. Less known, but equally chilling, are the accounts of American prisoners of war who were interned on Melville Island, which faced the burying ground.
Benjamin F. Palmer, a captured sailor, wrote in his diary of 1814, "This day we embark'd for Hell," referring to his confinement with 200 other Americans in a space measuring 40 feet by 40 feet. During a 31-month period, British Admiralty logs recorded the passage of 8,148 Americans through the prison.
At least once a week, prisoners would row a new corpse across an inlet to the improvised burying ground.
Military logs recorded causes of death: typhus, pneumonia, dysentery, smallpox, asthma, pleurisy, "infection of the lungs," consumption and "apoplexy."
"With the way they were jammed in here, most of the deaths were from contagious diseases," Guy R. MacLean, a neighborhood leader, said, strolling around the old prison island, now a yacht club. The unheated stone cells, which were used as late as World War I to hold German prisoners, now serve as storage lockers for local boat owners.
Few local residents had any illusions about the sinister history of Deadman's Island. Brian Cuthbertson, a historian, found that one owner of the land, Charles F. Longley, once dug up three skulls. He placed them in the basement of a dance hall he owned, hoping to scare thieves away from his liquor supplies. Instead, the skulls were stolen.
Generations of local boys used to dare each other to go digging on the peninsula. "Our mothers used to tell us, 'Don't go on that island, the ghosts will get you,' " recalled Al Chaddock, an artist and longtime resident.
Bill Piers, another resident, recalled: "A bunch of us went out there digging, up on the top part. One of the older boys found bones. We ran like crazy, afraid the ghosts were after us." Now 50, he added, "That was the last time I was on Deadman's Island."

HEADLINE: Start-Ups Raise Pay and Offer Options as Candidates Dwindle

BYLINE: By DAVID LEONHARDT 

 BODY:
The anecdote, in its many forms, is already a part of Internet lore: An executive leaves a major company for a start-up, takes a large pay cut and hopes that stock options in the new company will instead bring fabulous wealth in the future.
But thanks to an infusion of venture capital and a shortage of executives, that kind of trade-off has become considerably less common over the last year. To an increasing extent, pay experts say, executives at start-ups are receiving not only potentially enormous option packages, but large salaries as well. 
 The average vice president for sales at a start-up now makes $165,000 a year in salary and bonus, according to a survey released yesterday covering 800 American companies that have received venture capital but have not yet gone public. The average chief operating officer earns $190,000. And the typical chief executive brings home more than $200,000.
The survey, published by VentureOne, a San Francisco research company, is the first extensive study of executive pay at private, venture-backed companies, pay experts said.
The study also found that chief executives in the Washington area typically make 10 percent more than those in California and the Northeast and that employee turnover is higher in California than in the eastern part of the country.
The survey reflects the raises of the last two years, as start-ups have grown frantic over attracting managers at all levels who can help them survive the increasingly competitive Internet economy. Over the last 12 months, executive salaries at private companies have jumped 15 percent to 20 percent, said Dee DiPietro, the chief executive of Advanced-HR, a Saratoga, Calif., company that sells compensation data.
"The days of people going in as C.E.O. with $100,000 a year and 8 percent of a company's stock are over," said Stephen A. Unger, a managing partner at Heidrick & Struggles, an executive search firm. "C.E.O.'s want to go in with $300,000 a year and 8 percent of the stock, and they're getting it."
Driving the salary increases is a flood of venture capital, which has created a plethora of cash-rich companies, many of them scrambling to be the first of their kind to go public. The shortened period before initial public offerings, in turn, has increased the importance of hiring experienced managers, said start-up executives and human-resource consultants.
In addition, the Internet boom of the last five years has made many more people aware of the benefits of stock options and more are now demanding equity. "Stock has become a scarcer and scarcer commodity, and that's when you have to resort to more cash," said Bill Mitchell, the vice president for marketing at Astral Point Communications, a Chelmsford, Mass., company that has been offering higher salaries over the last year.
Executives at larger companies still make more money, but the gap has narrowed. The top marketing executive at a typical large or medium-sized company made $178,000 in salary and bonus last year, according to William M. Mercer, a human-resource consulting firm. That is $27,000 more than the typical marketing vice president in Venture-One's survey.
The gap, particularly for chief executives, is still big enough to force start-ups to offer stock. "The reason people leave big companies is for the equity, not the cash," said Andy Rachleff, a general partner at Benchmark Capital who disagreed with most analysts that start-up pay is increasing rapidly.
 The high start-up salaries underscore why older companies are having to fight so hard to keep employees.
Recently, for example, law firms in Silicon Valley, New York, Boston and other cities have increased starting salaries by as much as 40 percent, to $140,000. And some consulting and accounting firms are giving their associates access to venture-capital funds that allow them to invest in Internet companies without actually working for one.
The salary increases do have a downside for the start-ups, however. Many Internet companies are continuing to run losses and to drain their available cash. Adding to their payroll could keep them unprofitable longer, analysts said. "Some companies are going to run out of money," said Mark L. Smith, a managing director of Korn/Ferry International, the executive search firm.
For now, though, companies see little choice but to bid for the executives they want.
Consider Rick Wysocki, who spent 14 years at Computer Associates and last year found himself with his choice of executive posts at start-ups. To woo him, Artemis Ventures, a venture capital firm in Sausalito, Calif., offered him a large stake of Again Technologies, the company he would lead. But it also agreed to pay him $250,000 a year and to move the executive offices of Again from Silicon Valley to the East Bay area near Oakland to cut Mr. Wysocki's commute, he said.
In return, Mr. Wysocki brought along four other executives, who took control of some of Again's most important divisions. Initially, one of Artemis's managing directors, Christine Comaford, thought it was offering him too much. Now that it has four fewer executive searches to undertake, however, "I think this was one of the best decisions we've made," Ms. Comaford said.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
The golden formulafor Hollywood success. It only happens in the movies.

BYLINE: By Virginia Postrel 

 BODY:
AS Hollywood gathers on Sunday to heap Oscar praise on such surprise hits as "American Beauty" and "The Sixth Sense," producers and studio marketing heads are revamping their idea of what makes for box-office success. Action heroes, happy endings, special effects and high-concept synopses are out. Flawed protagonists, shock value, downbeat twists and hard-to-explain plots are in.
The formula movie is dead. Long live the formula movie. 
 Hollywood's eternal quest for formulas exasperates Arthur De Vany, professor of economics at the University of California at Irvine, and author of numerous papers on the economics of the movie business. "Here we go again," he says. "Hollywood is generalizing from a couple of data points. Trying to read into a handful of movies some deep property of audiences is bad science and bad moviemaking.
"The evidence is plain," he adds, "There is no formula."
Movies are, Professor De Vanysays, "a business of the extraordinary." Their statistical patterns do not fit the good old normal bell curve, with a predictable average and symmetrical chances of hits and losses. Like more and more products in a wealthy society, movies depend on subtle combinations of hard-to-articulate characteristics. Formulas, new or old, cannot capture what will make a movie appeal to an audience.
Studies by Professor De Vany and W. David Walls of the University of Hong Kong (available at www.socsci.uci.edu/mbs/personnel/devany/devany.html), examine the movies' strange statistics and the strategies studios use -- mostly unsuccessfully -- to try to reduce "the terror of the box office." Movie revenues (or profits) are not like people's heights, falling smoothly around an average with no one too far out on either end. They are like earthquakes, incomes or quasar pulses. The great majority are small, but a few are many, many times greater than the others.
The average revenue or profit of the business is determined almost entirely by those very few runaway hits. The rest of the movies are box- office duds whose negative returns are statistically swamped by the rare successes. The "average" movie does not really exist.
This pattern, which is called a Pareto law, is true not just for movies in general but within every subcategory: small budgets and big ones, action pictures and comedies, movies with stars and movies without stars, even Bruce Willis films. So making only star vehicles or only small-budget movies will not protect a studio from box-office flops.
What makes the movies so unpredictable? For starters, each is a unique product, and audiences have to try it to see whether they will like it. And this unique product is playing in a tournament against an ever-changing group of competitors.
To make matters worse, how audiences experience a movie depends on what they have already seen and how they reacted to those movies: Did the films whet their appetites for more, or create a desire for something different? After a decade of antiheroes, the good-vs.-evil plots of "Star Wars" and "Raiders of the Lost Ark" were refreshing, even though those movies recalled earlier formula pictures. And novelty takes many forms. It would be wrong to conclude that today's audiences do not want to see heroes waging special-effects battle against absolute evil, despite overwhelming odds. "The Matrix" followed that mythic outline and was a hit. Its freshness lay elsewhere.
Movies succeed when audiences resonate to what is on the screen. Customer word-of-mouth matters enormously, not just for sleepers but for all hits. That is why Professors De Vany and Walls find that a good opening weekend does not matter that much, at least for the real hits. The big successes -- the extraordinary films that garner profits -- are the movies with legs. The hits take off as information spreads beyond the control of the studio. That is true for surprises like "The Sixth Sense" and for expected successes like "Toy Story 2."
The data suggests that stars have their main effect not so much by helping movies open as by extending their runs. But most stars do not really make a difference. Professors De Vany and Walls looked at movies released from 1984 through 1996 and found only 19 stars, including a couple of directors, who had a "nonnegligible correlation with hit movies" grossing more than $50 million domestically. The top two stars were not macho action heroes but Michelle Pfeiffer and Sandra Bullock. These actresses cannot guarantee success, however. To the contrary, caution the authors, "Every star has a sizable probability of making a bomb."
And the past does not predict the future. Based on the 1984-96 data, Bruce Willis was a loser. If the study ran through 1999, including the megahits "The Sixth Sense" and "Armageddon" as well as some less successful films, Mr. Willis would be a plus. You just never know. The only way to succeed in this business is to experiment and adapt. That is why Professor De Vany admires industry practices that react quickly to information once a movie is out. Unfortunately, he says, antitrust actions in the 1950's misunderstood the business and blocked some adaptive practices, like letting studios own theaters. But studios and exhibitors developed nimble new practices. Licensing contracts encourage exhibitors to extend the run of movies that are doing well, for instance, while dumping the ones that flop.
These practices recognize the fundamental economic facts of moviemaking: the audience is in control, and moviegoers cannot explain in advance what they want to see. They know what they like only after they have experienced it.
"The real star," Professor De Vany said. "is the movie."

HEADLINE: Hostages Fled After Drugging Captor's Tea

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: BALTIMORE, March 22

 BODY:
After four days as hostages, a couple escaped from a suspected killer on Tuesday night by putting a sedative in his iced tea and then slipping out of an apartment window as he dozed.
The police then stormed the small apartment to rescue the couple's 12-year-old son and fatally shot the murder suspect, Joseph Palczynski, when he was startled awake and made a "furtive gesture." The police said he had three guns within reach. 
 The gunfire ended a three-week episode of violence by Mr. Palczynski, an unemployed electrician.
He was arrested on March 4 on charges of beating his former girlfriend, Tracy Whitehead. After getting out on bail, the police said, he kidnapped Ms. Whitehead and killed three people who tried to help her. Ms. Whitehead escaped on March 8, but Mr. Palczynski killed a woman and shot a child in the face while trying to steal a car, the police said.
Mr. Palczynski, 31, eluded the police for almost two weeks.
On Friday night, Mr. Palczynski forced his way into the apartment of Ms. Whitehead's mother, Lynn Whitehead, and held her hostage along with Andy McCord -- her boyfriend -- and their 12-year-old son, Bradley McCord, in Dundalk.
Mr. McCord said he and Bradley barricaded themselves in a bedroom and escaped injury while Mr. Palczynski shot about 50 rounds through the door.
The 25-by-27-foot apartment grew filthy, the police said. The family dog was not permitted to go outside. Bradley was tied up for most of the time, the police said.
On Tuesday, Mr. Palczynski told Ms. Whitehead, "Today is the day you're going to die," Mr. McCord said.
So the couple came up with a plan. The police and Mr. McCord said Ms. Whitehead ground up two Xanax pills, a prescription drug used to treat anxiety, and slipped them into Mr. Palczynski's iced tea.

HEADLINE: Senate Backs End to Penalty On Earnings in Retirement

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
The Senate voted 100 to 0 today to remove limits on how much money most Social Security recipients can earn without losing part of their retirement benefit, reflecting the politically potent combination of an aging population and a strong economy.
The Senate's action to repeal the Depression-era policy of discouraging the elderly from working followed a unanimous vote on the measure in the House three weeks ago. In a statement from India, where he is traveling, President Clinton restated his intention to sign the bill. 
 The bill amounts to an election-year benefit increase for about 800,000 current Social Security recipients who have been losing some or all of their benefits to the earnings limit. And it holds the promise of greater flexibility in working past normal retirement age for the tens of millions of baby boomers who will enter the ranks of senior citizens in the next few decades.
Under current law, people 65 through 69 years old lose $1 of their Social Security benefit for every $3 that they earn above $17,000. A 68-year-old woman earning $23,000, for example, would lose $2,000 in Social Security payments.
The earnings limit was already scheduled to rise to $30,000 by 2002, and it does not apply to people 70 and older. The legislation would abolish the limit altogether and make the change retroactive to the beginning of this year.
Members of both parties said the earnings limit might have made sense at the time that Social Security was established in the Depression, when the unemployment rate was 25 percent, many if not most jobs entailed hard physical labor, and life expectancies were much lower than they are today.
But they said it made no sense now, with unemployment so low that companies cannot find enough workers, jobs are generally less physically strenuous, and actuarial tables lead people to plan for long lives after normal retirement age.
"Coal mines were no place for 70-year-olds," said Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, the New York Democrat who is retiring from the Senate early next year at the age of 73. "Computer terminals are. It is as simple as that."
Many Republicans have been pressing for repeal of the limit for years, saying it was unfair to deprive people of benefits they had earned simply because they chose to work or had to work to support themselves.
"This is not a group of greedy millionaires who are being impacted by the earnings test restrictions," said Senator Connie Mack, Republican of Florida. "It is lower- and moderate-income seniors who need some relief from their government to be able to survive."
The measure will go to Mr. Clinton for his signature after the House and Senate work out technical differences in their bills over whether the changes should apply in the month that people turn 65 or in the year that they turn 65.
Some members of both parties said that while they wholeheartedly supported the repeal of the earnings limit, they were uncomfortable doing so at a time when Congress and the administration had failed to make any progress in addressing the long-term financial problems facing Social Security. Without any changes, Social Security will run short of money needed to pay promised benefits starting in 2033, according to the most recent projections.
"We have not done comprehensive reform of Social Security," said Senator Bob Kerrey, Democrat of Nebraska. "People under the age of 40 are going to pay a terrible price for that."
The Senate vote masked some complexities of the issue. Although proponents said the measure would help the economy by encouraging more people to remain in the work force or to work more, evidence about its economic effects was sketchy.
While the measure would help people who are willing and able to work, it would do nothing for those who subsist entirely on their Social Security checks. The retirement age is rising gradually over the next two decades to 67, reducing the number of people who will be affected by the earnings limit. And few of the measure's backers pointed out that the reduction in benefits suffered by people who earned more than the limit was offset by higher benefits starting at age 70.
The change would lead the Social Security system to pay out $22 billion more in benefits over the next 10 years. But those costs would be offset in subsequent years because beneficiaries would not get the increases at age 70 they would otherwise receive.
The bill would also leave in place an earnings limit on people who claim early retirement benefits from Social Security. Under that provision, people 62 through 64 lose $1 of their benefit for every $2 they earn above the limit, which this year is $10,080.
The two parties agreed not to lift the earnings cap on early retirees -- in essence encouraging people not to take Social Security before age 65 -- because research has shown that people who take a reduced Social Security benefit at age 62 are more likely to end up in poverty. The problem is particularly acute among widows who rely on their late husbands' benefits after the men retired early.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: G.O.P. Split Stalls Effort to Reap Gains From Jump in Gas Prices

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress would love to reap political advantage from the recent surge in gasoline prices, but they are so divided over what to do that they cannot act decisively.
The division was apparent today in the House of Representatives. After a debate that involved little more than finger-pointing, the House passed a toothless bill that would require the president to submit a report on which oil-exporting countries were fixing prices and then "undertake a concerted diplomatic campaign" to persuade those countries to lower prices.
The main reason for the high prices is that the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries and one major producer that does not belong to the cartel, Mexico, have limited production. The price of a barrel of crude oil is now about $30 a barrel, up from $12 a year ago. There are 42 gallons in a barrel. 
 As a consequence, the average price of a gallon of regular unleaded gasoline, about $1 a year ago, is now more than $1.50 and climbing. It is expected to reach $2 in some parts of the country by the summer.
As originally introduced, the bill before the House today would have required the president to cut foreign aid and military sales to countries that fix oil prices. Last week, the International Relations Committee voted to make the sanctions discretionary. And on Tuesday night, Republican leaders knocked the sanctions out of the bill altogether.
Asked what happened, the main sponsor, Representative Benjamin A. Gilman, a Republican from upstate New York, said lawmakers from oil states who are satisfied with the high prices had exercised their clout. "They've done things to take the teeth out of it," Mr. Gilman said.
The bill was approved, 382 to 38.
In the Senate, several Republicans from oil states who have formed what they call the oil caucus gave speeches today advocating such steps as a reduction in the gasoline tax and tax breaks for oil wells that produce 15 barrels a day or fewer. There is general agreement in the Senate that neither of those measures will become law.
While the lawmakers were making speeches, hundreds of truckers were on Capitol Hill lobbying for relief from the high fuel prices.
Bill Richardson, the secretary of energy, has been traveling around the globe this week meeting with officials of oil-producing nations -- countries that belong to OPEC as well as those that do not.
OPEC members will meet on March 27 in Vienna, and Mr. Richardson has said he expects them to agree to increase production. Jay Hakes, head of the government's Energy Information Agency, told a Congressional panel today that OPEC would have to increase production two million barrels a day to "move prices back into the normal level."
The debate in the House sounded like a "did so, did not" squabble.
Mr. Gilman accused the Clinton administration of being "asleep at the switch for the last 18 months."
Representative Tom DeLay of Texas, the Republican whip, declared, "This administration has no credibility in the world, and everybody understands that."
Mr. DeLay accused Mr. Richardson of "tip-cup diplomacy," begging oil-exporting countries to lower prices.
Democrats responded in kind. Taunting the Republicans for having offered such a weak bill, Representative Barney Frank of Massachusetts, said, "This has them quaking in Kuwait, terrified in Venezuela."
In mock horror, Mr. Frank said, "A report is coming."

HEADLINE: Council to Call for Tax Cut Weighted to Help the Poor

BYLINE: By ERIC LIPTON 

 BODY:
The City Council, answering Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani's $2 billion tax cut package, intends to propose exempting poor people from the city's income tax and giving a much larger tax cut to the middle class.
The tax cut plan is to be released this morning as part of the Council's response to the mayor's proposed budget for the 2001 fiscal year. The plan comes as the Council has been challenging the mayor on several fronts, from welfare reform to management of the city public markets. 
 Citing higher revenue than the mayor had projected, the Council is also calling for $355 million in additional spending, first to restore money the mayor wants to cut from libraries, cultural institutions and parks, and to pay for new initiatives like enhanced police training, hot meals for the elderly on weekends and higher salaries for some city librarians. The extra revenue would help pay for a $37.2 billion budget, 1 percent more than the mayor's budget, and it would also be used to increase the city's budget reserve, for use in case of a recession.
"Everybody will benefit," said Herbert E. Berman, a Brooklyn Democrat who heads the Council's finance committee. "But we have to do something extra to tell the taxpaying middle class that they can continue to live in the city of New York."
The Giuliani administration quickly called the Council's income tax restructuring plan unacceptable. Deputy Mayor Joseph J. Lhota said he thought it would never get the support of legislators in Albany, who would have to approve such changes.
"We already have a progressive income tax," Mr. Lhota said. "Why push for something that is politically impractical?"
The Council proposal, which comes in response to a budget plan Mr. Giuliani offered in January, represents one of the first steps in the Kabuki dance of sorts that occurs each spring as the two branches of New York City government try to compromise on how the city spends its money. The city is in an envious position, because this fiscal year should end with a surplus of at least $2.3 billion, money that can be used to help balance the coming year's budget and pay for the tax cuts.
The two tax cut packages would give back about the same total to city residents and businesses, starting at about $550 million in 2001 and climbing to about $2 billion by 2004. The biggest single chunk under both proposals -- about $800 million a year once it is fully in place -- would result from eliminating a 14 percent surcharge on the city's personal income tax, first added in 1991 during the city's fiscal troubles.
But the Council and mayor are offering drastically different plans for distributing this money. Under Mr. Giuliani's proposal, the 14 percent surcharge would be eliminated for all city taxpayers. A person earning $20,000 to $30,000 would save about $60 on average, and a taxpayer with an adjusted gross income of $500,000 to $1 million would get an annual tax cut averaging $2,977.
Under the Council's plan, those earning less than $10,000 would pay no city income tax. On the other end, taxpayers earning $500,000 to $1 million would see a cut of only 5.7 percent, or an average of $1,310 a year. And taxpayers with an income of $20,000 to $30,000 would get a 24 percent cut, averaging $97 a year. Over all, any taxpayer earning less than $150,000 would get a cut larger than 14 percent, and those earning more would get a smaller cut.
Mr. Lhota said the 14 percent surcharge should be removed the same way it was imposed. "It was imposed on all taxpayers at the start," he said, "and when we eliminate the surcharge everyone who is paying the tax should have it eliminated."
The extra spending the Council is advocating is possible because of its more optimistic revenue forecasts. The Council staff estimates that the current fiscal year will end with a nearly $3 billion surplus, instead of $2.3 billion. And the Council expects that an extra $1.2 billion will be available next year, mostly as a result of higher tax receipts.
With this extra money, the Council wants to restore $159 million in cuts proposed by Mr. Giuliani, including $42 million from libraries, $5 million from parks and even $3.5 million from the City Council budget.
Mr. Lhota criticized the extra spending, saying it was exactly what he would expect from the Democratic controlled Council. "It is unfortunate," he said, "that City Council believes that its sole purpose in life is to spend more and more money."

HEADLINE: Clinton Implores India's Legislators to Shun Nuclear Arms

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: AGRA, India, March 22

 BODY:
Before leaving politics behind and heading out to tour India's heartland, President Clinton laid out a picture of the world today in which this nation would have the "ability to shape the character of our time" by renouncing its nuclear weapons.
Making an impassioned argument to the Indian Parliament, Mr. Clinton laced his comments with respect for a country that is sensitive to being lectured to, but reminded its leaders that the United States and Russia are also planning to sharply reduce their stockpiles. 
 The president said that India, whose leaders told him during talks here that the nation was committed to keeping its nuclear weapons but would not carry out further tests, could make an immense impact with its choice.
"If India's nuclear tests shook the world, India's leadership for nonproliferation can certainly move the world," Mr. Clinton said to an audience that included Prime Minister Atal Behari Vajpayee, his cabinet and legislators. In talks on Monday, the prime minister told Mr. Clinton that India needed to maintain a nuclear deterrence for its security. India tested nuclear weapons in May 1998 and its neighbor Pakistan quickly followed.
The prime minister's national security adviser, Brajesh Mishra, has argued that its nuclear deterrence has kept the conflict from widening in Kashmir, the Himalayan territory claimed by both India and Pakistan where their forces clash along an uneasy cease-fire line. But Mr. Clinton pointed out that the massacre of 35 Sikhs in Kashmir this week reinforced the need for dialogue.
The president's speech in the circular Parliament chamber capped the official part of his visit to India. Immediately afterward, he took on the mantle of special tourist as he began a three-day tour of India. With his daughter, Chelsea, Mr. Clinton visited the Taj Mahal on the outskirts of this northern Indian town, posed against the majestic backdrop of the white marble tomb built by a 17th-century mogul in honor of the love for his wife, and then disappeared inside for a personal tour.
The complex at the Taj Mahal was closed early this morning in preparation for Mr. Clinton's arrival so that when he and Chelsea emerged arm-in-arm for their walk toward the mausoleum, the lawns and the building itself, usually teeming with tourists, were devoid of people. The president and his daughter stopped several times, and on the orders of photographers, looked this way and that for what was considered the hallmark image of his India trip.
The White House used the opportunity to make a political point at the Taj Mahal, where pollution is threatening the marble sheen of the dome and minarets. In an outdoor speech afterward, with the Taj as a backdrop, Mr. Clinton pledged to help India reduce greenhouse emissions and encourage energy conservation.
But nuclear weapons were the most intense subject of the Clinton visit. The public umbrage taken on Monday by the president of India, Kircheril Raman Narayanan, at Mr. Clinton's description of the subcontinent as the most dangerous place on earth, lent an extra tension to the differences between the United States and India as they tried to forge a new relationship. Mr. Clinton tried to defuse this strain by insisting in his address today that he was speaking as a friend who respected India's diversity, democracy and recent efforts at economic reform. And he posed the question that has often befuddled those who have just come to know India, and even those who have known it for ages.
"From a distance, India often appears as a kaleidoscope of competing, perhaps superficial, images. Is it atomic weapons or ahimsa?" he asked, referring to the message of nonviolence perpetuated by Mahatma Gandhi. "A land struggling against poverty and inequality, or the world's largest middle-class society? Is it still simmering with communal tensions or history's most successful melting pot? Is it Bollywood or Satyajit Ray? Swetta Chetty or Alla Rakha? Is it the hand loom or the hyperlink?"
The answer, Mr. Clinton said, was that "no single image can possibly do justice to your great nation." He praised India's embrace of information technology. "When Americans and other big software companies call for consumer and customer support, they're just as likely to find themselves talking to an expert in Bangalore as one in Seattle," he said to a round of applause. And he said he understood India's concern that the rules of the World Trade Organization advance "the cause of social justice around the world."
But Mr. Clinton tried hardest as he talked about India's nuclear strategy.
"I can only speak to you as a friend about America's own experience during the cold war," he said. Despite direct dialogue with the former Soviet Union, a fair understanding of each other's intentions and very good spies on both sides, "we came far too close to nuclear war."
One of Washington's major concerns about the standoff between India and Pakistan is the almost total lack of dialogue and the apparent belief in the two capitals, New Delhi and Islamabad, that possessing nuclear weapons is perhaps not all that dangerous.
"We learned that deterrence alone cannot be relied on to prevent accident or miscalculation," Mr. Clinton said, as the chamber listened to this part of his speech attentively but largely silently. "And in a nuclear standoff, there is nothing more dangerous than believing there is no danger."
The only passages of Mr. Clinton's nuclear appeal that won applause were his deference to India and the choice before the nation: "Only India can determine its own interests. Only India can know if it truly is safer today than before the tests." He added: "I do not presume to speak for you or to tell you what to decide."
Indian government officials have often chided the Clinton administration for what it calls its hypocrisy in telling another nation to give up nuclear weapons when the United States maintains a vast arsenal.
Trying to deal with it head-on, Mr. Clinton said he was aware he was speaking on behalf of a nation that has possessed nuclear weapons for "55 years and more."
But, he said, the United States has dismantled more than 13,000 nuclear weapons since 1988, helped Russia to dismantle its nuclear weapons and agreed to an outline of a treaty with Moscow that would reduce the remaining arsenals by half.
Mr. Clinton followed his appeal on nuclear weapons with another appeal: for India to cast aside its misgivings and to take the initiative in beginning talks with Pakistan over Kashmir. "I share many of your government's concerns about the course Pakistan is taking," the president said, referring to the military government that took power in October.
But he suggested that India could afford to take the high road because unlike Pakistan, it is a democracy.
"A special opportunity" awaited India to "show its neighbors that democracy is about dialogue," he said. "It does not have to be about friendship."

HEADLINE: Oil Producers' Loan Program Falling Short On Takers

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
A federal panel designed to offer subsidized loans to independent gas and oil companies whose business suffered when prices were low has received nearly two dozen applications for loans, the Department of Commerce says.
The program, created by Congress last summer, would offer guarantees on private loans totaling as much as $500 million for qualifying oil and natural gas producers and small oil-field service companies. The government would promise to repay 85 percent of the amount borrowed, up to $10 million per company, if they failed to repay the loans themselves. 
 At the end of last month, the deadline for filing for loans, 23 applications were received by the Emergency Oil and Gas Loan Guarantee Board totaling $68,173,972. The deadline had been extended twice before February.
Charles E. Hall, the executive director of the oil and gas loan board, said the number of loans requested was "significantly lower than anticipated." The board would determine how to manage the remaining money, including the possibility of considering another round of applications later, Mr. Hall said.
The loan requests come at a time when gas and oil prices are rising sharply. The price of a barrel of crude oil was more than $30 this month, up from $12 a year ago.
"The operating dynamics are better today," Mr. Hall said, "but there are still fundamental problems entrenched in the industry. A couple of months of good oil prices are not enough to rectify the situation."
Over the last few years, hundreds of small oil and gas producers have been struggling with record levels of imports that had been hitting the market at low prices, resulting in thousands of American workers losing their jobs.
Independent oil and gas companies qualify for the loans, as outlined by the Emergency Oil and Gas Guaranteed Loan Program, if they have experienced layoffs, production losses or financial losses since the beginning of the oil import crisis, during which oil prices began to drop severely in 1997.
The goal of the program was to encourage lending to companies that could not otherwise obtain credit. All loans guaranteed under the program must be repaid in full by Dec. 31, 2010.
A similar program was also created for steel companies, and they have applied for loans worth hundreds of millions of dollars.
Scott Espenshade, the vice president of economics for the Independent Petroleum Association of America in Washington, said that more companies might have applied if less paperwork had been required.
"We are dealing with small businesses here of 20 employees or fewer, often family owned," Mr. Espenshade said. "They typically do not have this kind of financial reporting."
From December 1997 to the middle of 1999, Mr. Espenshade said, the oil and gas industry lost roughly 65,000 jobs. And despite some recovery, the industry has made up only about 7,000 of the jobs.
"This program has been good for the industry, but it is not necessarily the cure," Mr. Espenshade said. "We certainly hope that changes are made to the plan to help the industry get back on its feet."
The loan guarantee board is reviewing the applications and should have recommendations by April, Mr. Hall said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Technology Lifts Nasdaq and Pushes S.& P. Over 1,500

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
Irrepressible optimism about high-technology propelled the Nasdaq stock market to its biggest gain in almost three weeks yesterday and lifted the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index above the 1,500 mark for the first time.
But investors resumed their general disregard for smokestack and other blue-chip shares, sending the Dow Jones industrial average, down as much as 118 points at one stage. It closed with a 40.64-point loss. 
 "It is a fever that has gripped the country," said Harry Cohen, manager of the Smith Barney Appreciation Fund, referring to demand for computer and other high-technology stocks that has generated huge wealth and added urgency to the Federal Reserve's efforts to cool off the supercharged American economy so inflation remains in check.
Noting that the Fed, headed by Alan Greenspan, raised interest rates again just the day before, Mr. Cohen added: "The market is spitting in his eye."
Robert Harrington, head of listed equities trading at PaineWebber, pointed to Micron Technology as a catalyst for the latest rally in technology. It jumped 8 1/4, to 139 1/2, as investors reappraised the memory-chip company's quarterly report, which included a profit shortfall, after the market's close on Tuesday.
"The whole chip sector is just on fire," Mr. Harrington said. Intel, which climbed 5 5/8, to 144 1/16 on turnover of 26.8 million shares, made the biggest positive contribution to all the major averages. The shares are up 75 percent so far this year.
Cisco Systems, which supplies much of the infrastructure for the Internet, jumped 333/64 , to 1441/16 , lifting its market capitalization above $500 billion and making it the first company based in California's Silicon Valley to break that ceiling. Microsoft, based in Redmond, Wash., and General Electric, based in Fairfield, Conn., are the only other companies valued above that level.
The Nasdaq composite index advanced 153.07 points, or 3.25 percent, its biggest gain since March 3. At 4,864.75, the index is up 19.6 percent so far this year but is still 3.6 percent below its peak on March 10.
The S.& P. 500 rose 6.77 points, or 0.45 percent, but that was enough to push it to 1,500.64, setting a record for the second consecutive day. For the year, the index is ahead 2.1 percent.
As for the Dow industrials, only 12 of its 30 components managed gains as the 0.37 percent loss left the average at 10,866.70, down 5.5 percent for the year.
The biggest drag came from Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing, down 47/16 , to 86, and Honeywell, down 37/16 , to 46 1/4. Coca-Cola and Exxon Mobil each lost more than 2.
While investors in technology basked in further good fortune, apparently also fueled by rumors of a settlement of the Microsoft antitrust case, some of those who concentrate on beaten-down industrial stocks took some comfort from the announcement of a second buyout of such a company in two days.
An investment group led by the management of U.S. Can offered to buy the maker of plastic and steel containers for $21 a share and the stock leaped 415/16 , to 1913/16 . Cameron Ashley Building Products was bid for on Tuesday.
Values have fallen so far that they invite takeover or privatization, said Andrew M. Brooks, a top trader at T. Rowe Price.
Nasdaq's national market industrial index surged 3.9 percent yesterday, an exceptionally strong performance but still far less than the 9.2 percent surge for Philadelphia's index of semiconductor stocks or one comprised of biotechnology companies. The Wilshire 5000 gained 1.2 percent.
On the New York Stock Exchange, volume edged up to 1.08 billion shares; 1,661 stocks rose, and 1,338 fell. There were 69 new 52-week highs and 40 new lows.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Treasury Prices Rise
 (By Reuters) -- Long-term Treasury bond prices rose modestly yesterday, their eighth consecutive session of gains, as investors took advantage of attractive yields after the Federal Reserve raised short-term rates on Tuesday and hinted that incremental rate increases would continue.
Five-year and 10-year notes saw the most activity, traders said, while the 30-year bond rose 2/32 , to 1033/32 . Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.96 percent from 5.97 percent.
"All in all, it was a day of relief following the F.O.M.C. meeting from yesterday," said Charles Reinhard, market strategist at ABN Amro. He was referring to the Federal Open Market Committee, the Fed's monetary policy panel, which increased the federal funds target rate a quarter percentage point, to 6 percent, and lifted the discount rate the same amount, to 5.5 percent.

SECTION: Section C; Page 4; Column 3; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 866 words

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
I.L.O., Long in Eclipse, Regains Some Prominence

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, March 22

 BODY:
Marginalized by decades of obscure work and a lack of enforcement power, the International Labor Organization has recently gained some renewed prominence for a possible future role in helping police the way nations protect workers' rights.
In the rush of public concern over globalization, the organization, a United Nations specialized agency, has found that its work to promote basic labor rights in all countries is suddenly relevant. Part of the reason is a debate in both the rich and poor nations over whether minimum labor standards can or should be linked to trade. 
 And unions are pressing for stronger worker protection in global trade pacts, an idea resisted by developing countries.
The debate comes as the organization is striving to change under new leadership. The agency is also trying to improve ties to the United States, which once considered it a toothless and irrelevant bureaucracy that ignored Soviet bloc labor violations. Indeed, the I.L.O. has been out of the limelight for so long that scholars may be among the few who recall that it won a Nobel Prize in 1969 for its work on labor injustices.
Juan Somavia, a Chilean diplomat elected a year ago to run the labor agency, has promised to modernize its bureaucracy -- one so steeped in old ways that a significant part of its staff cannot use a computer.
At the same time, the Clinton administration has been giving the agency significant financing for its campaigns against child labor and for basic workers' rights. Last spring, Mr. Clinton became the first American president to address the I.L.O. annual meeting in Geneva.
"With globalization, its essential mandate has come into prominence," said Andrew Samet, the top official in the Labor Department on international labor matters.
Just a few days ago, the I.L.O. work to curb child labor was underlined as Mr. Clinton visited Bangladesh, a country once notorious for the number of young children toiling in its garment industry. I.L.O. monitors have helped Bangladeshi authorities remove thousands of children from garment sweatshops in recent years, and Mr. Clinton announced $8.6 million in aid to Bangladesh to help expand the effort.
The I.L.O. sets guidelines covering areas that include female workers, working hours and migrant workers. Governments, workers and employers have equal voices in how the guidelines are formulated.
Critics say this structure is ineffective because it relies on consensus among three often-competing groups. "The I.L.O. may have the competence, but its procedures are a bit cumbersome and slow," said Giampiero Alhadeff, head of Solidar, a Brussels-based alliance of nongovernmental organizations associated with the trade union movement.
Mr. Somavia says he wants to update the agency, which has a two-year budget of $481 million. Friendly and energetic, Mr. Somavia walks through the agency's Geneva headquarters and pops unannounced into offices, a contrast with his predecessors' formal style. But he faces a work force of 2,200, with entrenched rights; dismissals are nearly impossible and layoffs are costly.
In the labor-standards area, the organization's biggest weakness is a lack of enforcement power. It can examine compliance by its 174 member countries but has no authority to punish violators. A case in point is Myanmar, formerly Burma. Opponents of the government contend it uses 800,000 forced laborers on public works and army projects. Last year, the I.L.O. barred Myanmar from technical assistance and agency meetings. But the country cannot be expelled or fined.
Mr. Somavia, interviewed recently in his office, said penalties were not the point. "I would not be in agreement that unless you have them, there is nothing you can do," he said. Mr. Somavia argued that labor conventions and treaties have an important role. "When countries ratify such conventions, they become national law and are enforceable in national courts," he said.
The strength of the I.L.O. is that it "can mobilize shame against a country," said Dan Cunniah of the International Confederation of Free Trade Unions. But to be effective, he said, the agency needs stronger tools against violators. Proposals to tie I.L.O. standards to trade have been floated over the last few years, but advocates are reluctant to push them too aggressively. They want to avoid alienating developing countries that fear enforcement of labor standards because it would hurt their competitive advantage.
Labor standards, argued Pakistan's trade negotiator, Munir Akram, are "a new protectionism" that threaten to "bedevil all future trade negotiations."
Under a possible compromise, the I.L.O. and the World Trade Organization, which does have some enforcement power, would share jurisdiction over such labor issues. American officials have urged a joint committee to examine how international trade relates to basic labor standards -- that would mean prohibitions on child labor and forced labor, and the right of workers to form unions and bargain collectively. "The growing reality," Mr. Somavia said, "is that a global economy needs a social floor and that can be found in the work the I.L.O. has done previously."

SECTION: Section A; Page 24; Column 3; National Desk 

LENGTH: 621 words

HEADLINE: Campaign Memo;
Gore, Mum on Reform, Raises $700,000

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 22

 BODY:
Perhaps it was best not to call attention to the incongruity. Vice President Al Gore has been trumpeting his "passion" for overhauling the campaign finance system, even while scooping up money and emerging from the primary season as the richest candidate in the race.
But today, while holding perhaps his most successful fund-raising session, he refrained entirely from mentioning his newfound "priority" of eliminating the large, unregulated contributions known as soft money. 
 It might have been a tad awkward had he made that pitch. Here he was in the St. Regis Hotel, sitting down to two lunches in adjacent rooms and taking in more than $700,000 from about 75 people for the Democratic National Committee in one hour.
Over the next two days, with a lunch in Cincinnati, two receptions in Detroit and two in Houston, Mr. Gore is expected to raise at least $1 million more for the party, which has a goal of $100 million this year.
Rather than tell his listeners that he did not want their money, Mr. Gore told them how well the economy is doing. The booming economy, or "unprecedented prosperity," as he calls it, has been his central theme for months, and he devoted his comments today to underscoring how the Clinton-Gore administration had retrieved the nation from what he has called the "mess" of the "Bush-Quayle recession."
He also gave an audition of sorts to one of the people who has been mentioned as a potential running mate, Senator Evan Bayh of Indiana, the 45-year-old freshman who, like Mr. Gore, is the relatively centrist son of a relatively liberal senator and who grew up mostly in Washington.
Mr. Bayh is honorary chairman of the Democratic Business Council, which is made up of about 100 business leaders who give at least $15,000 a year to the party. The group sponsored today's lunches.
Mr. Bayh introduced Mr. Gore, calling him "one of the principal architects of this economic renaissance" and hailing him for his "courage" on fiscal management, in favor of free trade and in favor of overhauling the welfare system.
"What this election really boils down to," Mr. Bayh said, "is, in the small hours of the night when the chips are down, while America may be sleeping, the stakes are high in the White House -- who do you trust?"
Mr. Gore took the microphone and said, "Evan makes a great speech, doesn't he?" as the knowing audience chuckled. Mr. Gore went on to praise Mr. Bayh's record as governor of Indiana and called him a national leader on fiscal responsibility and education reform.
Later, Mr. Bayh demurred when asked if he felt he was trying out for the part. But he did suggest that he has been thinking about what is involved in a national campaign.
"It does take a lot of energy," he said. "I remember from my father's run for the presidency in 1976, I took a semester off from Indiana University and went to Iowa and New Hampshire. And as I recall, it's almost as much of a physical endurance contest as anything else, and you've got to have a certain amount of stamina. When you're dog tired, you have to be able to still think quickly and speak coherently."
Among those in attendance at the fund-raiser were Terry McAuliffe, President Clinton's fund-raiser in chief; Mitchell Delk, an executive at Freddie Mac; James Free, president of the Smith-Free Group; Cliff Hudson, president of the Sonic Corporation; Justin W. Dart Jr., the industrialist and advocate for people with disabilities; John Hechinger, retired co-chairman of the Hechinger home-supply stores; Pepper English, executive director of BellSouth Corporation; Trish Vradenburg, a freelance writer, and Jeff Modisett, former attorney general of Indiana and now executive director of TechNet.

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 4; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1756 words

HEADLINE: Gentlemen, Merge Your Manufacturers;
Consolidation Hits on Virtually All Cylinders

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER 

DATELINE: DETROIT, March 22

 BODY:
The consolidation of the global auto industry has reached a full-throttle roar as automakers around the world respond to the changing economics of the business.
The list of companies partly or entirely acquired by other manufacturers in the last two years was impressive even before the frenzy of the last two weeks: Chrysler, Volvo Cars, Nissan, Saab, Fuji Heavy Industries, Suzuki, Daihatsu, Lamborghini, Bugatti, Bentley and Rolls-Royce. Since the beginning of last week, General Motors has agreed to buy a fifth of Fiat; Ford Motor has agreed to buy Land Rover from BMW; and DaimlerChrysler has moved close to taking a one-third stake in Mitsubishi Motors. Daewoo and Samsung are both up for sale in Korea, with deals likely later this year. 
 The consolidation, which is forcing consumers to choose from an ever-dwindling number of automotive groups, is driven by three broad trends: strong brands are increasingly important; manufacturers need to enter difficult markets; the cost of technology keeps rising.
Though the strategies of the leading manufacturers sometimes overlap, Ford and Volkswagen have mainly tried to acquire internationally known brands; DaimlerChrysler and Renault, of France, have mainly sought to enter new markets like Japan and Korea; and G.M. has mainly pursued ways to acquire new technology and parts more cheaply.
Some independent automakers are being driven into the arms of rivals by financial distress, as in the case of Nissan and Mitsubishi, but more are compelled to act by the steeply rising cost of technology, particularly for developing new, low-pollution engines and alternative propulsion sources like fuel cells. Automakers that cannot afford to develop vehicles with cleaner engines, better performance on the road and improved safety features risk being shut out of the European, United States and Japanese markets, either by regulation or by competition from cars designed by more financially solid rivals.
Though big automakers have long wanted to acquire their smaller rivals, only recently have many smaller companies been interested in deals as they face rising technology costs, said Alan G. Perriton, the president of G.M. Korea and G.M.'s executive in charge of new business alliances in the Asia-Pacific region. Until recently, among smaller companies "there was a greater sense of, 'I could do this myself and in my own fiefdom,' " Mr. Perriton said. "That has come home to a sense of reality, that you can't do that."
Higher gasoline prices have also made smaller manufacturers slightly more attractive because they tend to be strong in small, fuel-efficient cars.
Nine years of economic stagnation and recession have turned most of Japan's once proud automakers into takeover targets, rather than acquirers. Two exceptions, Honda and Toyota, have stayed financially sound through their robust performances in the United States but have for the most part shied away from international deals for fear of cultural clashes.
Vibrant economies. meanwhile, have given manufacturers with most of their sales in Europe and the United States the financial means to lead the consolidation. Executives at these manufacturers deny, however, that the simple pursuit of ever greater size is what motivates their deals.
"We think the consolidation is inevitable," said Jacques A. Nasser, chief executive at Ford. "It isn't about getting bigger -- that is not why we do it -- because it is about being better and quicker and making sure that what we're doing fits into an overall strategy that makes sense."
Consumer advocates have been watching the consolidation with varying degrees of wariness, while expressing concern that the biggest remaining companies not merge with each other.
Jack Gillis, the auto expert at the Consumer Federation of America, said that with so much competition among divisions at each automaker, as well as competition among different automakers, there was little opportunity for raising prices beyond what the costs justified. Ford's acquisitions of Jaguar and Volvo, for instance, have benefited consumers over all, he said, by allowing Ford to improve Jaguar's quality and to adopt Volvo's safety technologies across a much wider range of vehicles.
"The consolidation we've seen in the auto industry in the last year and a half is positive for the consumer," Mr. Gillis said. "If it continues, however, we may need to be concerned about the creation of some mini-monopolies."
But AAA, formerly the American Automobile Association, has worried that car buyers might end up paying for today's mergers with higher sticker prices for blandly similar cars. "It really dilutes creativity and presents a temptation to raise prices," said David Van Sickle, director of automotive and consumer information for AAA, which has 42 million members.
Ford and Volkswagen, which used to share reputations for inexpensive, even utilitarian cars, have pursued independent but strikingly similar strategies. Both have sought to escape the narrow profit margins and overcapacity of the mass market by moving upmarket.
They are buying luxury brands -- Volvo, Jaguar, Land Rover and Aston Martin for Ford, and Bentley, Bugatti and Lamborghini for Volkswagen. And they have tried to expand sales and reduce costs for these brands by investing heavily to increase production and by combining orders with other divisions for deep discounts from auto parts suppliers. Ford, for instance, is quadrupling sales of Jaguar cars through such steps as introducing the S-Type, which is based on the same underbody as the new Lincoln LS. The S-Type sells for $43,000 to $48,600, much less than other Jaguar models.
DaimlerChrysler and Renault have stressed instead the need for geographical diversity, mainly to limit their exposure if Europe ever suffers the kind of prolonged recession that Japan has endured. Daimler-Benz made itself a huge player overnight in the United States market by buying the Chrysler Corporation. It may be about to do the same in Japan if, as expected, it buys a third of Mitsubishi; the Japanese company's board gave its president broad authority today to negotiate a foreign alliance for the company.
Renault has made itself a big player in Japan and has indirectly re-entered the United States market by taking what has turned out to be a controlling stake in Nissan. Now Renault is seeking to buy Korea's insolvent Samsung Motors, which produces a Nissan-designed car at a Nissan-designed factory in South Korea and would allow Renault and Nissan to compete in Korea's virtually closed market.
"The only way to get into the Korean market is to become a Korean manufacturer," said Louis Schweitzer, chief executive at Renault.
G.M., a company run by finance executives more than marketers since its formation in 1908, has characteristically looked for ways to use corporate alliances less for marketing than for reducing expenses, particularly the soaring cost of engines, transmissions and other sophisticated pieces of machinery. As a result of this strategy, of the five big automakers leading the consolidation, G.M. is the only one motivated by the same rising technology costs that are causing smaller automakers to want to be acquired.
Some of the biggest economies of scale are found these days in engine production. Assembly plants tend to become too big to manage efficiently if they produce more than 250,000 or 300,000 automobiles a year. But engine factories are designed to churn out 500,000 or more engines a year.
With engines accounting for a tenth of the cost of a vehicle, part of Fiat's appeal for G.M. was its unusually efficient, highly automated engine factories, which will now produce engines for G.M., too. G.M. also surprised its main technology partner, Toyota, by agreeing this winter to buy certain low-pollution V-6 engines from Honda, which makes better engines at lower cost than practically any other company in the world.
"It is a much less expensive strategy to acquire, when technology is available, than to develop it yourself," said Mr. Perriton of G.M.
Building engines at a competitive cost depends not just on having immense, highly automated factories but also on spreading the research and development costs across as many vehicles as possible. These research costs are now soaring, partly because governments are imposing much tighter tailpipe emissions standards.
Family automobiles in the 1950's, for example, produced three or four grams a mile of smog-causing nitrogen oxides. To keep ahead of the rising number of miles driven, United States regulators have required that large sport utility vehicles emit only 1.1 grams a mile in the 2001 model year and that cars emit only 0.2 gram -- a difficult task that automakers struggled to accomplish. But in December, President Clinton signed a new rule that all family vehicles, cars and sport utilities be limited to just 0.07 gram a mile by the 2009 model year -- a herculean task.
Most easy gains -- from simply cleaning the exhaust by adding catalytic converters and other such technologies -- have already been made. So, manufacturers are now working on sophisticated, computerized systems for managing engine performance and fuel flow, with the goal of making the exhaust much cleaner even before it goes into the catalytic converter. Other governments around the world are following the United States example of ever stricter regulations.
At the same time, new propulsion technologies like fuel cells are starting to show so much promise that auto executives are compelled to invest huge sums. Such are the costs of this research that the biggest automakers have already formed research alliances. G.M. is allied with Toyota, and Ford has formed a partnership with DaimlerChrysler and Ballard Power Systems Inc., a fuel cell company in Vancouver, British Columbia. The existence of huge research blocs makes the future even murkier for relatively small, family- controlled companies like BMW and Peugeot, both of which are frequently cited as possible targets for acquisitions.
Even the proudest, most independent companies, including those that have resisted marketing alliances, have acknowledged that they cannot go it alone in responding to environmental regulations and technological changes. "Environmentally friendly cars will soon cease to be optional," Fujio Cho, president of Toyota, said in an interview. "The costs of developing environmental technologies are well beyond the reach of any single company."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Mexico to Raise Oil Output, but Tells U.S. Not to Be Pushy

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON 

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, March 22

 BODY:
Joining the frenetic jockeying before an oil producers' meeting next week, Energy Minister Luis Tellez said today that Mexico had decided on an oil production increase of less than 325,000 barrels a day starting in April.
Picking his words carefully, Mr. Tellez cautioned the United States not to be too blunt in pressing the oil nations for increases in output, warning that heavy lobbying could backfire by stirring nationalist political opposition. "The big players of the oil market have already said there needs to be more oil," Mr. Tellez said. "The message has gotten through. The facts are there. I think a proper decision will be taken." 
 Some American lawmakers -- their constituents paying soaring prices for home heating oil and facing the prospect of continued steep gasoline prices -- have sought to press the producers to pump more oil. Senior members of Congress have called on the Clinton administration to take antitrust action against the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
Mr. Tellez said President Clinton had "achieved a very fine balance" with his relatively mild suggestions to speed up production.
Since Mexico is not a member of OPEC, Mr. Tellez said he would not attend its oil ministers' meeting that begins on Monday in Vienna, but would send a deputy. He has been on the phone in recent days, telling many of his counterparts that Mexico has decided to raise output and encouraging them to do the same.
Mexico will disclose the final figures for its increase as soon as OPEC makes it announcement. Starting in March 1998, when demand was lagging and prices down, Mexico responded with cutbacks that amounted over time to 325,000 barrels a day. The reductions were part of an agreement with Saudi Arabia and Venezuela that expires on April 1. Mr. Tellez said the new increase would not completely erase that cutback. Mexico, the world's fifth-largest oil producer, now pumps 2.9 million barrels a day.
With a presidential campaign under way in this country, the government's opponents have accused Mr. Tellez of deferring to the United States and sacrificing Mexican interests by favoring larger supplies of oil to bring down prices. A newspaper cartoon depicted him as receiving credentials as "the second ambassador from the United States."
But Mr. Tellez argued that continued high prices could slow the world economy and eventually depress growth in Mexico. "We are most interested in having a dynamic world economy," he said, adding: "What we want is a stable, profitable price. For that, we need a stable supply of oil."
A government poll shows that most Mexicans, despite their strong patriotic attachment to the nationalized oil industry, agree with him. In a nationwide survey, 75 percent approved of raising production to bring down prices.
In December 1998, Mexico was getting less than $8 a barrel for its crude oil. Today, after price increases powered by OPEC's cutbacks as well as the continued economic boom in the United States and the rebound of some Asian nations, Mexican oil is selling at $24.26.
