HEADLINE: Gas Prices Are Rising, but Not the Tempers, Yet

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
This is not the gasoline shortage of the 70's.
True, the per-gallon cost has been going up so fast that the price placards at the curb seem to flip over as fast as the digital readout on the pump. A gallon of regular in the New York metropolitan region cost an average of $1.44 last month, up from $1.06 last year. Prices in the city itself are even higher. 
 Some bus and courier companies have applied surcharges to compensate. Some motorists are buying regular instead of premium, or using the car only at night or taking public transportation to work. But no one, it seems, is going out of business.
And instead of the fistfights and fender-benders that marked the long gas lines of the early 70's, drivers are grumbling but bearing it. After all, at least there's plenty of gas to buy.
But some people are cutting back.
Mary Szumski, a cabdriver from Brooklyn, limits herself to $12 worth of premium at a time for her personal car, a gas-guzzling 1981 Jaguar, and rides the bus when she goes to Manhattan to shop. But she is not even thinking about getting a more efficient car. Like many people, she does not expect the high prices to last more than a few months.
"It's only for a short time, so it's O.K.," she said as she pumped $1.79-a-gallon premium gas into her tank at a station in Red Hook, Brooklyn. "And you've got to pay it. You have no choice."
Dmitri Serebryakov, a limousine driver from Brooklyn, said that having to pay more to fill up twice a day "hits me right in the pocket" since he has to absorb his fuel costs. So whenever he is in New Jersey, where gas prices are lower than in New York, he makes a point of gassing up.
But in southern New Jersey, Ed Crane, of Medford, said he was commuting to Philadelphia only in his Ford Taurus. "Our other car is an S.U.V.," he said, "and we don't take that out at all these days because of the prices."
If the spike in prices does indeed prove brief, the local economy is not expected to suffer seriously, forecasters say. Most expect prices to rise to as much as $2 a gallon by summer and then begin dropping by fall.
"As long as it doesn't seem as if prices are going to continue to go up," said David Wyss, the chief economist at the market forecasting arm of Standard & Poor's, "we're in good shape."
Ken Goldstein, an economist at the Conference Board, a nonprofit research organization, said most businesses did not alter their strategy based on short spurts of price increases. "Clearly, there are places where the impact is more immediate," he said, "but across the board, I don't see a big, big change out there."
Bravo Messenger Service in Teaneck, N.J., is one of the businesses that has been seriously affected, and its customers now pay a 5 percent surcharge. "Most of them are pretty good about it," said Jeff Levy. The higher fuel costs have actually been good for business, Mr. Levy said, because people are more likely to consider hiring his service for office errands.
For more than a month, Essex County commuters traveling on the DeCamp Bus Lines have been charged 30 cents more per ride because of the rise in diesel fuel costs. But diesel prices, which are tied to the demand for home heating oil, are beginning to decline. If that trend continues, said Gary P. Pard, a vice president at DeCamp, the surcharge may be eliminated by April 30.
But there will be no surcharge -- or service reduction -- on buses operated by the Metropolitan Transportation Authority, which expects to spend an extra $9.2 million on diesel fuel this year, said Albert W. O'Leary, an authority spokesman. Though unwelcome, the additional expense is a relatively small part of the agency's $3 billion operating budget, he pointed out.
As for cabs, the New York City Taxi and Limousine Commission is in the "initial stages" of examining whether a surcharge is warranted, said Diane McGrath McKechnie, the commission chairwoman.
Usually, when delivery costs go up, the prices of goods and services also go up. But John L. Wieting, the federal Bureau of Labor Statistics' regional commissioner for the New York metropolitan region, said there was no indication that other prices were rising -- not so far, at least. "We have yet to see a surge in prices outside the energy sector," he said.
Mr. Wieting speculated that many businesses might be reluctant to pass on the costs in so competitive a marketplace. "There's a great deal of resistance on the part of consumers to higher prices," he said.
And there's no question that despite the robust economy, many people will go out of their way for a bargain. The Wawa market on Route 70 and Eayerstown Road in Medford, N.J., has been mobbed ever since a local news program reported that it had the lowest prices in Burlington County, said Jen Garron, the manager. "It just gets a little more hectic every day," she said.
In New York, officials said, the citywide average for a gallon of regular gasoline is up to $1.65. But they urged consumers to shop around, since prices vary. According to a survey by the Department of Consumer Affairs, the Gasland station at 425 Vanderbilt Avenue on Staten Island charges $1.57 a gallon for regular gasoline, the lowest in the city. (The highest is $1.74 at the Mobil station at 1132 York Avenue, in Manhattan.)
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has seized on surging gas prices as a major theme for his Senate campaign, said "ivory tower" economists have underestimated their effect.
"They don't have to pay the bills," he said.

HEADLINE: New Systems for Controllers May Ease Air Traffic Woes

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

DATELINE: MEMPHIS, March 16

 BODY:
A red warning on a screen told an air traffic controller here that two west-bound passenger jets, flying 100 miles apart over Tennessee and Alabama, were on courses that would intersect 250 miles ahead, setting up a possible collision over Arkansas.
Jim Ashe, a flight controller in Memphis, quickly set a new course for American Airlines 843, ensuring that it would get no closer than five miles to United 1801 -- and, as a bonus, shortening its route. The warning turned from red to yellow. 
 It might seem that in the digital age such computerized procedures to pre-empt conflicts would be routine. But they are not. Until now, a controller would not have detected collision courses until two planes were already in the same narrow sector, and he would quickly have had to bark orders to the pilots.
But the new computerized system used by Mr. Ashe at the Memphis Air Route Traffic Control Center enables a controller to study a much broader swath of sky and to test new routes with a few clicks of a mouse.
As the Federal Aviation Administration and the airlines prepare, with some dread, for another busy summer when there are more planes in the sky and more thunderstorms to skirt, they are counting on this new system and similar measures being introduced gradually around the country to help avoid the widespread problems and delays of last summer.
Potential collisions pop up dozens of times in an air traffic controller's shift. "Memphis is like the corner of Hollywood and Vine; it's all happening here," said Rick DeSantis, Mr. Ashe's partner, who was running a sector called Conway High. Traffic for Houston, Dallas, Atlanta and Denver continually crisscrossed overhead, seeking higher altitudes for better fuel economy or lower ones to avoid turbulence, and always asking for more direct routes.
"This is a tough one," Mr. Ashe said as he studied the intersecting routes of the American Airlines jet bound for the Dallas-Fort Worth airport from Cleveland and the United plane headed to Denver from Atlanta. But it seemed simple as he used the mouse and keyboard.
The F.A.A. sees the prototype of the software Mr. Ashe was using, called Conflict Probe, as the beginning of a revolution and a contrast to the agency's troubled modernization efforts.
Earlier this month, Congress passed a $40 billion, three-year aviation investment bill, and President Clinton announced a new program of collaboration among the airlines and the F.A.A. to reduce delays.
But the real hope for decongesting the system, experts say, is in software tools like Conflict Probe.
The goal is to have all five computer programs in place by 2002, by which time, if it does not get help, "the system will have serious constraints" and will "be near gridlock," said Charles Keegan, director of Free Flight, the F.A.A. effort that developed the software.
Free Flight is a break from the last 40 years of air traffic control, during which planes have been dispatched like trains, following fixed tracks through the sky and sometimes, impossible though it seems, running short of space up there.
Under Free Flight, the same kinds of advanced computers that already let airlines list 30 different fares for seats on the same plane or let a pilot fly thousands of miles with a few keystrokes are coming to the air traffic control business. The F.A.A. is now using computers to choreograph planes, instead of to simply organize data about them. Building radar mosaics and attaching data tags to each blip, the controllers know which plane is which and can now organize the traffic itself.
After wasting hundreds of millions of dollars on failed modernization projects that would have replaced the basic air traffic tools, the agency is having more success with its Free Flight strategy, which uses stand-alone systems that represent more manageable technological leaps.
The new software, for example, gathers data from the main air traffic control computers, but does not use the processing power of the computers themselves, which is already fully taxed. It does something no human could manage: it looks at hundreds or even thousands of flights and, like a master chess player, figures out where each will be much later in the game.
For years, the F.A.A. has made the system simple enough for controllers to handle by chopping it into smaller and smaller sectors. The computer can assemble the big picture by looking across many sectors.
The system allows corrections much earlier in a flight path, which means that turns are gentler and altitude changes are less frequent, with the plane staying closer to the altitude that is optimum for fuel efficiency. It may resolve a conflict by calculating that one plane should slow down by 10 or 20 knots, something controllers cannot often calculate in their heads with sufficient precision to prevent a conflict.
On average, the system at the Memphis center shortens the route of each airplane by about 1 mile, saving some 6,000 miles a day.
By the end of 2002, the system will be installed in another 7 of the 19 other Air Route Traffic Control Centers around the country, F.A.A. officials say.
The agency says a system for managing runway use will also soon be expanded beyond its use in the Dallas-Fort Worth area. The Dallas-Fort Worth airport has four runways, each controlled by a different controller. The system, called Passive Final Approach Spacing Tool, recommends which planes should go to which runways, sorting them by size and other characteristics so they can get as close as is safe.
With the spacing tool, "you don't miss assigning a turn to someone because you are worrying where the seventh guy in line is going to have to go with a runway assignment," said Bill Blackmer, safety and technology representative at the National Air Traffic Controllers Association. "It buys the controller time," he said. "A lack of time is our enemy."
The new system has allowed controllers to land an extra two planes during each of the 12 rush periods at Dallas-Fort Worth.
A related system, the Traffic Management Adviser, figures out how to merge airplanes arriving from three or four different directions into a single line that is evenly spaced.
Another new tool tells an airline what everyone wants to know: exactly when is a flight going to arrive? The question is important for the airlines because if the delay is too long, the plane will be diverted to another airport. Sometimes the delay turns out to be manageable but the airline does not know that, so it diverts because of uncertainty.
The last system, called Collaborative Decision Making, announced by Mr. Clinton on March 10, involves conference calls every two hours among the F.A.A. and the airlines.
But in Conway High, a sector which tracks planes at altitudes from 24,000 to 34,000 feet, the route adjustment Mr. Ashe had made with Conflict Probe went sour. The American plane picked up a stronger tailwind than expected, and the warning turned red again. So Mr. DeSantis turned the United plane by 20 degrees to the right, to make it cross well behind the other flight's path. Without the early intervention, he said, he would have had to turn the United plane by 40 degrees.
Then the two controllers used the new software to determine that they could direct the United plane straight to Garden City, Kan., saving a left turn and cutting several minutes off the flight. The system also informed all the other controllers who needed to know.
What is more, by evaluating whether the system can accommodate the altitude and route changes pilots ask for, the new procedures have a side benefit of spreading out the traffic and reducing conflicts.
This is essential to keep up with all the flights, said Mr. Ashe, who added that traffic handled by Memphis had roughly doubled in the last 15 years.
Mr. Ashe, who was appointed by his union to help develop the new tool, said that while some controllers were initially reluctant to use it, "now, people don't want to do without it."
And increasingly they will need it. "The aircraft numbers are going to go up, regardless," Mr. Ashe said.

HEADLINE: Essay;
Saddam's Sudan?

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
What do you do with a disturbing national security tip from a usually reliable source? You check it out, of course, with intelligence operatives who have no ax to grind.
But what do you do when those analysts say that they pondered the report at interagency meetings and doubt its accuracy -- but it could be true and bears watching? All I can do is pass along the disputed report with appropriate caveats. 
 It was first hinted at six months ago in a paragraph by the well-connected Bill Gertz of The Washington Times: "A Pentagon intelligence agency reported earlier this month that North Korea offered to sell the government of Sudan an entire factory for assembling Scud missiles."
That didn't seem to add up, because Sudan is nearly broke and doesn't need long-range missiles to fight its civil war. Where would the money be found to finance the missile factory, and who in that area wants the Scuds?
Enter Amir Rashid, Iraq's oil minister and Saddam Hussein's chief procurer of ballistic missiles.
Two years ago, I'm told, Rashid paid a secret visit to Pyongyang and saw North Korea's missile marketer, Chon Byong-Ho. Saddam's man also visited the Chang Gwang Sinyong Corporation, a key world source of illicit arms.
Topic A was Scuds, many of which were secreted by Iraq in Sudan to escape U.N. detection. A year later, Iraq's chief engineer, Ra'ad Ismail Jamil, received a North Korean delegation in Baghdad.
Only five weeks ago, says my informant, two delegations arrived in Khartoum, capital of Sudan. One was a group of North Korean technical experts; the other was a military research mission from Baghdad.
Their project? The Koreans are said to be working on building a ballistic-missile plant near Khartoum, with Iraqi financing of $475 million. Pyongyang gets a big chunk of that for turnkey construction and expert staffing; Khartoum a smaller percentage for acting as cutout, site protector and smuggler; and Baghdad gets its old missiles refurbished and new, longer-range missiles built.
If true, such conspiracy among three rogue nations would spell big trouble. So I rattled some American intelligence cages; had they heard of this three-pariah missile deal?
All had. The story (without the recent Khartoum meeting) has been bruited about for months, including the $475 million figure. It was the subject of two interagency meetings; the White House was briefed.
The current U.S. assessment is that any Iraqi-financed missile factory "cannot be confirmed," although there is no doubt that North Korea has been peddling arms in Sudan. "The report is impossible to stamp out," says a frustrated doubter. Another derogates the story that won't go away as "rumint" -- merely rumored intelligence.
Their logical reason for skepticism is that Sudan is heavily infiltrated by Iranian operatives, who might sabotage or publicize any Iraqi plant. Another is that newly secure Pyongyang is now in the midst of a charm offensive, which will soon include the first visit to Washington by a high-level diplomat since the end of the Korean War. This huge weapons deal would run counter to that opening.
On the other hand, there is reason for skepticism about the spookery's skepticism. Eighteen months ago, on indirect evidence later questioned, President Clinton ordered a cruise missile attack at the Al Shifa pharmaceutical plant. Our spies may now be super-cautious.
On the third hand, I am inclined to take the rumint seriously because this method of outsourcing his secret weapons development to a rogue-state neighbor so neatly fits Saddam Hussein's interest. Also, if true, a secret Sudanese missile plant financed by Iraqi oil sales would argue cogently against efforts to appease Saddam by lifting economic sanctions, so avidly desired by the Jiang-Putin-Chirac cabal at the U.N.
Wait -- this just in. Porter Goss, chairman of the Permanent House Select Committee on Intelligence, is willing to go on the record: "We have been concerned with the development of weapons of mass destruction and their delivery systems in Sudan, as well as Sudan's ties with North Korea. The matter is receiving our attention."

 BODY:

S.& P. 500 Tops 1,500 On Appetite for Technology
Optimism about high technology lifted the Nasdaq composite index 153.07 points, or 3.25 percent, to 4,864.75, its biggest gain in almost three weeks, and the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index rose above the 1,500 mark for the first time, closing at 1,500.64, up 6.77 points.
But investors resumed their general disregard for blue-chip stocks, and the Dow Jones industrial average, down as much as 118 points at one point during the session, closed with a 40.64-point loss, to 10,866.70. Page C12. 

The real proof of the power of the information technology revolution for investors can be found in the S.& P. 500, which represents a diverse set of large publicly traded companies. Three of the four most valuable companies in the index, and 17 of the top 40, are technology companies. Market Place. C13.
 
Phillips Auction House Sets Record
As the federal antitrust investigation of Sotheby's and Christie's continues, officials of Phillips, the distant third among worldwide auction houses, said that their New York business had exploded, with the house's coming spring sale setting a record. C10.
 
Air Travelers Prepare for Disruption

LENGTH: 1828 words

HEADLINE: U.S. Cracks Down on Rise In Appalachia Moonshine

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN 

DATELINE: ROCKY MOUNT, Va., March 16

 BODY:
Grinning seditiously, a prominent citizen of this Blue Ridge foothills town takes from his kitchen refrigerator an illegal gift from a moonshiner friend: a syrupy red liquor in a quart jar packed with grapelike damsonberries. He offers a taste to his visitor. It is a brandy, sweet and silky.
"Damson's the best," he says. 
 Next he selects a half-gallon jar of heart-stopping white lightning, as clear as vodka. Shaking it, he points to the "bead," or head. Bubbles that form a thick, beery bead indicate toxic contamination from sleazy stills that use old car radiators to condense the vapors from cooking and fermentation. But this bead is wafer-thin. "Look," he says. "No lead."
It might all seem a quaint act of hospitality merely appropriate to this town of 4,400 that likes to boast of being "the moonshine capital of the world," here in a southern Appalachian region that over the last two centuries has produced more moonshine than any other in America.
But to a task force of state and federal agents brought in to fight it, the illicit whiskey of Rocky Mount and the surrounding area is little other than the work of big-time criminals -- a new generation of moonshiners who in many cases have transformed the smoky little woodsmen's stills of legend and song into efficient distilleries, some capable of producing thousands of gallons of liquor a week.
The task force, applying the muscle of federal law rather than weaker state anti-moonshine statutes, made its first arrests earlier this month. Three people were charged with illegally distilling alcohol, and many more arrests are expected.
Rocky Mount is the hub of the trade, which investigators say operates here in Franklin County, in three or four nearby counties in south-central Virginia and just over the line in North Carolina.
Most of the illicit brandy is the work of exacting hobbyists, and seldom leaves the area. But moonshine whiskey, mass-produced at as much as 150 proof or even more and with little attention to health or safety, is growing as a product of interstate commerce. Even after a decade of unmatched national prosperity, resilient pockets of poverty provide ready markets -- in this case, throughout much of the East -- for a low-priced, illegal high.
Once a sideline of dirt-poor farmers who made whiskey in 50-gallon stills to get by, moonshining is now carried on here with 800-gallon stills, sometimes 5 or 10 linked like railroad cars, in a well-organized, high-profit business. Government investigators say hundreds of thousands of gallons of moonshine a year flow over the highways from Virginia and North Carolina, free of all state and federal taxes or regulatory scrutiny.
Moonshiners produce whiskey for as little as $3 a gallon, the investigators say, then package it in six-packs of gallon plastic jugs, a thicker-gauge variation of milk containers, and sell it, unlabeled, for $10 or $12 a gallon to nip joints, shot houses and the back rooms of bars in Philadelphia, Richmond, Washington and Baltimore. The bars then sell it for as little as $1 a shot, much less than the price of lawful whiskey.
Though the investigators do not know how much the moonshiners as a whole earn from their activity, the business here has grown big enough to draw a response from the Federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms.
About two decades ago, the bureau, turning more of its attention to the control of guns and explosives, largely abandoned its pursuit of untaxed liquor, an effort that had dated from the 1920's and Prohibition, when organized crime delivered vast amounts of moonshine to the nation's speakeasies. Two years ago, however, the bureau was called in by the alcoholic beverage control agencies of Virginia and North Carolina, bodies long frustrated by public tolerance of bootlegging and by local courts that treated moonshining much like speeding violations.
Together, the bureau and the two state agencies organized Operation Lightning Strike, to fight moonshiners unlike those of decades past.
"What you've seen over the years," said Bartley H. McEntire, the federal agent in charge of the investigation, "is a shift in how they operate." Rather than selling their liquor themselves, Mr. McEntire said, "these organizations use hired hands and hired transporters," or bootleggers. "They aren't your good ol' boys." Wily and resourceful, this new breed of moonshiner tends to be armed with night-vision goggles and two-way radios to help stay a jump ahead of the law.
Federal agents' past efforts to fight moonshining in cooperation with state regulators have been largely fruitless. But this time, said Sharon Burnham, assistant United States attorney in nearby Roanoke, the investigation is much broader and tougher: for the first time, federal money-laundering statutes will be used as a weapon against moonshiners.
"Under the federal liquor laws, they're facing up to five years in prison," Ms. Burnham said. "Under the money-laundering laws, they're facing up to 15 years."
In Operation Lightning Strike's first arrests, early this month, the agents charged a man with operating a 1,000-gallon still. Also seized were his two employees: a Mexican couple, both illegal immigrants who lived and worked at the site with their three young children.
Profits from moonshining can be serious money here in Franklin County, where a waning of the textile industry and a decline in tobacco and dairy production have cursed the economy. Those profits have been a boon, too, investigators say, for a few enterprising and newly land-rich families whom the government has named, though not yet charged, as leaders of the local moonshine industry.
For the most part, residents of moonshine communities see still operators as good people, said Allen G. Hudson, deputy director of the Virginia alcohol agency's Bureau of Law Enforcement. "It's an awkward situation," Mr. Hudson said. "They are good for the economy. They hire people locally and buy materials locally. We don't get a lot of cooperation, because they see them doing more good than we can do them."
William G. Davis, a former assistant United States attorney in Roanoke, is the area's leading defense lawyer for people charged with moonshining. Like many others in town, he acknowledges that illegal liquor is produced here. But the government, he says, has exaggerated the extent of it.
What is worse, Mr. Davis said, is the investigators' manner. "To me, it's the hobnail-boot approach," he said. "They're riding roughshod over people, calling them liars. They are mean."
In one instance, agents shut down the Helms Farmers' Exchange, a farm and garden business that was one of Rocky Mount's biggest retail and wholesale concerns. It was owned by Ramsey and William Helms, brothers in their 50's, and it included a warehouse two miles outside of town on busy Route 40 West and an imposing red-brick store on Main Street downtown, just a block from the county courthouse and the sheriff's office. Agents say the brothers had a sideline in moonshine supplies that dwarfed their legitimate commerce.
The government confiscated from the store and the warehouse 9,648 one-gallon jugs, 32 100-pound bags of sugar, 4 bags of rye and 14 boxes of Mason jars, and from Ramsey Helms's home a gun, radio scanners and a family photo album. Nine days after the raid, Ramsey Helms put a gun to his chest and killed himself. Since then, the agents have frozen $86,442 in William Helms's checking accounts and made a claim on 113 acres of his land, in effect a lien so that the government can sell it if Mr. Helms is charged and found guilty of ill-gotten gains.
Stripped of their money, business and personal vehicles, and livelihood, William Helms and his wife, Bonnie, are living on the charity of friends, Mr. Davis says. In answering the government's court requests to search and seize property, the Helmses told the court that all the property ultimately taken from them had come from inheritances and from income earned through legitimate commerce.
But the investigators' leading targets are 60-year-old Ralph D. Hale and several members of his family. The agents say that from 1990 through 1998, Mr. Hale and his wife, Judy, filed tax returns showing annual joint income ranging from $21,149 to $33,139. Yet, the government maintained on March 6 in an affidavit related to its request for a search warrant, Mr. Hale is the person code-named Hat Man in the journals of the Farmers' Exchange. According to the journals, Hat Man bought 17,925 100-pound bags of sugar, paying close to $700,000, and 2,710 bundles of one-gallon containers for which he paid $42,000. With the sugar, the affidavit said, he could have produced 179,250 gallons of illegal liquor, worth $1.8 million at $10 a gallon.
The Hales have also amassed many assets, including land on which illegal stills have been found. Holdings that the government has frozen are mostly in Mrs. Hale's name, with the rest in the names of family members other than Mr. Hale. They include nearly 400 acres worth $681,900, $59,405 in mutual fund accounts and $54,991 in bank accounts.
 Mr. Hale, reached by telephone on Monday, declined to comment.
Though choosing not to comment on those figures, Mr. Davis, who expects to represent the Hales in any criminal case, said, "A whole lot of that information" is "incorrect." The allegations attempt to portray the Hales as "monsters," he said, "and it's not true."
In fact, in the minds of some, even admitted moonshiners are far from monsters, instead little more than a link to a proud tradition. Even as the government crackdown continues, Rocky Mount's business people are divided over whether to shun or celebrate the area's historic bond with moonshine. Brian G. Duvall, executive director of the Franklin County Chamber of Commerce, says one contingent has proposed building a moonshine museum and even producing boutique liquor, in a legal still.
Ultimately, though, "we need to get away from it," said David Furrow, a prominent lawyer here. "It would be nicer if it were in the past, and we could say we used to be the moonshine capital of the world."
 
Whatever the Word, It's Against the Law
Hardscrabble farmers and mountaineers, primarily in the forested hills of lower Appalachia, have been making whiskey illegally since the earliest days of the Republic, when the government began taxing it.
Tax collectors call this illegal whiskey non-tax-paid liquor. Those who produce and consume it call it white lightning, rotgut, skull cracker, happy Sally or stump, but most often moonshine.
Of unknown authorship, the word "moonshine" has applied for more than two centuries to whiskey produced in the light of the moon, out of sight of government agents.
The Oxford English Dictionary traces its etymology to 1785, citing a reference that says, "The white brandy smuggled on the coasts of Kent and Sussex is called moonshine."

HEADLINE: No More 'Pssst!' For Iranian Rugs, But Who Cares?

BYLINE: By CHRISTIE BROWN 

 BODY:
THE 13-year-old import embargo on Iranian rugs is lifting, but that doesn't excite anyone at the Bloomingdale's store in Manhattan.
"Embargo?" said a rug salesman, referring to an open secret at department stores nationwide. "We've always had plenty. We buy them from two vendors on 34th Street." Ranging from $500 to $50,000, brand-new Iranian rugs -- "we just got a shipment last week," he said -- are even on sale this week. 
 Smuggled carpets from Iran have been pouring into the country ever since the United States imposed a ban on Iranian products in 1987 in response to clashes in the Persian Gulf. They come mainly from Canada, with bogus paperwork to pass customs. "The quantity of Iranian carpets coming into this country will not change," said Leslie Stroh, publisher of Rug News, a trade paper in New York. "Just the statistics will. Yesterday they were smuggled rugs; tomorrow they'll be 'legally entered' rugs."
The government's decision to restore legal access to Iran's fabled rug market -- whose time-honored traditions have defined both connoisseurship and opulence -- is mostly drawing yawns all around. One big reason, aside from the porousness of the American border, is that while Iran long dominated the industry, it has spent the last 13 years sitting in the penalty box. In the interim, India, Pakistan, Turkey, China and Egypt have increased production of their handmade rugs, which are now often considered better than Iran's. "The whole business has flip-flopped," said Graham Head, president of ABC Carpet & Home in New York. "The goal of Indian carpet makers 15 years ago was to look like the Persians. Now Iran's goal is to copy the Indian carpets."
Prices have reversed position as well. As an example, Mr. Head mentioned a carpet currently all the rage: a classic Persian Heriz design made by Afghan refugees in Peshawar, Pakistan, that sells for $12,000. He said the same basic design, made in Iran, would be priced at only $2,000, and would still be a tough sell because of bad dyes, bad washing and boring execution. "It's just incredible the amount of junk they've produced," he said. "They look like machine-made carpets." It is not only the countries making the rugs that have changed, but American tastes as well.
"What I think of as the classic Persian rug -- vivid colors, high knot count, intricate design -- is not what's selling," said Rosalind Rustigian, owner of Rustigian Rugs in Providence, R.I., and president of the Oriental Rug Retailers Association. "What I'm selling are soft colors, flowing designs with a patina of age and texture."
Buyers are turning their noses up at the traditional Iranian Tabriz and Sarouk styles, full of Oriental flower power or heavy red and blue, reminiscent of Grandpa and Grandma's parlor. Now the fashion is for muted colors. The top of the heap are Oushak and Agra designs. Originally derived from designs made in Turkey and India, respectively, they are now copied by weavers from Egypt to China, and are notable for their big geometric patterns and bland colors -- salmon, cream, orangey brown and moss green.
All this borrowing of designs across borders has made the country of origin almost irrelevant to buyers who once turned their noses up at anything not labeled Persian (so called because of the famous weaving centers in Persia, in the time before Iran formally existed as a nation).
"What matters now is color and design, not country of origin," Mr. Head said.
The New York interior decorator Kitty Hawks agreed, saying that she foresees no stampede to Persian-made rugs by her customers. "My clients couldn't care less where a rug comes from," she said. "On a purely aesthetic basis we've gotten used to the Oushaks and Agras. They're much easier to use than a formal-garden carpet that can take over the whole room."
Almost alone, auction houses are eagerly awaiting the end of the embargo. They will now be able to sell in America the expensive antique Persian rugs that have long been languishing in Europe or elsewhere, off limits to collectors. (Purchases made abroad were denied entry into this country.)
In the interim, prices have risen steadily for America's inventory of rarities: 16th- and 17th-century Persian carpets (ranging upward from $50,000), small tribal rugs from the Caucasus mountains and the newly popular antique Turkish Oushaks and Indian Agras that routinely fetch more than $50,000. A large 19th-century Agra rug that sold at retail for $90,000 around 1990 brought $240,000 at Christie's in 1997.
Yet the middle of the antique market, made up of many Persian rugs woven between 1870 and 1930, has declined about 50 percent in the last decade. Lumped in here are the ubiquitous red and blue Sarouks and garden-variety Tabrizes.
AN example is an intricately woven 4-by-6-foot Kirman rug that was made in Iran around 1900 and is up for sale at Christie's next month. Featuring a cartouche on an ivory field covered with twisting flowers, it should bring $3,500 to $4,500, by Christie's estimate. "Ten years ago it would have brought $6,000 to $8,000," said Elisabeth Poole, the head of Christie's rug department. "It's just very Persian taste, and that's completely out of fashion now."
Brand-new Persian carpets have also dropped steadily in price as a result of devaluations in both currency and quality. "Iranian carpets are now half to one-third the price they were in the early 1980's," said Steven Peykar, one of three Iranian brothers who own the Nourison Rug Company in Saddle Brook, N.J. The company, which is the country's largest importer of handmade carpets from China, Pakistan and India, sells to department stores, including Bloomingdale's and Macy's.
Before the 1987 embargo, the total wholesale value of Oriental hand-knotted rugs imported to the United States was $500 million, said Mr. Stroh of Rug News. (That's about $750 million in current dollars). Iran had the biggest share of that market, 28 percent, followed by China and India. When Iranian imports show up in the statistics next year, Mr. Stroh said, they will probably place fourth or fifth -- about where they have been all along during the embargo.
No one expects to see Iran back on top of the rug pile any time soon, except perhaps at the "going out of business" sales held at airports and hotels, which are prime arenas for cheating consumers. As Ms. Rustigian put it, "The lifting of the ban is a heyday for the G.O.B.'s, where the consumer is just determined to buy an Iranian rug and doesn't know the difference between one worth $3,000 or $30,000."
Both now and in the long term, industry experts agree, Iran faces tough competition. Iranian weavers will have to adjust their designs and colors for a share of the American market. There is interest among buyers in the possibility that the Iranians will make the changes, but no high hope.
Mr. Head, of ABC Carpet, is planning to fly to Tehran next week to look at rugs. "I'm ready to be very disappointed," he said. "They need a fresh, new approach and fresh, new designs that others will want to copy." And, he said, they will need money from joint partnerships with Americans. "Then -- in two, three, four, five years -- you'll see wonderful things being produced."
"After all," he added, "there wouldn't have been a Monet if there hadn't been people to sponsor the arts."
But India, Pakistan, China and Turkey may not be easy to push to the background again. "The quality has been degraded so much by the smuggled goods," Mr. Stroh said. "That's what's upsetting. There should be a premium for rugs for Iran, but there's not. Iran will never dominate the market again."
 
Trade Secrets
IF you plan to buy an Oriental carpet from any of the dozen or so rug-producing countries, from Iran to India, China to Pakistan, the professionals say there is a quick way to tell a bad dye job, which is the carpet equivalent of a lemon:
Rub a damp rag lightly over areas where the colors seem too deep or vivid to be true. Excess dye will come off on the rag, indicating that the carpet will bleed when it is cleaned.
Trust your eyes: if the colors seem ugly and harsh -- even to the untutored eye -- chances are the dye job is bad.
To test for bleaching (which is done to give rugs "instant age"), separate fibers at the carpet's base. Just as with a bad hair job, the roots will be darker. CHRISTIE BROWN

HEADLINE: MG's Faithful Get Hopes Up Again

BYLINE: By ROB FIXMER 

 BODY:
HOPE springs eternal among American MG owners. It has to. Only an incurable optimist would drive a car that hasn't been built since Jimmy Carter was president -- and that, even when new, was not particularly safe or reliable.
Yet British sports car enthusiasts on this side of the Atlantic seem downright skeptical about last week's announcement that Rover, the bleeding dog of British automakers, was about to be transformed into the MG Car Company by a group specializing in corporate turnarounds, Alchemy Partners. 
 "Alchemy -- turning base metal into gold? These guys better have a clue!" said John H. Twist, a prolific author and guru to MG owners, who has made University Motors in Ada, Mich., a mecca for enthusiasts. "We all want to believe that the new owners can succeed where BMW failed, but we've had our hopes raised and dashed before."
Indeed, when BMW Group took over Rover and MG five years ago, there was widespread speculation that the Germans would create a new MG for the American market. But BMW, which was introducing its own open-top two-seater, the Z3, never re-engineered the existing MGF for the United States. BMW said the economics didn't work, but disappointed MG fans said the Germans were afraid that the well-regarded MGF would steal sales from the Z3.
Alchemy faces a daunting challenge. Rover and MG, which still use the outdated Longbridge plant in Birmingham, England, are rent by labor strife and hemorrhaging red ink. BMW will keep the Mini, which is being redesigned, and Land Rover, which is Rover's only profitable operation. BMW has agreed to sell Land Rover to Ford.
But anyone reading discussions on Internet bulletin boards in the last week would think that the only question facing Alchemy was whether to return to the United States with the MGF or with a new MG it has promised to turn out within 18 months.
A writer calling himself John Z of Ann Arbor, Mich., noted that Alchemy had said it would build 100,000 cars in the first year. "The 100,000 unit 'limit' still means no MG in the States," he wrote. "It tells me that the new owners are not interested in us."
Alchemy Partners declined a request for an interview.
Americans have at least some reason to claim a vested interest in the MG brand.
From 1929 until 1980, the octagonal MG emblem was virtually synonymous with British sports cars. But while MG's were designed and built in Abingdon, England, a majority were sold in North America, a fact that heavily influenced engine design, emission controls, safety features and eventually styling. Of the 512,243 MG's built from 1962 to 1980, when production ceased, 349,503, or 68 percent, were made for North America, according to an MG historian, Anders Ditlev Clausager, in his book "Original MG."
The MG was the first foreign car to win American hearts. Beginning with a trickle of the two-seat, soft-top TC roadsters imported after World War II by returning GI's, MG sales in the United States peaked in the 1979 model year at 22,753 -- more than 10 times the number sold in Britain. A year later, MG closed its doors at Abingdon, having fallen victim to poor management and labor strife among parts suppliers.
But even after MG folded, appetite for the car wouldn't die. Rights to the brand changed hands several times over the years, ending up with Rover, which in 1992 offered a half-hearted domestic revival -- the MG RV8, basically a classic MGB roadster body with a Rover V8 engine. In 1995, Rover introduced the MGF, a midengine roadster that was a break from past MG's but a continuation of its design tradition.
That car has not made money, causing the online forums to buzz with questions about Alchemy's game plan. Was Alchemy, which is best known for turning around Parker Pen, simply planning to leverage MG's reputation by slapping the MG octagon on existing Rovers? Or would the partners live up to the promise of their announcement and "focus on developing a state-of-the-art, British-built product range worthy of the sporting heritage of the MG name"?
Whatever path Alchemy takes, how does it plan to succeed where BMW failed?
"You know, I thought the Germans would, and could, make a go of the MG name," Mr. Twist said. "How in the world will British ownership make things better?"
On the other hand, he allowed, "How could it make it worse?"
By continuing to ignore the American market, many MG enthusiasts would respond. Alchemy has so far remained resolutely mute on that point, but it is clear from sales of the Z3 and Mazda Miata, as well as from strong demand for the Honda S2000, that Americans have a strong and growing appetite for roadsters. The MGF sells for about $35,000 in Britain, where cars cost more than in the United States.
"Today everybody is looking for ways to spend," Mr. Twist said of the United States market. "Technology stocks into the stratosphere -- a perfect market for the MGF."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
German Chosen Managing Director of I.M.F.

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
Horst Kohler of Germany became managing director of the International Monetary Fund today just as the Clinton administration and members of Congress were discussing how the agency might be improved.
Mr. Kohler, 57, president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, was unanimously endorsed by the 24 members of the I.M.F. board, ending an awkward episode in which he became Germany's choice for the job after its first failed to garner broad international support. Mr. Kohler succeeds Michel Camdessus of France, who retired. 
 Mr. Kohler said last week that his goals for the 182-nation organization included making it "a cornerstone for promoting growth and stability" around the world and having a better relationship with Congress.
Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers talked about those very things today before the House Banking Committee, where he defended the core missions of the I.M.F. and its sister institution, the World Bank.
"Countries that are helped to succeed economically are much more likely to become democratic, and their people more likely to avoid debilitating disease, to learn to read and to work with human dignity," Mr. Summers said. "From the experience of Germany in the 1930's to Bosnia and Africa in more recent times, history teaches us that conflicts are most likely in situations of economic distress, when populations turn their frustration to nationalist leaders because of a lack of a sense of economic opportunity."
The I.M.F. and the World Bank were created in the mid-1940's to promote economic stability and lend money to developing countries. Congressional critics say the institutions have sometimes distributed money unwisely. A Congressional panel headed by Allan Meltzer, an economics professor at Carnegie Mellon University, has recommended sharply curtailed roles for both institutions.
Recent I.M.F. loans to Ukraine proved embarrassing after it was disclosed that officials there might have manipulated foreign exchange reserves to create a deceptive picture of the country's financial condition. Mr. Summers said the administration found that affair troubling and had pressed the I.M.F. to put new lending safeguards in place.
Mr. Summers also used the hearings to promote his own proposals to introduce changes in the way the I.M.F. and the World Bank work. He has suggested that the I.M.F. focus more on making short-term loans to countries that have financial crises and less on long-term lending and development assistance. He said the World Bank should ensure that its loans did not crowd out money that could be provided by the private sector and should also limit assistance to countries with poor records for using development loans effectively.
Mr. Summers also said that the Meltzer panel's most drastic recommendations would hobble the I.M.F. and the World Bank to the point that they "would no longer be able to advance America's core values and interests around the world."

HEADLINE: U.S.-Japan Phone Deregulation Talks Fall Flat

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, March 23

 BODY:
Talks between the United States and Japan over deregulation of the telecommunications market ended in failure here today.
Although negotiators had extended their discussions for one day on Wednesday, they failed to reach an agreement on the magnitude and speed of reductions in the fees that the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corporation charges for access to its local network, to which 99 percent of the phones in Japan are connected. 
 Further deregulation of the telecommunications market here is fast becoming the most contentious trade debate since United States and Japanese negotiators struggled over opening the Japanese automobile market in the mid-1990's.
The United States contends that Japan's refusal to move more swiftly to allow unfettered competition imperils the future of the Japanese economy. "This is not the U.S. against Japan," said Richard Fisher, deputy United States trade representative, at a news briefing. "This is Japan against the future."
He said Japan's resistance to further deregulating telecommunications was costing Japanese consumers and businesses by making them pay high prices for service. He contrasted the rate his daughter pays to cruise the Internet in the United States, which is less than $9 a month, or about 900 yen, with what one of her Japanese friends is paying -- 7,830 yen a month.
"Why should a Japanese girl be at such a disadvantage to an American girl?" he said.
The United States sought an immediate 41 percent reduction in fees, which eat up as much as 40 percent of the revenue of NTT's competitors, while Japan offered to cut rates 22.5 percent over four years.
Japan says that the American demands threaten 70,000 jobs at NTT, the former government telephone monopoly in which the government retains a 59.1 percent stake.
But Mr. Fisher countered that while it was a government's responsibility to worry about issues like layoffs, opening the market to competition would create jobs. He noted that in the last four years, 90,000 jobs have been created in telecommunications in the United States.
"Who governs Japan?" he said. "The elected people, the Diet, the government or a monopoly?" The Diet is Japan's parliament.
Japan is worried that the United States will take the matter to the World Trade Organization before the meeting of leaders of the top industrialized nations, in July in Okinawa. Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi considers a successful summit meeting critical to the success of the ruling party in parliamentary elections that must be held by mid-October.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
France Telecom Buying Big Stake in German Rate-Cutter

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: PARIS, March 23

 BODY:
France Telecom scored a rare strategic victory today in the jockeying for advantage in the European telecommunications industry with a $3.6 billion deal to acquire a substantial stake in MobilCom A.G., an aggressive provider of low-cost phone service in Germany.
The deal ends a series of setbacks for France Telecom that had left it largely isolated and in a single stroke provides it with access to the big but fiercely contested phone market in Germany, Europe's largest economy. 
 In acquiring 28.5 percent of MobilCom, the French company also gets a strong partner to help bid later this year for a German license in the newest generation of wireless phone service, which is expected to flourish as European countries develop wireless systems geared to the Internet.
France Telecom will pay 201 euros, or $195, each for 18.6 million new MobilCom shares, with an option to increase its stake in MobilCom in 2003.
Michel Bon, France Telecom's chief executive, said the deal was "perfectly in line with our ambition to become a leader in the convergence of fixed, mobile and Internet services in Europe." He said France Telecom expected strong growth in the German market for wireless phone systems with Internet capabilities.
The deal was a significant setback for the Stuttgart-based cellular phone provider Debitel, which had an arrangement for a joint bid with MobilCom when Germany auctions licenses this summer for the next generation of wireless phone systems. Debitel said today that it would withdraw from that arrangement.
Coming only a few weeks after the successful hostile bid by Vodafone AirTouch of Britain for Mannesmann, Germany's biggest cell phone provider, the France Telecom-MobilCom deal illustrates the kind of maneuvering under way in Europe's flourishing mobile communications industry. The biggest competitors are hastening to assemble Continent-wide wireless networks, given common European transmission standards, and are spending billions to expand into markets where they are not yet present.
A major prize for France Telecom is the Internet portal that MobilCom established in December, Freenet, which has signed up about a million customers, making it No. 3 in Germany after T-Online, which is operated by Deutsche Telekom and America Online. But some analysts say that Freenet has the potential to overtake AOL.
Gerhard Schmid, MobilCom's founder and chief executive, who will own 40 percent of his company after the French purchase, said the deal would give MobilCom vast new resources to develop operations on the Internet.
France Telecom, a former state monopoly, remains 63 percent-owned by the French government. It was largely cut out of Germany last year after it abandoned a decade-old partnership with Deutsche Telekom, the dominant German phone carrier, because of the Germans' surprising though unsuccessful bid to acquire Telecom Italia, another former government monopoly.
Later, France Telecom suffered still another setback in Germany after its plans to acquire the cellular phone provider E-Plus were thwarted by BellSouth, which teamed up with Royal KPN of the Netherlands to outbid the French.
MobilCom is the unlikely creation of Mr. Schmid, a 47-year-old former health resort employee, who started it in 1998 and built it on a shoestring budget, mostly with phone lines he leased from Deutsche Telekom. MobilCom now has about 1.9 million cellular phone customers, or 8 percent of the market, and 603,000 fixed-line long-distance users, or 9 percent.

HEADLINE: Fed Committee Was Unanimous As It Raised Rates in February

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, March 23

 BODY:
The Federal Reserve's policy-making committee was unanimous in its decision to raise a key interest rate by a quarter of a point in February, minutes of the meeting showed today. However, some members had urged that the rate be pushed even higher.
The Federal Open Market Committee, which includes the Fed chairman, Alan Greenspan, voted 10 to 0 to raise the federal funds rate -- the interest that banks charge one another on overnight loans -- to 5.75 percent, according to the minutes. 
 It was the fourth increase in the federal funds rate since June 30.
On Tuesday, the Fed increased interest rates by another quarter-point. That action pushed the federal funds rate to 6 percent. The minutes of that meeting are expected to be released in May.
Even though there was no dissent on the February increase, the minutes said that before the vote, a few unidentified members expressed a preference for a half-point increase "in order to provide greater assurance against a buildup of inflationary expectations and inflation over coming months."
And other members acknowledged that the Fed "might need to move more aggressively at a later meeting" should the rapidly growing economy generate a pickup in inflation pressures.
In the end, the minutes said that all members agreed to the quarter-point increase for a number of reasons, including uncertainties about the outlook for growth in demand relative to that of supply, the economy's response to previous rate increases and somewhat unsettled conditions in financial markets. Members "saw little risk in a gradual approach," the minutes said.
Policy makers were also united in expressing their concerns that inflation could spoil the economic good times the country is enjoying.
Members unanimously agreed that future risks to the economy were "weighted mainly toward conditions that may generate heightened inflation pressures in the foreseeable future."

HEADLINE: Residential Real Estate;
New Apartments in TriBeCa, but Luxury Rentals, Not Condos

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
As the conversion of old manufacturing buildings to loft condominiums marches on in TriBeCa, the 16-story structure nearing completion at 95 Worth Street is breaking from that trend as one of the few new luxury rentals to be built in the neighborhood in the last decade.
Leasing for the building's 147 apartments begins today, but more than 100 people have already put their names on a waiting list, said Laurie Zucker, a partner in the Zucker Organization, which is developing the building. Financing for the project is coming from the developer's own money and a construction loan from Fleet Bank. 
 The building, called the Saranac, will have 122 one-bedroom apartments, 20 two-bedrooms and five three-bedrooms, including the two penthouses, ranging in size from 550 to 1,870 square feet.
Initially, monthly rents for most of the smaller apartments will be $2,085 to $3,615. Some larger two-bedroom apartments as well as the three-bedroom units on the 14th and 15th floors, which include fireplaces and washers and dryers, will rent for $3,815 to $5,100 a month, while the penthouses, with private terraces, will start at $8,000 a month.
There will also be 6,000 square feet of ground-floor retail space, with an entrance on Broadway, and a parking garage for 114 cars in the building. It marks the first foray into the TriBeCa residential marketplace for the Zucker Organization, a 40-year-old Manhattan-based development company, which has built mostly rentals, and owns and manages 3,500 apartments in the city.
"We look for land at a reasonable cost in locations that are established or are up and coming," said Ms. Zucker, whose father, Donald Zucker, is a partner in the organization. She added, "We are not pioneering here."
Still, the project is rising in the easternmost stretch of TriBeCa, hard against an area of municipal and court buildings, reflecting how development is moving farther out from the heart of the neighborhood as developers look for available buildings to convert or sites to redevelop, residential brokers said. The Saranac occupies a site that since the mid-1970's was used as a surface parking lot.
"Our parking lots just keep disappearing," said Judy Duffy, assistant district manager of Community Board 1, which helps guide growth in TriBeCa. "I keep thinking we have maxed out, but development keeps coming." She estimates that this year, as in each of the last five years, about 400 apartments will be produced in the neighborhood.
Most of those have been and continue to be condominiums. A major reason, said Andrew J. Gerringer, a senior vice president at Douglas Elliman, the Manhattan brokerage, is the rising price of buildings to convert or land to buy. Buildings in TriBeCa suitable for conversion cost $200 to $250 a square foot, and costs for prime land are estimated at $100 to $120 per square foot of the building that zoning rules would allow to be constructed. Those prices make it difficult for the economics of a rental project "to pencil out, so you haven't seen a lot of them," Mr. Gerringer said.
Ms. Zucker said her company "prefers to develop rentals because it wants to retain ownership in what it builds." And in the case of the Saranac site, which the company acquired in the fall of 1997 for nearly $7 million, or $55 a square foot, the economics make sense, she said.
As for it being on the neighborhood's eastern fringe, she said, "It may be at the edge, but it is still in TriBeCa and brokers are always saying there is a demand for more luxury rentals."
Andrew Melnick, vice president of the rental division at Tabak Real Estate, a residential brokerage in TriBeCa, agreed, saying that "rentals are a scarcity these days, especially those on the higher-end side."
Most individual apartment owners, he said, "are selling rather than renting out their properties, which is another source of the supply drying up."
Mr. Gerringer of Douglas Elliman said that with the imbalance of supply and demand, rents in TriBeCa have risen about 10 percent over the last year to an average of $45 a square foot annually. That translates into an average monthly rental of $2,100 for typical 550-square-foot one-bedroom apartments and $3,750 for two-bedrooms with 1,000 square feet, Mr. Gerringer said, noting that newly constructed units could rent for $45 to $50 a square foot.
People would be willing to pay that premium even in a less-than-prime location in TriBeCa if they felt that they were getting a good value, he said, adding that "renters tend to decide with their feet, knowing they can leave when their leases expire."
At the Saranac, the average rents per square foot for the apartments, with 9- to 11-foot-high ceilings and open layouts, come to $50, Ms. Zucker said. With the majority of the units one-bedrooms, she said, the building is being marketed to young professional singles and couples. But families are expected to be drawn to the larger apartments as well as to the fact that the building is in the school district that includes the highly rated Public School 234, she said.
The Saranac will be clad in red brick and will feature brick detailing and a variegated roof line, ranging from angular to curved to rounded, to "mitigate its bulkiness," said Stephen B. Jacobs, who designed the building and heads the Manhattan architectural firm bearing his name. Just for whimsy, gargoyles will be added, he said.
In addition to the parking garage, for which tenants will pay an extra yet-to-be-determined monthly cost, amenities include a fitness center and laundry room as well as a second-floor outdoor recreation area atop the garage. And the Adirondacks-inspired lobby with its large stone fireplace, wood beamed ceiling and bluestone floor, will reveal to tenants the reason for the building's name.
Occupancy is set for May.

HEADLINE: Buying on Margin Becomes a Habit;
Investors Turn to Credit in a Bull Market

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Borrowing money to buy stocks has become immensely popular among individual investors today. And who can blame them? When stock prices are rising, the biggest gains go to those who buy shares on borrowed money.
When stock prices are falling, however, borrowing to buy stocks is an expensive and highly risky business. While recent tremors in some formerly hot market sectors may have awakened some investors to this unhappy reality, market regulators are growing concerned that the recent surge in investor indebtedness, which has been greatest at online firms, reflects the participation of many people who do not understand how dangerous stock market debt can be. 
 "I am troubled by the apparent ease with which real neophytes are going online these days all by themselves and trading on margin," said Bradley Skolnick, the Indiana securities commissioner and president of the North American Securities Administrators Association. "A lot of people are purchasing rather speculative, high-risk stocks with borrowed money and that's a source of concern for me. In a volatile market, trading on margin can find you in a whole lot of hurt very quickly."
Lael Desmond, a medical school student in Indiana, learned the hard way how risky borrowing on margin can be. In late 1997, Mr. Desmond, who was then 26, opened an account at Ameritrade; by June 1998 he had roughly $30,000 in his account. An investing novice, he began borrowing money to buy shares of Amazon.com, Dell Computer, Excite, America Online and Yahoo.
Mr. Desmond, who was to begin medical school the following fall, did not fully understand what investing on margin meant. Yes, when stocks go up, an investor can double his gains by borrowing from his broker, paying a relatively modest interest rate for the opportunity. But if the stock -- which serves as the asset backing the loan -- declines in value, the customer will be asked to put up more money to make up for the shortfall. This is known as a margin call. When an investor chooses not to put up more money, his shares are sold but he usually still owes money to the broker.
Mr. Desmond, according to his lawyer, Jeffrey V. Gery at Maddox, Koeller, Hargett & Caruso in Indianapolis, thought his margin borrowing was like a mortgage or bank loan. He had no idea that he could lose money on it.
Then, in the late summer of 1998, stocks took a dive because of the Russian debt crisis. On Friday, Aug. 28, stocks began to fall and continued their descent the following Monday, generating margin calls of roughly $12,000 to Mr. Desmond. By Tuesday, the call had grown to $21,000, which Mr. Desmond did not have. So he took out cash advances on credit cards in the amount of $13,000 and borrowed $8,000 from his brother. Nevertheless, by the time the funds were wired to Ameritrade the afternoon of September 1, the firm had already sold Mr. Desmond's holdings.
In Mr. Desmond's arbitration case, decided last January, he won $40,453 from Ameritrade. Although the arbitrators did not give the reason for their award, it is clear they believed Ameritrade sold Mr. Desmond's holdings too quickly.
Mr. Gery, one of two lawyers who represented Mr. Desmond, said of the case: "It's been our impression that a lot of online firms think they are Web sites first and brokerage firms second. But they are brokerage firms first and they have a duty to maintain very high standards."
It is investors like Mr. Desmond, trading through online brokers, who are most responsible for the jump in margin debt. Steven Galbraith, an analyst at the investment firm of Sanford C. Bernstein & Company, estimates that margin debt as a percent of market value has soared 459 percent at online brokers since 1995.
Growth in margin debt at firms that are members of the New York Stock Exchange, by comparison, has gone up 190 percent during the same period. The value of the market, as measured by the Standard & Poor's 500 has risen 139 percent during that time.
Some online brokerage firms have recently increased their margin requirements.
Dan Hubbard, a spokesman at Charles Schwab, said the firm required a greater down payment than the 50 percent minimum set by the Federal Reserve on 270 securities its executives feel are too volatile or illiquid.
Michael Dunn, a spokesman for Datek Online Holdings, said his firm had a large number of stocks where it refused to extend margin, while 227 others required higher down payments. T. D. Waterhouse requires higher than normal deposits on around 300 stocks, and Ameritrade, while not supplying details, said it required higher initial deposits on some stocks. Officials at E*Trade did not return a phone call seeking information about their current margin requirements.
But brokerage firms make big money lending to investors so it is perhaps not surprising that many still lend freely. Mr. Galbraith estimates that margin interest paid by investors accounts for 20 percent of a typical Internet brokerage firm's revenue. In a recent study, he found that even the most volatile highfliers -- including such stocks as Red Hat, Doubleclick, Broadcom, Inktomi and the Internet Capital Group -- were marginable at one online brokerage firm or another.
Indeed, as the market's gyrations become more pronounced, borrowing to buy stocks becomes positively treacherous. A stock that falls only 10 percent, for example -- not a big move in today's wild market -- could set off a request for more money from an investor who has borrowed the maximum amount.
If the investor does not have the funds to add to his portfolio, the shares are sold, possibly weakening an already sickly stock. This is why excessive investor indebtedness can add to downward moves in stocks.
Perhaps because falling stocks always seem to bounce back these days, investors remain unworried. Margin debt on the New York Stock Exchange has surged 75 percent in the last 12 months and now exceeds $265 billion, a record. Debt ballooned almost 9 percent in February alone and now accounts for more than 1.5 percent of the Big Board's total market value, also a peak.
Even more troubling is how fast margin debt is growing as a share of overall consumer credit. According to Mr. Galbraith's research, margin loans now account for 16 percent of total consumer borrowings, up from 7 percent in 1995. Numbers like these prove that the explosion in margin borrowing is coming from individual investors, not institutions, he said.
"They've supplanted buying a washer-drier with debt with buying Qualcomm on margin," Mr. Galbraith said. "If you think of the volatility of the asset being financed it is probably more dramatic than I suspect many of the people deploying leverage think about."
More investors seem to be discovering that margin trading has pitfalls. The Securities and Exchange Commission says investor complaints in that area have risen significantly in recent weeks.
The Federal Reserve Board, which has set the margin requirement at 50 percent since 1974, recently expressed concern over the outsized growth in margin debt. Yet in January, when the explosive growth in margin debt became evident, Alan Greenspan rejected calls to increase the initial amount required of investors when they buy stocks on margin. He argued that an increase in the margin requirement would be unfair to small investors because they would be unable to secure credit even as institutional investors could tap other sources of funds.
Still, the damage that heavily margined investors can sustain in a downward move in stocks is great enough that some observers question Mr. Greenspan's inaction. Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, said, "It's the little guys who are going to get unduly hurt when the market goes down, so I think there's nothing wrong with it."
The senator has been urging Mr. Greenspan to reconsider his reluctance to raise the margin requirement. "He has not closed the door on it," Senator Schumer said. "And right now the Fed is undergoing a study of margin debt."
Richard Sylla, a professor of financial history at the Stern School of Business at New York University, called Mr. Greenspan's small-investor argument inconsistent. "He's worried about the market being too high, but his argument that a margin requirement increase would make it harder for small investors to participate is in some sense saying, 'I don't want to spoil the party for them,' " Professor Sylla said.
Some regulators fear that investors are also borrowing from sources other than their brokers to buy stocks, including credit cards or second mortgages.
"I'm worried not just about the margin but about people borrowing on other assets like homes and the double-dip effect that would have in the event of a market decline," said Arthur Levitt, chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission. "If we have a market decline then that would play out not just in terms of lower security values but also in lower real estate values."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;
A new marketing effort tries to raise FT.com's U.S. profile.

BYLINE: By Courtney Kane 

 BODY:
FT.COM, the Internet venture of The Financial Times, the London-based financial newspaper, is embarking on its first consumer marketing campaign to raise its profile in the United States.
The advertisements, with the theme "The world doesn't turn on a dime," emphasize the importance of a global perspective in today's business environment. The $35 million campaign features Dan Aykroyd in a series of humorous television commercials, in addition to print, outdoor and online ads. 
 The campaign, which begins on Sunday, is the first from BBDO New York, part of the BBDO Worldwide unit of the Omnicom Group, since the agency was awarded the account in November. The commercials are the first that Mr. Aykroyd, the actor known for his work in the early years of "Saturday Night Live" and in many films, has done, the agency said.
The humor in the commercials, said Paul Waddington, marketing communications director for FT.com in London, "helps us to get away from any perhaps connotations of stuffiness that the parent brand has."
In the first commercial, Mr. Aykroyd portrays Mr. Kopeky, the chief executive of a leading American foam rubber company, who is negotiating with three Italian businessmen over the sale of his company. After intense price negotiations being passed back and forth on paper, Mr. Kopeky thinks he has pulled a fast one on the Italians by agreeing to sell his company for what he believes to be the astronomical price of 11 million lire, which a subtitle notes is just $5,741. After shaking hands to seal the deal, the three Italians raise their glasses to Mr. Kopeky and offer felicitations in Italian that are translated in a subtitle as 'idiot, moron and chowderhead.'
Subsequent commercials with Mr. Aykroyd portray him in similar predicaments where his ignorance of global business also hurts him.
Ted Sann, co-chief executive and chief creative officer at BBDO New York, noted that this sort of inept businessman has always been part of Mr. Aykroyd's repertory, "so, it seemed like a natural fit and you get more spin and noticeability of having a celebrity of his stature."
The use of a celebrity, in addition to the campaign's quirky humor, is indicative of many Web publishers' attempts to attract attention in a media category that has quickly grown cluttered.
"They're late to the party," said Sue Haxager, senior vice president and senior account director on the FT.com account at BBDO New York. "There are already a variety of business news services and the dot-com noise in general."
"From our perspective," she added, "we are trying to say that we are a dot-com and that FT, which has a very conservative image, is doing something radically different, and we felt if we approached it to somberly the 'Internetness' of it wouldn't come across."
The Web site, which was introduced in 1995, was revamped last month and is now being offered as an international business portal with news, views and archives. The target is a broader business audience in middle management ages 25 to 54.
FT.com says it has 1.2 million users every month. About 12 percent of those users come from the United States; 56 percent come from Britain; about 20 percent from Europe, with the remainder from the rest of the world. It competes with several financial Web news sites, including MarketWatch.com, TheStreet.com and WSJ.com, among others.
"We want to build upon the growing reputation of the newspaper in the U.S. and broaden it to increase the audience for the Financial Times brand over all," said Stephen Hill, group chief executive at FT.com's parent the Financial Times Group unit of Pearson P.L.C. in London. "What we want to is get people's minds to integrate the two services of the Financial Times Group."
Toward that end, the 11 print ads for FT.com use the distinctive salmon-pink color of The Financial Times as the backdrop. One headline proclaims: "Greeks, Chinese, Germans, Russians, Italians, Uzbeks, Namibians, Turks, Japanese and Americans all speak the same language. Money." Another ad directs readers to FT.com's Markets and Portfolio channel by promising, "Learn so much about Charles Schwab, you can call him Chuck." A third headline states, "Phrase often heard by FT.com users: Cha-ching!" And, "When your company does business in countries you can't spell."
Newspaper and magazine ads will begin appearing next week in publications including The Economist, Forbes, The New York Times, The Wall Street Journal and USA Today. The online advertising portion of the campaign, created by @tmosphere in New York, a digital branding agency started by BBDO New York last year, will be on various media properties including MSNBC.com, MSN.com and Hotmail.com.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Dow Climbs Over 11,000 In Wide Rally

BYLINE: By ALEX BERENSON 

 BODY:
Stocks soared again yesterday as investors poured into technology and financial shares in a bet that the Federal Reserve is almost finished raising short-term interest rates. Similar optimism fueled the Treasury bond market, as the price on the 30-year bond rose to its highest level since August.
The Dow Jones industrial average jumped above 11,000 for the first time in six weeks, gaining 253.16 points, or 2.3 percent, to 11,119.86. It was the 10th time since the beginning of February that the Dow has gained or lost more than 200 points, a level that once was eye-popping but has become almost routine. 
 The broader Standard & Poor's 500-stock index set its third consecutive record, rising 26.71 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,527.35, while the Nasdaq composite index gained 75.86 points, or 1.6 percent, to 4,940.61.
The market's gain was fueled by Microsoft, whose shares surged yesterday on reports that it might be close to a settlement with the Justice Department that would keep the company intact. Both The Washington Post and The Wall Street Journal reported that talks between the government and Microsoft had intensified. Shares of Microsoft gained $8.625, to $111.875, adding almost $45 billion to its market value and 43 points to the Dow.
With very few companies having issued earnings warnings for the first quarter, and interest rates dropping, investors are hungry again for equities. Notably, the biggest, most liquid stocks were the biggest gainers. Shares of companies like Microsoft, General Electric, and Cisco Systems, which all have billions of shares outstanding, gained more than 6 percent yesterday as investors jumped into the megacap stocks that have performed so well for the last decade.
Bond prices also gained, with the price of the benchmark 30-year issue rising 26/32, to 104 25/32. Its yield, which moves in the opposite direction from the price, fell to 5.91 percent from 5.96 percent on Wednesday. The rally in bonds came as a fight brewed yesterday between the Treasury Department and two government-sponsored companies that help finance home mortgages. Some analysts said safety-conscious institutional investors had bought Treasury bonds and sold bonds of the two companies, Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, helping the Treasury market.
Investor nervousness about Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac was not confined to the companies' bonds. Shares in both companies stumbled in morning trading yesterday, with Fannie Mae falling as low as $58 and Freddie Mac as low as $42.75.
Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have significant tax and regulatory advantages over commercial and investment banks, and Gary Gensler, a Treasury under secretary, urged a Congressional committee on Wednesday to consider stripping the companies of many of those benefits.
A bill pending in the House of Representatives would repeal a conditional line of credit that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac have with the Treasury. While the amount of money available is relatively small compared with the size of the companies, Mr. Gensler said that its repeal would make clear to investors that the government does not stand behind the debt of the companies.
But the two stocks ended the day higher after investors decided that the odds were against Congress's significantly changing the way the companies do business. Fannie Mae ended the day at $62.50, up 64.0625 cents, and Freddie Mac finished at $47, up 56.25 cents.
Kenneth Posner, who covers Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac for Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said Congress was unlikely to pass legislation that would raise borrowing costs for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac because those increased costs would probably be passed on to consumers in the form of higher mortgage rates.
"The reality is, it's hard for me to see politically what support this bill might have," Mr. Posner said. "If legislative momentum develops to make home ownership more difficult in the United States, maybe Fannie and Freddie are at risk."
But Bert Ely, who co-wrote a paper released two weeks ago by the American Enterprise Institute that argued against continuing the subsidies for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, said investors would be wise not to dismiss the prospect of Congressional action. As Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac grow, with Fannie Mae alone now issuing about $900 billion in debt, the controversy will increase, Mr. Ely said.
"The problem that Fannie and Freddie have is the bigger they get, the bigger a target they become," Mr. Ely said. The hubbub from Mr. Gensler's comments "will probably die down in the short term, but there will be long-term repercussions from it," he predicted.
Other market movers yesterday included General Electric, which was up $9.125, to $160 Cisco, up $5.625, to $77.8125 after a split; and American Express, which rose $8.125 to $155.875.
