HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Home Equity Lender Files For Bankruptcy Protection
First Alliance, a nationwide home equity lender facing a host of lawsuits accusing it of deceptive sales practices, announced that it had stopped making new loans to homeowners and that it had filed for bankruptcy protection.
The mortgage company, which had offices in more than a dozen states, including New York, New Jersey and California, said that it has closed its loan offices and laid off 85 percent of its work force. Page A1. 

Morgan Stanley Profit Up 49%
Riding a surge in trading of stocks and bonds, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter reported that its first-quarter net income rose 49 percent, making it the fourth big investment bank to post stronger-than-expected earnings. Morgan Stanley benefited from investors' seemingly insatiable appetite for the securities of companies in technology and telecommunications industries. Shares of Morgan Stanley rose $4.50, to $94.75. C2.
 
Kohler Becomes Head of I.M.F.
Horst Kohler of Germany, the president of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, became the International Monetary Fund's managing director just as the Clinton administration and members of Congress were discussing how the agency might be improved. The election put an end to an awkward episode in which Mr. Kohler became Germany's second choice for the job after its first failed to garner broad support. C4.
 
No Phone Accord Reached in Japan
Talks between the United States and Japan over deregulation of the telecommunications market ended without an agreement on the magnitude and speed of reductions in the fees that Nippon Telegraph and Telephone charges for access to its local network. C19.
 
Ukraine Transactions Scrutinized
An executive of Credit Suisse, the European banking giant, testified before the House Banking Committee that his institution engaged in unusual transactions on behalf of Ukraine's central bank, but he maintained that all of them were legal. Credit Suisse's activities in Ukraine have come under scrutiny after the International Monetary Fund revealed last week that Ukraine's central bank secured I.M.F. loans by misleading the fund about the country's financial health. Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers, who also testified, said the Treasury department would review audits of the transactions in question before he supports further I.M.F. lending to Ukraine. C2.
 
Chase in Talks for Robert Fleming
Chase Manhattan is negotiating to acquire the asset management and investment banking firm Robert Fleming Holdings. A deal would end the independence of Fleming, one of Britain's last privately held banks. C4.
 
Stake Sold in Mobilcom of Germany
France Telecom scored a rare strategic victory in the jockeying for advantage in the European telecommunications industry with a $3.6 billion deal to acquire nearly a third of Mobilcom, the aggressive provider of low-cost phone service in Germany. C4.
 
A New Editor at The Daily News
Ed Kosner, the former Newsweek editor drafted 16 months ago to revamp the slumping Sunday edition of The Daily News, has been named the newspaper's editor in chief. Mr. Kosner becomes the newspaper's fourth top editor in four years. B7.
 
FedEx Posts 37% Gain in Earnings
FedEx, the parent of Federal Express, the big overnight delivery company, said that its third-quarter earnings rose 37 percent, exceeding Wall Street expectations, on growth in international shipments. C6.

HEADLINE: Smuggling of Iraqi Oil Is Rising, U.N. Is Told

BYLINE: By BARBARA CROSSETTE 

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, March 23

 BODY:
Steeply rising oil prices have brought a huge increase in the smuggling of Iraqi oil, the American coordinator of the international fleet that patrols the waters off Iraq told a Security Council committee today.
The coordinator, Vice Admiral Charles Moore, told the committee on sanctions against Iraq that much of the oil passes through Iranian waters, diplomats said after the closed briefing. The admiral coordinates a small fleet from more than a dozen nations that polices the Persian Gulf, looking for ships that violate an international embargo on Iraq. 
 Admiral Moore and his team from the Pentagon told the committee that a political or diplomatic overture to Iran was necessary if the smuggling was to be curtailed, according to the representative of the Netherlands, Peter van Walsum, who is chairman of the committee.
"We have not discussed anything of that sort yet," Mr. van Walsum said after the meeting. He said the subject could be raised at the panel's next meeting, for which no date has been set.
Western diplomats said that Admiral Moore, briefing the committee the day before a debate on the sanctions, reported that at current rates of oil shipments, Iraq could earn up to a billion dollars this year in illegal sales. Diplomats said the profits go directly to Saddam Hussein or those he chooses to reward.
"The rate of smuggling is at record levels," a Western diplomat said. The oil, often bought and sold by private brokers using ships with fraudulent papers, goes to many destinations, including Iran, Pakistan and India.
Iranians skim part of the profit, diplomats said. It is not known whether the Iranians enriching themselves by allowing tankers to use their territorial waters are backed by the government in any way. But twice in the past -- in March and September of 1998 -- the Iranians were able to shut down the trade, diplomats say.
According to Western diplomats who heard Admiral Moore's briefing, Iraq was able to illegally export 1,868,466 barrels of oil in 1996, 10,497,000 barrels the following year, 13,296,000 barrels in 1998 and 7,557,838 barrels in 1999. Smuggling began to increase again in September, and record levels of smuggling were reported in December, January and February.
If current prices stay high, it is estimated that Iraq will sell about 33,590,390 barrels of illegal gas oil -- akin to diesel fuel -- this year.
"If the trend continues," a diplomat said, "more oil will be smuggled out of Iraq this year than the total smuggled out in the last four years."
Diplomats said that the oil comes from fields at Basra and is exported on vessels from the Iraqi port of Abu Flus. This port is not authorized for exports by the Security Council.

HEADLINE: Weiskirchen Journal;
At $4 a Gallon, Finding Joy on the Road Not Taken

BYLINE: By EDMUND L. ANDREWS 

DATELINE: WEISKIRCHEN, Germany, March 21

 BODY:
When Uwe Olzem finished filling the tank of his Nissan coupe, he could only envy Americans.
Faced with paying about $3.65 a gallon for regular unleaded -- about double the price in the United States -- Mr. Olzem said he is spending about $50 a week just to commute to his job. 
 "I don't blame Americans for being upset at the higher prices," said Mr. Olzem, a soldier in the German Army. "But they have a very good deal."
As the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries prepares to consider raising oil production quotas next Monday at a meeting in Vienna, Americans are fretting over the prospect of $2-a-gallon gasoline and fill-ups costing $50 or more for some big sport utility vehicles.
But in Europe, where prices have approached $4 a gallon for years, most drivers only wish they had it has bad as the Americans.
"It would be wonderful," sighed Carica De Hoere, a teacher from Harelbeke, Belgium, as she stopped here with a small group of friends en route from a skiing vacation in Austria. "But of course, it couldn't happen."
Gasoline prices have jumped at least 20 percent in many European countries over the past year, compared with more than 50 percent in the United States. Prices in Britain -- closing in on $5 a gallon -- are even higher than those in neighboring countries because the value of the British pound has climbed sharply against most other currencies. But there have been few if any diatribes against OPEC, nor grousing about the lack of gratitude for rescuing Kuwait from Iraq in the Persian Gulf war.
Nor are European officials emulating the United States secretary of energy, Bill Richardson, who has been on a whirlwind tour of oil-producing countries pleading for a sizable increase in production.
Even in Germany, a country of carmakers and car lovers and the legally enshrined right to drive the autobahn at speeds of 100 miles an hour -- few seem worried that their way of life is in danger.
"OPEC is the least of our problems," said Hermann Otto Solms, who oversees economic policy issues for Germany's Free Democratic Party, which has pushed for cutting taxes. "Our problem is that our own gasoline taxes are too high and are still going up. If OPEC reduces production, that is merely an additional problem."
Gasoline taxes are at the heart of the difference between American and European gasoline prices and attitudes. If American drivers are addicted to cheap gasoline, European governments are addicted to gasoline taxes.
Taxes total about three-quarters of the price of a gallon of gas in most European countries. Beyond paying for road construction and maintenance and public transportation, gasoline taxes have become a major source of government revenue and are increasingly used to offset cuts in social security taxes and other levies.
"We are the cash cows of the nation," complained Mr. Olzem, the German soldier. "I'm not bothered by what OPEC does. What bothers me is that the government is taking 75 percent of the money I pay for gasoline and putting it into its own pocket."
That has had a number of effects. Because the cost of oil makes up a smaller portion of the price of gasoline, prices here have climbed far more modestly.
Energy experts and economists contend that Europe's high gasoline taxes have also reduced its exposure to oil shocks. Though European oil imports have risen in recent years, both individuals and companies have invested heavily in ways to reduce energy consumption.
More important, Europeans have consistently been able to get by with less gasoline than Americans.
On average, Europeans drive less than half as many miles each year as Americans do, according to studies by the International Energy Agency, a publicly funded research institute in Paris. The standard explanation is that distances between cities and even within cities are so much greater in America than in Europe.
But that is only part of the story. In a study last year, the Paris agency reported that the length of the average car trip in the United States and Europe was virtually the same -- 8.7 miles versus 8.1 miles -- but the big difference was that Americans made nearly twice as many trips.
"Americans believe it is their God-given right to have as much cheap gasoline as they want," said Gary N. Ross, chief executive of PIRA Energy Group, an oil industry consulting firm in New York.
"Because of this addiction -- and addiction is a good word -- Americans drive almost 50 percent more than Europe, and its cars are less efficient," Mr. Ross said. "It has cost the United States dearly."
Even Europeans who want to reduce gasoline taxes, like Mr. Solms of the German Free Democratic Party, admit to being amazed when they visit the United States.
"In most cities, except perhaps New York, people can't understand why you would want to walk a short distance rather than drive," he said.
Europeans have long driven cars so small and fuel thrifty that they would be laughed off the American road by any self-respecting owner of a sport utility vehicle.
Lately, Europeans have developed a taste for heavier and more powerful models, but European automobiles over all get better mileage than American cars -- averaging about 27 miles per gallon compared with about 24 -- according to estimates by the International Energy Agency.
What's more, the gap is widening. According to the German government, the average fuel efficiency of cars on German roads has improved to about 27 miles per gallon from about 25.8 since 1992. By contrast, the fuel efficiency of American cars has not improved. In fact, since the sport utility craze in the United States began, new car and light-truck mileage has declined, to 23.8 miles per gallon last year from 25.4 in 1992.
The upshot is that European drivers have become inured to high gasoline prices and have learned to economize.
"You get used to high prices," said Freek Vlieger, a mechanic from Woerden, the Netherlands, as he filled up his tank on the way home from a ski holiday in Austria. "For us, it's not so much of a problem, because we don't use the car that much at home."
That is not to say people are happy about their lot. In the Netherlands and several other countries, people angry about gasoline prices are trying to organize a strike on April 1, in which drivers will refuse to drive or buy gasoline.
But if people are angry, they are more angry about gasoline taxes than the machinations of oil-producing countries. When Germany's Free Democrats campaigned against the ruling Social Democratic Party's plan to raise gasoline taxes in January, they arranged to sell gasoline tax-free for one hour at a station in Berlin.
The result led to mayhem, with thousands of drivers clogging the streets around the station to try to buy gas at 25 percent of the normal price.

HEADLINE: CLASSICAL MUSIC AND DANCE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy opera, classical music and dance events this weekend in the New York metropolitan region.
 
Classical Music
 
MARTHA ARGERICH. This superb and dynamic pianist has not played a solo recital in New York since 1981, undoubtedly in part because of her battle with melanoma. Here, in a benefit for the John Wayne Cancer Institute in Santa Monica, Calif., where she was treated, she plays Bach's Second Partita, Chopin's Barcarolle, Prokofiev's Seventh Sonata, Schumann's Piano Quintet (with the Juilliard String Quartet), Ravel's "Valse" (with the pianist Nelson Freire) and, the announcement says, more. More? The treatment was obviously a success, and amen to that. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Carnegie Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $23 to $101; sold out but returns may be available (James R. Oestreich). 

CZECH PHILHARMONIC. This wonderful orchestra has fallen on hard economic times as the Czech Republic labors through a transition to a market economy. It can still play with the best of them, however, as should be apparent here in the first of three programs, Hans Krasa's Symphony and Mahler's Seventh Symphony, conducted by Vladimir Ashkenazy. The Sunday concert is part of Lincoln Center's Prague Festival, which begins tomorrow with a symposium at 10 a.m. in the Kaplan Penthouse, 165 West 65th Street, 10th floor; with Michael Beckerman presiding, it promises to be lively. Performances are tomorrow at 8, Tilles Center for the Performing Arts, C. W. Post campus of Long Island University, Route 25A, Brookville, N.Y., (516) 299-3100; tickets: $42 and $56; $39 and $53 for the elderly; $12 for students; $8 for Long Island University students; and on Sunday at 3 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500; tickets: $25 to $47 (Oestreich).
 
ENSEMBLE SOSPESO. The outstanding Jeffrey Milarsky conducts a fine group of musicians in two weird, wonderful and comic scores produced by Gyorgy Ligeti in the 1960's: his "Fragment," for an ensemble of low instruments and percussion, and his Cello Concerto. The program is completed by his Horn Trio from two decades later, a piece just as astonishing and witty but with more bite and variety, dreaming of Brahms amid tricky Caribbean rhythms and breaths of central European folk music. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Miller Theater, Columbia University, Broadway at 116th Street, Morningside Heights, (212) 854-7799. Tickets: $15; $7.50 for students and the elderly; $5 for Columbia students (Paul Griffiths).
 
PHILIP GLASS ENSEMBLE. The composer Philip Glass has devoted himself increasingly to film music over the last 20 years, and the Brooklyn Academy of Music has recently shown several of them, with their soundtracks performed live by Mr. Glass's ensemble or by the Kronos Quartet. This week BAM has been offering a retrospective of Mr. Glass's film work, again with live performances by the Philip Glass Ensemble. Tonight's offering is "Powaqqatsi," the second of Mr. Glass's collaborations with the filmmaker Godfrey Reggio. The performance is to be followed by a discussion with Mr. Reggio. Tomorrow evening and Sunday afternoon the ensemble will perform Mr. Glass's score for the 1931 "Dracula," with Bela Lugosi, a work that had its premiere at BAM earlier this season. Today and tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. and Sunday at 3 p.m., Brooklyn Academy of Music, 30 Lafayette Avenue, at Fort Greene. (718) 636-4100. Tickets: $17 to $48 (Allan Kozinn).
 
SIMON KEENLYSIDE. The excellent British baritone Simon Keenlyside is currently singing the role of Marcello in Puccini's "Boheme" at the Metropolitan Opera. But this dashing actor and robust vocalist is also a probing and communicative recitalist. He gives his only New York recital this season on Sunday, with the in-demand pianist Malcolm Martineau. The program offers songs by Schubert, Strauss, Debussy and Faure. Sunday at 2 p.m., Alice Tully Hall. Tickets are $30. Call CenterCharge: (212) 721-6500 (Anthony Tommasini).
 
LIONHEART. The problem with those questionable birth dates from earlier eras is that they make awkward hooks for anniversary celebrations. So here it is, the 700th-birthday year of Guillaume de Machaut, more or less, and the Cloisters is presenting a series of concerts and lectures centering on Machaut's music and poetry. This acclaimed male vocal ensemble offers love songs and poetry drawn mainly from the "Remede de Fortune." While welcoming these events, it is hard not to look beyond and hope that the Cloisters will finally become the heavy hitter in early music that it has sometimes seemed on the verge of becoming. Sunday at 1 and 3 p.m., Cloisters, Fort Tryon Park, (212) 307-4100. Tickets: $32 (Oestreich).
 
MOSCOW STRING QUARTET. The concert room at the Frick Collection is a comfortably intimate place to hear chamber music and recitals, and its offerings include everything from early music on period instruments to the conservative side of the modern repertory. It is host this week to an ensemble formed at the Moscow Conservatory in 1975 and now resident at Colorado University in Denver. The program includes the Borodin Quartet No. 1, the Ravel Quartet and Stravinsky's Three Pieces for String Quartet. Sunday at 5 p.m., Frick Collection, 1 East 70th Street, Manhattan. (212) 288-0700. All tickets to the concert, which are free, have been distributed, but a waiting line for last-minute tickets will form one hour before the performance (Kozinn).
 
MOSCOW VIRTUOSI. The centerpiece of an attractive program by the violinist and conductor Vladimir Spivakov and his crack ensemble, the Moscow Virtuosi, is Mozart's "Coronation" Mass, for which the Russian ensemble is joining forces with a New York chorus, the Dessoff Choirs. Also on the program is one of Mozart's loveliest but most underplayed symphonies, No. 29 in A, and two works by Alfred Schnittke: the Sonata for Violin and Chamber Orchestra (Mr. Spivakov is the soloist) and "Five Fragments Based on Paintings of Hieronymus Bosch." The vocal soloists in the Mozart Mass are Inva Mula, soprano; Rinat Shaham, alto; Michael Lockley, tenor, and Robert Osborne, bass. Tomorrow at 8 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall, (212) 721-6500; tickets: $45 (Kozinn).
 
MUSICIANS FROM MARLBORO. The names of the younger players may not be familiar (though that of Todd Phillips, the violinist, is), but the name Marlboro is a solid assurance of quality. After the inevitable Haydn string quartet to start (here the D minor, Op. 9, No. 4) come bigger works: Reger's Clarinet Quintet and Mozart's String Quintet in C (K. 515). The composers are vintage Marlboro fare, and no doubt the players are already thoroughly steeped in the idioms. Tonight at 8, Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82nd Street, (212) 570-3949. Tickets: $25 (Oestreich).
 
ANTHONY NEWMAN. It wouldn't be a Bach year, 250th anniversary of the composer's death or no, without a substantial contribution from this provocative organist. Mr. Newman was rushed through an unusual performance of Bach's "Goldberg" Variations on organ last year in Purchase because of overambitious scheduling of other events. Here he is on his own, in two separate programs including many of Bach's big solo works. Well, almost on his own; he is joined in some numbers by Mary Jane Newman, a harpsichordist, and Amy Butler, a soprano. Sunday at 4 and 7:30 p.m., Purchase College Performing Arts Center, 735 Anderson Hill Road, Purchase, N.Y., (914) 251-6200; tickets: $20 for either part, $32 for both; discounts for students and the elderly (Oestreich).
 
NEW YORK PHILHARMONIC. The Russian conductor Valery Gergiev's concert with the New York Philharmonic last week was not always tidy technically. But in works by Beethoven, Scriabin and Prokofiev (a thrilling Third Piano Concerto with Leif Over Andsnes) Mr. Gergiev elicited ardent, bold and imaginative music making from the orchestra. This weekend's program is greatly anticipated. Two works are offered: Hindemith's Horn Concerto, with the orchestra's principal hornist, Philip Myers, as soloist, and Tchaikovsky's "Manfred" Symphony. Tomorrow the tireless Mr. Gergiev will conduct the program with the Philharmonic in the afternoon (and then cross the plaza at Lincoln Center to conduct Shostakovich's "Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk" at the Met in the evening). Today and tomorrow at 2 p.m., Avery Fisher Hall; tickets: $32 to $64. For ticket information, call CenterCharge: (212) 721-6500 (Tommasini).
 
VOGLER QUARTET OF BERLIN. This group, founded 15 years ago, has won awards and acclaim elsewhere but is still relatively unfamiliar in New York. Here, in its Weill Recital Hall debut, it starts -- as what quartet doesn't, these days? -- with Haydn, a G major work (Op. 76, No. 1), but proceeds slightly less predictably, with Wolf's Italian Serenade and Beethoven's B flat Quartet (Op. 130) along with the "Grosse Fuge," the gnarly movement that originally ended the work. Tonight at 8, Weill Recital Hall, (212) 247-7800. Tickets: $36; sold out, but returns may be available (Oestreich).
 
WILLARD WHITE AND JOYCE DiDONATO. The two singers offer a short program of songs and arias, accompanied by Craig Rutenberg. Ms. DiDonato includes two numbers from Handel's "Alcina" and cycles by Honegger and Michael Head. Mr. White's contributes songs by Aaron Copland and Vaughan Williams, as well as Gremin's aria from "Eugene Onegin." There will also be a discussion with George Jellinek and James King. Sunday at 4 p.m., Pierpont Morgan Library, 29 East 36th Street, Manhattan, (212) 685-0008. Limited tickets: $40, $30 for members (Griffiths).
 
Opera
 
"LA BOHEME." Franco Zeffirelli's lavish production of Puccini's "Boheme" is so popular with Metropolitan Opera audiences that who is actually singing the opera can seem of secondary importance. But "Boheme" fans should welcome the promising cast tonight when the production returns to the Met. Leontina Veduva, a fine Romanian soprano in her Met debut, will sing Mimi, a role she recorded with the tenor Roberto Alagna before a certain other Romanian soprano became his Mimi of choice (Angela Gheorghiu, his wife). The sweet-voiced tenor Luis Lima is Rodolfo; the vibrant soprano Ainhoa Arteta sings Musetta; the elegant baritone Simon Keenlyside will be Marcello. Marco Armiliato conducts. Metropolitan Opera House; tonight at 8. Standing-room-only tickets at $12 and $16; (212) 362-2000 (Tommasini).
 
"LA CLEMENZA DI TITO." Like "The Magic Flute" -- alongside which it was composed, in the last year of Mozart's life -- "Tito" is an opera of love and friendship under trial, and of music triumphant. This new City Opera production is conducted by Harry Bicket, who has done such good work in the past here with 18th-century scores, and directed by Stephen Wadsworth. The cast includes Lorraine Hunt Lieberson as Sextus and Kurt Streit as the Emperor Titus. Sunday at 1:30 p.m., New York State Theater, (212) 870-5570. Tickets: $22 to $95 (Griffiths).
 
"LADY MACBETH OF MTSENSK." Graham Vick's updated production of the great tragi-satirical opera by Shostakovich is a triumph. He daringly mixes riveting imagery -- westernized, modern, industrial, decadent, garish, comic book -- anything that will give an emotional and dramatic edge to the story of a bored, childless wife of a prosperous manufacturer in 19th-century Russia and the murders she is driven to commit. In the title role, the soprano Catherine Malfitano, trading beauty of tone for dramatic intensity, gives an unforgettable portrayal. The cast is excellent. You would think the Met Chorus was a company of character actors. And Valery Gergiev conducts a gripping performance. Metropolitan Opera House, tomorrow at 8 p.m. Remaining tickets, $180 and standing room, $12 and $16. $170 to $26; (212) 362-6000. (Tommasini).
 
"PORGY AND BESS." George Gershwin's grand and often sublime adventure into opera returns by way of the New York City Opera. The cast I heard on opening night was mostly first-rate; casts alternate. John DeMain conducts. The production, a survivor of the 1980's, does its job. New York State Theater, (212) 870-5570. Tomorrow at 1:30 and 8 p.m. Limited tickets, from $22 to $95; standing-room tickets on the day of the performance, $8 (Bernard Holland).
 
"TOSCA." Mark Lamos's spare, modern production of Puccini's "Tosca" for the New York City Opera gives the work a 1930's Fascist look. Some of the staging ideas, and occasional gestures from the singers, recall that the mannerisms of traditional verismo opera are at odds with the directorial concept. But the cast is strong, with the admirable soprano Amy Johnson as Tosca, and the stirring baritone Mark Delavan as Scarpia. The tenor Alfredo Portilla takes over the role of Mario Cavaradossi. Small flaws aside, this is an evening of compelling musical theater. New York State Theater, Tonight at 8. Tickets are $95 to $22; (212) 870-5570 (Tommasini).
 
 Dance
 
ARTHUR AVILES TYPICAL THEATER. Arthur Aviles is up to something special at his new uptown headquarters, the landmark former American Banknote building, where he creates and presents dance that could only have come from a New Yorker, from the South Bronx to be specific. Mr. Aviles's choreography is as unassuming and simple as good folk art. But it is also funky, political and gaudily irrepressible as it addresses issues including gender, homosexuality and children's stories, in this case "The Wizard of Oz," retold for adults as "Super Maeva de Oz." Today and tomorrow (and next Friday and Saturday) at 7 p.m. Tickets: $10. Bronx Academy of Arts and Dance, 841 Barretto Street, Hunts Point section of the Bronx; (718) 842-5223 (Jennifer Dunning).
 
BALLET TECH. Eliot Feld's high-energy ballet troupe bounds through its spring season with a large repertory that includes the premieres of Mr. Feld's "Coup de Couperin," to the Baroque music of Francois Couperin, and "Nodrog Doggo," to a score by Michael Gordon. (Hint: spell the first word of that odd title backward.) Among the many revivals are five works with music by Steve Reich. And Damian Woetzel, of the New York City Ballet, is appearing as guest artist in all performances of Mr. Feld's "Mending." Today at 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m.; Sunday at noon and 4 p.m., Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street, Chelsea, (212) 242-0800. Tickets: Evenings and at 4 p.m. Sunday, $35; Saturday at 2 p.m. and Sunday at noon, $25 adults, $15 children (Jack Anderson).
 
CIRCLE OF DANCE REPERTORY COMPANY. New works by the company director Nancy Brier; Carl Paris, who danced with Alvin Ailey and Martha Graham; and Jennifer Weaver, who performed with Merce Cunningham and Stephen Petronio. Today at 8 p.m. Tickets: $18; $15 for the elderly; $10, children. Queens Theater in the Park, Flushing Meadows-Corona Park, Flushing; (718) 760-0064 (Dunning).
 
CLARE BYRNE AND SHARON MANSUR. Young choreographers with imagination to spare, Clare Byrne and Sharon Mansur will present solos and a duet about everything from St. Patrick (Byrne) to solitude, contemplation and mutability (Mansur). Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets: $12; $6 for low-income audience members. Brooklyn Arts Exchange, 421 Fifth Avenue, at Eighth Street, Park Slope (718) 832-0018 (Dunning).
 
FLAMENCO EXTRAVAGANZA. The cast may change from performance to performance, depending on which guest artists turn up at this intimate club to sing, dance or play flamenco guitar. But the star of the evening is Carmen La Sala, featured with performers like La Conja, Paco Ortiz and Juan Amayatoday and tomorrow at 8:30 p.m. "Scheherazade's Tales," an evening of belly-dancing, may be seen on Tuesdays at 8:30 p.m., and there is a variety show on Wednesday Thursday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $25 for the flamenco program and $15 each for "Scheherazade's Tales" and the variety show. El Patio del East Side, 211 E. 60th Street, Manhattan; (212) 838-9090 (Dunning).
 
FLAMENCO MYSTICO: A FLAMENCO MEDITATION. Sandra Rivera has been imaginatively exploring the mystical qualities of flamenco for many years. This setting should be perfect. She will perform here in her own choreography and dances by Jose Molina and Mariano Parra, with music by Arturo Martinez, Carlos Revollar and Alfonso Cid. Today and tomorrow at 7:30 p.m. Tickets: $20; $15 for students and the elderly. Cathedral of St. John the Divine, 1047 Amsterdam Avenue, at 112th Street; (212) 662-2133 (Dunning).
 
ISABEL GOTZKOWSKY AND FRIENDS. New work by Isabel Gotzkowsky, a German-born choreographer who has performed with Fiona Marcotty, Young Soon Kim and Anahi Galante. Today through Sunday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15; $12 for dancers and students. Joyce SoHo, 155 Mercer Street. (212) 334-7479 (Dunning).
 
GUY KLUCEVSEK AND FRIENDS. Guy Klucevsek, a composer-accordionist whose witty, joyous music has helped propel many a dance, will perform in "Squeezeplay," a shared program with choreographers and performance artists who include David Dorfman, Dan Hurlin and Victoria Marks. Today and tomorrow (and Wednesday through Saturday next week) at 8 p.m. Tickets: $20. The Kitchen, 512 West 19th Street, Chelsea; (212) 255-5793, extension 11. Also at the Kitchen this weekend, "TV Dinner @ The Kitchen" with Charles Atlas, the creator of films and videos with a decidedly downtown look. Mr. Atlas will screen and talk about his work in and out of dance, over a vegetarian buffet. Reservations required. Today and tomorrow at 6 p.m. Tickets: $25; $35 includes the Klucevsek event (Dunning).
 
LA MAMA EXPERIMENTAL THEATER CLUB. You could spend the entire weekend at La MaMa in its multitudinous little spaces. Start with the Yara Arts Group, a resident group at La MaMa that collaborated with Siberian theater artists to produce "Circle," an unlikely sounding mix of Siberian legend and punk. Today and tomorrow (and Thursday and Saturday through April 8) at 8 p.m.; Sunday (and Sundays through April 9) at 3:30 and 8 p.m. Tickets: $20; $15 Sunday performances; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Next might come a dance and theater adaptation by Cati Blanche and George Bennett of Kafka's "Metamorphosis." Today and tomorrow at 10 p.m.; Sunday at 5 p.m. Tickets $12; fund vouchers accepted. La MaMa E.T.C., 74A East Fourth Street, East Village; (212) 475-7710 (Dunning).
 
NANCY MEEHAN DANCE COMPANY. Nancy Meehan is a consistent soul. Once more this former Erick Hawkins dancer is presenting work created with her longtime collaborators Eleanor Hovda, the composer; Anthony Candido, who made the costumes, and Blu, the lighting designer. In this program of new and recent pieces, Ms. Meehan may also be expected to present non-narrative dance that is serene, continuously in motion and beautiful, as Anna Kisselgoff put it in this newspaper, for "the naturalness of its sophistication." Today through Sunday at 8:30 p.m. Tickets: $15; Theater Development Fund vouchers accepted. Danspace Project, St. Mark's Church, 131 East 10th Street, East Village; (212) 674-8194 (Dunning).
 
ANN MORADIAN. The new works to be presented by Ann Moradian and her Perspectives in Motion company include "Vesper," a duet for two women and a chair; "Tear," a group work about the dual meanings of its title; and "Synthesis," a solo for Jim May set to Mozart. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets: $12; $8 for dancers. Clark Studio Theater, 165 West 65th Street, Lincoln Center; (212) 726-3612 (Dunning).
 
PILAR RIOJA. One of the most versatile of Spanish dancers offers solo programs designed to reveal the unusual richness of Spanish dance. The presentations include cheerful works in folk style, passionate flamenco dances, solos to music by Spanish classical composers and a choreographic adaptation of poetry by Federico Garcia Lorca. Today at 11 a.m. and 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 8 p.m. and Sunday at 2 p.m., Repertorio Espanol's Gramercy Arts Theater, 138 East 27th Street, (212) 889-2850. Tickets: $25 to $40 (Anderson).
 
SECOND AVENUE DANCE COMPANY. The performers are students in the dance department of New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. But their annual presentations usually have great professional polish. This spring's program features new works by Diane Coburn Bruning, Doug Elkins and Kevin Wynn and a reconstruction of Martha Graham's "Steps in the Street," a 1936 masterwork on themes of devastation, homelessness and exile. Today and Sunday at 8 p.m.; tomorrow at 2 and 8 p.m., Fifth-Floor Theater, Tisch School of the Arts, 111 Second Avenue, at Sixth Street, East Village, (212) 998-1982. Tickets: $10; $5 for students and the elderly (Anderson).
 
SIXTH ANNUAL 92ND STREET Y HARKNESS DANCE PROJECT: KOOSIL-JA HWANG/DANCE KUMIKOKIMOTO. In her new "The Anatomy of Happiness: The First Segment," Koosil-ja Hwang explores ethnicity, identity and culture from the perspective of a Korean born in Japan who has lived in New York City since 1981. Ms. Hwang's intricately layered work includes live and prerecorded video by Benton Bainbridge and Caspar Stracke. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m.; Sunday at 5 p.m. Tickets: $15. Playhouse 91, 316 East 91st Street, Yorkville; (212) 415-5553 (Dunning).
 
TAIPEI BALLET COMPANY. Established in 1994, the Taipei Ballet Company and its repertory by Sufen Wu seek to fuse elements of Western ballet and Taiwanese theater and dance. Today and tomorrow at 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 2 p.m. Tickets: $15; $10 for students and the elderly. Taipei Theater, McGraw-Hill Building, 1221 Sixth Avenue, near 48th Street; (212) 373-1850 (Dunning).
 
"TANGO-FEST." Tango dancers from Buenos Aires, Mexico City and New York and beyond, including Paul and Eleny, Guillermina and Roberto and Nito y Elba. Today at 8 p.m. Tickets: $25 to $35. Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan; (212) 307-4100 (Dunning).
 
URBAN BUSH WOMEN AND NATIONAL SONG AND DANCE COMPANY OF MOZAMBIQUE. Two dynamic companies, one from New York and the other from Africa, in work that is the product of a three-year collaboration. Today and tomorrow at 7:30 p.m.; Sunday at 2:30 p.m. Tickets: $36. New Jersey Performing Arts Center, One Center Street, Newark; (888) 466-5722 (Dunning).
 
JENNIFER WALKER AND COMPANY. Modern dance pieces that explore themes including human nature, chaos and stillness in the human experience, the nature of women and beauty. Today and tomorrow at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15; $12 students and the elderly. Context, 28 Avenue A, at Third Street, East Village; (718) 677-3644 (Dunning).
 
WORKS AND PROCESS AT THE GUGGENHEIM: MARK MORRIS AND ISAAC MIZRAHI. The choreographer Mark Morris and the designer Isaac Mizrahi talk about their new production of Rameau's "Platee" at the New York City Opera. Sunday and Monday at 8 p.m. Tickets: $15; $10 for students and the elderly. Sold out but returned tickets may be available. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street; (212) 423-3587 (Dunning).

HEADLINE: House Narrowly Passes Spending Plan With $150 Billion Tax Cut

BYLINE: By WILLIAM K. STEVENS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Friday, March 24

 BODY:
The House adopted a Republican budget plan this morning that would cut taxes by at least $150 billion over the next five years, provide more money for the military and education and cut spending on most other programs.
The vote was 211 to 207, largely along party lines, and came after Republican leaders had scrambled to avert defections by a bloc of conservatives who said the plan would allow too much spending. 
 Republicans said the plan, a nonbinding blueprint that sets the broad parameters for tax and spending bills, was a balanced approach that provided enough money for national priorities while restraining the overall growth of government and returning a substantial portion of the projected federal budget surplus to taxpayers.
The measure, which because it is not a law is not subject to veto, calls for total government spending authority next year of $1.85 trillion, an increase of 3 percent over this year. It would increase Pentagon spending by 6 percent, to $307.3 billion, and would effectively require cutbacks in most other categories of general government operations after taking account of inflation.
"The question is whether we're going to advance the reform agenda in Washington," said Representative John R. Kasich, the Ohio Republican who is chairman of the House Budget Committee, picking up a theme from his party's expected presidential nominee, Gov. George W. Bush of Texas.
Democrats said that the plan would force unacceptable cuts in programs from Head Start to the Drug Enforcement Administration, that it did nothing to secure the long-term solvency of Social Security and Medicare, and that it also risked plunging the budget back into deficit.
"The Republican budget sacrifices fiscal responsibility on the altar of massive tax cuts," said Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the Democratic leader.
Jacob J. Lew, the White House budget director, said in a letter to congressional leaders that the Clinton administration believed the House budget was "fundamentally flawed and fails to provide a balanced and workable economic plan."
The House defeated five alternative budget plans, including one backed by the Democratic leadership and another offered by a group of conservative Republicans.
Both parties supported using the surplus generated by the Social Security system -- estimated at $2.3 trillion over the next decade -- only to reduce the part of the national debt held by the public in the form of Treasury bonds.
But in many ways the debate was a replay of last year's budget battle, when Republicans passed a $792 billion, 10-year tax cut that was vetoed by President Clinton. And just as they did last year, Republican leaders in the House struggled to hold their slim majority together for the vote.
Fiscal conservatives said the measure did too little to guard against end-of-session surges in spending. Republican members of the appropriations committees that draw up spending bills warned that the spending levels in the budget might be unrealistically low.
The internal problems Republicans faced in the House were mirrored in the Senate, where a group of conservatives led by Senator Phil Gramm of Texas continued to block a vote in the Budget Committee on the Senate's own version of the budget. Mr. Gramm wants the budget to contain less spending and more tax cuts.
Republicans in the House also found themselves in the awkward situation of passing a budget that calls for a smaller tax cut than the one advocated by Mr. Bush in his presidential campaign.
Mr. Bush's plan would cut taxes by $483 billion over the five years starting in 2002, and by about $300 billion during the five-year period, starting next year, covered by the House budget plan. The House plan calls for at least $150 billion in tax cuts, and as much as $240 billion if the projected surplus continues to grow.
Democrats used the unwillingness of the House leadership to embrace the Bush tax plan to buttress their argument that the Texas governor's proposal is excessive even by the standards of his own party.
Much of the partisan wrangling was over the one-sixth of the budget that goes to general domestic spending outside of Social Security, Medicare and the Pentagon. The Republican plan would hold that so-called nonmilitary discretionary spending to $289.2 billion next year, less than a billion dollars more than this year and not nearly enough to keep up with the effects of inflation. Democrats proposed $309 billion in nonmilitary discretionary spending.
The Republican plan would increase spending in a few categories, like education, where spending would rise to $56.8 billion next year, an increase of 27.6 percent. But there would be cuts in most other categories after accounting for inflation.
Representative John M. Spratt Jr. of South Carolina, the senior Democrat on the House Budget Committee, said the Republican plan would hold nondefense discretionary spending $114 billion below what is needed to keep pace with inflation over the next five years. And he said the entire Republican approach was unrealistic because it failed to acknowledge that even the Republican-led Congress had ultimately passed spending bills each year that increased spending above the rate of inflation.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW YORK;
Decision on Monday For Baruch College Head

 BODY:
Edward V. Regan, the former New York State comptroller, is a leading candidate for the presidency of Baruch College of the City University of New York. A decision will be made on Monday when CUNY trustees are to meet.
Mr. Regan is a distinguished fellow at the Jerome Levy Economics Institute of Bard College and chairman of the Municipal Assistance Corporation for the City of New York, which helps oversee the city's finances. 
 The other two finalists for the position are Irwin Engelman, a former vice chairman and chief administrative officer of Revlon and the chairman of Baruch's fund-raising campaign, and Nicholas L. Henry, the former president of Georgia Southern University.

SECTION: Section A; Page 21; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 820 words

HEADLINE: India Needs The Bomb

BYLINE: By John J. Mearsheimer; John J. Mearsheimer is a professor of political science at the University of Chicago.

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
Despite its huge population, booming economy and growing nuclear arsenal, President Clinton, like his predecessors, refuses to show India the respect it deserves. He thereby perpetuates a needless estrangement between two natural allies.
This disrespect is most apparent on the nuclear front. In his address to the Indian Parliament on Wednesday, Mr. Clinton acknowledged many of India's concerns, but he did not give up his call for India to abandon its nuclear weapons. The administration wants India to sign both the Comprehensive Test Ban Treaty and the Treaty on the Nonproliferation of Nuclear Weapons. 
 India, however, refused to sign the nonproliferation treaty when it took effect in 1970 and refused again when the treaty was extended in 1995. India tested nuclear weapons in 1998 and has made it clear that it intends to build powerful nuclear forces.
The Clinton administration should stop opposing these moves and recognize that India is not going to give up its nuclear arsenal. India did not acquire these weapons for frivolous reasons, like misplaced pride or domestic politics, as some Americans believe. Rather, India, like the United States, had sound strategic reasons for wanting them.
Nuclear weapons are an excellent deterrent against aggression, and India lives in a dangerous neighborhood. Since gaining independence in 1947, it has fought three wars with Pakistan and has come close to war with Pakistan three other times. India also fought a losing war with China in 1962 over the still-contested Sino-Indian border. Moreover, both Pakistan and China have their own nuclear weapons, and over the next two decades, China will move to develop a much larger arsenal. India would be foolish to allow China to gain a nuclear advantage over it.
The Persian Gulf war of 1991 and the Kosovo war in 1999 also hardened India's determination to possess nuclear weapons. The United States easily beat Iraq and Serbia by exploiting its enormous advantage in conventional arms. Had either foe possessed nuclear weapons, the United States might not have gone to war. This lesson was not lost on India.
Finally, as President Clinton acknowledged on Wednesday, American hypocrisy on nuclear issues rubs Indians the wrong way. The United States allows itself to have nuclear weapons for its own security but says India should not have them for the same purpose. We expect India to sign the test ban treaty even though the United States Senate rejected it.
The Clinton administration should reverse course and recognize that India is a legitimate nuclear state, like Britain and Russia, not a dangerous nuclear rogue like North Korea. It should allow India to keep its nuclear weapons and sign the nonproliferation treaty, with all the attendant rights and obligations.
As a start toward closer political ties, the administration could support India's membership in the United Nations Security Council. At the same time, however, the United States should not one-sidedly favor India against Pakistan when Pakistan has legitimate concerns. Instead, the United States should strive to be a fair broker when disputes arise.
A more realistic policy toward India would benefit both Asia and American interests.
First, the United States could do more to resolve the conflict between India and Pakistan over the territory of Kashmir. India adamantly refuses to allow the United States to mediate that 53-year-old conflict because it has long felt that Washington favors Pakistan. But if the United States demonstrated even-handedness, showing greater sensitivity to India's interests, India might conceivably welcome constructive mediation.
Second, a more realistic policy would promote nuclear stability on the subcontinent. For example, by dropping its prohibition on nuclear weapons, the United States could provide India and Pakistan modern command-and-control technologies that would make their arsenals safer and more reliable. It could also share valuable safety lessons it learned from its competition with the Soviet Union.
Third, in the not-too-distant future, the United States may need other Asian countries to help it contain China. It would be difficult to fashion an effective coalition of Asian countries without India as a central pillar.
Fourth, with its increasing economic power, especially in software and pharmaceuticals, India is becoming an important player in international economic groups like the World Trade Organization. The United States has an interest in making India a cooperative rather than a disruptive force in those institutions.
India and the United States are the world's two largest democracies, and they are both multicultural democracies to boot. It only makes sense for them to be on the same side. It is thus not only in America's economic and strategic interests to become closer to India, but fully in line with its principles and ideals.

PUB-DATE: March 25, 2000

SECTION: Section A; Page 8; Column 2; Foreign DeskSection A;Page 8;Column 2;Foreign Desk

LENGTH: 990 words

HEADLINE: WORLD BRIEFING

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

EUROPE
 
FRANCE: NEW PROTESTS BY TEACHERS -- Tens of thousands of teachers marched through Paris to demand more spending on education and the resignation of Education Minister Claude Allegre. Similar demonstrations took place in Marseille, Toulouse and Toulon. The protest movement, which closed most public schools for a day last week, has added to pressure on Prime Minister Lionel Jospin to shake up his cabinet. Marlise Simons (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: AGENT ACCUSED OF TREASON -- Officials said an agent of the domestic Federal Security Service, arrested last week on charges of passing political information and names of Russian agents to Britain, had been charged with high treason. The unidentified agent was arrested as he left for Estonia, whose own officials, the Russians charged, had joined Britain in recruiting the spy. The British declined to comment. Michael Wines (NYT) 
 
BRITAIN: SECRETS STOLEN -- The police revealed that a laptop computer with confidential information about Northern Ireland was stolen from an officer of the M.I.5 secret service on March 4 when he put it on the platform of a London subway station momentarily to help passers-by. The police asserted there was no threat to national security because the information was heavily encrypted, and there was no evidence the thief knew the machine belonged to M.I.5. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
BOSNIA, CROATIA: TRAIN PACT -- The two countries agreed in Sarajevo to get trains rolling across their border again. Alija Izetbegovic, chairman of the Bosnian multiethnic presidency, said there was no starting date for re-establishing the railway, which stopped in 1992, soon after the Bosnian war began. But he praised the new Croatian president, Stipe Mesic, speaking of a "new spirit" between the two countries. (AP)
 
YUGOSLAVIA: SERBS MARK BOMBING -- In a defiant but smaller than expected display of anti-Western sentiment, thousands of Serbs rallied across Yugoslavia to mark the first anniversary of the start of NATO airstrikes. Opposition parties, and some Belgrade residents, said the rallies were in bad taste given the severe losses the country suffered during the conflict. (AP)
 
EUROPEAN UNION: NEW GOAL -- Leaders of the 15-member group approved a range of reforms to join the technological revolution and make them better able to compete with the United States. At the end of a two-day meeting in Lisbon dedicated to the economy, the 15 countries set themselves "a new strategic goal for the next decade" to promote growth and cut unemployment. (Reuters)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
CANADA: PRESSURE ON PARKS -- Visits to Canada's national parks will double in 15 years to 28 million, according to a government study. Faced with growing pressure from tourists, Sheila Copps, the minister responsible for the country's 39 national parks, vowed "no new ski hills, no new golf courses" and proposed limits on fishing, hiking, camping and snowmobiling in the most popular parks. Ms. Copps has fought to limit development in Banff National Park, the crown jewel of the 115-year-old system. James Brooke (NYT)
 
ASIA
 
PHILIPPINES: DEATH PENALTY SUSPENDED -- President Joseph Estrada has suspended the death penalty until the end of the year "in deference to the celebration of the Catholic Church's Jubilee Year," a palace statement said. The reprieve will be reviewed in January. Amnesty International called the move a breakthrough for rights in the Philippines, where seven people have been executed since 1994, when capital punishment was reintroduced. (Reuters)
 
SRI LANKA: REBELS SKEPTICAL -- The separatist Tamil Tiger rebels called for an internationally monitored cease-fire and a troop pullback before entering Norwegian-brokered peace talks, a Tamil paper reported. A rebel leader called the government's willingness to talk a bid to buy time to modernize the army. (Agence France-Presse)
 
MIDDLE EAST
 
IRAN: CLERIC WARNS REFORMERS -- A prominent member of the conservative Muslim clergy warned reformers who won a landslide victory in February elections not to try to ease Islamic social taboos. "It is not like the new deputies can pass any laws they like," Ayatollah Muhammad Yazdi said in a sermon at Tehran University. "The young people who you think voted for you have no right to demand laws to allow them to dance in the streets, or the annulment of any Islamic mandates." John F. Burns (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
ZIMBABWE: POLICE STILL DEFIANT -- The police continued to defy a court order requiring them to remove black squatters who have invaded hundreds of white farms. The police said they needed specific instructions from the government before moving against the squatters, who are led by veterans of Zimbabwe's war of independence from Britain. President Robert Mugabe has spoken out in support of the squatters. Rachel L. Swarns (NYT)
 
NIGERIA: CEASE-FIRE PROCLAIMED -- President Olusegun Obasanjo announced that communities at war over land rights have agreed to a cease-fire, ending hostilities in which at least 80 people have died. "The police will enforce the cease-fire," the president said. The long-running feud between the two communities in Ife and Modakeke, both from Mr. Obasanjo's Yoruba ethnic group, erupted anew on March 3 and involves a dispute over land ownership and local politics. (Agence France-Presse)
 
BURUNDI: GUERRILLAS JOIN IN -- The leader of Burundi's second largest Hutu guerrilla army said he would join peace talks in Tanzania along with the head of the largest Hutu group, who agreed to take part on Monday. Nelson Mandela, the former president of South Africa, who is acting as mediator, has consistently attributed the lack of progress in the 21-month-old talks to the absence of the Hutu rebels who are fighting the Tutsi-led army. (Agence France-Presse)
 Compiled by Terence Neilan
